Text

Produced by Al Haines THE THREE BROTHERS BY EDEN PHILLPOTTS AUTHOR OF

``THE SECRET WOMAN,'' (Al Haines BROTHERS)
``THE AMERICAN PRISONER,'' (Al Haines BROTHERS)
``CHILDREN OF THE MIST,'' (Al Haines BROTHERS)

New York THE MACMILLAN COMPANY 1909 All rights reserved COPYRIGHT, 1909, BY THE MACMILLAN COMPANY.

Set up and electrotyped.

Published January, 1909.

Norwood Press J. S. Cushing Co.--Berwick & Smith Co.. Norwood, Mass., U.S.A. TO MY BROTHER HERBERT MACDONALD PHILLPOTTS A SMALL TRIBUTE OF GREAT AFFECTION THE THREE BROTHERS BOOK I CHAPTER I From Great Trowlesworthy's crown of rosy granite the world extended to the moor-edge, and thence, by mighty, dim, air-drenched passages of earth and sky, to the horizons of the sea.

A clear May noon illuminated the waste, and Dartmoor, soaking her (MY) fill of sunshine, ran over with it, so that Devon's self spread little darker of bosom than the grey and silver of high clouds lifted above her (MY), mountainous under the sun.

Hills and plains were still mottled with the winter coat of the heather, and the verdure of the spearing grasses suffered diminution under a far-flung pallor of dead blades above breaking green; but the face of Dartmoor began to glow and the spring gorse leapt like a running flame along it.

At water's brink was starry silver of crow-foot, and the heath, still darkling, sheltered sky-blue milk-wort and violet and the budding gold of the tormentil.

One white road ran due north-east and south-west across the desert, and round about it, like the tents of the Anakim, rose huge snowy hillocks and ridges silver-bright in the sun.

Here the venerable Arch√¶an granites of Dartmoor, that on Trowlesworthy blush to a ruddy splendour, and elsewhere break beautifully in fair colour and fine grain through the coarser porphyritic stone, suffer a change, and out of their perishing constituents emerges kaolin, or china clay.

A river met this naked road, and at their junction the grey bridge of Cadworthy saddled Plym.

Beyond, like the hogged back of a brown bear, Wigford Down rolled above the gorges of Dewerstone, and further yet, retreated fields and forests, great uplifted plains, and sudden elevations that glimmered along their crests with the tender green of distant larch and beech.

The atmosphere was opalescent, milky, sweet, as though earth's sap, leaping to the last tree-tip and bursting bud, exuded upon air the very visible incense and savour of life.

Running water and lifting lark made the music of this hour; and at one spot on the desert a girl's voice mingled with them and enlarged the melody, for it was gentle and musical and belonged to the springtime.

She (girl) sat high on Trowlesworthy, where the rushes chatter and where, to their eternal treble, the wind strikes deep organ music from the forehead of the tor.

From the clefts of the rocks around her (girl), where foxes homed sometimes and the hawk made her (girl) nest, there hung now russet tassels and tufts of dead lady-fern; and above this rack of the old year sprang dark green aigrettes of the new.

Stonecrops and pennyworts also flourished amid the uncurling fronds; aloft, the heath and whortle made curls for the great tor's brow; below, to the girl's feet, there sloped up boulders that shone with fabric of golden-brown mosses and dappled lichens, jade-green and grey.

The woodsorrel had climbed hither, and its frail bells and sparkling trefoils glittered on the earth.

The sun shone with a thready lustre over the million flattened dead rushes roundabout this place, and its light spread out upon them into a pool of pale gold.

Thus a radiance as of water extended here and the wind, fretting all this death, heightened the deception; while the scattered rocks shone brilliantly against so much reflected light and looked like boulders half submerged at the fringe of a glittering sea.

The girl laughed and gazed down at her (girl) home.

It was a squat grey building half-way between the red tor and the distant bridge.

It stood amid bright green crofts, and beside it was a seemly hayrick and an unseemly patch of rufous light that stared--hideous as a bloodshot eye--from the harmonious textures of the waste.

There a shippen under an iron roof sank to rusty dissolution.

Here was Trowlesworthy Farm and a great rabbit warren that extended round about it.

Milly Luscombe lived at Trowlesworthy with an uncle and aunt.

She (Luscombe) was accustomed to work very hard for her (Luscombe) living, but for the moment she (Luscombe) did not work.

She (Luscombe) only breathed the breath of spring and talked of love.

Beside her (Luscombe) sat a sturdy youth with a red face and a little budding flaxen moustache.

His (uncle) countenance was not cast in a cheerful mould.

Indeed, he (uncle) frowned and gazed gloomily out of large grey eyes at the valley beneath him (uncle).

``I axed father in plain words if I might be tokened to you--of course, that was if you said `yes'--and he (uncle) answered as plainly that I might not.

You see, he (uncle) was terrible up in years afore he (uncle) got married himself, and so he (uncle) thinks a man's a fool to go into it young.'' (unknown)

``How old was he (uncle) then?'' (unknown)

``Forty-five to the day.

And he (uncle)'s seventy next month, though he (uncle) don't feel or look anything like so much.

He (uncle)'s full of old, stale sayings about marrying in haste and repenting at leisure: and such like.

So there it is, Milly.'' (The girl)

The girl nodded.

She (Milly) was a dark maiden with brown eyes and a pretty mouth.

She (Milly) sniffed rather tearfully and wiped her (Milly) eyes with the corner of her (Milly) sun-bonnet.

``Belike your father only waited so long because the right one didn't come.

When he (father) found your mother, I'm sure he (father) married her (mother) quick enough.'' (unknown)

``No, he (father) didn't.

They was tokened when he (father) was forty, and kept company for five years.'' (unknown)

``That ban't loving,'' (she)
she (mother) said.

``Of course it ban't!

And yet father isn't what you might call a hard man.

Far from it, to all but me.

A big-hearted, kindly creature and a good father, if he (father) could only understand more.

Like a boy in some things.

I'm sure I feel a lot older than him (father) sometimes.

If 'twas Ned now, he (Ned)'d be friendly and easy as you please.'' (unknown)

``What does Mrs. Baskerville say?'' (unknown)

``She (Baskerville)'s on our side, and so's my sisters.

Polly and May think the world of you.

'Tisn't as if I was like my brother Ned--a lazy chap that hates the sight of work.

I stand to work same as father himself, and he (father) knows that; and when there's anything calling to be done, 'tis always, `Where be Rupert to?'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

But lazy as Ned is, he (Ned)'d let him (Ned) marry to-morrow.''

``Mr. Baskerville's frighted of losing you from Cadworthy, Rupert.'' (The man)

The young man looked out where a wood rose south of the bridge, and his (man) father's farm lifted its black chimneys above the trees.

``He (man) tells me I'm his (man) right hand; and yet refuses, though this is the first thing that ever I've asked him (man),'' (he)
he (man) said.

``Wouldn't he (man) suffer it if you promised him (man) to do as he (man) done, and not marry for five years?'' (unknown)

``I'll promise no such thing.

Father seems to think 'tis all moonshine, but I shall have another go at him (Father) when he (Father) comes home next week.

Till then I shan't see you no more, for I've promised myself to get through a mighty pile of work--just to astonish him (Father).'' (unknown)

``The harder you work, the more he (Father)'ll want you to bide at home,'' (she)
she (man) said.

``Not that I mind you working.

All the best sort work--I know that.'' (unknown)

``I must work--no credit to me.

I'm like father there.

I ban't comfortable if I don't get through a good lump of work in the day.'' (She)

She (man) looked at him (father) with large admiration.

``Where's Mr. Baskerville gone to?'' (unknown)

``To Bideford for the wrestlin' matches.

He (Baskerville) always stands stickler when there's a big wrestlin'.

Such a famous man he (man) was at it--champion of Devon for nine years.

He (man) retired after he (man) was married.

But now, just on his (man) seventieth birthday, he (man)'s as clever as any of 'em.

'Twas his (man) great trouble, I do believe, that neither me nor Ned ever shaped well at it.

But we haven't got his (Ned) weight.

We take after my mother's people and be light built men--compared to father.'' (unknown)

``Pity May weren't a boy,'' (Milly/Milly Luscombe/Luscombe)
said Milly.

``She (Milly)'s got weight enough.'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (he)
he (boy) admitted.

``She (Milly)'s the very daps of father.

She (Milly)'ll be a whacker when she (Milly) grows up.

'Tis a nuisance for a woman being made so terrible beamy.

But there 'tis--and a happier creature never had to walk slow up a hill.'' (unknown)

Silence fell for a while between them.

``We must wait and hope,'' (she)
she (Milly) declared at last.

``I shan't change, Rupert--you know that.'' (unknown)

``Right well I know it, and more shan't I.'' (unknown)

``You're just turned twenty-three and I'm eighteen.

After all, we've got plenty of time,'' (Milly/Milly Luscombe/Luscombe)

said Milly.

``I hope so.

But that's no reason why for we should waste it.

'Tis all wasted till I get you.'' (She)

She (Milly) put her (Milly) hand out to him (Rupert), and he (Rupert) caught it and held it.

``It might be a long sight worse,'' (she)
she (Milly) said.

'''Tis only a matter of patience.''

``There's no need for patience, and there lies the cruelty.

However, I'll push him (Rupert) hard when he (Rupert) comes home.

Tokened I will be to `e--not in secret, but afore the nation.'' (unknown)

``Look!'' (she)

she (Milly) said.

``Two men riding up over.

Go a bit further off, there's a dear.'' (Rupert/Rupert Baskerville)

Rupert looked where she (Milly) pointed, and then he (Rupert) showed no little astonishment and concern.

``Good Lord!'' (he)

he (Rupert) exclaimed.

``If 'tisn't my Uncle Humphrey Baskerville; and Mark along with him (Mark).

What the mischief sent them here, of all ways?

Can't we hide?'' (unknown)

But no hiding-place offered.

Therefore the young people rose and walked boldly forward.

``He (Mark)'s going out to Hen Tor to look at they ruins, I reckon,'' (Milly/Milly Luscombe/Luscombe)
said Milly.

``I met your cousin Mark a bit ago, and he (Mark) told me his (Mark) father was rather interested in that old rogues-roost of a place they call Hen Tor House.

Why for I can't say; but that's where they be riding, I doubt.'' (men)

Two men on ponies arrived as she (Milly) spoke, and drew up beside the lovers.

The elder exhibited a cast of countenance somewhat remarkable.

He (Mark) was a thin, under-sized man with grey hair.

His (Mark) narrow, clean-shorn face sloped wedge-shaped to a pointed chin, and his (Mark) mouth was lipless and very hard.

Grotesquely large black eyebrows darkened his (Mark) forehead, but they marked no arch.

They were set in two patches or tufts, and moved freely up and down over a pair of rather dim grey eyes.

The appearance of dimness, however, was not real, for Humphrey Baskerville possessed good sight.

He (Baskerville) was sixty-three years old, and a widower.

He (Baskerville) passed for a harsh, secretive man, and lived two miles from his (Baskerville) elder brother, Vivian Baskerville, of Cadworthy.

His (Baskerville) household consisted of himself, his (Baskerville) son Mark, and his (Baskerville) housekeeper.

``Good morning, Uncle Humphrey,'' (Rupert/Rupert Baskerville)
said Rupert, taking the bull by the horns.

``You know Milly Luscombe, don't you?

Morning, Mark.'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

Mr. Baskerville's black tufts went up and his (Baskerville) slit of a mouth elongated.

``What's this then?'' (he)

he (Baskerville) asked.

``Fooling up here with a girl--you?

I hope you're not taking after your good-for-nothing brother?'' (unknown)

``Needn't fear that, uncle.'' (unknown)

``How's Mr.

Luscombe?'' (the man)

asked the old man abruptly, turning to the girl.

Milly feared nobody--not even this much-feared and mysterious person--and now she (Milly) turned to him (Luscombe) and patted his (Luscombe) old pony's neck as she (Milly) answered--

``Very well, thank you, Mr. Baskerville, and I'm sure he (Baskerville)'d hope you are the same.'' (she)

The tufts came down and he (Baskerville) looked closely at her (Milly).

``You playing truant too--eh?

Well, why not?

'Tis too fine a day for work, perhaps.'' (unknown)

``So it is, then.

Even your old blind pony knows that.'' (unknown)

``Only blind the near side,'' (he)
he (Baskerville) answered.

``He (Baskerville) can see more with one eye than many humans can with both.'' (unknown)

``What's his (Baskerville) name, please?'' (unknown)

``I don't know.

Never gave him (Baskerville) one.'' (Rupert/Rupert Baskerville)

They walked a little way forward, while Rupert stopped behind and spoke to his (Rupert) cousin Mark.

``So you like that boy very much--eh?'' (the man)

said the old man drily and suddenly to Milly.

She (Milly) coloured up and nodded.

``Nonsense and foolery!'' (unknown)

``If 'tis, I wouldn't exchange it for your sense, Mr.

Baskerville.'' (He)

He (Baskerville) made a deep grunt, like a bear.

``That's the pert way childer speak to the old folk now--is it?'' (unknown)

``Even you was in love once?'' (unknown)

``Nonsense and foolery--nonsense and foolery!'' (unknown)

``Would you do different if you could go back?'' (He)

He (Baskerville) did not answer the question.

``I doubt you're too good for Rupert Baskerville,'' (he)
he (Baskerville) said.

``He (Baskerville)'s too good for me.'' (unknown)

``He (Baskerville) stands to work--I grant that.

But he (Baskerville)'s young, and he (Baskerville)'s foolish, like all young things.

Think better of it.

Keep away from the young men.

Work--work--work your fingers to the bone.

That's the only wise way.

I'm going to look at yonder ruin on the side of Hen Tor.

I may build it up again and live there and die there.'' (unknown)

``What!

Leave Hawk House, Mr.

Baskerville?'' (unknown)

``Why not?

'Tis too much in the world for me and Mark.'' (unknown)

'''Tis the loneliest house in these parts.''

``Too much in the world,'' (he)
he (Mark) repeated.

``That's nonsense and foolery, if you like,'' (she)
she (Hawk) said calmly;
``I'm sure love-making be all plain common-sense compared to that.'' (she)

He (Mark) pulled up and regarded her (Hawk) with a grim stare.

``I've found somebody to-day that isn't afraid of me, seemingly.'' (unknown)

``Why for should I be?'' (unknown)

``For no reason, except that most others are.

What do they all think?

I'll tell you; they think I'm wrong here.'' (He)

He (Mark) tilted up his (Mark) black wide-awake hat and tapped his (Mark) forehead.

``Surely never!

The folk only be frightened of your great wittiness--so I believe.

Rupert always says that you are terrible clever.'' (unknown)

``That shows he (Rupert)'s a terrible fool.

Don't you mate with a fool, Milly.'' (unknown)

``I'll promise that anyway, sir.'' (She)

She (Milly) spoke with perfect self-possession and interested the old man.

Then he (man) found that he (man) was interested, and turned upon himself impatiently and shouted to his (man) son.

``Come on, boy!

What are you dawdling there for?'' (Mark/Mark Baskerville)

Mark instantly dug his (Mark) heels into his (Mark) pony and followed his (Mark) father.

He (Mark) was a youthful edition of the elder, with a difference.

Humphrey was ill-clad, and Mark was neat.

Humphrey's voice was harsh and disagreeable; Mark's was soft and almost womanly.

Mark also had a smooth face and heavy eyebrows; but his (Mark) features were clearer cut, more delicate; his (Mark) eyes were blue and beautiful.

He (Mark) had a manner somewhat timid and retiring.

He (Mark) was not a cringing man, but a native deference guided him (Mark) in all dealings with his (Mark) kind.

Before starting, Mr. Baskerville stopped, drew a letter from his (Baskerville) pocket, and called to Rupert.

``Take this to my brother Vivian, will you?

I was going to leave it on the way back, but I'll not waste his (Vivian) time.'' (The youth)

The youth came forward and took the letter.

``Father's away to Bideford--standing stickler for the wrestlin','' (he)
he (Father) said.

``Good God!

At his (Father) age!

Can't an old man of seventy find nothing better and wiser to do than run after childish things like that?'' (The son)

The son was silent, and his (son) uncle, with a snort of deep disdain, rode forward.

'''Tis about the birthday,'' Rupert explained to Milly.

``In June father will turn seventy, and there is to be a rare fuss made, and a spread, and all the family to come round him (Rupert) at Cadworthy.

Of course, Uncle Nat will come.

In fact, 'twas his (Nat) idea that we should have a celebration about it; but I doubt if Uncle Humphrey will.

He (Humphrey)'d think such a thing all rubbish, no doubt, for he (Humphrey)'s against every sort of merry-making.

You see how he (Humphrey) went just now when I told him (Humphrey) father was gone to the wrestlin' matches.'' (unknown)

``Don't you mind him (father) too much, all the same,'' (Milly/Milly Luscombe/Luscombe)
said Milly.

``He (father) looks terrible grim and says dreadful things, but I don't believe he (father)'s half in earnest.

I ban't feared of him (father), and never will be.

Don't you be neither.'' (the girl)

They left the tor and proceeded to the girl's home beneath.

The close-cropped turf of the warrens spread in a green and resilient carpet under their feet; and, flung in a mighty pattern upon it, young red leaves of whortleberry broke through and spattered the miles of turf with a haze of russet.

Rupert said farewell at the entrance; then he (Rupert) hastened homeward and presently reached his (Rupert) family circle as it was preparing to dine.

Hester Baskerville, the wife of Vivian, was a quiet, fair woman of fine bearing and above middle height.

She (woman) was twenty years younger than her (woman) husband, but the union had been a happy and successful one in every respect, and the woman's mild nature and large patience had chimed well with the man's strong self-assertion, narrow outlook, and immovable opinions.

Kindness of heart and generosity of spirit distinguished them both; and these precious traits were handed to the children of the marriage, six in number.

Ned Baskerville, the eldest son, was considered the least satisfactory and the best looking.

Then came Rupert, a commonplace edition of Ned, but worth far more as a responsible being.

These men resembled their mother and both lived at home.

Young Nathan Baskerville followed.

He (Baskerville) was a sailor and seldom seen at Cadworthy.

The two girls of this family succeeded Nathan.

May and Polly were like their father--of dark complexion and inclined to stoutness; while the baby of the household was Humphrey, a youngster of thirteen, called after the dreaded uncle.

All save Nat, the sailor, were at table when Rupert entered with his (Rupert) letter, and all showed keenest interest to learn whether Mr. Baskerville of Hawk House had accepted his (Baskerville) invitation.

Rupert handed the letter to his (Rupert) mother, and she (mother) was about to put it aside until her (mother) husband's return; but her (mother) children persuaded her (mother) to open it.

``Such a terrible exciting thing, mother,'' (unknown)
said stout May.

``Us never won't sleep a wink till us knows.'' (unknown)

``I hope to the Lord he (Lord) isn't coming,'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)
declared Ned.

''`Twill spoil all--a regular death's head he (Ned)'ll be, and us shan't dare to have an extra drop of beer or a bit of fun after with the girls.''

Beer and a bit of fun with the girls' represented the limit of Edward Baskerville's ambitions; and he (Edward) gratified them with determination when opportunity offered.

His (Edward) father was blind to his (father) faults and set him (father) on a pedestal above the rest of the family; but his (father) mother felt concern that her (mother) eldest son should be so slight a man.

She (mother) lived in hope that he (father) might waken to his (father) responsibilities and justify existence.

Ned was unusually well-educated, and would do great things some day in his (Ned) father's opinion; but the years passed, he (Ned) was now twenty-five, and the only great thing that he (Ned) had done was twice to become engaged to marry and twice to change his (Ned) mind.

None denied him (Ned) a rare gift of good looks; and his (Ned) fine figure, his (Ned) curly hair, his (Ned) twinkling eyes and his (Ned) mouth, when it smiled, proved attractive to many maidens.

Mrs. Baskerville left a spoon in the large beef-steak pudding and read her (Baskerville) brother-in-law's letter, while a cloud of steam ascended to the kitchen ceiling.

``DEAR BROTHER VIVIAN, ``You ask me to come and eat my dinner with you on the twenty-eighth day of June next, because on that day you will be up home seventy years old.

If you think 'tis a fine thing to find yourself past three score and ten--well, perhaps it is.

You can't go on much longer, anyway, and journey's end is no hardship.

At a first thought I should have reckoned such a birthday wasn't much to rejoice over; but you're right and I'm wrong.

A man may pride himself on getting so well through with the bulk of his (man) life and reaching nigh the finish with so few thorns in his (man) feet and aches in his (man) heart as what you have.

I'll come.

``Yours faithfully,

``HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE.'' (Uncle)

A mournful sound like the wind in the trees went up from Uncle Humphrey's nephews and nieces.

``Be damned to him (Humphrey)!'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

said Ned.

``Perhaps he (Ned) won't come after all, when he (Ned) hears Uncle Nat is coming,'' (She)
suggested May.

She (man) was always hopeful.

Mrs. Baskerville turned and put the letter on the mantel-shelf behind an eight-day clock.

Then she (Baskerville) sat down and began to help the pudding.

``We must make him (Nat) as welcome as we can, for father's sake,'' (she)
she (Baskerville) said.

CHAPTER II The hamlet of Shaugh Prior, a gift to the monks of Plympton in time past, stands beneath Shaugh Moor at the edge of a mighty declivity.

The Church of St. Edward lifts its battlemented tower and crocketed pinnacles above a world of waste and fallow.

It is perched upon a ridge and stands, supported by trees and a few cottages, in a position of great prominence.

The scant beauty that this holy place possessed has vanished under restoration; but there yet remain good bells, while a notable font-cover, cast forth by vanished vandals, is now returned to its use.

Round about the church dark sycamores shine in spring, and at autumn drop their patched and mottled foliage upon the dust of the dead.

Broad-bosomed fields ascend to the south; easterly a high road climbs to the Moor, and immediately north of Shaugh the slopes of High Down lead by North Wood to Cadworthy Farm and Cadworthy Bridge beyond it.

From High Down the village and its outlying habitations may be perceived at a glance.

The cots and homesteads converge and cluster in, with the church as the central point and heart of the organisation.

Around it dwellers from afar are come to sleep through their eternal night, and a double row of slates, like an amulet, girdles the ancient fane.

Here and there flash white marble in the string of grey above the graves of the people; and beside the churchyard wall stand heaped a pack of Time's playing cards--old, thin, and broken slates from graves forgotten--slates and shattered slabs that have fallen away from the unremembered dust they chronicled, and now follow into oblivion the bones they marked.

A school, a rectory, `The White Thorn' inn, and a dozen dwellings constitute Shaugh Prior, though the parish extends far beyond these boundaries; and on this spring day, one thrush warbling from a lilac bush at a cottage door, made music loud enough to fill the hamlet.

Undershaugh Farm stood near on the great hill that fell westerly to Shaugh Bridge, at watersmeet in the valley; and upon the land hard by it, two men tramped backward and forward, crossing and re-crossing in the bare centre of a field.

They were working over sown mangold and enriching the seed under their feet by scattering upon it a fertile powder.

The manure puffed from their hands in little golden clouds under the sunlight.

The secret of this mixture belonged to one man, and none grew such mangolds as he (man) could grow.

Undershaugh was the property of Nathan Baskerville, innkeeper, and he (Baskerville) had let it for twenty years to a widow; but Mr. Baskerville took an active personal interest in the welfare of his (Baskerville) property, and Mrs. Priscilla Lintern, his (Baskerville) tenant, was very well pleased to follow his (Baskerville) advice on all large questions of husbandry and rotation.

As did the rest of the world, she (Priscilla) knew his (Baskerville) worth and wisdom.

Nathan Baskerville had original ideas, and these were a source of ceaseless and amicable argument between him (Baskerville) and his (Baskerville) elder brother, Vivian Baskerville, of Cadworthy.

But Mr. Nathan's centre of activity and nidus, from which his (Nathan) enterprises and undertakings took shape and separate being, was `The White Thorn' public-house.

Here, at the centre of the little web of Shaugh Prior, he (White) pursued his (White) busy and prosperous life.

Nothing came amiss to him (White); nothing seemed to fail in his (White) hands.

He (White) had a finger in fifty pies, and men followed his (White) lead as a matter of course, for Nathan Baskerville was never known to make a bad bargain or faulty investment.

Nor did he (Baskerville) keep his (Baskerville) good luck to himself.

All men could win his (Baskerville) ear; the humblest found him (Baskerville) kind.

He (Baskerville) would invest a pound for a day labourer as willingly as ten for a farmer.

After five-and-twenty years in Shaugh Prior he (farmer) had won the absolute trust of his (farmer) neighbours.

All eyes brightened at his (farmer) name.

He (farmer) was wont to say that only one living man neither believed in him (man) nor trusted him (man).

``And that man, as luck will have it, is my own brother Humphrey,'' (the innkeeper)
the innkeeper would confess over his (innkeeper) bar to regular visitors thereat.

'''Tis no great odds, however, and I don't feel it so much as you might think, because Humphrey Baskerville is built on a very uncomfortable pattern.

If 'twas only me he (Baskerville) mistrusted, I might feel hurt about it; but 'tis the world, and therefore I've got no right to mind.

There's none--none he (Baskerville) would rely upon in a fix--a terrible plight for a man that.

But I live in hopes that I'll win him (man) round yet.''

The folk condoled with him (man), and felt a reasonable indignation that this most large-hearted, kindly, and transparent of spirits should rest under his (man) own brother's suspicion.

They explained it as the work of jealousy.

All Baskervilles had brains, and most were noted for good looks; but both gifts had reached their highest development and culmination in Nathan.

He (Nathan) was the handsomest and the cleverest of the clan; and doubtless Humphrey, a sinister and secret character, against whom much was whispered and more suspected, envied his (Humphrey) brother's gifts and far-reaching popularity.

Nathan was sixty, the youngest and physically the weakest of the three brothers.

He (Nathan) had a delicate throat which often caused him (Nathan) anxiety.

The men scattering manure upon the mangolds made an end of their work and separated.

One took some sacks and the pails used for the fertiliser.

Then he (Nathan) mounted a bare-backed horse that stood in a corner of the field, and rode away slowly to Undershaugh.

His (Nathan) companion crossed the stream beneath the village, mounted a hill beyond it, and presently entered `The White Thorn.'

He (White) was a well-turned, fair, good-looking youth in corduroys and black leathern leggings.

He (White) wore no collar, but his (White) blue cotton shirt was clean and made a pleasant contrast of colour with the brown throat that rose from it.

Young Lintern was the widow Lintern's only son and her (Lintern) right hand at Undershaugh.

The men in the bar gave him (son) good day, and Mr. Baskerville, who was serving, drew for him (Baskerville) half a pint of beer.

``Well, Heathman,'' (he)
he (Baskerville) said.

``So that's done.

And, mark me, 'twas worth the doing.

If you don't fetch home first prize as usual for they mangolds, say I've forgot the recipe.'' (queer)

'''Tis queer stuff,'' answered the youngster,

``and what with this wind blowing, my eyes and nose and throat's all full of it.'' (the youngster)

''`Twill do you no harm but rise a pleasant thirst.''

Mr. Baskerville had humour stamped at the wrinkled corners of his (Baskerville) bright eyes.

His (Baskerville) face was genial and rubicund.

He (Baskerville) wore a heavy grey beard, but his (Baskerville) hair, though streaked with grey, was still dark in colour.

A plastic mouth that widened into laughter a thousand times a day, belonged to him (Baskerville).

He (Baskerville) was rather above average height, sturdy and energetic.

He (Baskerville) declared that he (Baskerville) had never known what it was to be weary in mind or body.

Behind his (Baskerville) bar he (Baskerville) wore no coat, but ministered in turned-up shirt sleeves that revealed fine hairy arms.

Young Ned Baskerville sat in the bar, and now he (Baskerville) spoke to Heathman Lintern.

``Have one with me, Heathman,'' (he)
he (Baskerville) said.

``I was going down to your mother with a message, but now you can take it and save me the trouble.'' (uncle)

His (Baskerville) uncle shook his (Baskerville) head.

``Ah, boy--always the same with you.

Anybody as will save you trouble be your friend.

'Tis a very poor look-out, Ned; for let a certain party only get wind of it that you're such a chap for running from work, and he (chap)'ll mighty soon come along and save you all trouble for evermore.'' (unknown)

``And who might he (chap) be, Uncle Nat?'' (unknown)

``Old Nick, my fine fellow!

You may laugh, but Tommy Gollop here will bear me out, and Joe Voysey too, won't you, Joe?

They be both born and bred in the shadow of the church, and as well up in morals as grave-digging and cabbage-growing.

And they'll tell you that the devil's always ready to work for an idle man.'' (unknown)

``True,'' (Mr. Gollop/Gollop)
said Mr. Gollop.

``True as truth itself.

But the dowl won't work for nought, any more than the best of us.

Long hours, I grant you--never tired him (Gollop), and never takes a rest--but he (Gollop)'ll have his (Gollop) wages; and Ned here knows what they be, no doubt.'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

Ned laughed.

``I'm all right,'' (he)
he (Ned) said.

``I shall work hard enough come presently, when it gets to be worth while.'' (Mr. Gollop/Gollop)

Mr. Gollop spoke again.

He (Gollop) was a stout man with a little grey beard, a flat forehead, barely indicated under his (Gollop) low-growing, coarse hair, and large brown, solemn eyes.

He (Gollop) and his (Gollop) sister were leading figures at Shaugh Prior, and took themselves and their manifold labours in a serious spirit.

Some self-complacency marked their outlook; and their perspective was faulty.

They held Shaugh Prior as the centre of civilisation, and considered that their united labours had served to place and helped to maintain it in that position.

Thomas Gollop was parish clerk and sexton; his (Gollop) sister united many avocations.

She (sister) acted as pew-opener at the church; she (sister) was a sick-nurse and midwife; she (sister) took temporary appointments as plain cook; she (sister) posed as intelligencer of Shaugh Prior; and what she (sister) did not know of every man, woman, and child in the village, together with their ambitions, financial position, private relations, religious opinions, and physical constitutions, was not worth knowing.

``At times of large change like this, when we are threatened with all manner of doubts and dangers, 'tis well for every man among us to hold stoutly to religion and defy any one who would shake us,'' (Mr. Gollop/Gollop)
said Mr. Gollop.

``For my part I shall strike the first blow, and let it be seen that I'm a man very jealous for the Lord, and the village and the old paths.'' (unknown)

``What's going to happen?'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

asked Ned.

``You talk as if Doomsday was coming.'' (unknown)

``Not at all,'' (Mr. Gollop/Gollop)
answered Mr. Gollop.

``When Doomsday comes, if I'm still here, I shall know how to handle it; but 'tis the new vicar.

A man is a man; and with a strange man 'tis only too terrible certain there will creep in strange opinions and a nasty hunger for novelty.'' (unknown)

``And what's worse,'' (Mr. Voysey)
said Mr. Voysey,
``a young man.

An old man I could have faced from my sixty-five years without fear; but how can you expect a young youth--full of the fiery silliness of the twenties--to understand that as I've been gardener at the vicarage for forty year, so in right and decency and order I ought to go on being gardener there?'' (Mr. Voysey)

``Have no fear, Joe,'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)
said Mr. Baskerville.

``If there's one thing among us that Mr. Masterman won't change, 'tis you, I'm sure; for who knows the outs and ins of the garden up the hill like you do?'' (Tommy Gollop/Tommy)

'''Tis true,'' admitted Tommy Gollop.

``That land is like a human, you might say--stiff and stubborn and got to be coaxed to do its best; and I'm sure he (Gollop)'ll very soon see that only Voysey can fetch his (Voysey) beans and peas out of the soil, and that it's took him (Voysey) a lifetime to learn the trick of the place.

And I feel the same to the church.

If he (Voysey)'s got any new-fangled fashion of worship, Shaugh will rise against him (Shaugh) like one man.

After fifty-two years of the Reverend Valletort, we can't be blown from our fixed ways at a young man's breath; and I'm sure I do hope that he (man) won't want so much as a cobweb swept down, or else there'll be difficulties spring up around him (man) like weeds after rain.'' (unknown)

``What a pack of mouldy old fossils you are in this place!'' (Heathman/Heathman Lintern)

said Heathman Lintern.

``I'm sure, for my part, I hope the man will fetch along a few new ideas to waken us up.

If 'twasn't for Mr. Baskerville here, Shaugh would be forgot in the world altogether.

You should hear Jack Head on the subject.'' (Tommy Gollop/Tommy)

But Tommy Gollop little liked such criticism.

``You're young and terribly ignorant, and Jack Head's a red radical as ought to be locked up,'' (he)
he (Head) answered.

``But you'll do well to keep your ignorance from leaking out and making you look a ninny-hammer afore sensible men.

Shaugh Prior's a bit ahead of the times rather than behind 'em, and my fear always is, and always will be, that we shall take the bit in our teeth some day and bolt with it.

'Tis no good being too far ahead of the race; and that's why I'm afeared that this young Masterman, when he (Masterman) finds how forward we are, will try to go one better and stir up strife.'' (unknown)

``Don't think it, Tommy,'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)
said Nathan Baskerville.

``I've had a good tell with him (Tommy) and find him (Tommy) a very civil-spoken and well-meaning man.

No fool, neither.

You mustn't expect him (fool) to leave everything just as Mr. Valletort left it.

You must allow for the difference between eighty-two and twenty-eight, which is Mr. Masterman's age; but, believe me, he (Masterman)'s calm and sensible and very anxious to please.

He (Masterman)'s pleased me by praising my beer, like one who knew; and he (Masterman)'s pleased my brother Vivian by praising his (Masterman) riding-cob, like one who knew; and he (Masterman)'ll please Joe Voysey presently by praising the vicarage garden; and he (Masterman)'ll please you, Thomas, by praising your churchyard.'' (unknown)

``If he (Masterman)'s going to be all things to all men, he (Masterman)'ll please none,'' (Tommy Gollop/Tommy)
said Tommy.

``We've got no need of one of them easy ministers.

Him (Tommy) and me must keep the whip-hand of Shaugh, same as me and the Reverend Valletort used to do.

However, the man will hear my views, and my sister's also; because a clear understanding from the start be going to save a world of worry after.'' (unknown)

``Not married,'' (Mr. Voysey)
said Mr. Voysey.

``But he (Voysey)'ve a sister.

I hope she (sister) ban't one of they gardening sort, so-called, that's always messing round making work and finding things blowed down here or eaten with varmints there.

If she (sister)'s a flower-liking female, `twill be my place to tell her (sister) straight out from the shoulder that flowers won't grow in the vicarage garden, and that she (sister) must be content with the `dendrums in summer time and the foxgloves and such-like homely old stuff.'' (unknown)

``He (Voysey) was a football player to college and very skilled at it, so Barker told me,'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)
said Ned Baskerville.

``Then mark me, he (Baskerville)'ll be for making a club, and teaching the young chaps to play of a Saturday and keeping 'em out of your bar, Mr. Baskerville,'' (the parish clerk)
declared the parish clerk;
``Yes, look at it as you will, there's changes in the air, and I hope we'll all stand shoulder to shoulder against 'em, and down the man afore he (man) gets his (man) foot in the stirrup.'' (the parish clerk)

``You two--Joe Voysey and you--be enough to frighten the poor soul out of his (Voysey) seven senses afore he (Voysey)'s been in the place a week,'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)
declared Ned Baskerville.

``And I hope for one that Uncle Nat won't go against him (Nat); and I know father won't, for he (father)'s said this many a day that old Valletort was past his (father) work and ought to be pensioned off.'' (unknown)

``Your father's not a man for unseemly changes, all the same,'' (Tommy Gollop/Tommy)
declared Tommy;
``and if this new young minister was to go in the pulpit in white instead of black, for instance, as the Popish habit is, Vivian Baskerville would be the first to rise up and tell him (Baskerville) to dress himself decently and in order.'' (Tommy Gollop/Tommy)

But Ned denied this.

``Don't you think you know my father, Tommy, because you don't.

If this chap gets up a football club, he (chap)'ll have father on his (chap) side from the first; and he (chap) can preach in black or white or pea-green, so long as he (chap) talks sense through his (chap) mouth, and not nonsense through his (chap) nose, like the old one did.'' (unknown)

``Don't you speak for your father,'' (Joseph)
said Joseph Voysey.

He (Joseph) was a very tall and a very thin man, with pale, watery eyes and a scanty beard.

Nature had done so much for his (Joseph) long and rather absurd hatchet nose, that there was no material left for his (Joseph) chin.

``If I shouldn't talk for my father, who should?'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

retorted Ned.

Then Mr. Voysey descended to personalities and accused the other of irreverence and laziness.

The argument grew sharp and Mr. Baskerville was forced to still it.

``Come you along and don't talk twaddle, Ned,'' (he)
he (Ned) said to his (Ned) nephew.

``I'm going down to Undershaugh myself this minute, to see Mrs. Lintern, and you and Heathman will come with me.'' (He)

He (Ned) called to a pot-boy, turned down his (Ned) sleeves, took his (Ned) coat from a hook behind the door, and was ready to start.

``When Mr. Masterman does come among us, `twill be everybody's joy and pride to make him (Masterman) welcome in a kindly spirit,'' (he)
he (Masterman) said.

``Changes must happen, but if he (Masterman)'s a gentleman and a sportsman and a Christian--all of which he (Christian) certainly looks to be--then `twill be the fault of Shaugh Prior, and not the man's, if all don't go friendly and suent.

Give and take's the motto.'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (Mr. Gollop/Gollop)
admitted Mr. Gollop.

``Give nought and take all: that's the way of the young nowadays; and that'll be his (Gollop) way so like as not; and I'll deny him (Gollop) to his (Gollop) face from the first minute, if he (Gollop) seeks to ride roughshod over me, and the church, and the people.'' (unknown)

``Hear!

Hear!'' (Mr. Voysey)

cried Mr. Voysey.

``We'll hope he (Voysey)'ll have enough sense to spare a little for you silly old blids,'' (Heathman/Heathman Lintern)
said Heathman Lintern.

Then he (Voysey) followed the Baskervilles.

CHAPTER III Nathan Baskerville, like his (Voysey) brother Humphrey, was a widower.

Very early in life he (widower) had married a young woman of good means and social position superior to his (widower) own.

His (widower) handsome face and manifold charms of disposition won Minnie Stanlake, and she (Minnie) brought to him (widower) a small fortune in her (Minnie) own right, together with the detestation of her (Minnie) whole family.

Husband and wife had lived happily, save for the woman's fierce and undying jealousy which extended beyond her (woman) early grave.

She (woman) died childless at eight-and-twenty, and left five thousand pounds to her (woman) husband on the understanding that he (husband) did not marry again.

He (husband) obeyed this condition, though it was vain in law, and presently returned to his (husband) own people.

His (husband) married life was spent at Taunton, as a general dealer, but upon his (husband) wife's death he (husband) abandoned this business and set up another like it at Bath.

At five-and-thirty years of age he (husband) came back to Devonshire and his (husband) native village.

Great natural energy kept him (husband) busy.

He (husband) dearly liked to conduct all manner of pettifogging business, and his (husband) good nature was such that the folk did not hesitate to consult him (husband) upon their affairs.

His (husband) legal attainments were considered profound, while his (husband) shrewd handling of figures, and his (husband) personal prosperity, combined to place him (husband) on a pinnacle among the folk as a great financier and most capable man of business.

He (man) did not lend money at interest, but was known more than once to have helped a lame dog over a stile.

Many kind things he (man) did, and no man spoke a bad word of him (man).

People brought him (man) their savings and begged him (man) to invest them according to his (man) judgment.

They usually asked for no details, but received their interest regularly, and trusted Nathan Baskerville like the Bank of England.

He (Baskerville) was in truth a large-hearted and kindly spirit, who found his (Baskerville) pleasure in the affection and also in the applause of the people.

He (Baskerville) liked to figure among them as the first.

He (Baskerville) loved work for itself and enjoyed the universal praise of his (Baskerville) attainments.

Mr. Gollop might delude himself into believing that he (Gollop) was the leading citizen of Shaugh; but the master of `The White Thorn' knew better.

Without undue vanity he (Thorn) was not able to hide the fact that he (Thorn) stood above others in the esteem of the countryside.

He (Thorn) was not so rich as people thought, and he (Thorn) had not laid foundations of such a fortune as they supposed during the years at Bath; but he (Thorn) fostered the impression and the fame it gave him (Thorn).

It suited better his (Thorn) native idiosyncrasy to tower among smaller men, than to be small amidst his (Thorn) betters.

He (Thorn) liked the round-eyed reverence of ploughboys and the curtsey of the school children.

The late vicar, a Tory of the early Victorian age, had contrived to let Mr. Baskerville perceive the gulf that existed between them; and that the more definitely because Nathan was a Nonconformist.

The publican professed strong Conservative principles, however, and the attitude of the last incumbent of Shaugh had caused him (Shaugh) some secret annoyance; but he (Shaugh) too hoped that with the advent of a younger man and modern principles this slight disability might vanish.

For the rest he (Shaugh) rode to hounds, and his (Shaugh) attitude in the hunting field was admitted to be exceedingly correct and tactful.

He (Shaugh) had no known confidant and he (Shaugh) seldom spoke about himself.

That he (Shaugh) had never married astonished many people exceedingly; but it was significant of the genuine affection and esteem entertained for him (Shaugh) that none, even when they came to learn of his (Shaugh) dead wife's bequest and its condition, ever imputed sordid motives to his (Shaugh) celibacy.

Five thousand pounds was guessed to be but a small part of Mr. Baskerville's fortune, and, when the matter chanced upon local tongues, men and women alike were quite content to believe that not affection for money, but love for his (Baskerville) dead partner, had proved strong enough to maintain Nathan in widowhood.

He (Nathan) liked the company of women, and was never so pleased as when doing them a service.

For their part they admired him (Nathan) also and wished him (Nathan) well.

Mr. Baskerville not only owned `The White Thorn' and its adjacencies, but had other house property at Shaugh and in the neighbouring parish of Bickleigh.

His (Baskerville) principal possession was the large farm of Undershaugh; and thither now he (Baskerville) proceeded with his (Baskerville) nephew, Ned Baskerville, on one side of him (Baskerville) and young Heathman Lintern on the other.

According to his (Baskerville) wont Nathan chattered volubly and suited the conversation to his (Baskerville) listeners.

``You young chaps must both join the football club, if there is one.

I'm glad to think new parson's that sort, for 'tis just the kind of thing we're wanting here.

You fellows, and a lot like you, spend too much time and money at my bar to please me.

You may laugh, Ned, but 'tis so.

And another thing I'd have you to know: so like as not we shall have a rifle corps also.

I've often turned my mind on it.

We must let this man see we're not all willingly behind the times, but only waiting for a bit of encouragement to go ahead with the best.'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

Ned pictured his (Ned) own fine figure in a uniform, and applauded the rifle corps; and Heathman did the like.

``Ned here would fancy himself a lot in that black and silver toggery the yeomanry wear, wouldn't you, Ned?'' (a chaps)

'''Tis a very good idea, and would help to make you and a few other round-backed chaps as straight in the shoulders as me,'' declared Ned complacently.

``Well, you may be straight,'' (unknown)
answered the other with a laugh.

``Certainly you've never been known yet to bend your shoulders to work.

A day's trout-fishing be the hardest job that ever you've taken on--unless courting the maidens be a hard job.'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

Ned laughed and so did his (Ned) uncle.

``You're right there, Heathman,'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)
declared Mr. Baskerville.

``A lazy scamp you are, Ned, though your father won't see it; but nobody knows it better than the girls.

They like you very well for a fine day and a picnic by the river; but I can tell you this: they're getting to see through you only too well.

They don't want fair-weather husbands; but stout, hard fellows, like Heathman here, as have got brains and use 'em, and arms and legs and use 'em.'' (unknown)

``No more use--you, than a pink and white china joney stuck on a mantelshelf,'' (Heathman/Heathman Lintern)
said Heathman.

Whereupon Ned dashed at him (Ned) and, half in jest, half in earnest, they wrestled by the roadside.

Mr. Baskerville looked on with great enjoyment, and helped presently to dust Heathman after he (Baskerville) had been cross-buttocked.

``That'll show 'e if I'm a pink and white puppet for a mantelpiece,'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)
declared Ned.

The other laughed and licked a scratch on his (Ned) hand.

``Well done you!'' (he)

he (Ned) said.

``Never thought you was so spry.

But let's have a whole day's ploughing over a bit of the five-acre field to Undershaugh, and see what sort of a man you are in the evening.'' (unknown)

``Not me,'' (unknown)
answered the other.

``Got no use for the plough-tail myself.

Rupert will take you on at that.'' (unknown)

``To see you wrestle puts me in mind of your father,'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)
said Nathan.

``This generation can't call home his (Nathan) greatness, and beside him (Nathan) you're a shrimp to a lobster, Ned; but 'twas a grand sight to see him (Ned) handle a man in his (Ned) prime.

I mind actually getting him (Ned) up to London once, because I named his (Ned) name there among some sporting fellows and 'twas slighted.

They thought, being my brother, that I held him (brother) too high, though he (brother) was champion of Devon at the time.

But my way is never to say nought with my tongue that I won't back with my pocket, and I made a match for thirty pounds a side for your father.

A Middlesex man called Thorpe, from down Bermondsey way, was chosen, and your father came up on a Friday and put that chap on his (father) back twice in five minutes, and then went home again fifteen pound to the good.

A very clever man too, was Thorpe, but he (Thorpe) never wanted to have no more to do with your father.

Vivian weighed over fourteen stone in them days, and not a pound of fat in the lot, I believe.

He (Vivian) could have throwed down a tor, I reckon, if he (Vivian) could have got a hold on it.

But you fellows be after your mother's build.

The best of you--him (Vivian) that's at sea--won't never draw the beam to twelve stone.'' (A tramp)

A tramp stopped Mr. Baskerville, touched his (Baskerville) hat and spoke.

``You gave me a bit of work harvesting two year ago, master, and you didn't pull much of a long face when I told you I wasn't fond of work as a rule.

I'm more broke than usual just for the minute, and rather short o' boot-leather.

Can 'e give me a job?'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)

Nathan was famous at making work for everybody, and loafers rarely appealed to him (Nathan) in vain.

How such an exceedingly busy man could find it in his (man) heart to sympathise with drones, none knew.

It was another of the anomalies of Mr. Baskerville's character.

But he (Baskerville) often proved good for a square meal, a day's labour and a night's rest, as many houseless folk well knew.

``You're the joker who calls himself the `Duke of Drake's Island,' aren't you?'' (unknown)

``The Duke of Drake's Island'' (He)
grinned and nodded.

He (Drake) was a worthless soul, very well known to the Devon constabulary.

``Get up to the village and call at `The White Thorn' in an hour from now, and ask for me.'' (unknown)

``Thank you kindly, Mr.

Baskerville.'' (unknown)

``We'll see about that later.

I can find a job for you to-night; but it ain't picking primroses.'' (Priscilla/Priscilla Lintern/Lintern)

Priscilla Lintern met her (Lintern) landlord at the gate of Undershaugh.

They were on terms of intimacy, and nodded to each other in an easy and friendly manner.

She (Lintern) had been feeding poultry from a basin, and now set it down, wiped her (Lintern) fingers on her (Lintern) apron, and shook hands with Ned Baskerville.

``How be you, then?

'Tis a longful time since you called on us, Master Ned.'' (unknown)

``I'm clever, thank you; and I see you are, Mrs. Lintern.

And I hope Cora and Phyllis be all right too.

Heathman here be growing as strong as a lion--ban't you, Heathman?'' (Mrs. Lintern)

Mrs. Lintern was a brown, good-looking woman of rather more than fifty.

For twenty years she (Lintern) had farmed Undershaugh, and her (Lintern) power of reserve surprised a garrulous village.

It was taken by the sensible for wisdom and by the foolish for pride.

She (Lintern) worked hard, paid her (Lintern) rent at the hour it was due, as Nathan often mentioned to her (Lintern) credit, and kept her (Lintern) own counsel.

Very little was known about her (Lintern), save that she (Lintern) had come to Shaugh as a widow with three young children, that she (Lintern) was kind-hearted and might have married Mr. Gollop a year after her (Lintern) arrival, but had declined the honour.

Her (Lintern) daughters were at dinner when the men entered, and both rose and saluted Ned with some self-consciousness.

Phyllis, the younger, was like her (Phyllis) mother: brown, neat, silent and reserved; the elder was cast in a larger mould and might have been called frankly beautiful.

Cora was dark, with black eyes and a fair skin whose purity she (Phyllis) took pains to preserve.

She (Phyllis) was tall, straight and full in the bosom.

Her (Phyllis) mouth alone betrayed her (Phyllis), for the lips set close and they were rather thin; but people forgot them when she (Phyllis) laughed and showed her (Phyllis) pretty teeth.

Her (Phyllis) laugh again belied her (Phyllis) lips, for it was gentle and pleasant.

She (Phyllis) had few delusions for a maiden, and she (Phyllis) worked hard.

To Cora belonged a gift of common-sense.

The girl lacked sentiment, but she (girl) was shrewd and capable.

She (girl) kept her (girl) mother's books and displayed a talent for figures.

It was said that she (girl) had the brains of the family.

Only Mr. Baskerville himself doubted it, and maintained that Cora's mother was the abler woman.

Phyllis was lost at all times in admiration of her (Phyllis) more brilliant sister, but Heathman did not like Cora and often quarrelled with her (Phyllis).

Ned gave his (Ned) message and asked for a drink of cider.

Thereupon Phyllis rose from her (Phyllis) dinner and went to fetch it.

But young Baskerville's eyes were on Cora while he (Cora) drank.

He (Cora) had the manner of a man very well accustomed to female society, and long experience had taught him (Cora) that nine girls out of ten found him (Cora) exceedingly attractive.

His (Cora) easy insolence won them against their will.

Such girls as demanded worship and respect found Ned not so agreeable; but those who preferred the male creature to dominate were fascinated by his (Ned) sublimity and affectation of knowledge and worldly wisdom.

He (Ned) pretended to know everything--a convincing attitude only among those who know nothing.

The talk was of a revel presently to take place at Tavistock.

``And what's your gown going to be, Phyllis?'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

asked Ned.

The gown of Phyllis did not interest him (Ned) in the least, but this question was put as a preliminary to another, and when the younger sister told him (Ned) that she (sister) meant to wear plum-colour, he (Ned) turned to Cora.

``Cora's got a lovely frock--blue muslin wi' little pink roses, and a straw hat wi' big pink roses,'' (Phyllis/Phyllis Lintern)
said Phyllis.

Ned nodded.

``I'd go a long way to see her (Phyllis) in such a beautiful dress,'' (he)
he (Ned) said;
``and, mind, I'm to have a dance or two with you both.

There's to be dancing in the evening--not rough and tumble on the grass, but boards are to be laid down and everything done proper.'' (he)

They chattered about the promised festivity, while Nathan and Mrs. Lintern, having discussed certain farm matters, spoke of another and a nearer celebration.

``You see, my brother Vivian and I are of the good old-fashioned sort, and we're bent on the whole family meeting at a square feed, with good wishes all round, on his (Vivian) seventieth birthday.

To think of him (Vivian) turned seventy!

I can't believe it.

Yet Time won't stand still--not even with the busiest.

A family affair 'tis to be, and none asked outside ourselves.'' (unknown)

``Does Mr. Humphrey go?

He (Humphrey)'s not much of a hand at a revel.'' (unknown)

``He (Humphrey) is not; and I thought that he (Humphrey) would have refused the invitation.

But he (Humphrey)'s accepted.

We shall try our hardest to cheer him (Humphrey) up and get a drop of generous liquor into him (Humphrey).

I only hope he (Humphrey) won't be a damper and spoil the fun.'' (unknown)

``A pity he (Humphrey)'s going.'' (unknown)

``We shall know that better afterwards.

`Twill be a pity if he (Humphrey) mars all; but `twill be a good thing if we overmaster him (Humphrey) amongst us, and get him (Humphrey) to take a hopefuller view of life and a kinder view of his (Humphrey) fellow-creatures.'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

Ned chimed in.

``You'll never do that, Uncle Nat.

He (Nat)'s too old to change now.

And Cousin Mark be going just the same way.

He (Mark)'s getting such a silent, hang-dog chap, and no wonder, having to live with such a father.

I'd run away if I was him (father).'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)

Nathan laughed.

``I believe you'd almost rather work than keep along with your Uncle Humphrey,'' (he)
he (Humphrey) said.

'''Tis pretty well known I can work when I choose,'' declared Ned.

``Yes,'' (Heathman/Heathman Lintern)
said Heathman, with his (Ned) mouth full;
``and 'tis also pretty well known you never do choose.'' (Heathman/Heathman Lintern)

The elder Baskerville clapped his (Baskerville) hands.

``One to you, Heathman!'' (he)

he (Baskerville) said.

``Ned can't deny the truth of that.'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

But Ned showed no concern.

``I shall make up for lost time very easily when I do start,'' (he)
he (Ned) said.

``I've got ideas, I believe, and they go beyond ploughing.

I'm like Cora here--all brains.

You may laugh, Uncle Nat, but you're not the only Baskerville with a head on your shoulders.

I'll astonish you yet.'' (unknown)

``You will--you will--the day you begin to work, Ned; and the sooner the better.

I shall be very glad when it happens.'' (The women)

The women laughed, and Cora much admired Ned's lofty attitude.

She (Ned) too had ambitions, and felt little sympathy with those who were content to labour on the soil.

She (Ned) strove often to fire her (Ned) brother and enlarge his (brother) ambitions; but he (brother) had the farmer's instinct, enjoyed physical work, and laughed at her (Ned) airs and graces.

``Give me Rupert,'' (Heathman/Heathman Lintern)
said Heathman now.

``He (Rupert)'s like me--not much good at talking and ain't got no use for the girls, but a towser to work.'' (unknown)

``The man who ain't got no use for the girls is not a man,'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)
declared Ned very positively.

``They're the salt of the earth--ban't they, Mrs.

Lintern?'' (She)

She (Lintern) smiled and looked at him (Ned) curiously, then at his (Ned) uncle; but she (Lintern) did not answer.

``Anyway,'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)
continued Ned,
``you're out when you say Rupert's like you; for hard worker that he (Rupert) is, he (Rupert)'s found time for a bit of love-making.'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

Cora and Phyllis manifested instant excitement and interest at this news.

``Who is she (Phyllis)?

You must tell us,'' (unknown)

said the elder.

``Why, I will; but say nought, for nothing be known about it outside the families, and Rupert haven't said a word himself to me.

I reckon he (Rupert) don't guess that I know.

But such things can't be hid from my eyes--too sharp for that, I believe.

'Tis Milly Luscombe, if you must know.

A very nice little thing too in her (Luscombe) way.

Not my sort--a bit too independent.

I like a girl to feel a man's the oak to her (girl) ivy, but--'' (uncle)

Uproarious laughter from his (man) uncle cut Ned short.

``Mighty fine oak for a girl's ivy--you!'' (he)

he (Ned) said.

``You wait,'' (unknown)
repeated the younger.

``Anyway, Rupert be sweet on Milly, and father knows all about it, and won't hear of it.

So there's thunder in the air for the moment.'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

They discussed this interesting private news, but promised Ned not to retail it in any ear.

Then he (Ned) left them and, with Nathan, returned to the village.

Ned, undeterred by Mr. Baskerville's raillery, began loudly to praise Cora as soon as they had passed beyond earshot of the farmhouse-door.

``By Jove, she (Milly)'s a bowerly maiden and no mistake!

Not her (Milly) like this side of Plymouth, I do believe.

Haven't seen her (Milly) for a month of Sundays, and she (Milly)'s come on amazing.'' (unknown)

``She (Milly)'s a very handsome girl without a doubt,'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)
admitted Nathan.

``And a very clever girl too; but a word in your ear, my young shaver: you mustn't look that way once and for all.'' (unknown)

``Why not, if I choose?

I'm a free man.'' (unknown)

``You may be--now--more shame to you.

But Cora--well, your cousin Mark be first in the field there.

A word to the wise is enough.

You'll be doing a very improper thing if you look in that quarter, and I must firmly beg you won't, for everybody's sake.'' (unknown)

``Mark!'' (unknown)

``Mark.

And a very good chap he (Mark) is--worth fifty of you.'' (unknown)

``Mark!'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

repeated Ned, as though the notion was unthinkable.

``I should have guessed that he (Mark) would rather have run out of the country than lift his (Mark) eyes to a girl!'' (Reverend)

CHAPTER IV The Reverend Dennis Masterman was a bachelor.

He (Masterman) came to Shaugh full of physical energy and certain hazy resolutions to accomplish notable work among a neglected people.

His (Masterman) scholastic career was nugatory, and his (Masterman) intellect had offered no bar to his (Masterman) profession.

He (Masterman) was physically brave, morally infirm.

Therefore his (Masterman) sister, Alice Masterman, came to support him (Masterman) and share his (Masterman) lot and complement his (Masterman) character.

She (Masterman) might indeed fly from cows, but she (Masterman) would not fly from parochial opposition.

She (Masterman) was strong where he (Masterman) was weak.

They were young, sanguine, and of gentle birth.

They enjoyed private means, but were filled with wholesome ardour to justify existence and leave the world better than they found it.

Dennis Masterman possessed interest, and regarded this, his (Masterman) first cure, as a stepping-stone to better things.

Shaugh Prior was too small for his (Masterman) natural energies and powers of endurance--so he (Masterman) told his (Masterman) sister; but she (sister) said that the experience would be helpful.

She (sister) also suspected that reform might not be a matter of energy alone.

One evening, a week after their arrival, they were planning the campaign and estimating the value of lay helpers, when two important visitors were announced.

A maiden appeared and informed the clergyman that Thomas Gollop and Eliza Gollop desired to see him (Gollop).

``Show them into the common room,'' (he)
said he (Gollop); then he (Gollop) twisted a little bronze cross that he (Gollop) wore at his (Gollop) watchchain and regarded Miss Masterman.

``The parish clerk and his (Gollop) sister--I wonder if you'd mind, Alice?'' (he)

he (Gollop) asked.

For answer she (Alice) put down her (Alice) work.

``Certainly.

Since you saw Joe Voysey alone and, not only engaged him (Voysey), but promised he (Voysey) might have a boy for the weeding, I feel--well, you are a great deal too easy, Dennis.

Gollop is a very masterful person, clearly, and his (Gollop) sister, so I am told, is just the same.

You certainly must not see women alone.

They'll get everything they want out of you.'' (unknown)

``Of course, one wishes to strike a genial note,'' (he)
he (Gollop) explained.

``First impressions count for such a lot with common people.'' (unknown)

``Be genial by all means; I say nothing against that.'' (unknown)

``Let's tackle them, then.

Gollop's a tremendous Conservative, but we must get Liberal ideas into him (Gollop), if we can--in reason.'' (Dennis/Masterman/Dennis Masterman)

Dennis Masterman was tall, square-shouldered and clean-shaven.

He (Masterman) regarded himself as somewhat advanced, but had no intention of sowing his (Masterman) opinions upon the parish before the soil was prepared.

He (Masterman) considered his (Masterman) character to be large-minded, tolerant, and sane; and for a man of eight-and-twenty he (Masterman) enjoyed fair measure of these virtues.

His (Masterman) sister was plain, angular, and four years older than Dennis.

She (sister) wore double eyeglasses and had a gruff voice and a perceptible beard.

The Gollops rose as the vicar and his (vicar) sister appeared.

Miss Gollop was shorter and stouter than her (Gollop) brother, but resembled him (vicar).

``Good evening, your reverence; good evening, miss,'' (the parish clerk)
said the parish clerk.

``This is my sister, Miss Eliza.

For faith, hope, and charity she (Eliza) standeth.

In fact, a leading light among us, though I say it as should not.'' (Mr. Masterman/Masterman)

Mr. Masterman shook hands with the woman; his (Masterman) sister bowed only.

``And what does Miss Gollop do?'' (Dennis/Masterman/Dennis Masterman)

asked Dennis.

''`Twould be easier to say what she (Gollop) don't do,'' answered Thomas.

``She (Gollop)'s butt-woman to begin with, or as you would call it, `pew-opener.'

Then she (Gollop)'s sick-nurse to the parish, and she (Gollop)'s midwife, and, when free, she (Gollop)'ll do chores or cook for them as want her (Gollop).

And she (Gollop)'s got a knowledge and understanding of the people round these parts as won't be beaten.

She (Gollop) was Mr. Valletort's right hand, wasn't you, Eliza?'' (unknown)

``So he (Valletort) said,'' (Gollop/Eliza/Eliza Gollop)
answered Miss Gollop.

She (Gollop) was not self-conscious, but bore herself as Fame's familiar and one accustomed to admiration.

She (Gollop) had estimated the force of the clergyman's character from his (character) first sermon, and judged that her (Gollop) brother would be a match for him (brother).

Now she (Gollop) covertly regarded Miss Masterman, and perceived that here must lie any issue of battle that might arise.

``Do you abide along with your brother, miss, or be you just settling him (brother) into the vicarage?'' (she)

she (Gollop) asked.

``I live with him (brother).'' (Gollop/Eliza/Eliza Gollop)

Miss Gollop inclined her (Gollop) head.

``And I'm sure I hope, if I can serve you any way at any time, as you'll let me know.'' (unknown)

``Thank you.

Everybody can serve us: we want help from one and all,'' (Mr. Masterman/Masterman)

said Mr. Masterman.

``Ezacally so!'' (Thomas/Thomas Gollop)

said Thomas.

``And you must larn each man's value from those that know it--not by bitter experience.

Likewise with the women.

My sister can tell you, to threepence a day, what any female in this parish be good for; and as to the men, you'll do very well to come to me.

I know 'em all--old and young--and their characters and their points--good and bad, crooked and odd.

For we've got some originals among us, and I'm not going to deny it, haven't us, Eliza?'' (unknown)

``Every place have,'' (she)
she (Eliza) said.

``Might we sit down?'' (the man)

asked the man.

``We'm of the bungy breed, as you see, and not so clever in our breathing as we could wish.

But we'm here to go through the whole law and the prophets, so to speak, and we can do it better sitting.'' (unknown)

``Please sit down,'' (Dennis/Masterman/Dennis Masterman)
answered Dennis.

Then he (Dennis) looked at his (Dennis) watch.

``I can give you an hour,'' (he)
he (Dennis) said.

``But I'm going to ride over to Bickleigh at nine o'clock, to see the vicar there.'' (unknown)

``And a very nice gentleman you'll find him (gentleman),'' (Thomas/Thomas Gollop)
declared Thomas.

``Of course, Bickleigh be but a little matter beside Shaugh Prior.

We bulk a good deal larger in the eyes of the nation, and can hold our heads so much the higher in consequence; but the Reverend Coaker is a very good, humble-minded man, and knows his (man) place in a way that's a high example to the younger clergymen.'' (Miss Masterman/Masterman)

Miss Masterman cleared her (Masterman) throat, but her (Masterman) voice was none the less gruff.

``Perhaps you will now tell us what you have come for.

We are busy people,'' (she)

she (Masterman) said.

Her (Masterman) brother deprecated this brevity and tried to tone it down, but Thomas accepted the lady's statement with great urbanity.

``Miss be right,'' (he)
he (Thomas) answered.

``Busy as bees, I warrant--same as me and my own sister here.

She (sister) don't wear out many chairs, do you, Eliza?'' (unknown)

``Not many,'' (Gollop/Eliza/Eliza Gollop)
said Miss Gollop.

``I always say, `Let's run about in this world; plenty of time to sit down in the next.''' (unknown)

``I may tell you,'' (Thomas/Thomas Gollop)
added Thomas kindly,
``that your first sermon went down very suent.

From where I sits, along by the font, I can get a good look across the faces, and the important people, the Baskervilles and the Lillicraps and the Luscombes and the Mumfords--one and all listened to every word, and nodded now and again.

You'll be glad to know that.'' (Thomas/Thomas Gollop)

``Some thought 'twas a sermon they'd heard afore, however,'' (Gollop/Eliza/Eliza Gollop)
said Miss Gollop;
``but no doubt they was wrong.'' (Gollop/Eliza/Eliza Gollop)

``Quite wrong,'' (Dennis/Masterman/Dennis Masterman)
declared Dennis warmly.

``It was a sermon written only the night before I preached it.

And talking of the font--'' (Mr. Gollop/Gollop)

``Yes, of course, you've marked the famous font-cover over the holy basin, I suppose?'' (Mr. Gollop/Gollop)

interrupted Mr. Gollop.

'''Tis the joy and pride of the church-town, I assure you.

Not another like it in the world, they say.

Learned men come all across England to see it--as well they may.''

The famous font-cover, with its eight little snub-nosed saints and the Abbot elevated in the midst, was a special glory of St. Edward's.

``I meant to speak of that,'' (the clergyman)
said the clergyman.

``The figure at the top has got more than his (clergyman) proper vestments on, Gollop.

In fact, he (clergyman)'s wrapped up in cobwebs.

That is not worthy of us.

Please see they are cleaned off.'' (unknown)

``I hadn't noticed them; but since you say so--I'll look to it myself.

Where the vamp-dish be concerned I allow none to meddle.

It shall be done; but I must say again that I haven't noticed any cobwebs--not last Sunday.

Have you, Eliza?'' (Thomas/Thomas Gollop)

said Thomas.

``No, I have not,'' (sister)
answered his (Thomas) sister.

``The dirt has clearly been there for months,'' (Miss Masterman/Masterman)
remarked Miss Masterman.

There was a painful pause, during which Miss Gollop gazed at the vicar's sister and then at the vicar.

'''Tis a well-known fact that spiders will spin,'' she (Gollop) said vaguely, but not without intention.

The other woman ignored her (woman) and turned to Thomas.

``Will you be so good as to proceed?'' (unknown)

``Yes, and gladly, miss,'' (he)
he (Thomas) answered.

``And I'll begin with the Gollops, since they've done as much for this parish as anybody, living or dead.

My father was parish clerk afore me, and a very remarkable man, wasn't he (man), Eliza?'' (unknown)

``He (man) was.'' (unknown)

``A remarkable man with a large faith in the power of prayer, was father.

You don't see such faith now, worse luck.

But he (father) believed more than even I hold to, or my sister, either.

You might say that he (father) wasn't right always; but none ever dared to doubt the high religious quality of the man.

But there he (man) was--a pillar of the Church and State, as they say.

He (man) used to help his (man) money a bit by the power of prayer; and they fetched childer sick of the thrush to him (man); and he (man)'d tak 'em up the church tower and hold 'em over the battlements, north, south, east, and west--while he (man) said the Lord's Prayer four times.

He (man)'d get a shilling by it every time, and was known to do twenty of 'em in a good year, though I never heard 'twas a very quick cure.

But faith moves mountains, and he (man) may have done more good than appeared to human eyes.

And then in his (man) age, he (man) very near let a heavy babby drop over into the churchyard--just grabbed hold of un by a miracle and saved un.

So that proper terrified the old man, and he (man) never done another for fear of some lasting misfortune.

Not but what a few devilish-natured people said that if 'twas knowed he (man) let the childer fall now and again, he (man)'d brisk up his (man) business a hundred per centum.

Which shows the evil-mindedness of human nature.'' (unknown)

``I'll have no gross superstition of that sort here,'' (Mr. Masterman/Masterman)
said Mr. Masterman firmly.

``No more won't I,'' (Thomas/Thomas Gollop)
answered Thomas.

''`Other times, other manners,' as the saying is.

Have no fear.

The church is very safe with me and Eliza for watch-dogs.

Well, so much for my father.

There was only us two, and we never married--too busy for that.

And we've done no little for Shaugh Prior, as will be better told you in good time by other mouths than ours.''

He (father) stopped to take breath, and Miss Masterman spoke.

``My brother will tell you that with regard to parish clerks the times are altering too,'' (she)
she (Masterman) said.

``And don't I know it?'' (he)

he (brother) answered.

``Why, good powers, you can't get a clerk for love or money nowadays!

They'm regular dying out.

`He (brother)'ll be thankful he (brother)'ve got one of the good old sort,' I said to my sister.

`For he (brother)'d have had to look beyond Dartymoor for such another as me.'

And so he (brother) would.'' (unknown)

``That's true,'' (Gollop/Eliza/Eliza Gollop)
declared Miss Gollop.

``I mean that the congregation takes the place of the clerk in most modern services,'' (Miss Masterman/Masterman)
continued Miss Masterman.

``In point of fact, we shall not want exactly what you understand by a `clerk.'

`Other times, other manners,' as you very wisely remarked just now.'' (Mr. Gollop/Gollop)

Mr. Gollop stared.

``Not want a clerk!'' (he)

he (Gollop) said.

``Woman alive, you must be daft!'' (unknown)

``I believe not,'' (Miss Masterman/Masterman)
answered Miss Masterman.

``However, what my brother has got to say regarding his (brother) intentions can come later.

For the present he (brother) will hear you.'' (unknown)

``If you don't want a clerk, I've done,'' (Mr. Gollop/Gollop)
answered Mr. Gollop blankly.

``But I'll make bold to think you can't ezacally mean that.

Us'll leave it, and I'll tell my tale about the people.

The Lillicraps be a harmless folk, and humble and fertile as coneys.

You'll have no trouble along with them.

The Baskervilles be valuable and powerful; and Mr. Humphrey and his (Humphrey) son is Church, and Mr. Vivian and his (Humphrey) family is Church also, and his (Humphrey) darters sing in the choir.'' (unknown)

``We shall manage without women in the choir,'' (Miss Masterman/Masterman)
said Miss Masterman.

``You may think so, but I doubt it,'' (Gollop/Eliza/Eliza Gollop)
answered Eliza Gollop almost fiercely.

``You'll have to manage without anybody in the church also, if you be for up-turning the whole order of divine service!'' (She)

She (Gollop) was excited, and her (Gollop) large bosom heaved.

``Not up-turning--not up-turning,'' (the clergyman)
declared the clergyman.

``Call it reorganisation.

Frankly, I propose a surpliced choir.

I have the bishop's permission; he (bishop) wishes it.

Now, go on.'' (unknown)

``Then the Lord help you,'' (Thomas/Thomas Gollop)
said Thomas.

``We'd better be going, Eliza.

We've heard almost enough for one evening.'' (unknown)

``Be reasonable,'' (Miss Masterman/Masterman)
urged Miss Masterman with admirable self-command.

``We are here to do our duty.

We hope and expect to be helped by all sensible people--not hindered.

Let Mr. Gollop tell us what he (Gollop) came to tell us.'' (unknown)

``Well--as to reason--I ask no more, but where is it?'' (Thomas/Thomas Gollop)

murmured Thomas.

'''Twas the Baskervilles,'' he (Thomas) continued, wiping his (Thomas) forehead.

``The other of 'em--Nathan--be unfortunately a chapel member; and if you be going to play these here May games in the House of the Lord, I'm very much afeared he (Lord)'ll draw a good few after him (Lord).

They won't stand it--mark me.'' (unknown)

``Where do the people at Undershaugh worship?

I did not see Mrs. Lintern and her (Lintern) family last Sunday.'' (unknown)

``They'm all chapel too.'' (Mr. Masterman/Masterman)

Mr. Masterman nodded.

``Thank you for these various facts.

Is there anything more?'' (unknown)

``I've only just begun.

But I comed with warnings chiefly.

There be six Radicals in this parish, and only six.'' (unknown)

``Though the Lord knows how many there will be when they hear about the choir,'' (Gollop/Eliza/Eliza Gollop)
said Eliza Gollop.

``I'm an old-fashioned Liberal myself,'' (the vicar)
declared the vicar.

``But I hope your Radicals are sound churchmen, whatever else they may be.'' (unknown)

``Humphrey Baskerville is--and so's his (Baskerville) son.'' (unknown)

``Is that young Mark Baskerville?'' (unknown)

``Yes--tenor bell among the ringers.

A very uneven-minded man.

He (man)'s a wonderful ringer and wrapped up in tenor bell, as if 'twas a heathen idol.

In fact, he (man)'m not the good Christian he (man) might be, and he (man)'ll ring oftener than he (man)'ll pray.

Then Saul Luscombe to Trowlesworthy Warren--farmer and rabbit-catcher--be a very hard nut, and so's his (Warren) man, Jack Head.

You won't get either of them inside the church.

They say in their wicked way they ain't got no need for sleeping after breakfast of a Sunday--atheists, in fact.

The other labouring man from Trowlesworthy is a good Christian, however.

He (Christian) can read, but 'tis doubtful whether he (Christian) can write.'' (unknown)

``You'll have to go to keep your appointment, Dennis,'' (sister)
remarked his (Dennis) sister.

``Plenty of time.

Is there anything more that's particularly important, Gollop?'' (unknown)

``Lots more.

Still, if I'm to be shouted down every minute-- I comed to encourage and fortify you.

I comed to tell you to have no fear, because me and sister was on your side, and always ready to fight to the death for righteousness.

But you've took the wind out of our sails, in a manner of speaking.

If you ban't going to walk in the old paths, I'm terrible afraid you'll find us against you.'' (unknown)

``This is impertinence,'' (Miss Masterman/Masterman)
said Miss Masterman.

``Not at all,'' (the clerk)
answered the clerk's sister.

``It's sense.

'Tis a free country, and if you'm going to set a lot of God-fearing, right-minded, sensible people by the ears, the sin be on your shoulders.

You'd best to come home, Thomas.'' (Mr. Masterman/Masterman)

Mr. Masterman looked helplessly at his (Masterman) watch.

``We shall soon arrive at--at--a modus vivendi ,'' (he)
he (Masterman) said.
