'Tis very coarse, and the gentlefolks wouldn't like it.'' (he)

``Nonsense, Tom,'' (the vicar)
answered the vicar,
``it's all in keeping with the play.

There's no harm in it at all.'' (the vicar)

``Evil be to them as evil think,'' (Jack/Jack Head)
said Jack Head.

``Now comes the song, reverend Masterman, and I was going to propose that the Bear, though he (Masterman)'s dead as a nit, rises up on his (Masterman) front paws and sings with the rest, then drops down again--eh, souls?'' (unknown)

``They'll die of laughing if you do that, Jack,'' (Vivian/Vivian Baskerville/Mr. Vivian Baskerville)
declared Vivian.

``I vote for it.'' (Dennis/Masterman/Dennis Masterman)

But Dennis firmly refused permission and addressed his (Dennis) chorus.

``Now, girls, the song--everybody joins.

The other songs are not written yet, so we need not bother about them till next time.'' (The girls)

The girls, glad of something to do, sang vigorously, and the song went well.

Then the Turkish Knight was duly slain, restored and slain again.

``We can't finish to-night,'' (Dennis/Masterman/Dennis Masterman)
declared Dennis, looking at his (Dennis) watch,
``so I'm sorry to have troubled you to come, Mrs. Hacker, and you, Voysey.'' (Dennis/Masterman/Dennis Masterman)

``They haven't wasted their time, however, because Head and I have showed them what acting means,'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)
said Nathan.

``And when you do come on, Susan Hacker, you've got to quarrel and pull my beard, remember; then we make it up afterwards.'' (unknown)

``We'll finish for to-night with the Giant,'' (Dennis/Masterman/Dennis Masterman)
decreed Dennis.

``Now speak your long speech, St. George, and then Mr. Baskerville can do the Giant.'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

Ned, who declared that he (Ned) had as yet learned no more, read his (Ned) next speech, and Vivian began behind the scenes--

``Fee--fi--fo--fum!

I smell the blood of an Englishman.

Let him (Englishman) be living, or let him (Englishman) be dead, I'll grind his (Englishman) bones to make my bread.'' (Vivian/Vivian Baskerville/Mr. Vivian Baskerville)

``You ought to throw a bit more roughness in your voice, farmer,'' (Mr. Gollop/Gollop)
suggested Mr. Gollop.

``If you could bring it up from the innards, `twould sound more awful, wouldn't it, reverend Masterman?'' (unknown)

``And when you come on, farmer, you might pass me by where I lie dead,'' (Jack/Jack Head)
said Jack,
``and I'll up and give you a nip in the calf of the leg, and you'll jump round, and the people will roar again.'' (Jack/Jack Head)

``No,'' (the vicar)
declared the vicar.

``No more of you, Head, till the end.

Then you come to life and dance with the French Eagle--that's Voysey.

But you mustn't act any more till then.'' (unknown)

``A pity,'' (Jack/Jack Head)
answered Jack.

``I was full of contrivances; however, if you say so--'' (Mr. Voysey)
``Be I to dance?'' (Mr. Voysey)

asked Mr. Voysey.

``This is the first I've heard tell o' that.

How can I dance, and the rheumatism eating into my knees for the last twenty year?'' (unknown)

``I'll dance,'' (unknown)
said Head.

``You can just turn round and round slowly.'' (unknown)

``Now, Mr.

Baskerville!'' (Vivian/Vivian Baskerville/Mr. Vivian Baskerville)

Vivian strode on to the stage.

``Make your voice big, my dear,'' (Gollop/Eliza/Eliza Gollop)
pleaded Gollop.

``Here come I, the Giant; bold Turpin is my name, And all the nations round do tremble at my fame, Where'er I go, they tremble at my sight: No lord or champion long with me will dare to fight.'' (unknown)

``People will cheer you like thunder, Vivian,'' (brother)
said his (Vivian) brother,
``because they know that the nations really did tremble at your fame when you was champion wrestler of the west.'' (brother)

``But you mustn't stand like that, farmer,'' (Jack/Jack Head)
said Jack Head.

``You'm too spraddlesome.

For the Lord's sake, man, try and keep your feet in the same parish!'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

Mr. Baskerville bellowed with laughter and slapped his (Baskerville) immense thigh.

``Dammy!

that's funnier than anything in the play,'' (he)

he (Baskerville) said.

''`Keep my feet in the same parish!'

Was ever a better joke heard?''

``Now, St. George, kill the Giant,'' (Dennis/Masterman/Dennis Masterman)
commanded Dennis.

``The Giant will have a club, and he (Dennis)'ll try to smash you; then you run him (Dennis) through the body.'' (unknown)

``Take care you don't hit Ned in real earnest, however, else you'd settle him (Ned) and spoil the play,'' (Mr. Voysey)
said Mr. Voysey.

''`Twould be a terrible tantarra for certain if the Giant went and whipped St.

George.''

''`Twouldn't be the first time, however,'' said Mr. Baskerville.

``Would it, Ned?'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)

Nathan and Ned's sisters appreciated this family joke.

Then Mr. Gollop advanced a sentimental objection.

``I may be wrong,'' (he)
he (Gollop) admitted,
``but I can't help thinking it might be a bit ondecent for Ned Baskerville here to kill his (Baskerville) father, even in play.

You see, though everybody will know 'tis Ned and his (Ned) parent, and that they'm only pretending, yet it might shock a serious-minded person here and there to see the son kill the father.

I don't say I mind, as 'tis all make-believe and the frolic of a night; but--well, there 'tis.'' (he)

``You'm a silly old grandmother, and never no King of Egypt was such a fool afore,'' (Jack/Jack Head)
said Jack.

``Pay no heed to him (Jack), reverend Masterman.'' (Gollop/Eliza/Eliza Gollop)

Gollop snarled at Head, and they began to wrangle fiercely.

Then Dennis closed the rehearsal.

``That'll do for the present,'' (he)
he (Dennis) announced.

``We've made a splendid start, and the thing to remember is that we meet here again this day week, at seven o'clock.

And mind you know your part, Ned.

Another of the songs will be ready by then; and the new harmonium will have come that my sister is going to play.

And do look about, all of you, to find somebody who will take the Doctor.'' (unknown)

``We shall have the nation's eyes on us--not for the first time,'' (Mr. Gollop/Gollop)
declared Mr. Gollop as he (Gollop) tied a white wool muffler round his (Gollop) throat;
``and I'm sure I hope one and all will do the best that's in 'em.'' (he)

The actors departed; the oil lamps were extinguished, and the vicar and his (vicar) sister returned home.

She (sister) said little by the way, and her (sister) severe silence made him (vicar) rather nervous.

``Well,'' (he)
he (vicar) broke out at length,
``jolly good, I think, for a first attempt--eh, Alice?'' (he)

``I'm glad you were satisfied, dear.

Everything depends upon us--that seems quite clear, at any rate.

They'll all get terribly self-conscious and silly, I'm afraid, long before the time comes.

However, we must hope for the best.

But I shouldn't be in a hurry to ask anybody who really matters.'' (Hawk House/House)

CHAPTER XII In a triangle the wild land of the Rut sloped down from Hawk House to the valley beneath, and its solitary time of splendour belonged to Spring, when the great furzes were blooming and the white thorns filled the valley with light.

Hither came Mark to keep tryst with Cora beside the stream.

He (Mark) walked not loverly but languid, for his (Mark) mind was in trouble, and his (Mark) gait reflected it.

To water's brink he (Mark) came, sat on a familiar stump above Torry Brook, and watched sunshine play over the ripples and a dance of flies upon the sunshine.

Looked at in a mass, the insects seemed no more than a glimmering, like a heat haze, over the water and against the background of the woods; but noted closer the plan and pattern of these myriads showed method: the little storm of flies gyrated in a circle, and while the whole cluster swept this way and that with the proper motion of the mass, yet each individual, like planets round the sun, revolved about a definite but shifting centre.

The insects whirled round and round, rose and sank again, each atom describing repeated circles; and though the united motion of this company suspended here in air appeared inconceivably rapid and dazzling, yet the progress of each single gnat was not fast.

Mark observed this little galaxy of glittering lives, and, knowing some natural history, he (Mark) considered intelligently the thing he (Mark) saw.

For a moment it distracted him (Mark).

A warm noon had wakened innumerable brief existences that a cold night would still again.

All this immense energy must soon cease and the ephemeral atoms perish at the chill touch of evening; but to Nature it mattered neither more nor less if a dance of nebul√¶ or a dance of gnats should make an end that night.

Countless successions of both were a part of her (Mark) work.

From awful marriages of ancient suns new suns would certainly be born; and out of this midge dance here above the water, potential dances for another day were ensured, before the little system sank to rest, the aureole of living light became extinguished.

He (Mark) turned from the whirl and wail of the gnats to his (Mark) own thoughts, and found them also revolving restlessly.

But their sun and centre was Cora.

He (Cora) had asked her (Mark) to meet him (Cora) here, in a favourite and secret place, that he (Cora) might speak harsh things to her (Mark).

There was no love-making toward just now.

She (Mark) had angered him (Cora) once and again.

He (Cora) considered his (Cora) grievances, strove to palliate them, and see all with due allowance; but his (Cora) habit of mind, if vague, was not unjust.

He (Cora) loved her (Mark) passionately, but that she (Mark) should put deliberate indignities upon him (Cora) argued a faulty reciprocity of love.

Time had revealed that Cora did not care for Mark as well as he (Cora) cared for her (Mark); and that would not have mattered--he (Cora) held it reasonable.

But he (Cora) desired a larger measure of affection and respect than he (Cora) had received.

Then to his (Cora) quick senses even the existing affection diminished, and respect appeared to die.

These dire shadows had risen out of the rehearsals for the play.

Cora's attitude towards other young men first astonished Mark and then annoyed him (Mark).

He (Mark) kept his (Mark) annoyance to himself, however, for fear of being laughed at.

Then, thanks to his (Mark) cousin, Ned Baskerville, and the young farmer, Timothy Waite, he (Waite) was laughed at, for Cora found these youths better company than Mark himself, and Jack Head and others did not hesitate to rally him (Head) about his (Head) indifferent lady.

``She (lady)'s more gracious with either of them than with me,'' (he)
he (Head) reflected.

``Why, actually, when I offered as usual to walk home with her (lady) last week, she (lady) said yonder man had promised to do so and she (lady) need not trouble me!'' (he)

As he (man) spoke he (man) lifted his (man) eyes where a farm showed on the hills westerly through the trees.

Coldstone was a prosperous place, and the freehold of a prosperous man, young Waite, the Turkish Knight of the play.

He (Knight) had seen Cora home according to her (lady) wish, and Mark had kept his (Mark) temper and afterwards made the present appointment by letter.

Now Cora came to him (Cora), late from another interview--but concerning it she (lady) said nothing.

On her (lady) way from Undershaugh it happened that she (lady) had fallen in with Mark's father.

The old man rode his (man) pony, and Cora was passing him (Cora) hastily when he (Cora) stopped and called her (lady) to him (Cora).

They had not met since the occasion of the girl's first and last visit to Hawk House.

``Come hither,'' (he)
he (House) said.

``I've fretted you, it seems, and set you against me.

I'm sorry for that.

You should be made of stouter stuff.

Shake hands with me, Cora, please.'' (He)

He (Cora) held out his (Cora) hand and she (girl) took it silently.

``I'll turn and go a bit of your road.

If you intend to marry my son, you must make shift to be my daughter, you see.

What was it made you so cross that you ran away?

But I know--I spoke against your clothes.'' (unknown)

``You spoke against everything.

I felt in every drop of blood in my body that you didn't like me.

That's why I had to run.'' (He)

He (son) was silent a moment.

Suddenly he (son) pointed to one faint gold torch above their heads, where a single bough of an elm was autumn-painted, and began to glow on the bosom of a tree still green.

It stood out shining against the deep summer darkness of the foliage.

``What d'you make of that?'' (he)

he (son) asked.

She (me) looked up.

'''Tis winter coming again, I suppose.''

``Yes--winter for us, death for the leaves.

I'm like that--I'm frost-bitten here and there--in places.

'Twas a frosty day with me when you came to dinner.

I'm sorry I hurt you.

But you must be sensible.

It's a lot harder to be a good wife than a popular maiden.

My son Mark will need a strong-minded woman, not a silly one.

The question is, are you going to rise to it?

However, we'll leave that.

How did you know in every drop of your blood, as you say, that you'd failed to please me?'' (unknown)

``I knew it by--oh, by everything.

By your eyes and by the tone of your voice.

You said you wanted to talk to me.'' (unknown)

``Well, I did.'' (unknown)

``You never asked me nothing.'' (unknown)

``There was no need, you told me everything.'' (unknown)

``I said nought, I'm sure.'' (unknown)

``You said all I wanted to hear and told me a lot more than I wanted, or expected, to hear for that matter.'' (unknown)

``I'm sure I don't understand you, Mr.

Baskerville.'' (unknown)

``No need--no need.

That's only to say you're like the rest.

They wonder how 'tis they don't understand me--fools that they are!--and yet how many understand themselves?

I'll tell you this: you're not the right wife for Mark.'' (unknown)

``Then I won't marry him (Mark).

There's quite as good as him (Mark), and better, for that matter.'' (unknown)

``Plenty.

Take young Waite from Coldstone Farm, for instance.

A strong man he (man) is.

My son Mark is a weak man--a gentle character he (Mark) hath.

'Tis the strong men--they that want things--that alter the face of the world, and make history, and help the breed--not such as Mark.

He (Mark)'d spoil you and bring out all the very worst of you.

Such a man as Waite would do different.

He (Waite)'d not stand your airs and graces, and little silly whims and fancies.

He (Waite)'d break you in; he (Waite)'d tame you; and you'd look back afterwards and thank God you fell to a strong man and not a weak one.'' (unknown)

``Women marry for love, not for taming,'' (she)
she (Waite) said.

``Some, perhaps, but not you.

You ban't built to love, if you want to know the whole truth,'' (he)

he (man) answered calmly.

``You belong to a sort of woman who takes all and gives nought.

I wish I could ope your eyes to yourself, but I suppose that's beyond human power.

But this I'll say: I wish you nothing but good; and the best good of all for such a one as you is to get a glimpse of yourself through a sensible and not unkindly pair of eyes.

If you are going to marry Mark, and want to be a happy woman and wish him (Mark) to be a happy man, you must think of a lot of things beside your wedding frock.'' (unknown)

``For two pins I wouldn't marry him (Mark) at all after this,'' (she)
she (woman) said.

``You'd break any girl's heart, speaking so straight and coarse to her (woman).

I ban't accustomed to be talked to so cruel, and I won't stand it.'' (unknown)

``I do beg you to think again,'' (he)
he (Mark) said, stopping his (Mark) pony.

``I'm only telling you what I've often told myself.

I'm always open to hear sense from any man, save now and again when I find myself in a black mood and won't hear anything.

But you--a green girl as haven't seen one glimpse of the grey side yet--why, 'tis frank foolishness to refuse good advice from an old man.'' (unknown)

``You don't want to give me good advice,'' (she)
she (girl) answered, and her (girl) face was red and her (girl) voice high;
``you only want to make me think small things of myself, and despise myself, and to choke me off Mark.'' (she)

``To choke you off Mark might be the best advice anybody could give you, for that matter, my dear; and as to your thinking small things of yourself--no such luck I see.

You'll go on thinking a lot of your little, empty self till you stop thinking for good and all.

Life ban't going to teach you anything worth knowing, because you've stuffed up your ears with self-conceit and vanity.

So go your way; but if you get a grain of sense come back to me, and I shall be very glad to hear about it.'' (He)

He (you) left her (you) standing still in a mighty temper.

She (you) felt inclined to fling a stone after him (you).

And yet she (you) rejoiced at the bottom of her (you) heart, because this scene made her (you) future actions easier.

Only one thing still held her (you) to Mark Baskerville, and that was his (Baskerville) money.

The sickly ghost of regard for him (Baskerville), which she (you) was pleased to call love, existed merely as the answer to her (you) own appeal to her (you) conscience.

She (you) had never loved him (Baskerville), but when the opportunity came, she (you) could not refuse his (Baskerville) worldly wealth and the future of successful comfort it promised.

Now, however, were appearing others who attracted her (you) far more.

Two men had entered into her (you) life since the rehearsals, and both pleased her (you) better than Mark.

One she (you) liked for his (Mark) person and for his (Mark) charms of manner and of speech; the other for his (Mark) masterful character and large prosperity.

One was better looking than Mark, and knew far better how to worship a woman; the other was perhaps as rich as Mark would be, and he (Mark) appealed to her (woman) much more by virtue of his (Mark) masculinity and vigour.

Mr. Baskerville had actually mentioned this individual during the recent conversation; and it was of him (Baskerville), too, that Mark considered where he (Mark) sat and waited for Cora by the stream.

But though she (woman) felt Timothy Waite's value, yet a thing even stronger drew her (woman) to the other man.

Ned Baskerville was the handsomest, gallantest, most fascinating creature that Cora had ever known.

Chance threw them little together until the rehearsals, but since then they had met often, and advanced far along a road of mutual admiration.

Like clove to like, and the emptiness of each heart struck a kindred echo from the other; but neither appreciated the hollowness of the sound.

Under these circumstances Humphrey Baskerville's strictures, though exceedingly painful to her (woman) self-love, were not unwelcome, for they made the thing that she (woman) designed to do reasonable and proper.

It would be simple to quote his (Baskerville) father to her (woman) betrothed when she (woman) threw him (Baskerville) over.

In this temper Cora now appeared to Mark.

Had he (Mark) been aware of it he (Mark) might have hesitated before adding further fuel to the flames.

But he (Mark) began in a friendly fashion, rose and kissed her (woman).

``You're late, Cora.

Look here.

Sit down and get cool and watch these flies.

The merry dancers, they are called, and well they may be.

'Tis a regular old country measure they seem to tread in the air--figure in and cross over and all--just like you do when you go through the old dance in the play.'' (she)

But she (woman) was in no mood of softness.

``A tidy lot of dancing I'll get when I'm married to you!

You know you hate it, and hate everything else with any joy and happiness to it.

You're only your father over again, when all's said, and God defend me from him (God)!

I can't stand no more of him (God), and I won't.'' (unknown)

``You've met him (God)?'' (Mark/Mark Baskerville)

said Mark.

``I was afraid you might.

I'm sorry for that.'' (unknown)

``Not so sorry as I am.

If I was dirt by the road he (Mark) couldn't have treated me worse.

And I'm not going to suffer it--never once more--not if he (Mark) was ten times your father!'' (unknown)

``What did he (Mark) say?'' (unknown)

``What didn't he (Mark) say?

Not a kind word, anyway.

And 'tis vain your sticking up for him (Mark), because he (Mark) don't think any better of you than he (Mark) do of me seemingly.

'Twas to that man he (man) pointed.'' (She)

She (father) raised her (father) arm towards the farm through the trees.

``He (man) thinks a lot more of Timothy Waite than he (Waite) does of you, I can tell you.'' (unknown)

``I'll talk to father.

This can't go on.'' (unknown)

``No, it can't go on.

Life's too short for this sort of thing.

I won't be bullied by anybody.

People seem to forget who I am.'' (unknown)

``You mustn't talk so, Cora.

I'm terrible sorry about it; but father's father, and he (father)'ll go his (father) own rough way, and you ought to know what way that is by now.

Don't take it to heart--he (father) means well.'' (unknown)

''`Heart!'

I've got no heart according to him (father)--no heart, no sense, no nothing.

Just a dummy to show off pretty clothes.''

``He (father) never said that!'' (unknown)

``Yes, he (father) did; and worse, and I'm tired of it.

You're not the only man in the world.'' (unknown)

``Nothing is gained by my quarrelling with father.'' (unknown)

``I suppose not; but I've got my self-respect, and I can't marry the son of a man that despises me openly like he (man) does.

I won't be bullied by him (man), I promise you--a cruel hunks he (man) is, and would gore me to pieces if he (man) dared!

No better than a mad bull, I call him (man).'' (father Cora)

'''Tis no good your blackguarding my father, Cora,'' said Mark.

``Perhaps not; and 'tis no good his (Mark) blackguarding me.

Very different to your Uncle Vivian, I'm sure.

Always a kind word and a pat on the cheek he (Vivian)'ve got; and so have your Uncle Nathan.'' (unknown)

``Uncle Vivian can be hard enough too--as my cousin Rupert that means to marry Milly Luscombe will tell you.

In fact, Rupert's going away because he (Rupert) won't stand his (Rupert) father.'' (unknown)

``Why don't you go away then?

If you were worth your salt, you'd turn your back on any man living who has treated me so badly as your father has.'' (unknown)

``We're in for a row, it seems,'' (Mark/Mark Baskerville)
answered Mark,
``and I'd better begin and get a painful job over.

When you've heard me, I'll hear you.

In the matter of my father I'll do what a son can do--that I promise you; but there's something on my side too.'' (Mark/Mark Baskerville)

``Say it out then--the sooner the better.'' (She)

She (it) found herself heartily hating Mark and was anxious to break with him (Mark) while angry; because anger would make an unpleasant task more easy.

``In a word, it's Ned Baskerville and that man over there--Waite.

These rehearsals of the play--you know very well how you carry on, Cora; and you know very well 'tisn't right or seemly.

You've promised to marry me, and you are my life and soul; but I can't share you with no other man.

You can't flirt with Ned while you're engaged to me; you can't ask Waite to see you home of a night while you're engaged to me.

You don't know what you're doing.'' (unknown)

``Why ban't you more dashing then?'' (she)

she (you) asked.

``You slink about so mean and humble.

Why don't you take a part in the play, and do as other men, and talk louder and look people in the face, as if you wasn't feared to death of 'em?

If you grumble, then I'll grumble too.

You haven't got enough pluck for me.

Ned's different, and so's t`other man, for that matter.

I see how much they admire me; I know how they would go through fire and water for me.'' (unknown)

``Not they!

Master Ned--why--he (Ned) can roll his (Ned) eyes and roll his (Ned) voice; but--there--go on!

Finish what you've got to say.'' (unknown)

``I've only got to say that there's a deal about Ned you might very well copy in my opinion.

He (Ned)'s a man, anyway, and a handsome man for that matter.

And if you're going to fall out with your father, then you'll lose your money, and--'' (unknown)

``I'm not going to fall out with him (father).

You needn't fear that.'' (unknown)

``Then more shame to you, for keeping friendly with a man that hates me.

Call that love!

Ned--'' (he)

``Have done about Ned!'' (he)

he (Ned) cried out.

``Ned's a lazy, caddling good-for-nought--the laughing-stock of every decent man and sane woman in Shaugh.

A wastrel--worthless.

You think he (man)'s fond of you, I suppose?'' (unknown)

``I know he (man) is.

And you know it.'' (unknown)

``Yes, just as fond of you as he (man) is of every other girl that will let him (man) be.

Anything that wears a petticoat can get to his (man) empty heart--poor fool.

Love!

What does he (man) know of that--a great, bleating baby!

His (man) love isn't worth the wind he (man) takes to utter it; and you'll very soon find that out--like other girls have--if you listen to him (man).'' (unknown)

``He (man) knows what pleases a woman, anyway.'' (unknown)

``Cora!

Cora!

What are you saying?

D'you want to drive me mad?'' (He)

He (Cora) started up and stared at her (woman).

''`Twouldn't be driving you far.

Better sit down again and listen to me now.''

``I'll listen to nothing.

I'm choking--I'm stifling!

To think that you--oh, Cora--good God Almighty--and for such a man as that--'' (He)

He (man) rushed away frantically and she (woman) saw him (man) no more.

He (man) had not given her (woman) time to strike the definite blow.

But she (woman) supposed that it was as good as struck.

After such a departure and such words, they could not meet again even as friends.

The engagement was definitely at an end in her (woman) mind, for by no stretch of imagination might this be described as a lovers' quarrel.

All was over; she (woman) rejoiced at her (woman) renewal of liberty and resolved not to see Mark any more, no matter how much he (Mark) desired it.

She (woman) flung away the luncheon that she (woman) had brought and set off for home, trusting that she (woman) might meet Humphrey Baskerville upon the way.

She (woman) longed to see him (Baskerville) again now and repay him (Baskerville) for a little of the indignity that he (Baskerville) had put upon her (woman).

But she (woman) did not meet Mark's father.

On the evening of the same day a congenial spirit won slight concessions from her (woman).

Ned Baskerville arrived on some pretext concerning the play.

He (Baskerville) knew very well by this time that, in the matter of her (woman) engagement, Cora was a victim, and he (Cora) felt, as he (Cora) had often felt before in other cases, that she (woman) was the only woman on earth to make him (Cora) a happy man.

He (Cora) despised Mark and experienced little compunction with respect to him (Cora).

Upon this night Mrs. Lintern was out, and Cora made no objection to putting on her (Lintern) hat and going to the high ground above Shaugh Prior to look at the moon.

''`Twon't take above ten minutes, and then I'll see you back,'' said Ned.

They went together, and he (Ned) flattered her (Lintern) and paid her (Lintern) many compliments and humbled himself before her (Lintern).

She (Lintern) purred and was pleased.

They moved along together and he (Ned) told her (Lintern) that she (Lintern) was like the princess in the play.

``You say nought, but, my God, you look every inch a princess!

If 'twas real life, I'd slay fifty giants and a hundred bears for you, Cora.'' (unknown)

``Don't you begin that silliness.

I'm sure you don't mean a word of it, Ned.'' (unknown)

``If you could see my heart, Cora, you'd see only one name there--I swear it.'' (unknown)

``What about t`other names--all rubbed out, I suppose?'' (unknown)

``They never were there.

All the other girls were ghosts beside you.

Not one of them--'' (unknown)

Suddenly near at hand the church bells began to throb and tremble upon the peace of moonlit night.

``Mark's out of the way then,'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)
said Ned.

``Not that I'm afraid of him (Ned), or any other man.

You're too good for Mark, Cora--a million times too good for him (Cora).

I'm bound to tell you so.'' (unknown)

``I'm sick of him (Cora) and his (Cora) bell-ringing,'' (she)
she (Ned) said violently.

``Hullo!

That's strong,'' (he)

he (Cora) exclaimed.

``So would any maiden be.

He (Cora) puts tenor bell afore me.

'Tis more to him (Cora) than ever I was.

In a word, I've done with the man!'' (unknown)

``You splendid, plucky creature!

'Twas bound to come.

Such a spirit as yours never could have brooked a worm like him (man)!

You're free then?'' (unknown)

``Yes, I am.'' (Mark/Mark Baskerville)

Elsewhere in the belfry Mark rang himself into better humour.

The labour physicked his (Mark) grief and soothed his (Mark) soul.

He (Mark) told himself that all the fault was his (Mark), and when the chimes were still, he (Mark) put on his (Mark) coat and went to Undershaugh to beg forgiveness.

Phyllis met him (Mark).

``Cora's out walking,'' (she)
she (Phyllis) said.

``Out walking!

Who with?'' (he)

he (Cora) asked.

But Phyllis was nothing if not cautious.

She (Phyllis) had more heart, but not more conscience than her (Phyllis) sister.

``I don't know--alone, I think,'' (she)
she (Phyllis) answered.

CHAPTER XIII A day of storm buffeted the Moor.

Fitful streaks of light roamed through a wild and silver welter of low cloud; and now they rested on a pool or river, and the water flashed; and now they fired the crests of the high lands or made the ruddy brake-fern flame.

Behind Shaugh Moor was storm-cloud, and beneath it, oozing out into the valleys, extended the sullen green of water-logged fields hemmed in with autumnal hedges.

Hither came Mark Baskerville on his (Baskerville) way to Shaugh, and then a man stopped him (man) and changed his (man) plan.

For some time he (man) had neither seen nor heard from Cora, and unable longer to live with this cloud between them, Mark was now on his (Mark) way to visit her (Moor).

Consideration had convinced him (Mark) that he (Mark) was much in fault, and that she (Moor) did well to keep aloof until he (Mark) came penitent back again; but he (Mark) had already striven more than once to do so, and she (Moor) had refused to see him (Mark).

He (Mark) told himself that it was natural she (Moor) should feel angered at the past, and natural that she (Moor) should be in no haste to make up so serious a quarrel.

But the catastrophe had now shrunk somewhat in his (Mark) estimation, and he (Mark) doubted not that Cora, during the passage of many days, also began to see it in its proper perspective.

He (Cora) did not wholly regret their difference, and certain words that she (Moor) had spoken still stung painfully when he (Cora) considered them; but the dominant hunger in his (Cora) mind was to get back to her (Moor), kiss her (Moor) lips and hear her (Moor) voice again.

He (Cora) would be very circumspect henceforth, and doubtless so would she (Moor).

He (Cora) felt sure that Cora regretted their difference now, and that the time was over-ripe for reconciliation.

The next rehearsal would take place upon the following day, and Mark felt that friendly relations must be re-established before that event.

He (Mark) was on his (Mark) road to see Cora and take no further denial, when her (Moor) brother met him (brother) and stopped him (brother).

``Lucky I ran against you,'' (Heathman/Heathman Lintern)
said Heathman;
``I've got a letter for you from my sister, and meant to leave it on my way out over to Lee Moor.

Coarse weather coming by the look of it.'' (Heathman/Heathman Lintern)

``Thank you,'' (Mark/Mark Baskerville)
answered Mark.

``You've saved me a journey then.

I was bound for Undershaugh.'' (Heathman/Heathman Lintern)

Heathman, who knew that he (Mark) bore evil news, departed quickly, while the other, with true instinct of sybarite, held the precious letter a moment before opening it.

It happened that Cora seldom wrote to him (Cora), for they met very often; but now, having a difficult thing to say, she (Heathman) sought this medium, and Mark, knowing not the truth, was glad.

``Like me--couldn't keep it up no more,'' (he)
he (Mark) thought.

``I almost wish she (Heathman)'d let me say I was sorry first; but she (Heathman) might have heard me say so a week ago, if she (Heathman)'d liked.

Thank Heaven we shall be happy again before dark.

I'll promise everything in the world she (Heathman) wants to-night--even to the ring with the blue stone she (Heathman) hungered after at Plymouth.'' (He)

He (Mark) looked round, then the wind hustled him (Mark) and the rain broke in a tattered veil along the edge of the hill.

``I'll get up to Hawk Tor, and lie snug there, and read her (Heathman) letter in the lew place I filled with fern for her (Heathman),'' (he)
he (Hawk) thought.

There was a natural cavern facing west upon this height, and here, in a nook sacred to Cora, he (Cora) sat presently and lighted his (Cora) pipe and so came to the pleasant task.

He (Cora) determined that having read her (Heathman) plea for forgiveness, it would be impossible to wait until nightfall without seeing her (Heathman).

``I'll go down and take dinner with them,'' (he)
he (Cora) decided: then he (Cora) read the letter:-- ``DEAR MARK, ``After what happened a little while ago you cannot be surprised if I say I will not marry you.

There is nothing to be said about it except that I have quite made up my mind.

I have thought about it ever since, and not done nothing in a hurry.

We would not suit one another, and the older we grew, the worse we should quarrel.

So it will be better to part before any harm is done.

You will easily find a quieter sort of girl, without so much spirit as me.

And she (girl) will suit you better than what I do.

I have told my mother that I am not going to marry you.

And Mr. Nathan Baskerville, your own uncle, though he (Baskerville) is very sorry indeed about it, is our family friend and adviser, and he (adviser) says it is better we understand and part at once.

I hope you won't make any fuss, as nothing will change me .

And you will have the pleasure of knowing your father will be thankful.

No doubt you will soon find a better-looking and nicer girl than me, and somebody that your father won't treat the same as he (father) treated ``Yours truly,

``CORA LINTERN.'' (he)

Through the man's stunned grief and above the chaos of his (father) thoughts, one paramount and irrevocable conviction reigned.

Cora meant what she (girl) wrote, and nothing that he (Cora) had power to say or to do would win her (girl) back again.

She (girl) would never change; she (girl) had seen him (Cora) in anger and the sight had determined her (girl); she (girl) had met his (Cora) father and had felt that such antagonism must ruin her (girl) life.

He (Cora) possessed imagination and was able swiftly to feel what life must mean without her (girl).

He (Cora) believed that his (Cora) days would be impossible henceforth.

He (Cora) read the letter again and marked how she (girl) began with restraint and gradually wrote herself into anger.

She (girl) smarted when she (girl) reflected on his (Cora) father; and he (Cora) soon convinced himself that it was his (Cora) father who had driven her (girl) to these conclusions.

He (Cora) told himself that he (Cora) did not blame her (girl).

The pipe in his (Cora) mouth had been given to him (Cora) by Cora.

He (Cora) emptied it now, put it into its case, rose up and went home.

He (Cora) planned the things to say to his (Cora) father and determined to show him (Cora) the letter.

Mark desired to make his (Mark) father suffer, and did not doubt but that he (Mark) would suffer when this catastrophe came to his (Mark) ears.

Then his (Mark) father appeared before him (father), far off, driven by the wind; and Mark, out of his (Mark) tortured mind, marvelled to think that a thing so small as this dim spot, hastening like a dead leaf along, should have been powerful enough, and cruel enough, deliberately to ruin his (Mark) life.

For he (Mark) was now obsessed by the belief that his (Mark) father alone must be thanked for the misfortune.

They came together, and Humphrey shouted to be heard against the riot of the wind.

His (Humphrey) hat was pressed over his (Humphrey) ears; the tails of his (Humphrey) coat and the hair on his (Humphrey) head leapt and danced; his (Humphrey) eyes were watering.

``A brave wind!

Might blow sense into a man, if anything could.

What are you doing up here?'' (unknown)

``Read that,'' (father)
said the other, and his (man) father stopped and stared at him (man).

Despite the rough air and the wild music of heath and stone, Mark's passion was not hidden and his (Mark) face as well as his (Mark) voice proclaimed it.

``See what you have done for your only son,'' (he)
he (Mark) cried.

Humphrey held out his (Humphrey) hand for the letter, took it and turned his (Humphrey) back to the wind.

He (Humphrey) read it slowly, then returned it to Mark.

``She (Mark) means that,'' (he)
he (Mark) answered.

``This isn't the time to speak to you.

I know all that's moving in you, and I guess how hard life looks.

But I warn you: be just.

I'm used to be misread by the people and care nought; but I'd not like for you to misread me.

You think that I've done this.'' (unknown)

``I know you have--and done it with malice aforethought too.

The only thing I've ever loved in life--the only thing that ever comed into my days to make 'em worth living--and you go to work behind my back to take it away from me.

And me as good a son to you as my nature would allow--always--always.'' (unknown)

``As good a son as need be hoped for--I grant that.

But show a little more sense in this.

Use your brains, of which you've got too many for your happiness, and see the truth.

Can a father choke a girl off a man if she (girl) loves the man?

Was it ever heard that mother or father stopped son or daughter from loving?

'Tis against nature, and nought I could have said, and nought I could have done would have come between her (mother) and you--never, if she (mother)'d loved you worth a curse.

But she (mother) didn't.

She (mother) loved the promise of your money.

She (mother) loved the thought of being the grey mare and playing with a weak man's purse.

She (mother) loved to think on the future, when I was underground and her (mother) way clear.

And that hope would have held with her (mother) just as strong after knowing me, as before knowing me.

The passing trouble of me, and my straight, sour speeches, and my eyes looking through her (mother) into her (mother) dirty little heart, wouldn't have turned the girl away from you, if she (mother)'d loved you honestly.

Why, even lust of money would have been too strong to break down under that--let alone love of man.

'Tis not I but somebody else has sloked-LSB-1-RSB- her (mother) away from thee.

And the time will come when you may live to thank your God that it's happened so.

But enough of that.

I can bear your hard words, Mark; and bitter though `twill sound upon your ear, I'll tell you this: I'm thankful above measure she (mother)'s flung you over.

'Tis the greatest escape of your life, and a blessing in disguise--for more reasons than you know, or ever will.

And as for him (Mark) that's done it, nought that you can wish him (Mark) be likely to turn out much worse than what he (Mark)'ll get if he (Mark) marries that woman.'' (unknown)

-LSB-1-RSB- Sloked --enticed and tempted.

``Shouldn't I know if 'twas another man?

She (woman) was friendly and frank with all.

She (woman) hadn't a secret from me.

'Twas only my own blind jealousy made me think twice about it when she (woman) talked with other men.'' (unknown)

``But she (woman) did talk with 'em and you did think twice?

And you didn't like it?

And you quarrelled -eh?

And that was the sense in you--the sense trying to lift you above the blind instinct you'd got for her (woman).

Would you have quarrelled for nothing?

Are you that sort?

Too fond of taking affronts and offering the other cheek, you are--like I was once.

You can't blind me.

You've suffered at her (woman) hands already, and spoken, and this is her (woman) slap back at you.

No need to drag me in at all then; though I did give her (woman) raw sense for her (woman) dinner when she (woman) came to see me.

Look further on than your father for the meaning of this letter.

Look to yourself first, and if that don't throw light, look afield.'' (unknown)

``There's none--none more than another--I'll swear it.'' (unknown)

``Seek a man with money and with a face like a barber's image and not over-much sense.

That's the sort will win her (woman); and that's the sort will suit her (woman).

And now I've done.'' (people)

They walked together and said the same things over and over again, as people are prone to do in argument.

Then they separated in heat, for the father lost patience and again declared his (father) pleasure at this accident.

Whereon Mark cried out against him (Mark) for a callous and brutal spirit, and so left him (Mark), and turned blindly homeward.

He (Mark) did not know what to do or how to fight this great tribulation.

He (Mark) could not believe it.

He (Mark) came back to Hawk House at last and found himself in an angle of the dwelling, out of the wind.

Here reigned artificial silence and peace.

The great gale roared overhead; but beneath, in this nook, not a straw stirred.

He (Mark) stood and stared at his (Mark) fallen hopes and ruined plans; while from a dry spot beside the wall, there came to him (Mark) the sweet, sleepy chirruping of chickens that cuddled together under their mother's wings.

CHAPTER XIV While the desolation of Mark Baskerville came to be learnt, and some sympathised with him (Baskerville) and some held that Cora Lintern had showed a very proper spirit to refuse a man cursed with such a father, lesser trouble haunted Cadworthy Farm, for the parent of Rupert Baskerville declared himself to be suffering from a great grievance.

Vivian was an obstinate man and would not yield to his (Vivian) son's demand; but the situation rapidly reached a climax, for Rupert would not yield either.

Night was the farmer's time for long discussions with his (Rupert) wife; and there came a moment when he (Rupert) faced the present crisis with her (wife) and strove for some solution of the difficulty.

``Unray yourself and turn out the light and come to bed,'' (he)
he (Rupert) said to Mrs. Baskerville.

He (Rupert) already lay in their great four-poster, and, solid though the monster was, it creaked when Vivian's immense bulk turned upon it.

His (Vivian) wife soon joined him (Vivian) and then he (Vivian) began to talk.

He (Vivian) prided himself especially on his (Vivian) reasonableness, after the fashion of unreasonable men.

``It can't go on and it shan't,'' (he)
he (Vivian) said.

``Never was heard such a thing as a son defying his (son) father this way.

If he (son)'d only given the girl up, then I should have been the first to relax authority and tell him (son) he (son) might have her (girl) in due season if she (girl) liked to wait.

But for him (son) to cleave to her (girl) against my express order--'tis a very improper and undutiful thing--specially when you take into account what a father I've been to the man.'' (unknown)

``And he (man)'ve been a good son, too.'' (unknown)

``And why not?

I was a good son--better than ever Rupert was.

And would I have done this?

I never thought of marriage till my parents were gone.'' (unknown)

``Work was enough for you.'' (unknown)

``And so it should be for every young man.

But, nowadays, they think of nought but revels and outings and the girls.

A poor, slack-twisted generation.

My arm would make a leg for any youth I come across nowadays.'' (unknown)

``You must remember you'm a wonder, my dear.

We can't all be like you.'' (unknown)

``My own sons ought to be, anyway.

And I've a right to demand it of 'em.'' (unknown)

``Rupert works as hard as a man can work--harder a thousand times than Ned.'' (unknown)

``I won't have you name 'em together,'' (he)
he (Ned) answered.

``A man's firstborn is always a bit different to the rest.

Ned is more given to reading and brain work.'' (She)

She (Ned) laughed fearlessly and he (Ned) snorted like a bull beside her (Ned).

``What are you laughing at?'' (he)

he (Ned) said.

``At your silliness.

Such a sharp chap and so wise as you are; and yet our handsome eldest--why, he (eldest) can't do wrong!

And Lord knows he (Lord) can't do wrong in my eyes neither.

Still, when it comes to work--'' (the father)

``We'll leave Ned,'' (the father)
answered the father.

``He (Ned) can work all right, and when you've seed him (Ned) play St. George and marked his (Ned) intellects and power of speech, you'll be the first to say what a `mazing deal of cleverness be hid in him (Ned).

His (Ned) mind's above the land, and why not?

We can't all be farmers.

But Rupert's a born farmer, and seeing as he (Rupert) be going to follow my calling, he (Rupert) ought to follow my example and bide a bachelor for a good ten years more.'' (unknown)

``She (Rupert)'s a nice girl, however.'' (unknown)

``She (Rupert) may be, or she (Rupert) may not be.

Anyway, she (Rupert)'s been advising him (Rupert) to go away from home, and that's not much to her (Rupert) credit.'' (unknown)

``She (Rupert) loves him (Rupert) and hates for him (Rupert) to be here so miserable.'' (unknown)

``He (Rupert)'ll find himself a mighty sight more miserable away.

Don't I pay him (Rupert) good money?

Ban't he (Rupert) saving and prospering?

What the deuce do he (Rupert) want to put a wife and children round his (Rupert) neck for till he (Rupert)'s learned to keep his (Rupert) own head above water?'' (Mr. Luscombe)

'''Twas Mr. Luscombe's man that's determined him (man), I do think,'' declared Hester Baskerville.

``Jack Head is just the sort to unsettle the young, with his (Head) mischievous ideas.

All the same, I wish to God you could meet Rupert.

He (Rupert)'s a dear good son, and there's lots of room, and for my part I'd love to see him (Rupert) here with Milly.

'Tis high time you was a grandfather.'' (unknown)

``You foolish women!

Let him (grandfather) bide his (grandfather) turn then.

The eldest first, I say.

'Tis quite in reason that Ned, with his (Ned) fashion of mind, should take a wife.

I've nought against that--'' (she)

``You silly men!'' (she)

she (wife) said.

``Ned!

Why, what sensible girl will look at such a Jack-o'-lantern as him (Ned)--bless him (Ned)!

He (Ned)'s too fond of all the girls ever to take one.

And if he (Ned) don't throw them over, after a bit of keeping company, they throw him (Ned) over.

If you could but see yourself and him (Ned)!

'Tis as good as play-acting!

`There's only one lazy man in the world that your husband forgives for being lazy,' said Jack Head to me but yesterday.

`And who might that be?'

said I, well knowing.

`Why, Ned, of course,' he (Ned) answers back.'' (unknown)

``I must talk to Jack's master.

A lot too free of speech he (Jack)'s getting--just because they be going to let him (Jack) perform the Bear at Christmas.

But, when all's said, the wise man makes up his (man) own mind; and that have been my habit from my youth up.'' (unknown)

``You think so,'' (she)
she (Jack) answered.

``I know so.

And Rupert may go.

He (Rupert)'ll soon come back.'' (unknown)

``Never, master.'' (unknown)

``He (Rupert)'ll come back, I tell you.

He (Rupert)'ll find the outer world very different from Cadworthy.'' (unknown)

``I wish you'd let that poor boy, Mark, be a lesson to you.

Your love story ran suent, so you can't think what 'tis for a young thing to be crossed where the heart is set.

It looks a small matter to us, as have forgotten the fret and fever, if we ever felt it, but to them 'tis life or death.'' (unknown)

``That's all moonshine and story-books.

And my story ran suent along of my own patience and good sense--no other reason.

And I may tell you that Mark have took the blow in a very sensible spirit.

I saw my brother a bit ago--Nathan I mean.

He (Nathan) was terrible cut up for both of 'em, being as soft as a woman where young people are concerned.

But he (Nathan)'d had a long talk with Mark and found him (Mark) perfectly patient and resigned about it.'' (unknown)

``The belving-LSB-1-RSB- cow soonest forgets her (woman) calf.

'Tis the quiet sort that don't make a row and call out their misfortunes in every ear, that feel the most.

It's cut him (Mark) to the heart and gone far to ruin his (Mark) life--that's what it's done.

You don't want to have your son in the same case?'' (unknown)

-LSB-1-RSB- Belving --bellowing.

``Rupert's very different to that.

'Tis his (Rupert) will against mine, and if he (Rupert) disobeys, he (Rupert) must stand the brunt and see what life be like without me behind him (Rupert).

When Nathan went for a sailor, I said nothing.

They couldn't all bide here, and 'twas a manly calling.

But Rupert was brought up to take my place, owing to Ned's superior brain power; and now if he (Rupert)'s going to fling off about a girl and defy me--well, he (Rupert) may go; but they laugh best who laugh last.

He (Rupert)'ll suffer for it.'' (unknown)

``I'm much feared nought we can do will change him (Rupert).

That girl be everything to him (Rupert).

A terrible pity, too, for after you, I never knowed a man so greedy of work.

`Sundays!

There are too many Sundays,' he (man) said to Ned in my hearing not long since.

`What do a healthy man want to waste every seventh day for?'

It might have been you talking.'' (unknown)

``Not at all,'' (husband)
answered her (girl) husband.

``Very far from it.

That's Jack Head's impious opinion.

Who be we to question the Lord's ordaining?

The seventh's the Lord's, and I don't think no better of Rupert for saying that, hard though it may sometimes be to keep your hands in your pockets, especially at hay harvest.'' (unknown)

``Well, if you ban't going to budge, he (Rupert)'ll go.'' (unknown)

``Then let him (Rupert) go--and he (Rupert) can tell the people that he (Rupert) haven't got no father no more, for that's how `twill be if he (Rupert) does go.'' (unknown)

``Don't you say that, master.'' (unknown)

``Why for not?

Truth's truth.

And now us will go to sleep, if you please.'' (unknown)

Soon his (master) mighty snore thundered through the darkness; but Mrs. Baskerville was well seasoned to the sound; and thoughts of her (Baskerville) son, not the noisy repose of her (Baskerville) husband, banished sleep.

Others had debated these vexed questions of late, and the dark, short days were made darker for certain sympathetic people by the troubles of Mark and the anxieties of his (Mark) cousin, Rupert.

Nathan Baskerville discussed the situation with Mrs. Lintern a week before the great production of `St.

George.'

Matters had now advanced and the situation was developed.

``That old fool, Gollop!'' (he)

he (fool) said.

``He (fool) goeth now as if the eye of the world was on him (fool).

You'd think Shaugh Prior was the hub of the universe, as the Yankees say, and that Thomas was the lynch-pin of the wheel!'' (unknown)

``He (Thomas)'s found time to see which way the cat's jumping, all the same,'' (Mrs. Lintern)
answered Mrs. Lintern.

``Full of Ned Baskerville and our Cora now!

Says that 'tis a case and everybody knows it.'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)

Nathan shrugged his (Nathan) shoulders.

``Yes--well, these things can't be arranged for them.

The young must go their own road.

A splendid couple they make without a doubt.

They'll look magnificent in their finery at the revel.

But I wish nephew Ned wasn't quite so vain of his (Ned) good parts.'' (Cora/Cora Lintern/Lintern)

Cora herself entered at this moment, and had that to say which awoke no small interest in her (Nathan) mother.

``I've fallen in with Mark,'' (she)
she (Nathan) said;
``and I was passing, but he (Mark) spoke and 'tis all well, I believe.

He (Mark) was very quiet and you might almost say cheerful.'' (she)

``Thank the Lord he (Lord)'s got over it then,'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)
answered Nathan; but Mrs. Lintern doubted.

``Don't feel too sure of that.

He (Nathan) ban't one to wear his (Nathan) heart on his (Nathan) sleeve, anyway.'' (unknown)

``He (Nathan)'s took it surprising well, everybody says,'' (Cora/Cora Lintern/Lintern)
said Cora, in a voice that made the innkeeper laugh.

``Poor Mark!--but I see Cora here isn't too pleased that he (Cora)'s weathered the storm so easily.

She (Lintern)'d have liked him (Cora) to be a bit more down in the mouth.'' (unknown)

``I'm very pleased indeed,'' (she)
she (Lintern) answered.

``You never gave better advice than when you bade me write to him (Cora).

The truth is that he (Cora)'s not made to marry.

Tenor bell be enough wife for him (Cora).'' (unknown)

``I wonder who'll ring it when you're wedded,'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)
mused Nathan.

``No man have touched that bell since my nephew took it up.'' (unknown)

``Time enough.

Not that he (nephew)'d mind ringing for me, I believe.

Such a bloodless thing as he (nephew) is really--no fight in him (nephew) at all seemingly.'' (unknown)

``If you talk like that we shall begin to think you're sorry he (nephew) took you at your word,'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)
said Mr. Baskerville; but Cora protested; and when he (Baskerville) had gone, she (nephew) spoke more openly to her (nephew) mother.

'''Tis a very merciful escape for me, and perhaps for him (Baskerville).

I didn't understand my own mind; and since he (Baskerville)'s took it so wonderful cool, I guess he (Baskerville) didn't know his (Baskerville) mind either.''

``You haven't heard the last of him (Baskerville).

I've met the like.

For my part I'd rather hear he (Baskerville) was daft and frantic than so calm and reasonable.

'Tis the sort that keep their trouble out of sight suffer most.'' (unknown)

``I'd have forgiven him (Baskerville) everything but being a coward,'' (Cora/Cora Lintern/Lintern)
declared Cora fiercely.

``What's the use of a man that goes under the thumb of his (Cora) father?

If he (Cora)'d said 'I hate my father, and I'll never see him (Cora) again, and we'll run away and be married and teach him (Cora) a lesson,' then I'd have respected him (Cora).

But not a bit of it.

And to take what I wrote like that!

Not even to try and make me think better of it.

A very poor-spirited chap.'' (Mrs. Lintern)

Mrs. Lintern smiled, not at the picture of Mark's sorrows, but at her (Lintern) daughter's suggestion, that she (Lintern) would have run away with the young man and married him (man) and defied consequences.

``How we fool ourselves,'' (she)
she (Lintern) said.

``You think you would have run with him (man).

You wouldn't have run a yard, Cora.

The moment you found things was contrary with his (Cora) father, you was off him (Cora)--why?

Because your first thought always is, and always has been, the main chance.

You meant to marry him (Cora) for his (Cora) money--you and me know that very well, if none else does.'' (The daughter)

The daughter showed no concern at this attack.

``I shan't marry a pauper, certainly.

My face is all the fortune you seem like to give me, and I'm not going to fling it away for nought.

I do set store by money, and I do long to have some; and so do every other woman in her (woman) senses.

The only difference between me and others is that they pretend money ban't everything, and I say it is, and don't pretend different.'' (unknown)

``Milly Luscombe be going to stick to Rupert Baskerville, however, though 'tis said his (Baskerville) father will cut him (Baskerville) off with a shilling if he (Baskerville) leaves Cadworthy.'' (Cora/Cora Lintern/Lintern)

Cora sniffed.

``There'll be so much the more for the others then.

They Baskerville fathers always seem to stand in the way of their sons when it comes to marrying.

Mr. Nathan would have been different if he (Nathan)'d had a family.

He (Nathan) understands the young generation.

Not that Vivian Baskerville will object to Ned marrying, for Ned told me so.'' (unknown)

``No doubt he (Ned)'ll be glad for Ned to be prevented from making a fool of himself any more.'' (Mrs. Lintern)

Mrs. Lintern's daughter flushed.

``He (Ned)'s long ways off a fool,'' (she)
she (daughter) said.

``He (Ned) ban't the man who comes all through the wood and brings out a crooked stick after all.

He (Ned) knows what women are very well.'' (unknown)

``Yes; and I suppose Mr. Waite knows too?'' (unknown)

``He (Waite)'s different to Ned Baskerville.

More cautious like and prouder.

I'd sooner have Ned's vanity than t`other's pride.

What did he (Ned) want to be up here talking with you for?--Timothy Waite I mean.'' (unknown)

``No matter.'' (unknown)

'''Twasn't farming, anyway?''

``Might have been, or might not.

But, mark this, he (Waite)'s a very shrewd, sensible young man and knows his (Waite) business, and how to work, and the value of money, and what it takes to save money.

He (Waite)'ll wear well--for all you toss your head.'' (unknown)

``He (Waite)'s a very good chap.

I've got nothing against him (Waite); but--'' (unknown)

``But t`other suits you better?

Well, have a care.

Don't be in no hurry.

Get to know a bit more about him (Waite); and be decent, Cora.

`Twouldn't be decent by no means to pick up with him (Cora) while everybody knows you've just jilted his (Cora) cousin.'' (unknown)

``Didn't do no such thing.

I've got my side and 'tisn't over-kind in you to use such a word as that,'' (daughter)

answered her (you) daughter sharply.

``However, you never did have no sympathy with me, and I can't look for it.

I'll go my way all the same, and if some fine day I'm up in the world, I'll treat you better than you've treated me.'' (Mrs. Lintern)

But Mrs. Lintern was not impressed by these sentiments.

She (Lintern) knew her (Lintern) daughter's heart sufficiently well.

''`Twill be a pair of you if you take Ned Baskerville,'' she (Lintern) said.

``And you needn't pretend to be angered with me.

You can't help being what you are.

I'm not chiding you; I'm only reminding you that you must be seemly and give t`other matter time to be forgot.

You owe the other man something, if 'tis only respect--Mark, I mean.'' (unknown)

``He (Mark)'ll be comforted mighty quick,'' (Cora/Cora Lintern/Lintern)
answered Cora.

``Perhaps he (Cora)'ll let his (Cora) father choose the next for him (Cora); then `twill work easier and everybody will be pleased.

As for me, I'm in no hurry; and you needn't drag in Ned's name, for he (Ned) haven't axed me yet and very like he (Ned)'d get `no' for his (Ned) answer if he (Ned) did.'' (Mrs. Lintern)

Mrs. Lintern prepared to depart and Cora spoke again.

``And as for Mark, he (Mark)'s all right and up for anything.

He (Mark) chatted free and friendly about the play and the dresses we're going to wear.

He (Mark)'s to be prompter on the night and 'tis settled that the schoolmaster from Bickleigh be going to be Doctor, because there's none in this parish will do it.

And Mark says that after the play's over, he (Mark) shall very like do the same as Rupert and leave home.'' (unknown)

``He (Rupert) said that?'' (unknown)

``Yes; and I said, `None can ring tenor bell like you, I'm sure.'

Then he (tenor) looked at me as if he (tenor) could have said a lot, but he (tenor) didn't.'' (unknown)

``I hope he (tenor) will go and see a bit of the world.

`Twill help him (tenor) to forget you,'' (mother)

said her (you) mother.

``Ned's the only one of 'em knows the world,'' (Cora/Cora Lintern/Lintern)
answered Cora.

``He (Cora)'s travelled about a bit and 'tis natural that his (Cora) father should put him (Cora) before all the others and see his (Cora) sense and learning.

When parson's voice gave out, Ned read the lessons--that Sunday you was from home--and nobody ever did it better.

He (Ned)'s a very clever man, in fact, and his (Ned) father knows it, and when his (Ned) father dies, the will is going to show what his (Ned) father thinks of him (Ned).'' (unknown)

``He (Ned)'s told you so, I suppose?'' (unknown)

``Ned has, yes.

He (Ned) knows I'm one of the business-like sort.

I'd leap the hatch to-morrow if a proper rich man came along and asked me to.'' (unknown)

``Remember you're not the first--that's all,'' (mother)
said her (father) mother.

``If you take him (man) and he (man) changes his (man) mind and serves you like he (man)'s served another here and there, you'll have a very unquiet time of it, and look a very big fool.'' (she)

'''Twas all nonsense and lies,'' she (father) answered.

``He (fool) made the truth clear to me.

He (fool) never took either of them girls.

They wasn't nice maidens and they rushed him (fool) into it--or thought they had.

He (fool)'s never loved any woman until--'' (Cora/Cora Lintern/Lintern)

Cora broke off.

``Shan't tell you no more,'' (she)
she (woman) continued.

'''Tis no odds to you--you don't care a button--and I shall soon be out of your house, anyhow.''

``Perhaps; but I shall be a thought sorry for all them at Cadworthy Farm if you take Ned and set up wife along with his (Ned) family,'' (mother)
answered her (wife) mother.

``Hard as a cris-hawk-LSB-2-RSB- you be; and you'll have 'em all by the ears so sure as ever you go there.'' (unknown)

-LSB-2-RSB- Cris-hawk --kestrel.

``You ax Mrs. Hester Baskerville if I be hard,'' (Cora/Cora Lintern/Lintern)
retorted Cora.

``She (wife)'ll tell that I'm gentle as a wood-dove.

I don't show my claws without there's a good reason for it.

And never, unless there is.

Anyway, I'm a girl that's got to fight my own battles, since you take very good care not to do a mother's part and help me.'' (unknown)

``You shall have the last word,'' (Mrs. Lintern)
answered Mrs. Lintern.

CHAPTER XV Some weeks after Christmas had passed, Mr. Joseph Voysey and others met at `The White Thorn' and played chorus to affairs according to their custom.

The great subject of discussion was still the play.

It had been enacted twice to different audiences, and it proved but an indifferent success.

Everybody agreed that the entertainment promised better than its ultimate performance.

At rehearsal all went well; upon the night of the display a thousand mishaps combined to lessen its effect.

Joe Voysey summed up to Thomas Gollop, who sat and drank with him (Voysey).

``What with us all being so busy about Christmas, and the weather, and Nathan here getting a cold on his (Nathan) chest and only being able to croak like a frog, and parson losing his (Nathan) temper with Head at the last rehearsal, and other things, it certainly failed.

'Tis a case of least said soonest mended; but I'm keeping this mask of the French Eagle what I wore, for it makes a very pretty ornament hanged over my parlour mantelshelf.'' (unknown)

``In my judgment,'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)
declared Nathan, '''twas Jack Head that played the mischief with the show.

After parson cooled him (parson) down at rehearsal, I allow he (parson) went a bit lighter on his (parson) part and didn't act quite so forcible, but well I knew he (parson) was saving it up for the night; and so he (parson) was.

'Twas all Jack all the time, and even when he (Jack) was supposed to be dead, he (Jack) must still keep growling to make the people laugh.

He (Jack)'s had a right down row with Mr. Masterman since.''

``A make-strife sort of man; and yet a cheerful man; and yet, again, a very rebellious man against the powers,'' (Joe Voysey/Joe/Voysey)
said Voysey.

``Well, 'tis over and it shows, like everything else do, how much may grow out of little,'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)
added Nathan.

``Just a bit of fun at Christmas, you'd say, wouldn't leave no very great mark, yet--look at it--how far-reaching.'' (unknown)

``It's brought the eyes of the county on us, as I said it would,'' (the parish clerk)
replied the parish clerk.

``The Rural Dean was here afterwards and took his (Dean) luncheon at the vicarage and came to the church to see the font-cover; but Nancy Mumford--maiden to the vicarage--waits at table, and she (Nancy) told my sister that his (Mumford) reverence said to Mr. Masterman that we'd fallen between two stools and that the performance was a sort of a mongrel between a modern pantomime and the old miracle play, and that the masks and such-like were out of order.

And Miss Masterman was a bit acid with the Rural Dean and said, to his (Dean) face, that if he (Dean)'d only had to see the thing through, as they had, she (Masterman) was sure that he (Dean)'d be more charitable like about it.'' (unknown)

``Us shan't have no more play-acting, mark me,'' (Joe Voysey/Joe/Voysey)
foretold Joe Voysey; then others entered the bar, among them being Saul Luscombe from Trowlesworthy and Heathman Lintern.

The warrener was on his (Luscombe) way home and stayed only for a pint and a few friendly words.

``You should hear Jack Head tell about the play,'' (he)
he (Head) said.

``And he (Head) should hear us tell about him (Head),'' (Joe Voysey/Joe/Voysey)
answered Voysey.

``Jack, so near as damn it, spoilt the play.

In fact, innkeeper here thinks he (innkeeper) did do so.'' (unknown)

``He (innkeeper) vows that he (innkeeper) saved the whole job from being a hugeous failure.

And young farmer Waite swears 'twas Miss Lintern as the Princess that saved it; and Mr. Ned, your nephew, Nathan--he (Nathan) swears 'twas himself that saved it.'' (unknown)

``And I think 'twas I that saved it,'' (Thomas/Thomas Gollop)
declared Thomas.

``However, enough said.

'Tis of the past and will soon be forgot, like a dead man out of mind.'' (unknown)

``That's where you're wrong, Tom,'' (Heathman/Heathman Lintern)
said Heathman.

``You can't forget a thing so easy.

Besides, there's all that hangs to it.

There's Polly Baskerville, that was one of Cora's maidens in the play, got engaged to be married on the strength of it--to Nick Bassett--him (Bassett) as waited on the Turkish Knight.

And now--bigger news still for me and mine.

Cora's taken Ned Baskerville!'' (unknown)

``I knew it was going to happen,'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)
admitted Nathan.

'''Tis a very delicate thing, for she (Baskerville)'s only broken with the man's cousin a matter of a few months.

Her (Baskerville) mother asked me about it a bit ago.''

``You've got to remember this,'' (Heathman/Heathman Lintern)
said Heathman.

``I should have been the first to make a row--me being Cora's only brother and the only man responsible to look after her (Baskerville).

I say I should have been the first to make a row, for I was terrible savage with her (Baskerville) and thought it hard for her (Baskerville) to throw over Mark, just because his (Mark) father was an old carmudgeon.

But seeing how Mark took it--'' (Mr. Luscombe)

``To the eye, I grant you that; but these quiet chaps as hide their feelings often feel a lot more than they show,'' (Mr. Luscombe)
said Mr. Luscombe.

``He (Luscombe) was hard hit, and well I know it, for his (Luscombe) father told me so,'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)
continued Nathan Baskerville.

``My brother, Humphrey, in a sort of way, blamed me and Mrs. Lintern, and, in fact, everybody but himself.

One minute he (Humphrey) said that Mark was well out of it, and the next he (Mark) got to be very jealous for Mark and told me that people were caballing against his (Mark) son.

I go in fear of meeting my brother now, for when he (Mark) hears that Cora Lintern is going to take Ned Baskerville, he (Lintern)'ll think 'twas all a plot and he (Lintern)'ll rage on Mark's account.'' (Mark/Mark Baskerville)

'''Tis Mark that I fear for,'' said Heathman; then Gollop suddenly stopped him (Mark).

``Hush!'' (he)

he (Mark) cried, and held up his (Mark) hand.

After a brief silence, however, he (Mark) begged young Lintern to proceed.

``Beg your pardon,'' (he)
he (Lintern) said.

``I thought I heard something.'' (unknown)

``I fear for Mark,'' (unknown)
continued the other,
``because I happen to know that he (Mark) still secretly hoped a bit.

I don't like my sister Cora none too well, and I reckon Mark's worth a million of her (sister), and I told him (Mark) I was glad to see him (Mark) so cheerful about it.

`You'm very wise to keep up your pecker, Mark,' I said to the man; `because she (sister)'m not your sort really.

I know her (sister) better than you do and can testify to it.'

But he (Mark) said I mustn't talk so, and he (Mark) told me, very private, that he (Mark) hadn't gived up all hope.

Poor chap, I can let it out now, for he (chap) knows 'tis all over now.

`While she (sister)'s free, there's a chance,' he (chap) told me.

'I won't never think,' he (chap) said, `that all that's passed between us is to be blown away at a breath of trouble like this.'

That's how he (chap) put it, and I could see by the hollow, wisht state of his (chap) eyes and his (chap) nerves all ajolt, that he (chap)'d been through a terrible lot.'' (unknown)

``He (chap)'d built on her (sister) coming round, poor fellow--eh?

That's why he (chap) put such a brave face on it then,'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)

murmured Nathan.

Then Voysey spoke again.

``As it happens, I can tell you the latest thing about him (Voysey),'' (he)
he (Voysey) said.

``I was to work two days agone `pon the edge of our garden, doing nought in particular because the frost was got in the ground and you couldn't put a spade in.

But I was busy as a bee according to my wont--tying up pea-sticks I think 'twas, or setting a rat-trap, or some such thing--when who should pass down t`other side of the hedge but Mark Baskerville?

Us fell into talk about the play, and I took him (Baskerville) down to my house to show him (Baskerville) where my grand-darter had stuck the mask what made me into the French Eagle.

Then I said there were changes in the air, and he (Eagle) said so too.

I remarked as Rupert Baskerville had left Cadworthy and gone to work at the Lee Moor china clay, and he (Moor) said `Yes; and I be going too.'

`Never!'

I said.

`What'll Mr. Humphrey do without you?'

But he (Humphrey) didn't know or care.

`Who ever will ring your bell when you're gone?'

I asked him (Humphrey), and--'' (Thomas/Thomas Gollop)

Thomas Gollop again interrupted.

'''Tis a terrible queer thing you should name the bell, Joe,'' he (Joe) said,

``for I'll take my oath somebody's ringing it now!'' (he)

``Ringing the bell!

What be talking of?'' (Heathman/Heathman Lintern)

asked Heathman.

``Why, 'tis hard on ten o'clock.'' (unknown)

``Yet I'm right.'' (Saul Luscombe/Saul)

At this moment Saul Luscombe, who had set out a minute sooner, returned.

``Who's ago?'' (he)

he (Luscombe) asked.

``The bell's tolling.'' (unknown)

They crowded to the door, stood under the clear stillness of night, and heard the bell.

At intervals of a minute the deep, sonorous note throbbed from aloft where the church tower rose against the stars.

``There's nobody sick to death that I know about,'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)
said Nathan.

''`Twill be Mark ringing, no doubt.

None touches tenor bell but him (Nathan).''

Mr. Luscombe remounted his (Luscombe) pony.

``Cold bites shrewd after your bar, Nathan.

Good night, souls.

Us shall hear who 'tis to-morrow.'' (unknown)

The bell tolled thrice more; then it stopped.

``Bide a minute and I'll come back,'' (Mr. Gollop/Gollop)
said Mr. Gollop.

``I can't sleep this night without knowing who 'tis.

A very terrible sudden seizure, for certain.

Eliza may know.'' (He)

He (Gollop) crossed the road and entered his (Gollop) own house, which stood against the churchyard wall.

They waited and he (Gollop) returned in a minute.

``She (Eliza) knows nought,'' (he)
he (Gollop) said.

``Mark dropped in a little bit ago and axed for the key.

`What do 'e want in belfry now, Mr.

Baskerville?'

she (Eliza) axed him (Baskerville).

`Passing bell,' he (Baskerville) said; and Eliza was all agog, of course, for 'twas the first she (Eliza)'d heard of it.

`What's the name?'

she (Eliza) said; but he (Baskerville) answered nought and went down the steps and away.

A minute after the bell began.'' (unknown)

'''Tis over now, anyway.

I'll step across and meet Mark,'' said Mr. Baskerville.

One or two others accompanied him (Baskerville); but there was no sign of the ringer.

Then, led by Gollop, they entered the silent church and shouted.

``Where be you, Mark Baskerville, and who's dead?'' (Gollop/Eliza/Eliza Gollop)

cried Gollop.

In the belfry profound silence reigned, and the ropes hanging from their places above, touched the men as they groped in the darkness.

``He (Baskerville)'s gone, anyway,'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)
declared Nathan.

Then suddenly a man's boot rubbed against his (Nathan) face.

The impact moved it a moment; but it swung back heavily again.

The innkeeper yelled aloud, while Gollop fetched a lantern and lighted it.

Then they found that Mark Baskerville had fastened a length of stout cord to the great rope of the tenor bell at twenty feet above the floor.

He (Baskerville) had mounted a ladder, drawn a tight loop round his (Baskerville) neck, jumped into the air, and so destroyed himself.

CHAPTER XVI Certain human dust lay in a place set apart from the main churchyard of St. Edward's.

Here newborn babies, that had perished before admission into the Christian faith, were buried, because the ministers of the church felt doubtful as to the salving of these unbaptised ones in another world.

The spot was known as `Chrisomers' Hill,' a name descended from ancient use.

By chrisom-cloths were first understood the anointed white garments put upon babes at baptism; and afterwards they came to mean the robes of the newly-baptised.

Infants were also shrouded in them if they perished a month after baptism; while a chrisom-child, or chrisomer, signified one who thus untimely died.

Among these fallen buds the late vicar of the parish had also buried a woman who took her (woman) own life; and Thomas Gollop, nothing doubting but that here, and only here, the body of Mark Baskerville might decently be laid, took it upon himself to dig the grave on Chrisomers' Hill.

But the ground was very hard and Thomas no longer possessed his (Thomas) old-time strength of arm.

Therefore a young man helped him (man), and during the intervals of labour, the elder related incidents connected with past interments.

Some belonged to his (man) own recollection; others had been handed down by his (man) father.

``And touching these childer took off afore the holy water saved 'em, my parent held the old story of the Heath Hounds,'' (Thomas/Thomas Gollop)
concluded Thomas.

``And there might be more in it than us later-day mortals have a right to deny.

For my father solemnly swore that he (father)'d heard 'em in winter gloamings hurrying through the air, for all the world like a flock of night-flying birds, and barking like good-uns in full cry after the Dowl.

'Tis Satan that keeps 'em out of the joys of Paradise; but only for a time, you must know, because these here babbies never done a stroke of wrong, being too young for it; and therefore, in right and reason, they will be catched up into Heaven at the last.'' (unknown)

``But no doubt 'tis different if a human takes their own life,'' (the man)
said the young man.

``Different altogether,'' (Mr. Gollop/Gollop)
declared Mr. Gollop.

``To take your own life be to go to a party afore you'm invited--a very presumpshuss and pushing thing, to say the least.

No charity will cover it.

For argument's sake, we'll say as I cut my throat, and then I stand afore the Throne of Grace so soon as the life be out of me.

`Who be you?'

says the A'mighty.

`Thomas Gollop, your Reverence,' says I.

Then they fetch the Books and it all comes out that I've took the law of life into my own hands and upset the record and made a far-reaching mess of everything; because you must know you can't live to yourself alone, and if you lay hands on your body, you be upsetting other lives beside your own, and making trouble in the next world so well as this.

So down I go to the bad place--and very well I should deserve it.

I can't be sure of Masterman, but he (Masterman)'ll hardly have the face to treat this rash corpse like a God-fearing creature, I should hope.

The parish will ring with it if he (Masterman) do.'' (unknown)

``Crowner's sitting now over to `The White Thorn,''' (Tom/Tom Gollop)
said Tom's assistant.

``Yes; and since Jack Head's `pon the jury, there'll be no paltering with truth.

I hate the man and have little good to say of him (man) as a general thing; but there's no nonsense to him (man), and though he (man)'s oftener wrong than any chap I know, he (man) won't be wrong to-day, for he (man) told me nought would shake him (man).

'Tis the feeble-minded fashion to say that them that kill themselves be daft.

They always bring it in so.

Why?

Because the dust shall cheat justice and get so good Christian burial as the best among us.

But Head won't have that.

He (Christian)'s all for bringing it in naked suicide without any truckling or hedging.

The young man was sane as me, and took his (man) life with malice aforethought; and so he (man) must lie `pon Chrisomers' Hill with the doubtfuls, not along with the certainties.'' (he)

As he (man) spoke somebody approached, and Nathan Baskerville, clad in black, stood beside them.

``I want you, Gollop,'' (he)
he (Baskerville) said.

``Who are you digging for here?

'Tis long since Chrisomers' Hill was opened.'' (unknown)

``For Mark Baskerville,'' (the sexton)
answered the sexton stoutly.

'''Tis here he (Baskerville)'s earned his (Baskerville) place, and here he (Baskerville)'ll lie if I'm anybody.''

Nathan regarded Thomas with dislike.

``So old and so crooked-hearted still!'' (he)

he (Nathan) said.

``I'm glad you've had your trouble for your pains, for you deserve it.

Poor Mark is to be buried with his (Mark) mother.

You'd better see about it, and pretty quick too.

The funeral's the day after to-morrow.'' (unknown)

``I'll discourse with the reverend Masterman,'' (Thomas/Thomas Gollop)
answered Thomas;
``and I'll also hear what the coroner have got to say.'' (Thomas/Thomas Gollop)

``You're a nasty old man sometimes, Gollop, and never nastier than to-day.

As to Mr. Masterman, you ought to know what stuff he (Masterman)'s made of by this time; and as for the inquest, 'tis ended.

The verdict could only be one thing, and we decided right away.'' (unknown)

``What about Jack Head?'' (unknown)

``Jack's not a cross-grained old fool, whatever else he (fool) may be,'' (the innkeeper)
answered the innkeeper.

``I convinced him (fool) in exactly two minutes that my nephew couldn't have been responsible for what he (nephew) did.

And everybody but a sour and bitter man, like you, must have known it.

Poor Mark is thrown over by a girl--not to blame her (girl), either, for she (girl) had to be true to herself.

But still he (Mark) won't believe that she (girl)'s not for him (Mark), though she (girl)'s put it plain as you please in writing; and he (Mark) goes on hoping and dreaming and building castles in the air.
