Always dreamy and queer at all times he (Mark) was--remember that.

Then comes the crashing news for him (Mark) that all is over and the maiden has taken another man.

Wasn't it enough to upset such a frail, fanciful creature?

Enough, and more than enough.

He (man) hides his (man) trouble and his (man) brain fails and his (man) heart breaks--all unseen by any eye.

And then what happens?

He (man) rings his (man) own passing-bell!

Was that the work of a sane man?

Poor chap--poor chap!

And you'd deny him (chap) Christian burial and cast him (chap) here, like a dog, with the poor unnamed children down under.

I blush for you.

See to his (chap) mother's grave and try and be larger-hearted.

'Tis only charity to suppose the bitter cold weather be curdling your blood.

Now I'm off to my brother Humphrey, to tell him (Humphrey) what there is to tell.'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)

Then Mr. Nathan buttoned up his (Nathan) coat and turned to the grinning labourer.

``Don't laugh at him (Nathan),'' (he)
he (Nathan) said.

``Be sorry for him (Nathan).

'Tis no laughing matter.

Fill up that hole and take down yonder slate at the far end of the Baskerville row, and put everything in order.

Our graves be all brick.'' (He)

He (Baskerville) departed and Mr. Gollop walked off to the vicarage.

A difficult task awaited Nathan, but he (Nathan) courted it in hope of future advantage.

He (Nathan) was terribly concerned for his (Nathan) brother and now designed to visit him (Nathan).

As yet Humphrey had seen nobody.

Vivian had called at Hawk House the day after Mark's death, but Mrs. Hacker had told him (Vivian) that her (Hacker) master was out.

On inquiries as to his (master) state, she (Hacker) had merely replied that he (master) was not ill.

He (master) had directed that his (master) son's body should remain at the church, and he (master) had not visited Shaugh again or seen the dead since the night that Mark perished.

Now Nathan, secretly hoping that some better understanding between him (Mark) and Humphrey might arise from this shattering grief, and himself suffering more than any man knew from the shock of it, hastened to visit his (man) bereaved brother and acquaint him (man) with the circumstances of the inquest.

Humphrey Baskerville was from home and Nathan, knowing his (Nathan) familiar haunt, proceeded to it.

But first he (Nathan) asked Mrs. Hacker how her (Hacker) master fared.

The woman's eyes were stained with tears and her (Hacker) nerves unstrung.

``He (master) bears it as only he (master) can bear,'' (she)
she (Hacker) said.

``You'd think he (master) was a stone if you didn't know.

Grinds on with his (master) life--the Lord knows at what cost to himself.

He (Lord) lighted his (Lord) pipe this morning.

It went out again, I grant you; still it shows the nature of him (Lord), that he (Lord) could light it.

Not a word will he (Lord) say about our dear blessed boy--done to death--that's what I call it--by that picture-faced bitch to Undershaugh.'' (unknown)

``You mustn't talk like that, Susan.

'Twas not the girl's fault, but her (Susan) cruel misfortune.

Be honest, there's a good creature.

She (Susan)'s suffered more than any but her (Susan) mother knows.

No, no, no--not Cora.

The terrible truth is that Humphrey's self is responsible for all.

If he (Humphrey)'d met Mrs. Lintern's daughter in a kinder spirit, she (Lintern)'d never have feared to come into the family and never have thrown over poor Mark.

But he (Mark) terrified her (Lintern) to death nearly, and she (Lintern) felt a marriage with such a man's son could never come to good.'' (Mrs. Hacker)

Mrs. Hacker was not following the argument.

Her (Hacker) mind had suffered a deep excitation and shock, and she (Hacker) wandered from the present to the past.

``The ups and downs of it--the riddle of it--the indecency of it--life in general, I mean!

To think that me and you not above a week agone were dancing afore the public eye--Father Christmas and Mother Dorothy.

How the people laughed!

And now--'' (She)

She (Dorothy) stared stupidly before her (Dorothy) and suddenly began repeating her (Dorothy) part in the play.

``Here come I, old Mother Dorothy, Fat, fair, plump and commodity.

My head is big, my body is bigger: Don't you think I be a handsome old figure?'' (unknown)

``And the quality said I might have been made for the part!'' (unknown)

``You're light-headed along of all this cruel grief,'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)
answered Nathan.

``Go in out of this cold wind, Susan, and drink a stiff drop of spirits.

I suppose my brother is up on the tor?'' (unknown)

``Yes, he (brother)'s up there; you can see him (brother) from the back garden.

Looks like an image--a stone among the stones, or a crow among the crows.

But the fire's within.

He (brother) was terrible fond of Mark really, though he (Mark)'d rather have had red-hot pincers nip him (Mark) than show it.'' (unknown)

``I'll go up,'' (the innkeeper)
declared the innkeeper.

He (innkeeper) climbed where his (innkeeper) brother appeared against the skyline and found Humphrey bleakly poised, standing on a stone and looking into the eye of the east wind.

His (Humphrey) coat was flapping behind him (Humphrey); his (Humphrey) hat was drawn over his (Humphrey) eyes; his (Humphrey) nose was red and a drop hung from it.

He (Humphrey) looked like some great, forlorn fowl perched desolate and starving here.

``Forgive me for coming, brother, but I hadn't the heart to keep away.

You wouldn't see me before; but you must now.

Get down to the lew side of these stones.

I must speak to you.'' (unknown)

``I'm trying to understand,'' (unknown)
answered the other calmly.

``And the east wind's more like to talk sense to me than ever you will.'' (unknown)

``Don't say that.

We often court physical trouble ourselves when we are driven frantic with mental trouble.

I know that.

I've suffered too in my time; though maybe none of the living--but one--will ever know how much.

But 'tis senseless to risk your own life here and fling open your lungs to the east wind because your dear son has gone.

Remember 'tis no great ill to die, Humphrey.'' (unknown)

``Then why do you ask me to be thoughtful to live?'' (unknown)

``I mean we mustn't mourn over Mark for himself--only his (Mark) loss for ourselves.

He (Mark)'s out of it.

No more east wind for him (Mark).

'Tis our grief that's left.

His (Mark) grief's done; his (Mark) carking cares be vanished for ever.

You mustn't despair, Humphrey.'' (unknown)

``And you pass for an understanding man, I suppose?

And tell me not to despair.

Despair's childish.

Only children despair when they break their toys.

And grown-up children too.

But not me.

I never despair, because I never hope.

I made him (man).

I created him (man).

He (man) was a good son to me.'' (unknown)

``And a good man every way.

Gentle and kind--too gentle and kind, for that matter.

Thank God we're all Christians.

Blessed are the meek.

His (meek) cup of joy is full, and where he (meek) is now, Humphrey, his (Humphrey) only grief is to see ours.'' (unknown)

``That's the sort of stuff that's got you a great name for a sympathetic and feeling man, I suppose?

D'you mean it, or is it just the natural flow of words, as the rain falls and the water rolls down-hill?

I tell you that he (man) was a good man, and a man to make others happy in his (man) mild, humble way.

Feeble you might call him (man) here and there.

And his (man) feebleness ended him (man).

Too feeble to face life without that heartless baggage!'' (unknown)

``Leave her (man) alone.

You don't understand that side, and this isn't the time to try and make you.

She (man)'s hit hard enough.'' (Humphrey/Humphrey Baskerville/HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE)

Humphrey regarded his (Humphrey) brother with a blazing glance of rage.

Then his (Humphrey) features relaxed and he (Humphrey) smiled strangely at his (Humphrey) own heart, but not at Nathan.

``I was forgetting,'' (he)
he (Nathan) said.

Then he (Nathan) relapsed into silence.

Presently he (Nathan) spoke again.

``My Mark wasn't much more than a picture hung on a wall to some people.

Perhaps he (Mark) wasn't much more to me.

But you miss the picture if 'tis taken down.

I never thought of such a thing happening.

I didn't know or guess all that was hidden bottled up in him (Mark).

I thought he (Mark) was getting over it; but, lover-like, he (Mark) couldn't think she (Mark)'d really gone.

Then something--the woman herself, I suppose--rubbed it into him (Mark) that there was no more hope; and then he (Mark) took himself off like this.

For such a worthless rag--to think!

And I suppose she (Mark)'ll hear his (Mark) bell next Sunday without turning a hair.'' (unknown)

``Don't say that.

She (Mark)'s terribly cut up and distressed.

And I'm sure none--none will ever listen to his (Mark) bell like we used to.

`Twill always have a sad message for everybody that knew Mark.'' (unknown)

``Humbug and trash!

You'll be the first to laugh and crack your jokes and all the rest of it, the day that girl marries.

And the bell clashing overhead, and the ashes of him (Mark) in the ground under.

Let me choose the man--let me choose the man when she (girl) takes a husband!'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)

Nathan perceived that his (Nathan) brother did not know the truth.

It was no moment to speak of Cora and Ned Baskerville, however.

``I've just come from the inquest,'' (he)
he (Baskerville) said.

``Of course 'twas brought in `unsound mind.''' (unknown)

``Of course--instead of seeing and owning that the only flash of sanity in many a life be the resolve and deed to leave it.

He (Baskerville) was sane enough.

No Baskerville was ever otherwise.

'Tis only us old fools, that stop here fumbling at the knot, that be mad.

The big spirits can't wait to be troubled for threescore years and ten with a cargo of stinking flesh.

They drop it overboard and--'' (unknown)

His (Baskerville) foot slipped and interrupted the sentence.

``Take my arm,'' (the innkeeper)
said the innkeeper.

``I've told Gollop that Mark will lie with his (Mark) mother.'' (unknown)

The other seemed suddenly moved by this news.

``If I've misjudged you, Nathan, I'm sorry for it,'' (he)
he (Nathan) said.

``You know in your heart whether you're as good as the folk think; and as wise; and as worthy.

But you catch me short of sleep to-day; and when I'm short of sleep, I'm short of sense, perhaps.

To lie with his (Nathan) mother--eh?

No new thing if he (Nathan) does.

He (Nathan) lay many a night under her (mother) bosom afore he (Nathan) was born, and many a night on it afterwards.

She (mother) was wonderful wrapped up in him (Nathan)--the only thing she (mother) fretted to leave.

How she (mother) would nuzzle him (Nathan), for pure animal love, when he (Nathan) was a babby--like a cat and her (mother) kitten.'' (unknown)

``He (Nathan) promised her (mother) when he (Nathan) was ten years old--the year she (mother) died--that he (Nathan) would be buried with her (mother),'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)
said Nathan.

``I happen to know that, Humphrey.'' (unknown)

``Few keep their promises to the dead; but he (Nathan)'s dead himself now.

Burrow down--burrow down to her (mother) and put him (Nathan) there beside her (mother)--dust to dust.

I take no stock in dust of any sort--not being a farmer.

But his (farmer) mother earned heaven, and if he (farmer) didn't, her (mother) tears may float him (farmer) in.

To have bred an immortal soul, mark you, is something, even if it gets itself damned.

The parent of a human creature be like God, for he (God)'s had a hand in the making of an angel or a devil.'' (unknown)

``Shall we bring Mark back to-night, or shall the funeral start from the church?'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)

asked Nathan.

They had now descended the hill and stood at Humphrey's gate.

``Don't worry his (Humphrey) bones.

Let him (Humphrey) stop where he (Humphrey) is till his (Humphrey) bed's ready.

I'm not coming to the funeral.'' (unknown)

``Not coming!'' (unknown)

``No.

I didn't go to my wife's, did I?'' (unknown)

``Yes, indeed you did, Humphrey.'' (unknown)

``You're wrong there.

A black hat with a weeper on it, and a coat, and a mourning hankercher was there--not me.

Bury him (Humphrey), and toll his (Humphrey) own bell for him (Humphrey), but for God's sake don't let any useful person catch their death of cold for him (Humphrey).

Me and his (Humphrey) mother--we'll mourn after our own fashion.

Yes, her (mother) too: there are spirits moving here for the minute.

In his (Humphrey) empty room she (mother) was the night he (Humphrey) finished it.

Feeling about she (mother) was, as if she (mother)'d lost a threepenny piece in the bed-tick.

I heard her (mother).

`Let be!'

I shouted from my chamber.

`The man's not there: he (man)'s dead--hanged hisself for love in the belfry.

Go back where you come from.

Belike he (man)'ll be there afore you, and, if not, they'll tell you where to seek him (man).''' (He)

He (man) turned abruptly and went in; then as his (man) brother, dazed and bewildered, was about to hurry homeward, the elder again emerged and called to him (man).

``A word for your ear alone,'' (he)
he (man) said as Nathan returned.

``There's not much love lost between us, and never can be; but I thank you for coming to me to-day.

I know you meant to do a kindly thing.

My trouble hasn't blinded me.

Trouble ban't meant to do that.

Tears have washed many eyes into clear seeing, as never saw straight afore they shed 'em.

I'm obliged to you.

You've come to me in trouble, though well you know I don't like you.

'Twas a Christian thing and I shan't forget it of you.

If ever you fall into trouble yourself, come to me, innkeeper.'' (unknown)

'''Twas worth my pains to hear that.

God support you always, brother.''

But Humphrey had departed.

Nathan drifted back and turned instinctively to Undershaugh rather than his (Nathan) own house.

Darkness and concern homed there also; Cora had gone away to friends far from the village, and the Linterns all wore mourning for Mark.

Priscilla met her (Priscilla) landlord and he (Mark) came into the kitchen and flung his (Mark) hat on the table and sat down to warm himself by the fire.

``God knows what's going to happen,'' (he)
he (God) said.

``The man's mind is tottering.

Never such sense and nonsense was jumbled in a breath.'' (he)

After a pause he (God) spoke again.

``And poor old Susan's half mad too.

An awful house of it.

Nothing Humphrey may do will surprise me.

But one blessed word he (Humphrey) said, poor chap, though whether he (Humphrey) knew what he (Humphrey) was talking about I can't guess.

He (Humphrey) thanked me for coming to him (Humphrey) in trouble--thanked me even gratefully and said he (Humphrey)'d never forget it.

That was a blessed thing for me to hear, at such a time.'' (The man)

The emotional man shed tears and Priscilla Lintern ministered to him (man).

CHAPTER XVII Humphrey Baskerville had sought for peace by many roads, and when the final large catastrophe of his (Baskerville) life fell upon him (Baskerville), it found him (Baskerville) treading a familiar path.

He (Baskerville) had conceived, that only by limiting the ties of the flesh and trampling love of man from his (man) heart, might one approximate to contentment, fearlessness, and rest.

He (man) had supposed that the fewer we love, the less life has power to torment us, and he (man) had envied the passionless, sunless serenity of recorded philosophers and saints.

He (man) was glad that, at a time when nature has a large voice in the affairs of the individual and sways him (man) through sense, he (man) had not incurred the customary responsibilities.

Chance threw him (Chance) but a single child; and when the mother of the child was taken from him (Chance), he (Chance) felt a sort of dreary satisfaction that fate could only strike one more vital blow.

He (Chance) had dwarfed his (Chance) affections obstinately; he (Chance) had estimated the power of life to inflict further master sorrows, and imagined that by the death of one human creature alone could added suffering come.

So at least he (Chance) believed before the event.

And now that creature was actually dead.

Out of the ranks of man, the bullet had found and slain his (man) son.

Yet, when Mark sank to the grave and the first storm of his (Mark) passing was stilled in the father's heart, great new facts and information, until then denied, fell upon Humphrey Baskerville's darkness and showed him (Baskerville) that even this stroke could not sever his (Baskerville) spirit from its kind.

The looked-for deliverance did not descend upon him (Baskerville); the universal indifference did not come.

Instead his (Baskerville) unrest persisted and he (Baskerville) found the fabric of his (Baskerville) former dream as baseless as all dreaming.

Because the alleged saint and the detached philosopher are forms that mask reality; they are poses only possible where the soul suffers from constitutional atrophy or incurred frost-bite.

They who stand by the wayside and watch, are freezing to death instead of burning healthily away.

Faulty sentience is not sublime; to be gelded of some natural human instinct is not to stand upon the heights.

He (saint) who lifts a barrier between himself and life, shall be found no more than an unfinished thing.

His (saint) ambition for detachment is the craving of disease; his (saint) content is the content of unconsciousness; his (saint) peace is the peace of the mentally infirm.

A complete man feels; a complete man suffers with all his (man) tingling senses; a complete man smarts to see the world's negligences, ignorances, brutalities; he (man) endures them as wrongs to himself; and, because he (man) is a complete man, he (man) too blunders and adds his (man) errors to the sum of human tribulation, even while he (man) fights with all his (man) power for the increase of human happiness.

The world's welfare is his (man) own; its griefs are also his (man).

He (man) errs and makes atonement; he (man) achieves and helps others to achieve; he (man) loathes the cloister and loves the hearth.

He (man) suffers when society is stricken; he (man) mourns when the tide of evolution seems to rest from its eternal task `of pure ablution round earth's human shores'; he (man) is troubled when transitory victories fall to evil or ignorance; in fine, he (man) lives.

And his (man) watch-tower and beacon is not content, not peace, but truth.

He (man) stands as high above the cowardly serenity of any anchorite or chambered thinker, as the star above glimmering and rotten wood in a forest hidden; and he (man) knows that no great heart is ever passionless, or serene, or emparadised beyond the cry of little hearts, until it has begun to grow cold.

To be holy to yourself alone is to be nought; a piece of marble makes a better saint; and he (saint) who quits the arena to look on, though he (saint) may be as wise as the watching gods, is also as useless.

Dimly, out of the cloud of misery that fell upon him (saint) when his (saint) son perished, Baskerville began to perceive and to feel these facts.

He (Baskerville) had consoled himself by thinking that the only two beings he (Baskerville) loved in the whole world were gone out of it, and now waited together in eternity for his (Baskerville) own arrival thither.

Their battle was ended; and since they were at rest, nothing further remained for him (Baskerville) to trouble about.

But the anticipated peace did not appear; no anodyne poured into his (Baskerville) soul; and he (Baskerville) discovered, that for his (Baskerville) nature, the isolated mental standpoint did not exist.

There could arise no healing epiphany of mental indifference for him (Baskerville).

He (Baskerville) might be estranged, but to exile himself was impossible.

He (Baskerville) must always actively hate what he (Baskerville) conceived to be evil; he (Baskerville) must always suspect human motives; he (Baskerville) must always feel the flow and ebb of the human tide.

Though his (Baskerville) own rocky heart might be lifted above them, the waves of that sea would tune its substance to throb in sympathy, or fret it to beat with antagonism, so long as it pulsed at all.

This discovery surprised the man; for he (man) had believed that a radical neutrality to human affairs belonged to him (man).

He (man) attributed the sustained restlessness of his (man) spirit to recent griefs and supposed that the storm would presently disappear; and meantime he (man) plunged into a minor whirlwind by falling into the bitterest quarrel with his (man) elder brother.

Nathan indeed he (Nathan) had suffered to depart in peace; but as soon as the bereaved father learned that Vivian's son, Ned, was engaged to Cora, and perceived how it was this fact that had finally killed hope in Mark and induced the unhappy weakling to destroy himself, his (Mark) rage burst forth against the master of Cadworthy; and when Vivian called upon the evening of the funeral to condole with Humphrey, an enduring strife sprang up between them.

``I'm come as the head of the family, Humphrey,'' (the veteran)
began the veteran,
``and it ban't seemly that this here terrible day should pass over your head without any of your kith and kin speaking to you and comforting you.

We laid the poor young man along with his (man) mother in the second row of the Baskerville stones.

My word!

as Gollop said after the funeral, `even in death the Baskervilles be a pushing family!'

Our slates stretch pretty near from the church to the churchyard wall now.'' (the veteran)

``Thank you for being there,'' (brother)
answered his (man) brother.

``I couldn't have gone, because of the people.

There was no maiming of the rite--eh?'' (unknown)

``Not a word left out--all as it should be.

Eight young men carried him (man), including a farmer or two, and my son Ned, and Heathman Lintern, and also my son Rupert--though where he (Rupert) came from and where he (Rupert) went to after 'twas ended, I don't know, and don't care.

He (Rupert)'s left me--to better himself--so he (Rupert) thinks, poor fool!

A nice way to treat a good father.'' (unknown)

``You've lost a son, too, then--lost him (son) to find him (son) again, doing man's work.

You'll live to know that he (man) was right and you were wrong.

But my son--my mind is turned rather rotten of late.

After dark I can't get his (son) dead face out of my eyes.

Nought terrible, neither--just, in a word, `dead.'

He (son) broke his (son) neck--he (son) didn't strangle himself.

He (son) knew what he (son) was about.

But there, I see it.

Gone--and none knows what he (son) was to me.

He (son) never knew himself; and for that matter I never knew myself, neither--till he (son) was gone.'' (unknown)

``We never do know all other folk mean to us--not until they be snatched off.

If anybody had told me how my son Rupert's going would have made such a difference, I'd not have believed it.'' (unknown)

``Then think of this house.

You feel that--you with your store of children and Rupert, after all, but gone a few miles away to go on with his (Rupert) work and marry the proper wife you deny him (Rupert).

But me--nought left--nought but emptiness--no `Good morning, father'; no `Good night, father'; no ear to listen; no voice to ask for my advice.

And I'd plotted and planned for him (father), Vivian; I'd made half a hundred little secret plans for him (Vivian).

I knew well the gentle fashion of man he (man) was--not likely ever to make a fighter--and so I'd cast his (man) life in a mould where it could be easy.

He (man)'d have come to know in time.

But he (man) never did know.

He (man) went out of it in a hurry, and never hinted a whisper of what he (man) was going to do.

If he (man)'d but given me the chance to argue it out with him (man)!'' (unknown)

``We've acted alike, me and you,'' (brother)
answered his (man) brother;
``and it ban't for any man to dare to say that either of us was wrong.

When the young fall into error, 'tis our bounden duty to speak and save 'em if we've got the power.

I don't hold with Rupert--'' (brother)

``No need to drag in your affairs.

That case is very different.

I did not treat my son like a child; I did not forbid him (son) to marry and turn him (son) out of doors.'' (unknown)

``Stay!'' (Vivian/Vivian Baskerville/Mr. Vivian Baskerville)

cried Vivian, growing red,

``you mustn't speak so to me.'' (Vivian/Vivian Baskerville/Mr. Vivian Baskerville)

``What did you do if it wasn't that?

No proud man can stay under the roof where he (man)'s treated like a child.

But Mark--did I forbid?

No.

I only made it clear that I despised the woman he (Mark)'d set his (Mark) heart on.

I only told him (Mark) the bitter truth of her (woman).

If she (woman)'d clung to him (Mark) through all, would I have turned him (Mark) away or refused him (Mark)?

Never.

`Twould have made no difference.

'Twas not me kept 'em apart--as you are trying to keep apart your son and Saul Luscombe's niece--trying and failing.

'Twas the proud, empty, heartless female herself that left him (Luscombe).'' (unknown)

``I'll hear nought against her (niece),'' (Vivian/Vivian Baskerville/Mr. Vivian Baskerville)
answered Vivian stoutly.

``She (niece)'s not proud and she (niece)'s not empty.

She (niece)'s a very sensible woman, and this cruel piece of work has been a sad trouble to her (niece).

She (niece) left Mark because she (niece) felt that you hated her (niece), and would torment her (niece) and make her (niece) married life a scourge to her (niece) back.

Any woman with proper sense and self-respect would have done the like.

'Twas you and only you choked her (niece) off your son, and 'tis vain--'tis wicked to the girl--to say now that 'twas her (girl) fault.

But I've not come to speak these things--only I won't hear lies told.'' (unknown)

``You've heard 'em already, it seems.

Who's been telling you this trash?

Nathan Baskerville belike?'' (unknown)

``As a matter of fact 'tis my son Ned,'' (Vivian/Vivian Baskerville/Mr. Vivian Baskerville)
answered Vivian.

``You must surely know how things have fallen out?

It happened long afore poor Mark died.

Didn't he (Mark) tell you?'' (unknown)

``He (Mark) told me nought.

What should he (Mark) tell me?

Ned he (Mark) certainly wouldn't name, for he (Mark) knew of all your brood I like your eldest son least--a lazy, worthless man, as all the world well knows but you.'' (unknown)

``You shan't anger me, try as you will, Humphrey.

I'm here, as your elder brother and the head of the family, to offer sympathy to you in your trouble; and I'll ax you to leave my family alone.

Young men will be young men, and as for Ned, if I be the only one that feels as I should feel to him (Ned), 'tis because I'm the only one that understands his (Ned) nature and his (Ned) gifts.

He (Ned)'ll astonish you yet, and all of us.

The books he (Ned) reads!

You wait.

Soon ripe, soon rotten.

He (Ned)'s taking his (Ned) time, and if he (Ned) wants a wife, 'tis only in reason that the future head of the family should have a wife; and why not?

He (Ned) shan't have to work as I have worked.'' (unknown)

``A fool's word!

What made you all you are?

Work and the love of it.

Yet you let him (fool) go to the devil in idleness.'' (unknown)

``If you'd but suffer me to finish my speech--I say that Ned won't work as I have worked--with my limbs and muscles.

He (Ned)'s got a brain, and the time be coming when he (Ned)'ll use it.'' (unknown)

``Never.'' (unknown)

``Anyway a settled life is the first thing, and the mind free to follow its proper bent.

And I don't say `no' to his (Ned) marrying, because the case is different from Rupert's, and 'tis fitting that he (Rupert) should do so.'' (unknown)

``But Rupert must not.

And you pass for a just and sensible man!'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

'''Tis strange--something in the Baskerville character that draws her (it)--but so it is,'' continued the master of Cadworthy, ignoring his (master) brother's last remark.

``In a word, when he (master) found she (it) was free, my Ned took up with Cora Lintern, and she (it)'s going to marry him (Ned).

But 'tis to be a full year from this sad Christmas--I bargained for that and will have it so.'' (him)

''`Going to take him (Ned)'?

Going to take your son!''

cried the other.

``She (it) is; and I sanction it; for I found her (it) a very different maiden to what you did.'' (unknown)

``Going to marry Ned!

Going from my Mark to your Ned!'' (unknown)

'''Twas settled some time ago.

Mark knew it, for I myself let it out to him (Mark) when I met him (Mark) one day in North Wood.

'Twas but two days afore his (Wood) last breath, poor fellow.

Of course, I thought that he (Wood) knew all about it, and as it was understood that he (Wood) had got over his (Wood) loss very bravely and was cheerful and happy as usual again, I made nothing of the matter, thinking that was the best way to take it.''

Humphrey stared at him (Humphrey).

``Go on--you're letting in the light,'' (he)
he (Humphrey) said.

``That's all--all save this.

When I told Mark that Cora was going to wed his (Cora) cousin, I saw by his (Cora) face 'twas news for him (Cora).

His (Cora) colour faded away.

Then I knew that he (Cora) hadn't heard about it.

Accident had kept it from him (Cora) till the matter was a week old.'' (unknown)

``And he (Cora) said--?'' (unknown)

``He (Cora) just said something stammering like.

He (Cora) was a bit of a kick-hammer in his (Cora) speech sometimes--nothing to name; but it would overtake him (Cora) now and again if he (Cora) was very much excited.

I didn't catch just what the words were--something about one of the family having her (Cora), I think 'twas.'' (unknown)

``Then he (Cora) went and killed himself, and not till then.

So 'twas your son after all as settled him (son)--don't roar me down, for I'll be heard.

Your son--all his (son) work!

He (son) plotted and planned it.

And lazy I thought him (son)!

And I might have known there's no such thing as laziness of mind and body both.

Busy as a bee damning himself--damning himself, I tell you!

A shifty traitor, a man to stab other men in the back, a knave and the vilest thing that ever bore our name.

And you know it--you know it as well as I do.'' (unknown)

``By God!

this is too much,'' (Vivian/Vivian Baskerville/Mr. Vivian Baskerville)

shouted out Vivian, rising to his (Vivian) feet and towering over the crouching figure opposite him (Vivian).

``What are you made of to say such vile things of an innocent man?

You see life all awry; you see--

``I see a hard-hearted, blind old fool,'' (unknown)
answered the other.

``You let your wretched son rob you of justice and reason and sense and everything.

Get hence!

I'll have no more of you.

But your time will come; you'll suffer yet; and this godless, useless brute--this murderer--will murder you yourself, maybe, or murder your love of living at the least.

Wait and watch him (murderer) a little longer.

He (murderer)'ll bring your grey hairs with sorrow to the grave afore he (murderer)'s done with you--take my word for that.

And as for me, I'll curse him (murderer) to his (murderer) dying day, and curse you for breeding him (murderer)!

Wait and watch what you've done and the fashion of man you've let loose on the world; and let them marry--the sooner the better--then his (man) punishment's brewed and there's no escape from the drinking.

Yes, let him (man) eat and drink of her (murderer), for man's hate can't wish him (man) a worse meal than that.'' (He)

He (man) ceased because he (man) was alone.

Vivian had felt a terrible danger threatening him (Vivian), and had fled from it.

``My anger heaved up like seven devils in me,'' (he)
he (Vivian) told his (Vivian) wife afterwards.

``If I'd bided a moment longer I must have struck the man.

So I just turned tail and bolted afore the harm was done.

Not but what harm enough be done.

Mad--mad he (Mad) was by the froth on his (Mad) lip and the light in his (Mad) eye, and them awful eyebrows twitching like an angry ape's.

'Twas more a wild beast in a tantrum than a human.

'Tis all over, and no fault of mine.

I'll never speak to thicky horrible creature no more so long as I live--never.

And I'll not willingly so much as set eyes upon him (Mad) again.'' (unknown)

``A very Pharaoh of a man, no doubt,'' (Mrs. Baskerville)
declared Mrs. Baskerville.

``The Lord has hardened his (Lord) heart against us; but He (Lord)'ll soften it in His (Lord) own good time.

Though for that matter 'tis difficult to see how he (Lord) can be struck again.

His (Lord) all be took from him (Lord).'' (Vivian/Vivian Baskerville/Mr. Vivian Baskerville)

Vivian considered this saying, but it did not shake his (Vivian) intention.

``He (Vivian)'s growed dangerous and desperate, and `twill be wiser that I see him (Vivian) no more,'' (he)
he (Vivian) answered.

``He (Vivian)'s flung my sympathy back in my face, and that's a sort of blow leaves a bruise that a long life's self can't medicine.'' (unknown)

''`Twill come right.

Time will heal it,'' she (Lord) told him (Vivian).

But he (Vivian) was doubtful.

``There may not be time,'' (he)
he (Vivian) said.

``The man won't live long at the gait he (man)'s going--burning away with misery, he (man) is.

And calls himself a Christian!

Little enough comfort the poor soul sucks out of Christ.'' (Humphrey/Humphrey Baskerville/HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE)

Within a week of this incident Humphrey Baskerville was seeking his (Baskerville) brother's society again--a thing of all others least likely to have happened.

It fell out that he (Baskerville) was walking as usual on the waste above Hawk House, when he (House) saw his (House) nephew Rupert proceeding hastily along the distant road to Cadworthy Farm.

The young man noted him (man), left his (man) way and approached.

'''Tis well I met you, uncle,'' he (man) said.

``Young Humphrey's just ridden over to you with a message from mother.

Then he (man) came on to me.

There's terrible trouble at home--father, I mean.

You know what he (father) is for doing heavy work--work beyond his (father) years, of course.

He (father) was shifting grain from the loft, and they found him (father) fallen and insensible with a sack on top of him (father).

I hope to God it ban't very bad.

Mother sent off for me, for fear it might be a fatal thing.

And Humphrey says my name was on father's lips when they laid him (Humphrey) to bed after doctor had gone.

He (doctor) said, `This be Rupert's fault.

I be driven to this heavy work along of him (Rupert) leaving me, and now he (Rupert)'s killed me.'

I'm sure I hope he (Rupert)'ll call that back, for 'tis a terrible thing for me to live under if he (Rupert) died.'' (unknown)

``I'll come along with you,'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)
said Mr. Baskerville;
``and as to what your father may have spoken in his (father) anger at being stricken down, pay no heed to it.

He (father)'s like a silly boy over these feats of strength, and he (father)'d have shifted the sacks just the same if you'd been there.

The thing he (father) said isn't true, and there's an end on it.

He (father)'ll be sorry he (father) uttered the word when he (father)'s better.'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

They hurried forward and presently stood at the door of Cadworthy.

``You'd best knock afore you enter,'' (unknown)
said the elder.

``We're both in disgrace here, and come as strangers.

I had a difference with your father last time we met.

Ned Baskerville is tokened to that woman that killed Mark.

I could not hear and keep dumb.

I cursed my brother in my rage, and I owe him (brother) an apology.'' (Rupert/Rupert Baskerville)

Rupert knocked at the door, and his (Rupert) sister May answered it.

Her (sister) eyelids were red with tears and her (sister) manner agitated.

``How's your father?'' (Humphrey/Humphrey Baskerville/HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE)

asked Humphrey.

``Very bad, uncle.

'Tis a great doubt if he (Humphrey)'ll get better, doctor says.'' (unknown)

``Then be sure he (Humphrey) will.

I've come to see him (Humphrey).'' (Mrs. Baskerville)

Mrs. Baskerville appeared behind May.

She (Baskerville) was very pale, but appeared collected.

``I'm sorry--terrible sorry,'' (she)
she (Baskerville) said.

``I've told dear master that I'd sent for Rupert and for you, Humphrey, but he (Humphrey) won't see neither of you.

'Tis no good arguing about it in his (Humphrey) state; but I pray God he (God)'ll change his (God) mind to-morrow.'' (Rupert/Rupert Baskerville)

Rupert kissed his (Rupert) mother.

``Bear up,'' (he)
he (Rupert) said.

``With his (Rupert) strength and great courage he (Rupert)'ll weather it, please God.

You know where I am--not five mile away.

I'll come running the moment he (God)'ll see me.'' (unknown)

``And ask him (God) to forgive his (God) brother.

I'm sorry I said the things I did,'' (Humphrey/Humphrey Baskerville/HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE)

declared Humphrey Baskerville.

A pony cart drove up at this moment and Eliza Gollop alighted from it.

She (Gollop) carried a large brown-paper parcel, and a corded box was lifted out after her (Gollop).

``I've come,'' (she)
she (Gollop) said.

``Doctor left a message for me as he (Doctor) went back along, and I was ready as usual.

How's the poor man going on?

I'm afraid you must not be very hopeful--so doctor said on his (doctor) way back; but where there's life and me there's always hope, as my brother Thomas will have it.'' (Humphrey/Humphrey Baskerville/HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE)

Humphrey and his (Humphrey) nephew walked slowly away together.

At the confines of the farmyard Rupert turned out of the road a little and pointed upwards to a window that faced the east.

A white blind was drawn down over it.

``That's father's room,'' (he)
he (father) said.

CHAPTER XVIII Jack Head entered the bar of `The White Thorn,' and was glad to find Nathan Baskerville at home.

``I don't want to drink, I want to talk,'' (he)
he (Baskerville) said.

``Then come into my room, Jack,'' (the innkeeper)
answered the innkeeper, and Mr. Head followed him (Head) into a little chamber known as `Mr.

Nathan's office.'

``I've got together another five pounds,'' (the labourer)
explained the labourer,
``and I know you'll do for me what you do for all--put it by with the rest.

We come to you, Mr. Baskerville, and we trust you with our savings, for why?

Because you ban't a lawyer.

You're the poor man's bank, as I always say, and I only hope you get your fair share of good for all the money you put away to goody for us.'' (the labourer)

``That's all right, Jack.'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)

Mr. Nathan produced a ledger and turned over the pages.

``This makes twenty to you, and interest three-ten.'' (He)

He (Nathan) wrote a receipt and handed it to the other.

``Wish I'd got your `mazing head for figures; and so I should if I'd been properly eggicated.'' (unknown)

``I shall have some pretty big money on my hands before long, I'm afraid,'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)
said Nathan gloomily.

``Doctor called coming back from Cadworthy.

'Tis all over with my poor brother, I'm afraid.'' (unknown)

``My stars--that mighty man to drop amongst us!

Well, he (man)'s had a good life and full share of fortune.'' (unknown)

``His (man) own folly has finished him (man) too--that's the worst of it.

Would be doing the young men's work, and did it once too often.'' (unknown)

``A fall, so they say.

But none appear to know the rights seemingly.'' (unknown)

``Simple enough.

Vivian was carrying oats, and slipped his (Vivian) foot on a frosty place.

Down he (Vivian) came with the sack on his (Vivian) back.

He (Vivian) went insensible; but by the time young Humphrey, who was along with him (Humphrey), had fetched help, Vivian had come to again.

He (Vivian) crept in the house and up to his (Vivian) bed.

'' (he)

Tis nought,' he (Vivian) told 'em, `just a shake up; I'll be right in the morning.'

But he (Vivian) wasn't.

He (Vivian) couldn't rise, and felt a lot of pain to the inwards.

Doctor won't be sure what's gone, but he (Doctor) reckons that the poor man's ruptured spleen or liver.

Anyway, he (Doctor)'s going.

Fading out fast--and suffering, too.''

``Such a mountain as him (Doctor).

I suppose they can't reach the evil.

And will all his (Doctor) affairs come down on your shoulders?'' (unknown)

``That is so.

Everything will have to be done by me.

The boys know nought of business.

He (Doctor)'s a rich man--I know that.'' (unknown)

``A great responsibility, but no doubt you're up to it.'' (unknown)

``Not that it will be so difficult either,'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)
added Nathan,
``because all his (Nathan) money was invested pretty much as I advised.

His (Nathan) wife is joint executor with me; but she (wife) knows nothing.

I could have wished he (Nathan)'d drawn my brother Humphrey in and made him (Nathan) responsible; but he (Nathan) never was sure of Humphrey, I'm sorry to say; and, as bad luck would have it, just before Vivian met with this trouble, he (Vivian) had a terrible quarrel with Humphrey--so terrible, in fact, that when Humphrey called, after the accident, farmer wouldn't see him (Humphrey).'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)

``Nor his (Humphrey) son neither.

I took hope from that, for if a man's well enough to keep up such a hatred against his (man) own kin, it looks as if he (man) was likely to get better.'' (unknown)

``I'm afraid not.

I'm going over this afternoon to see him (man) and hear about his (man) will.

Please God he (man)'ll prove softer.

`Twould be a cruel thing if he (man) clouded his (man) great name for justice at the end by striking from the grave.'' (unknown)

``Where should he (man) strike?'' (unknown)

``Rupert, I mean.

He (Rupert) took Rupert's going terrible to heart, and when Rupert wrote very properly last Christmas and offered his (Rupert) father his (Rupert) respects, and said as he (Rupert) meant to marry Saul Luscombe's niece next spring, Hester tells me that my brother pretty well threw the doors out of windows.

He (Hester) went to Tavistock next day, and there's an ugly fear in his (Hester) wife's mind that he (Hester) had his (Hester) will out and tinkered it.

I shall ax him (Hester) this evening, and try to get him (Hester) to see sense.'' (Hester/Hester Baskerville)

Elsewhere Hester Baskerville spoke with her (wife) husband, and found that he (Baskerville) already knew what the doctor had advised her (wife) to tell him (Baskerville).

``You can spare speech,'' (he)
he (Baskerville) said,
``I saw it in the man's eyes; and I knew it afore he (Baskerville) came, for that matter.

I'm not going to get better.

I'm going to die.'' (he)

``There's hope still, but not enough to--'' (unknown)
``I'm going to die.

Where's Eliza Gollop?'' (unknown)

``I'll call her (Gollop).'' (unknown)

``You'd best to hot up the milk he (Baskerville) ordered.

I'll try to let it down if I can.

And give Eliza pen, ink, and paper.'' (unknown)

``Don't be writing.

Lie still and let her (Eliza) read to you.'' (unknown)

``You needn't be afraid.

My writing was done to Tavistock afore I came to grief.

You're all right, and all that have treated me as a father should be treated are all right.

There's tons of money.

Where's Ned to?'' (unknown)

``He (Ned)'s going to ride in to the surgery for the medicine to stop that cruel pain.'' (unknown)

``Let Humphrey get it.

And send Ned to me instead of Eliza Gollop.

'Tis him (Humphrey) I want--not her (Gollop).'' (She)

She (Gollop) pressed his (Humphrey) hand and kissed him (Humphrey), and went out.

The huge form lay still, breathing slowly.

A fly, wakened out of hibernation by the heat of the fire, buzzed about his (Humphrey) face.

He (Humphrey) swore, and his (Humphrey) scarlet nightcap bobbed as he (Humphrey) moved painfully.

Ned came in, little liking to be there.

He (Ned) lacked the spirit and mental courage for such a time.

``Kill this blasted fly, will `e?

Then get pen and ink.

'Tis a very old custom in our race, Ned, to write our own epitaphs when we can.

I've put mine off and off, along of a silly fancy about doing it; but the time be ripe, and my head's clear.'' (unknown)

``Don't say things like that, father.

You may get better yet.

He (father)'s going to fetch another doctor to-morrow.'' (unknown)

``Let him (father) fetch twenty--they can do nought.

'Tis the last back-heel that none ever stand against.

I don't grumble.

I'm only sorry that 'twas my own son has struck his (son) father.

Death don't matter, but 'tis a bitter death to know the fruit of your loins-- His (son) work I was doing: let him (son) know that--his (son) work.

An old man doing a young man's work.

If Rupert had been here, he (Rupert)'d have been shifting they sacks.

Let none deny it.

'Tis solemn truth.'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

Ned knew the extreme falsity of this impression, but he (Ned) made no effort to contradict his (Ned) father.

``What I done to Tavistock a month agone, I might have undone afore I went,'' (the man)
continued the sick man.

``But not now--not when I remember 'twas his (man) wickedness has hurried me into my grave.

Where be my son Nathan's ship to now?'' (unknown)

``Don't know, father.'' (unknown)

``You ought to know, then.

Him (father) that I would see I can't see; and him (father) that would see me I won't see.'' (unknown)

``You might see him (father), father, for his (father) peace.'' (unknown)

''`Peace'!

Damn his (father) peace!

What peace shall he (father) have that killed his (father) own father?

He (father) don't deserve to look upon me again, and he (father) shan't--living nor dead--mark that.

Tell your mother that when I'm dead, Rupert ban't to see me.

Only the coffin lid shall he (Rupert) see.''

The old man snorted and groaned.

Then he (Rupert) spoke again.

``Have you got pen and ink ready?'' (unknown)

``Yes, father.'' (unknown)

``Turn to the first leaf of the Bible, then, and see my date.'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

Ned opened the family register and read the time of his (Ned) father's birth.

``Born June, died January--and just over the allotted span.

Let me see, how shall the stone read?

There's good things on the Baskerville stones.

`Sacred to the memory of Vivian Baskerville, of Cadworthy Farm, in this parish, yeoman.'

You can begin like that.'' (unknown)

``Shall you say anything about being champion of the west country at wrestling?'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

asked Ned.

``No.

That ban't a thing for the grave--at least, perhaps it might be.

Your uncle, the great musicker, had a fiddle cut `pon his (uncle) stone very clever.

If 'twas thought that the silver belt could be copied upon my slate-- But no, let that pass, 'tis but a small matter.'' (unknown)

``Better leave it to us to think about.

Uncle Nathan will know best.'' (unknown)

``So he (Nathan) will, then.

And we must work in a rhyme, for certain; but first, I've got a fine thought to put down.'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

Ned waited, pen in hand; then his (Ned) father continued to dictate:-- ''`What it pleased the great I AM'--capital letters for I AM--`what it pleased the great I AM to give me in shape of a body in eighteen hundred and eighteen, it likewise pleased Him (father) to call home again in eighteen hundred and eighty-nine.'

How does that sound?''

``Splendid, father.'' (unknown)

``Now there's the rhyme to follow.

I want to work in `breath' and `death' if it can be done.

You ought to be able to do it, seeing all the learning you've had and what it cost.'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

Ned frowned and puzzled.

Then, while Vivian groaned, he (Vivian) had an inspiration, and wrote rapidly.

``How's this, father?'' (he)

he (father) asked.

``It just flashed in my mind.'' (he)

Then he (father) read:--

``Three score years and ten I kept my breath; So long I felt no fear of Death.'' (he)

``It goes very well, but I haven't got no more fear of death now than ever I had.

You must alter that.'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

Silence fell again and Ned mended his (Ned) rhyme.

``How would this answer?'' (he)

he (Ned) asked:--

``Three score years and ten I kept my breath And stood up like a man and feared not Death.'' (he)

``Yes, that's very good indeed.

Now us must make two more lines to finish--that is, if we can be clever enough to think of 'em.'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

Ned's pen squeaked and stopped, squeaked and stopped again.

He (Ned) scratched out and wrote for several minutes.

``Listen to this, father,'' (he)
he (father) said at length, '''tis better even than the first.''

He (father) read once more:--

``Yet now I'm gone, my thread is spun, And I know my God will say, `Well done!''' (He)

``The cleverness of it!

And didn't I always say you were crammed up with cleverness?

But the last line won't do.'' (father)

'''Tis the best of all, father.''

``Won't do, I tell you.

Who be I to know my God will pat me on the back?

Little enough to be pleased with--little enough.

Put, 'I hope my God will say,

``Well done!'' (God)
'''

``You may only hope, but all else know that He (God) will,'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)
declared Ned stoutly.

As he (Ned) finished writing Nathan Baskerville entered with the wife of the sufferer.

Hester brought a cup of hot milk, but Vivian in his (Vivian) excitement would not taste until the epitaph had been rehearsed.

``Ned's thought,'' (he)
he (Ned) said.

``And I helped him (Ned).

And I shall be proud to lie under it--any man might.

Give me the paper.'' (son)

His (man) son handed it to him (man), and he (man) read the rhyme aloud with great satisfaction.

``Three score years and ten I kept my breath, And stood up like a man and feared not Death; Yet now I'm gone, my thread is spun, And I hope my God will say, `Well done!''' (Nat/Uncle Nat)

How's that, Nat?

So good as the musicker's own in my judgment.''

``Splendid!

Splendid!'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)

declared Nathan.

He (Nathan) was much moved.

He (Nathan) blew his (Nathan) nose and went to the window awhile.

Then, Vivian being relieved and fed, the innkeeper returned to him (Vivian) and sat beside him (Vivian).

Hester Baskerville and her (innkeeper) son went out and left the brothers together.

``Us'll talk business, Nat,'' (the man)
said the sick man presently.

``And first I want you to know that you'll have more than your trouble for your pains.

'Tis a common thing with dying people to leave a lot of work behind 'em for somebody to do, and never a penny piece of payment for doing it.

But not me.

There's fifty pound for you, Nat.

I've scrimped in reason all my life.

I've--'' (He)

He (Nat) was stopped by pain.

``Ban't far off, I reckon.

Can't talk much more.

You'll do all right and proper.

I trust my widow and childer to you.

My boy Ned be no good at figures, so I look to you.'' (unknown)

``To the very best of my power I'll do by them all.

Leave that now.

You're the sort who isn't taken unprepared.

I want to say a word about Rupert, if you'll let me.'' (unknown)

``Not a word--not a breath!

That book is closed, not to be opened no more.

You don't want to add another pang to my end, do you?

Let me forget him (Rupert).

I've forgiven him (Rupert)--that's enough.'' (him)

'''Tisn't to forgive him (Rupert), my dear Vivian, if you have cut him (Vivian) off with nought.''

``I'll hear no more!'' (unknown)

cried the other.

``I'll think no more of him (Vivian), nor yet of Humphrey.

'Tis they have cruelly and wickedly wronged me.

'Tis Rupert have brought me here, and hastened me into my grave ten years afore the time, and he (Rupert)'ll have to answer to his (Rupert) God for it.'' (unknown)

``Leave it then--leave it and talk of other things.

You'll like Ned to take Cora Lintern?

You'll like that?

And I shall do something for Cora.

I'm very fond of her (Rupert).'' (unknown)

They talked for half an hour.

Then Vivian cried out for his (Vivian) wife and Nathan left him (Vivian).

That evening Dennis Masterman came to see the farmer, and on the following day he (Masterman) called again.

None knew what passed between them, but it seemed that by some happy inspiration the clergyman achieved what Vivian Baskerville's wife and brother had failed to do.

Dennis had heard, from the master of `The White Thorn,' that the sick man was passing at enmity with his (man) brother and with his (man) son; but he (man) strove successfully against this determination and, before he (man) left Cadworthy, Vivian agreed to see his (Vivian) relations.

The day was already waning when Ned Baskerville himself rode to fetch Rupert, and the lad Humphrey hastened to Hawk House.

Eliza Gollop told the sequel to her (Gollop) brother afterwards.

``It got to be a race towards the end, for the poor man fell away all of a sudden after three o'clock.

Nature gived out, as it will sometimes, like a douted candle.

He (man)'d forgot all about everything afore he (man) died.

Only his (man) grave stuck in his (man) mind, and I read over the epitaph till I was weary of it.

Then he (man) went frightened all of a sudden.

`To think o' me lying there alone among dead folk of evenings, wi' nought but the leather-birds-LSB-1-RSB- squeaking over the graves,' he (man) said.

`You won't be there, my dear,' I told him (man).

`You'll be up where there's no sun nor yet moon, bathing for evermore in the light of righteousness.'

Then he (man) flickered and he (man) flickered, and wandered in his (man) speech, and the last words I could catch was, `What's all this pucker about?

I shall be my own man again in a day or two.'

He (man) was hollow-eyed and his (man) nose growed so sharp as a cobbler's awl, poor dear, and I knowed he (man)'d soon be out of his (man) misery.

His (man) wife was along with him (man) when he (man) died, her (wife) and the two daughters; and poor Hester--Hester I call her (wife), for she (wife) let me use the Christian name without a murmur--she (wife) was cut in half listening to his (Hester) death-rattle o' one side and hoping to hear her (wife) son Rupert gallop up `pon the other.

'Twas a race, as I say; but Rupert had been long ways off to work, and Ned had to find him (Ned), and what with one thing and another, his (Ned) father had been out of the world twenty good minutes afore he (Ned) came.

He (Ned) runned up the stairs white from the clay-works.

But there was only more clay on the bed to welcome him (Ned).

I left 'em at that sacred moment, as my custom is, and went down house, and was just in time to see Humphrey Baskerville ride up in hot haste on his (Baskerville) one-eyed pony.

`How is it with him (Baskerville)?'

he (Baskerville) said, getting off very spry.

'I hope, as he (Baskerville) could send for me, that he (Baskerville) finds hisself better.'

`Not at all,' I answered him (Baskerville).

`The poor man sent because he (man) was worse, and felt himself slipping away.'

`Then I'd best be quick,' he (man) replied to me; and I broke it to him (man) that 'twas too late.

`He (man)'s gone, sir,' I said.

`Like the dew upon the fleece he (man) be gone.

Half an hour ago he (man) died, and suffered very little at the end, so far as a mortal but experienced woman can tell you.'

He (man) stared slap through me, in that awful way he (man) has, then he (man) turned his (man) back and got up on his (man) beast and rode off without a word or a sign.

Lord, He (Lord) knows what that old pony must have thought of it all.

'Twas sweating and staggering, and, no doubt, full of wonder and rage at being pushed along so fast.'' (unknown)

-LSB-1-RSB- Leather-birds --bats.

END OF FIRST BOOK BOOK II CHAPTER I Upon the highway between Cadworthy and the border village of Cornwood there stands an ancient granite cross.

For many years the broken head reposed in the heather; then it was lifted upon the pedestal again and the vanished shaft restored.

To north and south the white road sweeps by it; easterly tower Penshiel and Pen Beacon, and westerly rolls Shaugh Moor.

Here, upon a day one year after the death of Vivian Baskerville, there met two of his (Baskerville) sons, and the conversation that took place between them served roughly to record the development of their affairs, together with the present situation and future interests of the family.

Ned Baskerville was riding home from Cornwood, and his (Baskerville) brother Rupert, knowing that he (Baskerville) must come this way, sat by St. Rumon's Cross, smoked his (Baskerville) pipe and waited.

The younger had found himself forgotten when his (Baskerville) father's will came to be read.

It was a pious fiction with Hester Baskerville that her (himself) husband had striven, when too late, against his (Baskerville) own hasty deed.

She (himself) believed that near his (Baskerville) end the dying man attempted to repair this wrong.

She (himself) declared that his (Baskerville) eyes and his (Baskerville) mutterings both spoke to that effect.

But the fact of disinheritance was all that remained for Rupert to face, and in his (Rupert) bitterness he (Rupert) had turned from his (Rupert) family and continued to toil at the china-clay works, despite his (Rupert) mother's entreaties and Ned's handsome propositions.

Now, however, the case was altered.

After nine months of this unwisdom, Milly prevailed with Rupert to go back to Cadworthy and take her (Milly) with him (Rupert).

His (Rupert) mother was thankful to welcome him (Rupert) home, and Ned did what he (Ned) might to further the prospect.

Rupert stood within sight of marriage, and he (Rupert) and his (Rupert) wife were presently to dwell at Cadworthy.

Then control of the farm would be made over by Ned Baskerville to his (Baskerville) brother.

Now Rupert, in working clothes, sat by the cross.

Opportunity to see Ned was not always easy, for the elder lived a life of pure pleasure and occupied much of his (Ned) time from home.

He (Ned) was only concerned to spend money, but showed no interest in the sciences of administering and making it.

He (Ned) rode up presently, stopped, and, bending over, shook hands with his (Ned) brother, but did not dismount.

``Hullo!

Don't often see you smoking and taking your ease.

Look at my new mare.

Isn't she (mare) a beauty?

But Lord knows what Uncle Nathan will say when I come down upon him (Nathan) for the cash.

And I've got another unpleasant surprise in store for him (Nathan).

I've bought a horse for Cora.

It'll be my wedding-present to her (mare), but she (mare) may as well have it now.'' (unknown)

``Pity we couldn't have all been married together; then one fuss and flare up and expense would have done for the lot of us.'' (unknown)

``I shouldn't have minded; but she (mare) didn't take to the idea at all.

Wants to have a first-prize wedding all to herself.

And about time too.

I'm sick of waiting.'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

As a matter of fact Ned had found no difficulty in suspense.

With possession of money, life's boundaries considerably enlarged for him (Ned), and he (Ned) became a person of increased importance.

Cora was not jealous, and finding Ned extremely generous, she (mare) continued content with the engagement.

The present year was to see her (mare) married, however; but when Nathan Baskerville suggested a triple wedding, Cora objected very strongly.

She (mare) intended that her (mare) nuptials should be in a style considerably grander than those of Milly Luscombe, or Polly Baskerville; but she (Baskerville) finally promised Ned to marry him (Ned) during the following autumn.

``A nice mare,'' (Rupert/Rupert Baskerville)
admitted Rupert;
``she (mare)'s got a temper, though--won't carry beer.

I know the man who used to own her (mare).

She (mare) very near broke his (man) neck for him (man) the night after Cornwood revel.'' (Rupert/Rupert Baskerville)

``The horse isn't foaled that will ever throw me, I believe.'' (unknown)

``I reckon not.

Well, I'm here to meet you, Ned.

I want to run over the ground.

You hate business so bad that 'tis difficult to talk about it with you; but, all the same, as a man with money you must think a bit.'' (unknown)

``Uncle Nathan thinks for me.

He (Nathan) was paid to.

Didn't father leave him (Nathan) fifty pounds to be trustee, or whatever 'tis?'' (unknown)

``But you never will look ahead.

Uncle Nathan, since that bad bout of health last winter, isn't what he (Nathan) was.

Clever enough, I grant; but he (Nathan) has got his (Nathan) own affairs, and his (Nathan) own worries too, for that matter.

Everything be safe and proper in his (Nathan) hands; but suppose he (Nathan) fell ill?

Suppose he (Nathan) was to die?'' (unknown)

``You're such a beggar for supposing.

Never meet troubles half-way--that's my rule, and I've found it work very well too.

I trust Uncle Nathan like the rest of the world trusts him (Nathan).

I sign his (Nathan) blessed papers and I get my quarter's allowance very regular, with a bit of money over and above when I want it, though he (Nathan) grumbles.

I ask for no more but to be allowed to enjoy life as long as I can.'' (unknown)

``I'm going to do this anyway,'' (Rupert/Rupert Baskerville)
said Rupert.

``I'll tell you my hopes and plans.

'Tis right and wise to make plans and look ahead and set yourself a task.

And my task be to get Cadworthy Farm away from you for my own in twenty years from the time I go there.'' (unknown)

``I shan't object--be sure of that.

'Tisn't likely I'd make hard terms with my own brother.

You go in as my tenant at just what rent you please to pay in reason; and you pay me as much over and above the rent as you can afford till the price of the farm is polished off.

And mother stops with you, and May stops with you.

Mother has her (Mother) allowance and May has hers, so they'll be no charge on you.

And I stop too--till I'm married.'' (unknown)

``That's all clear, then.'' (unknown)

``Yes; and what I'm going to do is this.

It seems there are things called sleeping partnerships--jolly convenient things too.

All you do is to find a good, safe, established business that wants a bit of cash.

And you put your cash in, and just go to the business once in a blue moon and sign your name in a book or two and draw your fees, and there you are!

Uncle Nathan's on the look-out for some such a thing for a bit of my money.

And I hope it will be in Plymouth for choice, because Cora's frightfully keen to be near Plymouth.

She (you) wants to make some decent woman pals, naturally.

It's ridiculous such a girl messing about in a hole like Shaugh.

She (girl) hinted at a shop, but I won't have that for a moment.'' (unknown)

``All the same, I don't see why you shouldn't try and look out for something that would give you a bit of work.

Work won't hurt her (girl) or you.

You must be pretty well sick of doing nothing by this time, I should think.'' (unknown)

``Far from it,'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)
declared Ned.

``I find myself quite contented.

I shall turn my hand to work presently.

No hurry that I can see.

I'm learning a lot, remember that.

A great learner I am.

The first use of money is to learn the world, Rupert.

That's where that old fool at Hawk House has messed up his (House) life.

No better than a miser, that man.

A spendthrift may be a fool, but a miser always is.

And so it comes back to the fact that Uncle Humphrey's a fool, as I always said he (Humphrey) was--a fool and a beast both.'' (unknown)

``He (Humphrey)'s different enough from Uncle Nathan, I grant you--can't be soft or gentle; but he (Nathan)'s no fool, and though he (Nathan) pretends he (Nathan)'s not interested in people, he (Nathan) is.

Things slip out.

Look how he (Nathan) reads the newspapers.'' (unknown)

``Yet now, for very hatred of all human beings--it can't be for anything else--'tis rumoured he (Nathan)'ll leave Hawk House and get away from the sight of roads even.

Susan Hacker told mother, not a week agone, that he (Nathan) was getting restless to go farther off.

Pity he (Nathan) don't go and stick his (Nathan) head in Cranmere, and choke himself, and leave you and me and a few other dashing blades to spend his (Nathan) money.

We ought to be his (Nathan) heirs--all of us.

But we shan't see the colour of his (Nathan) cash, mark me.'' (unknown)

``You won't.

He (Nathan) hates your way of life.

But he (Nathan)'s got no quarrel with the rest of us.

You never know with a man like him (man).

I'm going over to him (man) now; and I've got a tale of a chap that's broke his (chap) legs.

He (chap) may give me five shillings for the man's wife.

He (chap)'s done it before to-day.

'Tis in him (chap) to do kind things, only there's no easy outlet for 'em.

Keeps his (chap) goodness bottled up, as if he (chap) was afraid of it.'' (unknown)

``You've got his (chap) blind eye, I reckon,'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)
said Ned.

``It's all up with me anyway.

I look t`other way when I pass him (Ned).

He (Ned)'ll never forgive me for marrying Cora.'' (unknown)

``Well, you'd best to go on and not keep your horse dancing about no longer.'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

Ned galloped off, and his (Ned) brother, having sat a little longer by St. Rumon's Cross, rose and struck over Shaugh Moor in the direction of Humphrey Baskerville's dwelling.

The old man was expecting his (man) nephew and came upon the waste to meet him (man).

They had not spoken together for many days and Rupert was glad to see the elder again.

A year had stamped its record upon Humphrey Baskerville, and the significance of his (Baskerville) son's death might now be perceived.

Mark's passing left a permanent scar, but the expected callosity of spirit by no means overtook the sufferer.

Man, if he (Man) did not delight him (Man), bulked upon his (Man) mind as the supreme experience.

It was an added tribulation that, upon his (Man) brother's estrangement and death, one of the few living beings with whom he (Man) enjoyed the least measure of intimacy had dropped out of his (Man) life.

And now he (Man) became increasingly sensitive to the opinion of the people and developed a morbidity that was new.

Mrs. Hacker was his (Man) frank intelligencer, and more than once he (Man) smarted to hear her (Hacker) tell how sensible men had spoken ill of him (Man).

Now he (Man) fell into talk with Rupert and uttered the things uppermost in his (Rupert) mind.

``Well enough in body, but sometimes I doubt if my brain's all it used to be.

Mayhap in the head is where I'll go first.'' (Rupert/Rupert Baskerville)

Rupert laughed.

``Not much fear of that, uncle.'' (unknown)

``You must know,'' (unknown)
answered the other,
``that every man in this life has to suffer a certain amount of injustice.

From the king on his (king) throne to the tinker in his (king) garret, there are thorns stuffed in all pillows.

Human nature misunderstands itself at every turn, and the closest, life-long friends often catch their secret hearts full of wonder and surprise at each other.

But I--I've had more than my share of that.

The injustice that's heaped upon me is insufferable at times.

And why?

Because I don't carry my heart on my sleeve, and won't palter with truth at the world's bidding.'' (fools)

'''Tis only fools laugh at you or grumble at you.''

``You're wrong there,'' (Humphrey/Humphrey Baskerville/HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE)
answered Humphrey.

``The scorn of fools and the snarl of evil lips are a healthy sign.

There are some men and some dogs that I would rather bark at me than not.

But how is it that wise men and understanding men hold aloof and say hard things and look t`other way when I pass by?'' (unknown)

``Lord knows,'' (Rupert/Rupert Baskerville)
answered Rupert.

``They'm too busy to think for themselves, I suppose, and take the general opinion that you're rather--rather unsociable.

You do many and many a kind thing, but they ban't known.'' (unknown)

``No I don't.

I can't--'tisn't my nature.

Kind things are often terrible silly things.

Leave your Uncle Nathan to do the kind things.

He (Nathan) did a kind thing when my son died; and I felt it.

For warmth of heart there never was such another.

The trouble that man takes for people is very fine to see.

I'm not saying he (man)'s wise.

In fact, I don't think he (man) is wise.

To do other folks' work for 'em and shelter 'em from the results of their own folly is to think you know better than God Almighty.'' (unknown)

``He (Almighty)'s wonderful good, I'm sure.

A godsend to my mother.

Taken all the business over for her (mother).

When father died--'' (unknown)

``Leave that.

Keep on about his (father) character,'' (Humphrey/Humphrey Baskerville/HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE)

said Humphrey.

``There's nought so interesting to a man like me as burrowing into human nature and trying the works.

Now, in your Uncle Nathan you see one that has the cleverness to make nearly every human being like him (Nathan) and trust him (Nathan).

But how does he (Nathan) get his (Nathan) hold on the heart?

Is it by shutting his (Nathan) eyes to what people really are, like I shut my ears to Jack Head's arguments against the Bible; or is it by sheer, stupid, obstinate goodness, that can't see the weakness and folly and wickedness and craft of human beings?'' (unknown)

``He (Head) puts a large trust in his (Head) fellow-creatures,'' (Rupert/Rupert Baskerville)
answered Rupert.

``He (Head) believes everybody is good till he (Head)'s proved 'em bad.'' (Humphrey/Humphrey Baskerville/HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE)

Humphrey nodded.

``True enough, and I'll tell you what that means in Nathan.

The real secret of sympathy in this world is to be a sinner yourself.

There's no end to the toleration and forgiveness and large-mindedness of people, if they know in their own hearts that they be just as bad.

A wise man hedges, and never will be shocked at anything--why?

Because he (man) says, 'I may be found out too, some day.''' (He)

He (man) broke off and his (man) nephew spoke.

``I know you're just as kind, really.

By the same token I've come begging to-day.

A poor Cornwood chap has had a bad accident.

Market merry he (chap) was and got throwed off his (chap) pony.

He (chap)'s in hospital with both legs broke and may not recover, and his (chap) wife and four children--'' (unknown)

``What about his (chap) club?'' (unknown)

``He (chap) wasn't a member of a club.'' (unknown)

``What's his (chap) name?'' (unknown)

``Coombes.'' (unknown)

``Drunk too?

And you ask me to take my money and help that sort of man?

But I won't.'' (unknown)

``Perhaps, in strict justice, he (man) don't deserve it; but--'' (unknown)
``Did you ask your Uncle Nathan for him (Nathan)?'' (unknown)

``Yes.

It shows the difference between you, I suppose.'' (unknown)

``He (Nathan) gave?'' (unknown)

``He (Nathan) gave me ten shillings.

There's a nice point to argify about.

Which of you was right, Uncle Humphrey--you or Uncle Nat?

You can't both be right.'' (unknown)

``We can both be right and both be wrong,'' (the man)
answered the old man.

``Uncle Nat was preaching at the chapel a bit ago, afore he (Nat) had his (Nat) illness; and me and Milly went to hear him (Nat).'' (unknown)

``He (Nat) preaches, does he (Nat)?'' (unknown)

``Now and again--to work off his (Nat) energy, he (Nat) says.

But never no more will he (Nat).

His (Nat) voice won't stand it, he (Nat) says.

He (Nat) chose for his (Nat) text a question, and he (Nat) said 'twas a simple and easy thing, afore we took any step in life, to ax ourselves and say, what would the Lord do?'' (unknown)

``Simple enough to ask--not so simple to answer.'' (unknown)

``He (Lord) seemed to think 'twas as simple to answer as to ask.'' (unknown)

``His (Lord) brain isn't built to see the difficulties.

Jack Head laughs at all these here Tory Christians.

He (Head) says that a man can no more be a Tory and a Christian than he (Tory) can walk on water.

He (Tory) says, flat out, that Christ was wrong here and there--right down wrong.

Mind, I don't say so; but Head will argue for it very strong if you'll let him (Christ).'' (unknown)

``Uncle Nat wouldn't hear of that.'' (unknown)

``Nor would I. I've got as much faith as my brother.

And as to what Christ would do or would not do in any given case, 'tis a matter for very close reasoning, because we act only seeing the outside of a puzzle; He (Christ) would act seeing the inside.

To say that we always know what the Lord would do, is to say we're as wise as Him (Lord).

To go to the Bible for an answer to trouble is right enough though.

'Tis like a story I read in a wise book a few nights agone; for I've taken to reading a terrible lot of books lately.

It told how two fellows fell out and fought like a pair of martin-cats over a bit of ground.

Each said 'twas his (Lord), and presently they carried their trouble to a wise king, as reigned over a near nation, and was always happy to talk sense to anybody who had the time to listen.

So to the neighbour kingdom they went, and yet never got to the king at all.

And why not?

Because, so soon as they were in his (king) land, they found the spirit and wisdom of him (king) working like barm in bread throughout the length and breadth of the place.

They saw peace alive.

They saw the people living in brotherly love and unity and understanding.

They saw the religion of give and take at work.

They saw travellers yielding the path to each other; they saw kindness and goodness and patience the rule from the cradle to the grave; and they felt so terrible ashamed of their own little pitiful quarrel that they dursn't for decency take it afore the throne, but made friends there and then and shared the strip of earth between 'em.

And so 'tis with the Bible, Rupert: you bring a trouble into the Lord's kingdom and you'll find, in the clear light shining there, that it quickly takes a shape to shame you.'' (Nat/Uncle Nat)

'''Tis pretty much what Uncle Nat said in other words.

But didn't it ought to make you give me ten shillings for Coombes?''

'''Tisn't for us to stand between the State and its work.''

``But his (Coombes) wife and children?'' (unknown)

``The sins of the fathers are visited on the children.

Who are we to come between God Almighty and His (Almighty) laws?'' (Rupert/Rupert Baskerville)

Rupert shrugged his (Rupert) shoulders.

``Christ Almighty would have done--what?'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

asked Mr. Baskerville.

Rupert reflected.

``He (Rupert)'d have done something, for certain.

Why, of course!

He (Rupert)'d have healed the man's broken legs first!'' (unknown)

``And that's what mankind is doing as best it can.'' (unknown)

``And if the man dies?'' (unknown)

``Then the State will look after his (man) leavings.'' (unknown)

``You're justice itself,'' (Rupert/Rupert Baskerville)
said Rupert;
``but man's justice be frosty work.'' (Rupert/Rupert Baskerville)

``That's right enough.

Justice and mercy is the difference between God and Christ.

The one's a terrible light to show the way and mark the rock and point the channel through the storm; but `twill dazzle your eyes if you see it too close, remember.

And t`other's to the cold heart what a glowing fire be to the cold body.'' (unknown)

``And I say that Uncle Nathan's just that--a glowing, Christlike sort of man,'' (unknown)
declared the younger fervently.

``Say so and think so,'' (uncle)
answered his (man) uncle.

``He (man) stands for mercy; and I'll never say again that he (man) stands for mercy, because he (man) knows he (man)'ll stand in need of mercy.

I'll never say that again.

And I stand for justice, and hope I'll reap as I have sowed--neither better nor worse.

But between my way and Nathan's way is yet another way; and if I could find it, then I should find the thing I'm seeking.'' (unknown)

``The way of justice and mercy together, I suppose you mean?'' (unknown)

``I suppose I do.

But I've never known how to mix 'em and keep at peace with my own conscience.

Justice is firm ground; mercy is not.

Man knows that very well.

We may please our fellow-creatures with it; but for my part, so far as I have got till now, I'm prone to think that mercy be God's work only--same as vengeance is.

For us 'tis enough that we try to be just, and leave all else in higher hands.

Life ban't a pretty thing, and you can't hide its ugliness by decorating it with doubtful mercies, that may look beautiful to the eye but won't stand the stark light of right.'' (unknown)

``Justice makes goodness a bit hard at the edges, however,'' (nephew)
answered his (God) nephew.

``And when all's said, if mercy be such treacherous ground, who can deny that justice may give way under us too now and again?'' (Hawk House/House)

They now stood at the door of Hawk House.

``Enter in,'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)
said Mr. Baskerville.

``You argue well, and there's a lot in what you say.

And words come all to this, as the rivers come all to the sea, that we know nothing, outside Revelation.

And now let's talk about your affairs.

When is your marriage going to be?

Has Milly Luscombe said she (Luscombe) wants me to come to it?

Answer the truth.'' (Dennis/Masterman/Dennis Masterman)

CHAPTER II Dennis Masterman took the opportunity that offered after a service to meet his (Masterman) parish clerk and perambulate the churchyard.

For the vicar's sister had pointed out that the burying-ground of St. Edward's was ill-kept and choked with weeds.

Overhead the bells made mighty riot.

Two weddings had just been celebrated, and the ringers were doing their best.

``With spring here again, this place will be a scandal,'' (Dennis/Masterman/Dennis Masterman)
said Dennis.

``You must set to work in earnest, Gollop, and if it's more than you can do single-handed, you'd better get help.'' (unknown)

``Hay is hay,'' (unknown)
answered the other;
``and the Reverend Valletort was above any fidgets like what some people suffer from nowadays.

He (Valletort) had the churchyard hay as his (Valletort) right in his (Valletort) opinion, and, given a good year, us made a tidy little rick for him (Valletort).

`All flesh is grass,' he (Valletort) used to say in his (Valletort) wise fashion, `and grass is not the less grass because it comes off a man's grave.''' (unknown)

``I think differently.

To make hay in a churchyard, Thomas, is very bad form, and shows a lack of proper and delicate feeling.

Anyway, there's to be a thorough clean-up.

We've got a lot of very interesting graves here, and when people come and ask to see the churchyard I don't like wading through a foot of weeds.

Where's the famous tomb with the music book and bass viol on it?

I wanted to show it to a man only last week, and couldn't find it.'' (Mr. Gollop/Gollop)

Mr. Gollop led the way and indicated a slate amid the Baskerville monuments.

``There 'tis.

A riddle and an open book; and the book actually had a bit of the Old Hundredth--the music, I mean--scratched on it when first 'twas set up.

But time have eaten that off, I believe.

He (Gollop) was a fine fiddler in the days afore the organs was put in the church, and then he (Gollop) had to go; and he (Gollop) soon died after the joy of playing on Sundays was taken from him (Gollop).
