He (Gollop) made up his (Gollop) verse himself.'' (Mr. Gollop/Gollop)

Mr. Gollop drew back the herbage from this slate and read out the rhyme half hidden beneath.

''`Praises on tombs are to no purpose spent, A man's good name is his (man) own monument.'

``But a good name don't last as long as a good slate, when all's said.

There's Vivian Baskerville's stone, you see.

'Tis a great addition to the row, and cost seven pounds odd.

And there lieth the suicide, as should be yonder if justice had been done.

But Humphrey Baskerville don't mean to take his (Baskerville) place in the family row.

Like him (Baskerville), that is.

Won't even neighbour with his (Baskerville) fellow dust.'' (unknown)

``You oughtn't to repeat such nonsense, Gollop.'' (unknown)

``Nonsense or no nonsense, 'tis the truth.

Here's the place he (Baskerville)'s chosen, and bought it, too, right up in this corner, away from everybody; and his (Baskerville) gravestone is to turn its back upon t`other dead folk--like he (Baskerville)'s always turned his (Baskerville) back upon the living.'' (Mr. Gollop/Gollop)

Mr. Gollop indicated a lonely corner of the churchyard.

``That's where he (Gollop)'s going to await the trump.'' (unknown)

``Well, that's his (Gollop) business, poor man.

He (Gollop)'s a good Christian, anyway.'' (unknown)

``If coming to church makes him (Gollop) so, he (Gollop) may be; but Christian is as Christian does in my opinion.

Show me a man or beast as be the better for Humphrey Baskerville, and I'll weigh up what sort of Christian he (Christian) may be.'' (unknown)

``Judge nobody; but get this place respectable and tidy.

No half measures, Gollop.

And you'll have to work out all those unknown mounds with a pair of shears.

They are running together, and will disappear in a year or two.

And that pile of broken slates in the corner had better be carted away altogether.

You ought to know the graves they belong to, but of course you don't.'' (unknown)

``No, I don't, and more don't any other living man.

I ban't God Almighty, I believe.

'Tis Miss Masterman have put you on to harrying me out of my seven senses this way, and I wish she (Masterman)'d mind her (Masterman) own business and let me mind mine.'' (unknown)

``No need to be insolent.

I only ask you to mind your own business.

If you'd do that we should never have a word.'' (Mr. Gollop/Gollop)

Mr. Gollop grunted rudely.

When conquered in argument he (Gollop) always reserved to himself, not the right of final speech, but the licence of final sound.

On these occasions he (Gollop) uttered a defiant, raucous explosion, pregnant with contempt and scorn, then he (Gollop) hurried away.

At times, under exceptional stress, he (Gollop) would also permit himself an offensive gesture before departing.

This consisted in lifting his (Gollop) coat-tail and striking the part of his (Gollop) person that occurred beneath it.

But such an insult was reserved for his (Gollop) acquaintance; obviously it might not be exploited against the vicar of the parish.

Now Gollop marched off to `The White Thorn,' and Masterman, turning, found that the man of whom they had recently spoken walked alone not far off.

Dennis instantly approached him (Dennis).

It was his (Dennis) wish to know this member of his (Dennis) congregation better, but opportunity to do so had been denied.

Now there was no escape for Humphrey Baskerville, because the minister extended his (minister) hand and saluted him (minister).

``How do you do, Mr. Baskerville?

Glad to see you.

A pretty pair of weddings, and two very popular young couples, I fancy.'' (Humphrey/Humphrey Baskerville/HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE)

Humphrey admitted it.

``There's no better or harder working man about here than my nephew Rupert Baskerville,'' (he)
he (Baskerville) said.

``So I understand.

Not much of a church-goer, though, I'm afraid.

However, perhaps he (Baskerville)'ll come oftener now.

The bells make the tower shake, I do believe.

We've never had the tenor bell rung like your son rang it, Mr.

Baskerville.'' (The man)

The old man shrugged his (man) shoulders.

``I always fancy so; but then, I've a right to fancy so.

I was his (man) father.

No doubt 'tis folly.

One pair of hands can pull a rope as well as another.

But `as the heart thinketh, so the bell clinketh,' though the heart of man is generally wrong.

My son would have done his (son) best to-day, no doubt, though such was his (son) nature that he (son)'d sooner toll alone than peal in company.'' (unknown)

``Are you going to the wedding breakfast?'' (unknown)

``Yes; not that they really want me.

'Twas only because the boys and girls wouldn't take `no' for an answer that I go.

I doubt whether they're in earnest.

But I'm glad to be there too.'' (unknown)

``Who was the fine young brown fellow in the Baskerville pew beside Mrs.

Baskerville?'' (unknown)

``Nathan Baskerville the younger.

Called after my brother, the innkeeper.

He (Baskerville)'s just off the sea for a bit.'' (unknown)

``A handsome man.'' (unknown)

``He (man) is for certain.'' (unknown)

``Well, I'm very glad to meet you.

I was telling Gollop that our graves are not worthy of us.

We must make the churchyard tidier.'' (Dennis/Masterman/Dennis Masterman)

They had reached the lich-gate and Dennis held Mr. Baskerville's pony while he (Baskerville) mounted it.

``Thank you,'' (unknown)
said the elder.

``By the way, I've never called at Hawk House, because I've been told you wouldn't care about it.'' (unknown)

``As to that, 'tisn't whether I'd care or not, 'tis whether you ought to call or not.'' (unknown)

``You're right.

Then come I shall.

How about next Friday?'' (unknown)

``I shall be there.'' (unknown)

``I hear you're a great reader, Mr. Baskerville.

I might lend you some of my books--and gladly would do so, if you'd care to have them.'' (unknown)

``Thank you, I'm sure.

A kindly thought in you.

'Tis no great art to think kindly; but let the thought blossom out into a deed and it grows alive.

Yes, I read a lot now since my son died.

Jack Head is a reading man, likewise; but he (Head) reads terrible dangerous books.

He (Head) lent me one and I burnt it.

Yes, I burnt it, and told him (Head) so.'' (unknown)

``Probably you were right.'' (unknown)

``No, I wasn't.

He (Head) showed me very clearly that I was wrong.

You can't burn a book.

A bad book once out in the world is like a stone once flung--it belongs to the devil.

Not but what Jack Head says many things that can't be answered--worse luck.'' (unknown)

``I wish he (Head)'d bring his (Head) difficulties to me.'' (unknown)

``You needn't wish that.

He (Head)'s got no difficulties.

He (Head)'s going with the wind and tide.

'Tis you, not him (Head)--'tis you and me, and the likes of us--that will be in difficulties afore long.

I see that plain enough.

'Tis idle to be blind.

I shall die a Christian, and so will you, and so belike will your childer, if ever you get any; but all's in a welter of change now, and very like your grandchilder will think 'twas terrible funny to have a parson for a grandfather.

Jack Head says they'll put stuffed curates in the British Museum afore three generations.'' (unknown)

``A free-thought wave,'' (Dennis/Masterman/Dennis Masterman)
said Dennis.

``Be under no concern, Mr. Baskerville.

Christianity is quite unassailable.

Remember the Rock it's founded on.'' (unknown)

'''Tis the rock it will split on be the thing to consider.

However, if you've got any books that stand for our side, I shall thank you to lend 'em to me.

Jack's had it all his (Jack) own way of late.''

``I'll bring some,'' (Dennis/Masterman/Dennis Masterman)
declared Masterman.

They parted, and Humphrey trotted off on his (Humphrey) pony.

Meantime at `The White Thorn' a considerable gathering had met to discuss the weddings, and Nathan Baskerville, his (Baskerville) namesake, the sailor, Heathman Lintern, Joe Voysey, and others enjoyed a morning drink.

For some the entertainment was now ended, but not a few had been bidden to the feast at Cadworthy, where a double banquet was planned, and many would soon set out on foot or in market-carts for the farm.

``One may hope for nought but good of these here weddings,'' (Joe Voysey/Joe/Voysey)
said Voysey.

``There's only one danger in my judgment, and that is for two of the young people to set up living with the bridegroom's mother; but Rupert ban't Hester Baskerville's favourite son, I believe.

If he (son) was it certainly wouldn't work.

The poor chap would be pulled in two pieces between mother and wife.

However, if the mother ban't jealous of him (chap), it may do pretty well.'' (unknown)

``When Master Ned marries, he (Ned)'ll have to go a bit further off,'' (the innkeeper)
said the innkeeper.

``How is it brother Ned ban't married a`ready?'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)

asked the younger Nathan.

``Why, 'tis more than a year agone since I heard from my sister that he (Nathan) was going to marry Heathman's sister, and yet nothing done.

I'd make her (sister) name the day jolly quick if 'twas me.'' (Heathman/Heathman Lintern)

Heathman laughed and shook his (Nathan) head.

``No, you wouldn't, Nat.

You don't know Cora.

None will hurry her (sister) if she (sister)'s not minded to hurry.

Ned has done what he (Ned) could, and so have I--and so has my mother.

But she (mother)'s in no haste.

Likes being engaged and making plans, getting presents, and having a good time and being important.'' (unknown)

``The autumn will see them married, however,'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)
declared Mr. Baskerville.

``I've told Master Ned that he (Baskerville)'ll have to draw in his (Baskerville) horns a bit, for he (Baskerville)'s not made of money, though he (Baskerville) seems to think so.

`Twill be his (Baskerville) best economy to marry pretty quick and settle down.

Never was a man with wilder ideas about money; but Cora's different.

She (Baskerville)'s a woman with brains.

He (Cora)'ll do well to hand her (Baskerville) over the purse.'' (unknown)

``She (Baskerville) wants to start a shop at Plymouth,'' (Heathman/Heathman Lintern)
said Heathman.

``A shop for hats and women's things.

But Ned's against it.

He (Ned) says she (Baskerville) shan't work--not while he (Ned) can help it; and as he (Ned) certainly won't work himself while he (Ned) can help it, we must hope they've got tons of money.'' (unknown)

``Which they have not,'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)
answered Nathan Baskerville.

``And the sooner Ned understands that and gives ear to me, the better for his (Ned) peace of mind.'' (Mr. Gollop/Gollop)

Mr. Gollop entered at this moment.

He (Gollop) was ruffled and annoyed.

``That man!'' (he)

he (man) moaned,

``that headstrong, rash man will be the death of me yet.

Of course, I mean Masterman.

Won't let the dead rest in their graves now.

Wants the churchyard turned into a pleasure-ground seemingly.

Must be mowing and hacking and tacking and trimming; and no more hay; and even they old holy slates in the corner to be carted off as if they was common stones.'' (he)

``Lie low and do nought,'' (Joe Voysey/Joe/Voysey)
advised Joe Voysey.

'''Tis a sort of fever that takes the gentleman off and on.

He (gentleman) catches the fit from his (gentleman) sister.

She (sister)'ll be down on me sometimes, with all her (sister) feathers up and everything wrong.

I must set to that instant moment and tidy the garden for my dear life, till not a blade be out of place.

Likes to see the grass plot so sleek as a boy's head after Sunday pomatum.

But the way is to listen with all due and proper attention, as becomes us afore our betters, and then--forget it.

The true kindness and charity be to let 'em have their talk out, and even meet 'em in little things here and there--if it can be done without loss of our self-respect.

But we understand best.

Don't you never forget that, Thomas.

Where the yard and the garden be concerned, you and me must be first in the land.

They be children to us, and should be treated according.

We've forgot more than they ever knowed about such things.''

Others came and went; Joe and Thomas matured their Fabian tactics; Nathan Baskerville, with his (Baskerville) nephew and young Lintern, set off in a pony trap for Cadworthy.

The bells still rioted and rang their ceaseless music; for these new-made wives and husbands were being honoured with the long-drawn, melodious thunder of a full five-bell `peal.'

CHAPTER III Cora Lintern waited for Ned Baskerville at the fork of the road above Shaugh.

Here, in the vicarage wall, the stump of a village cross had been planted.

Round about stitchwort flashed its spring stars, and foxgloves made ready, while to the shattered symbol clung ivy tighter than ever lost sinner seeking sanctuary.

Upon a stone beneath sat the woman in Sunday finery, and she (woman) was beautiful despite her (woman) garments.

They spoke of untutored taste and a mind ignorantly attracted by the garish and the crude.

But her (woman) face was fair until examined at near range.

Then upon the obvious beauty, like beginning of rust in the leaf, there appeared delicate signs of the spirit within.

Her (woman) eyes spoke unrest and her (woman) mouth asperity.

The shadow of a permanent line connected her (woman) eyebrows and promised a network too soon to stretch its web, woven by the spiders of discontent, upon her (woman) forehead.

Cora built always upon to-morrow, and she (woman) suffered the fate of those that do so.

She (woman) was ambitious and vain, and she (woman) harboured a false perspective in every matter touching her (woman) own welfare, her (woman) own desert, and her (woman) own position in the world.

She (woman) largely overrated her (woman) beauty and her (woman) talents.

She (woman) was satisfied with Ned Baskerville, but had ceased to be enthusiastic about him (Baskerville).

A year of his (Baskerville) society revealed definite limitations, and she (woman) understood that though her (woman) husband was well-to-do, he (husband) would never be capable.

The power to earn money did not belong to him (husband), and she (woman) rated his (husband) windy optimisms and promises at their just value.

She (woman) perceived that the will and intellect were hers, and she (woman) knew that, once married, he (husband) would follow and not lead.

The advantage of this position outweighed the disadvantages.

She (woman) desired to live in a town, and rather favoured the idea of setting up a shop, to be patronised by the local leaders of rank and fashion.

She (woman) loved dress, and believed herself possessed of much natural genius in matters sartorial.

At present Ned absolutely refused any suggestion of a shop; but she (woman) doubted not that power rested with her (woman) presently to insist, if she (woman) pleased to do so.

He (Ned) was a generous and fairly devout lover.

He (Ned) more than satisfied her (woman) requirements in that direction.

She (woman) had, indeed, cooled his (Ned) ardour a little, and she (woman) supposed that her (woman) common-sense was gradually modifying his (Ned) amorous disposition.

But another's common-sense is a weak weapon against lust, and Ned's sensual energies, dammed by Cora, found secret outlet elsewhere.

So it came about that he (Cora) endured the ordeal of the lengthy engagement without difficulty, and the girl wore his (Cora) fancied sobriety and self-control as a feather in her (girl) cap.

When she (girl) related her (girl) achievement to Ned and explained to him (Ned) how much his (Ned) character already owed to her (girl) chastening influence, he (Ned) admitted it without a blush, and solemnly assured her (girl) that she (girl) had changed his (Ned) whole attitude to the sex.

Now the man arrived, and they walked together by Beatland Corner, southerly of Shaugh, upon the moor-edge.

Their talk was of the autumn wedding and the necessity for some active efforts to decide their domicile.

Cora was for a suburb of Plymouth, but Ned wanted to live in the country outside.

The shop she (girl) did not mention after his (Ned) recent strong expressions of aversion from it; but she (girl) desired the first step to be such that transition to town might easily follow, when marriage was accomplished and her (girl) power became paramount.

They decided, at length, to visit certain places that stood between town and country above Plymouth.

There were Stoke and Mannamead to see.

A villa was Cora's ambition--a villa and two servants.

Ned's instincts, on the other hand, led to a small house and a large stable.

He (Ned) owned some horses and took great part of his (Ned) pleasure upon them.

Since possession of her (girl) own steed, however, Cora's regard for riding had diminished.

It was her (girl) way to be quickly satisfied with a new toy.

Now she (girl) spoke of a `victoria,' so that when she (girl) was married she (girl) might drive daily upon her (girl) shopping and her (girl) visiting.

``The thing is to begin well,'' (she)
she (girl) said.

``People call according to your house, and often the difference between nice blinds and common blinds will decide women whether they'll visit a newcomer or not.

With my taste you can trust the outside of your home to look all right, Ned.

At Mannamead I saw the very sort of house I'd like for us to have.

Such a style, and I couldn't think what 'twas about it till I saw the short blinds was all hung in bright shining brass rods across the windows, and the window-boxes was all painted peacock-blue.

`I'll have my house just like that!'

I thought.'' (unknown)

``So you shall--or any colour you please.

And I'll have my stable smart too, I promise you.

White tiles all through.

I shall have to do a bit myself, you know--looking after the horses, I mean--but nobody will know it.'' (unknown)

``You'll keep a man, of course?'' (unknown)
'

``A cheap one.

Uncle Nathan went into figures with me last week.

He (Nathan) was a bit vague, and I was a bit impatient and soon had enough of it.

`All I want to know,' I told him (Nathan), `is just exactly what income I can count upon,' and he (Nathan) said five hundred a year was the outside figure.

Then, against that, you must set that he (Nathan)'s getting a bit old and, of course, being another person's money, he (Nathan)'s extra cautious.

He (Nathan) admitted that if I sold out some shares and bought others, I could get pretty near another one hundred a year by it.

But, of course, we've got to take a bite out of the money for furnishing and all the rest of it.

My idea, as you know, is to invest a bit in a sleeping partnership, but he (Nathan) hasn't found anything of the sort yet, apparently.

He (Nathan)'s not the man he (Nathan) was at finding a bargain.'' (Cora/Cora Lintern/Lintern)

Here opened a good opportunity for her (it) ambitions, and Cora ventured to take it.

``I wish you'd think twice about letting me start a little business.

It's quite a ladylike thing, or I wouldn't offer it, but with my natural cleverness about clothes, and with all the time I've given to the fashions and all that--especially with the hats I can make--it seems a pity not to let me do it.

You don't want much money to start with, and I should soon draw the custom.'' (unknown)

``No,'' (he)
he (Cora) said.

``Time enough if ever we get hard up.

I'm not going to have you making money.

'Tis your business to spend it.

You'll be a lady, with your own servants and all the rest of it.

You'll walk about, and pick the flowers in your garden, and pay visits; and if you do have a little trap, you can drive out to the meets sometimes when I go hunting.

Why, damn it all, Cora, I should have thought you was the last girl who would ever want to do such a thing!'' (unknown)

``That's all you know,'' (she)
she (girl) said.

``People who keep hat shops often get in with much bigger swells than ever we're likely to know at Mannamead, or Stoke either.

They come into the shop and they see, of course, I'm a lady, and I explain that I only keep the shop for fun, and then I get to know them.

I'd make more swell friends in my hat shop than ever you do on your horse out fox-hunting.'' (unknown)

``I know a lot of swells, for that matter.'' (unknown)

``Ask 'em to come to tea and then you'll see if you know 'em,'' (she)
she (lady) said.

'''Tis no use for us to be silly.

We're poor people, compared to rich ones, and we always shall be, so far as I can see.

We must be content with getting up the ladder a bit--and that's all I ask or expect.''

``I know my place all right, if that's what you mean,'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)
answered Ned.

``I'm not anxious to get in with my betters, for they're not much use to me.

I'm easily satisfied.

I want for you to have a good time, and I mean for myself to have a good time.

You can only live your life once, and a man's a fool to let worry come into his (fool) life if he (fool) can escape from it.

The great thing in the world is to find people who think as you do yourself.

That's worth a bit of trouble; and when you've found them, stick to them.

A jolly good motto too.'' (an acquaintance)

They spilt words to feeble purpose for another half-hour, and then there came an acquaintance.

Timothy Waite appeared on his (Waite) way from Coldstone Farm.

He (Waite) overtook them and walked beside them.

``I suppose you don't want company,'' (he)
he (Waite) said,
``but I'll leave you half a mile further on.'' (he)

``We do want company, and always shall,'' (Cora/Cora Lintern/Lintern)
declared Cora.

``And yours most of all, I'm sure.

We're past the silly spooning stage.

In fact, we never got into it, did we, Edward?'' (unknown)

``You didn't,'' (betrothed)
said her (Waite) betrothed,
``and as you didn't, I couldn't.

Spooning takes two.'' (betrothed)

Mr. Waite remained a bachelor and no woman had ever been mentioned in connection with him (Waite).

He (Waite) was highly eligible and, indeed, a husband much to be desired.

He (husband) enjoyed prosperity, good looks, and a reputation for sense and industry.

Cora he (Cora) had always admired, and still did so.

At heart he (Cora) wondered why she (woman) had chosen Ned Baskerville, and sometimes, since the marriage hung fire, he (Cora) suspected that she (woman) was not entirely satisfied of her (woman) bargain and might yet change her (woman) mind.

He (Cora) would have married her (woman) willingly, for there was that in her (woman) practical and unsentimental character which appealed to him (character).

He (character) had indeed contemplated proposing when the announcement of young Baskerville's engagement reached him (Baskerville).

He (Baskerville) met Cora sometimes and always admired her (woman) outlook on life.

He (Baskerville) did so now, yet knowing Ned too, doubted at heart whether the woman had arrested his (Ned) propensities as completely as she (woman) asserted.

``The question on our lips when you came along was where we should set up shop,'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)
said Ned.

``A shop is what I really and truly want to set up,'' (Cora/Cora Lintern/Lintern)
declared Cora;
``but Edward won't hear of it--more fool him (Edward), I say.

He (Edward) can't earn money, but that's no reason why I shouldn't try to.'' (Cora/Cora Lintern/Lintern)

Mr. Waite entirely agreed with her (woman).

``No reason why you shouldn't.

If Cadworthy's to be handed over to Rupert and you're going to live in Plymouth, as I hear,'' (he)

he (Rupert) said,
``then why not business?

There's nothing against it that I know, and there's nothing like it.

If I wasn't a farmer, I'd keep a shop.

For that matter a farmer does keep a shop.

Only difference that I can see is that he (farmer) has fields instead of cupboards and loses good money through the middleman between him (farmer) and his (farmer) customers.

I'm going to take another stall in Plymouth market after Midsummer.

There's nought like market work for saving cash.'' (he)

``And as nearly half our money will come from the rent that Rupert pays for Cadworthy, we shall be living by a shop in a sense whether you pretend to or not,'' (Cora/Cora Lintern/Lintern)
added Cora.

But Ned denied this.

He (Ned) aired his (Ned) views on political economy, while Waite, who valued money, yet valued making it still more, reduced the other's opinions to their proper fatuity and laughed at him (Waite) into the bargain.

Timothy's contempt for Baskerville was not concealed.

He (Baskerville) even permitted himself a sly jest or two at the expense of the other's mental endowments; and these thrusts, while unfelt by the victim, stabbed Cora's breast somewhat keenly.

Even Timothy's laughter, she (Cora) told herself, was more sane and manly than Ned's.

She (Cora) fell into her (Cora) own vice of contrasting the thing she (Cora) had with the thing she (Cora) had not, to the detriment of the former.

It was an instinct with her (Cora) to under-value her (Cora) own possessions; but the instinct stopped at herself--an unusual circumstance.

With herself and her (Cora) attributes of mind and body, she (Cora) never quarrelled; it was only her (Cora) environment that by no possibility compared favourably with that of other people.

Her (Cora) mother, her (Cora) sister, her (Cora) brother, her (Cora) betrothed, and her (Cora) prospects--none but seemed really unworthy of Cora when dispassionately judged by herself.

Now she (Cora) weighed Timothy's decision against Ned's doubt, his (Ned) knowledge against Ned's ignorance, his (Ned) sense against Ned's nonsense.

She (Cora) felt the farmer's allusions, and she (Cora) throbbed with discomfort because Ned did not also feel them and retort upon Mr. Waite in like manner.

She (Cora) told herself that the difference between them was the radical difference between a wise man and a fool.

Then she (Cora) fell back in self-defence of her (Cora) own judgment, and assured herself that, physically, there could be no comparison, and that Ned had a better heart and would make a gentler husband.

Timothy had admired her (Cora)--she (Cora) remembered that; but he (Timothy) was caution personified and, while he (Timothy) had considered, Ned had plunged.

She (Cora) strove to see this as a virtue in Ned.

Yet Timothy's old attitude to her (Cora) forbade any slighting of him (Ned).

She (Cora) remembered very well how, when he (Ned) congratulated her (Cora) on her (Cora) engagement, he (Ned) had pointedly praised Ned for one thing alone: his (Ned) precipitation.

A fault at other seasons may be a virtue in the love season.

``I thought him (Ned) not very clever,'' (Timothy/Waite/Mr. Waite)
said Timothy on that occasion;
``but now I see he (Timothy) was cleverer than any of us.

Because he (Timothy) was too clever to waste a moment in getting what every other chap wanted.

We learn these things too late.'' (Timothy/Waite/Mr. Waite)

He (chap) said that and said it with great significance.

It comforted Cora now to remember the circumstance.

Whatever else Ned might not know, he (Ned) knew a good deal about women; and that would surely make him (Ned) by so much a better husband.

Then her (it) wits told her (it) the opposite might be argued from this premise.

She (it) was not enjoying herself, and she (it) felt glad when Waite left them.

Anon Ned rallied her (it) for lengthened taciturnity and even hinted, as a jest, that he (Ned) believed she (it) was regretting her (it) choice.

They turned presently and went back over Shaugh Moor to drink tea at the man's home.

But upon the threshold Cora changed her (it) mind.

She (it) pleaded headache and some anxiety about her (it) health.

``I've got a cold coming--else I wouldn't be so low-spirited,'' (she)
she (it) said.

``I'll get back through North Wood and go to bed early.'' (He)

He (Wood) instantly expressed utmost solicitation and concern.

``I'll come back with you, then.

If you like, I'll put in the pony and drive you,'' (he)

he (Wood) said.

But she (it) would neither of these things.

``I shall be all right.

You go in and have your tea, and don't trouble.

I'll get back by the wood path, and you'll find I shall be better to-morrow.'' (he)

'''Tis that flimsy dress that lets the wind through like a net,'' he (Wood) said.

``The weather's not right for such clothes as you will wear.'' (she)

But she (it) laughed and told him (Wood) to mind his (Wood) own business.

Then she (it) kissed him (Wood) on the cheek and went away.

He (Wood) stood doubtful.

First he (Wood) felt moved to follow her (it), and then he (Wood) changed his (Wood) mind.

He (Wood) knew Cora better than she (it) thought he (Cora) did, and he (Cora) was aware that at the present moment she (it) felt perfectly well but desired to be alone.

He (Cora) had not missed the significance of Mr. Waite's views on his (Waite) sweetheart's mind, though he (Waite) had failed to appreciate Timothy's sly humour at his (Timothy) own expense.

Now, therefore, he (Timothy) let Cora have her (sweetheart) will and made no further effort to overtake her (sweetheart).

He (Cora) waited only until she (sweetheart) looked back, as he (Cora) knew she (sweetheart) would; then he (Cora) kissed his (Cora) hand, turned, and departed.

She (sweetheart) passed along through the forest homeward, and, when hidden in a silent place, dusted a stone and sat down to think.

A wild apple tree rose above her (sweetheart), half smothered in a great ivy-tod.

But through the darkness of the parasite, infant sprays of bright young foliage sprang and splashed the gloomy evergreen with verdure.

Aloft, crowning this gnarled and elbowed crab, burst out a triumphant wreath of pale pink blossom--dainty, diaphanous, and curled.

Full of light and pearly purity it feathered on the bough, and its tender brightness was splashed with crimson beads of the flower-buds that waited their time and turn to open.

Higher still, dominating the tree, thrust forth a crooked, naked bough or two.

They towered, black, dead, and grim above the loveliness of the living thing beneath.

From reflections not agreeable, this good sight attracted Cora and turned the tide of her (its) thoughts.

Even here the instinct of business dominated any sentiment that might have wakened in another spirit before such beauty.

She (its) gazed at it, then rose and plucked a few sprays of the apple-blossom.

Next she (its) took off her (its) hat and began to try the effect of the natural flowers therein.

Her (its) efforts pleased her (its) not a little.

``Lord!

What a hand I have for it!'' (she)

she (its) said aloud.

Then, refreshened by this evidence of her (its) skill, she (its) rose and proceeded to Shaugh.

``I know one thing,'' (she)
she (its) thought,
``and that is, man or no man, I shall always be able to make my living single-handed in a town.

'Tisn't for that I want a husband.

And be it as `twill, when master Ned finds a lot more money coming in, he (Ned)'d very soon give over crying out at a shop.'' (she)

CHAPTER IV Humphrey Baskerville still sought to determine his (Baskerville) need, and sometimes supposed that he (Baskerville) had done so.

More than once he (Baskerville) had contemplated the possibility of peace by flight; then there happened incidents to change his (Baskerville) mind.

Of late the idea of a home further from distracting influences had again seemed good to him (Baskerville).

More than once he (Baskerville) considered the advantages of isolation; more than once he (Baskerville) rode upon the Moor and distracted his (Baskerville) gloom with visions of imaginary dwellings in regions remote.

The folly of these thoughts often thrust him (Baskerville) with a rebound into the life of his (Baskerville) fellow-beings, and those who knew him (Baskerville) best observed a rhythmic alternation in Humphrey.

After periods of abstention and loneliness would follow some return to a more sociable style of living.

From a fierce hectic of mind that sent him (Humphrey) sore and savage into the heart of the wilderness, he (Humphrey) cooled and grew temperate again as the intermittent fever passed.

And then, when the effort towards his (Humphrey) kind had failed by his (Humphrey) own ineptitude and the world's mistrust, he (Humphrey) retreated once more to suffer, and banished himself behind the clouds of his (Humphrey) own restless soul.

Humanity has no leisure to decipher these difficult spirits; the pathos of their attempts must demand a philosophic eye to perceive it; and unless kind chance offers the key, unless opportunity affords an explanation, the lonely but hungry heart passes away unfathomed, sinks to the grave unread and unreconciled.

Inner darkness turned Baskerville to the Moor again, and he (Moor) rode--where often he (Moor) had already ridden: to inspect the ruin of an old dwelling upon the side of a great hill above the waters of Plym.

Brilliant summer smiled upon this pilgrimage, and as he (Moor) went, he (Moor) fell in with a friend, where Jack Head tramped the high road upon his (Head) way to Trowlesworthy.

Jack now dwelt at Shaugh, but was head man of Saul Luscombe's farm and rabbit warren.

``A fine day,'' (Humphrey/Humphrey Baskerville/HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE)
said Humphrey as he (Humphrey) slowed his (Humphrey) pony.

``Yes, and a finer coming,'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)
answered the other.

Mr. Baskerville was quick to note the militant tone.

``Been at your silly books again, I warrant,'' (he)
he (Baskerville) said.

``There's one book I could wish you'd read along with t`others, Jack.

'Tis the salt to all other books, for all you scorn it.'' (unknown)

``Bible's a broken reed, master, as you'll live to find out yet.'' (unknown)

``No, Jack.

'Tis what makes all other writing but a broken reed.

A fountain that never runs dry, I promise you.

No man will ever get the whole truth out of the Bible.'' (unknown)

``No, by Gor!

Because it ban't there,'' (unknown)

said the other.

``It's there all right--hidden for the little children to find it.

You bandage your eyes and then you say you can't see--a fool's trick that.'' (unknown)

``I can see so far as you.

'Tis you put coloured spectacles on your nose to make things look as you'd have 'em.

Your book be played out, master.

Let the childer read it, if you like, along with the other fairy tales; but don't think grown men be going to waste their time with it.

The whole truth is that the book be built on a lie.

There never was no Jehovah and never will be.

Moses invented Him (Moses) to frighten the folk from their naughtiness, same as you invent a scarecrow to frighten the birds from the seed.

And the scarecrow works better than Jehovah did, by all accounts.'' (unknown)

``You talk out of your narrow, bitter books, Jack.'' (unknown)

``No need to call my books names.

That's all your side can do.

Why don't they try to answer 'em instead of blackguarding 'em?'' (unknown)

'''Tis a great danger to the poor that they begin to think so much.''

``Don't you say that.

Knowledge be the weapon the poor have been waiting for all these years and years.

'Tis the only weapon for a poor man.

And what will it soon show 'em?

It'll show 'em that the most powerful thing on this earth be the poor.

They are just going to find it out; then you rich people will hear of something that will terrible astonish you.'' (unknown)

``You're a rank Socialist, Jack.

I've no patience with you.'' (unknown)

``There you are: `no patience!'

But that's another thing we men of the soil be going to teach you chaps who own the soil.

`Patience,' you say.

There's a time coming when the rich people will have to be mighty patient, I warn you!

And if you're impatient--why, 'tis all one to us, for never was heard that any impatient man could stop the tide flowing.'' (unknown)

``I believe that,'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)
said Baskerville grimly.

``You'll pay us presently for teaching you, and clothing you, and helping to enlarge your minds.

When you're learned enough, you'll turn round, like the snake, and bite the hand that fed you.

Gratitude the common soul never knows and never will, whatever else it may learn.

Knowledge is poison to low natures, and we ought to have kept you ignorant and harmless.'' (Jack/Jack Head)

Jack Head stared.

``That's a pretty speech!'' (he)

he (Head) said.

``That's a good healthy bit of Christian charity--eh?

Why for should you ax so much credit for your side?

Take me.

What's the rich man done for me?

A workhouse boy I was.'' (unknown)

``And look at you now--a prosperous man and saving money.

Who fed you and taught you and brought you up?

The State.

Society saved you; society played mother to you; and now you want to kick her (mother).

That's how you'd pay your debts.

You take a base and a narrow view--dishonest too.

The State have got to look after the rich as well as the poor.

Why not?

The poor aren't everybody.

You're the sort that think no man can be a decent member of society unless he (man) was born in a gutter.

Class prejudice 'tis called, and some of the chaps who think they're the salt of the earth, stink of it.'' (unknown)

``Class be damned,'' (Mr. Head)
said Mr. Head.

``Class is all stuff and nonsense.

There are only two classes--good men and bad ones.

The difference between a duke and me be difference between a pig with a ring in his (Head) nose and another without one.

We'm built the same to the last bone in our bodies, and I've got more sense than half the dukes in the kingdom.'' (unknown)

``And t`other half have got more sense than you,'' (the rider)
returned the rider.

``It's summed up in a word.

Class there will be, because class there must be.

The poor we have always with us--you know that well enough.

Your books, though they deny most things, can't deny that.'' (unknown)

``Another of your silly Christian sayings.

We have got the poor with us--but it won't be always.

So long as we have the rich with us, we shall have the poor, and no longer.

No longer, master!

Finish off the one and you'll finish off t`other.

That's a bit of home-grown wisdom, that is got from no book at all.'' (unknown)

``Wisdom, you call it!

And what power is going to root out the rich?

How are you clever folk going to alter human nature, and say to this man you shan't save your money and to this man you shall save yours?

While some men and women are born to thrift and sense, and some to folly and squandering, there must be rich and poor; and while men are born to hunger for power, there must be war.

These things can't be changed.

And you can't say where any man can reach to; you can't put up a mark and tell your fellow-man, `you shan't go higher than that.''' (unknown)

``Granted.

You can't say where they shall reach to; but you can say where they shall start from.

Half the world's handicapped at the starting-post.

I only ax for the race to be a fair one.

I only ax for my son to start fair with yours.

If yours be the better man, then let him (man) win; but don't let him (man) win because he (man)'s got too long a start.

That's not justice but tyranny.

Give every man his (man) chance and make every man work--that's all I ask.

If a man's only got the wits to break stones, then see that he (man) breaks 'em; and let them who can do better and earn better money not grudge the stone-breaker a little over and above what his (man) poor wits earn in the market.'' (unknown)

``I grant that's good,'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)
admitted Baskerville.

``Let the strong help the weak.

'Twas Christ found that out, not you Socialists.'' (Jack/Jack Head)

'''Tis found out anyway,'' said Jack Head.

``And 'tis true; and therefore it will happen and we can't go back on it.

And it follows from that law of strong helping weak that nobody ought to be too rich, any more than they ought to be too poor.

Let the State be a millionaire a million times over, if you like--and only the State.

So long as the hive be rich, no bee is poor.'' (Humphrey/Humphrey Baskerville/HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE)

Humphrey did not immediately reply.

He (Humphrey) was following Head's argument to a still larger conclusion.

``And you'd argue that as the strong man can help the weak one, so in time the strong State might help the weak one instead of hindering it, and the powerful of the earth give of their abundance to strengthen the humble and feeble?'' (unknown)

``Why not?

Instead of that, the great Powers be bristling with fighting men, and all the sinews of the world be wasted on war.

And it shows the uselessness of the Book, anyway, that the Christian nations--so-called--keep the biggest armies and the largest number of men idle, rotting their bodies and souls away in barracks and battleships.'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

Baskerville nodded.

``There's sense of a lop-sided sort in much that you say, Jack.

But 'tisn't the Book that's to blame--'tis the world that misunderstands the Book and daren't go by the Book--because of the nations around that don't go by it.'' (unknown)

``Then why do they pretend they'm Christians?

They know if they went by the Book they'd go down; yet they want to drive it into the heads of the next generation.

The child hears his (Jack) father damning the Government because they ban't building enough men-of-war, and next day when the boy comes home with a black eye, his (boy) father turns round and tells him (boy) to mind his (boy) Bible and remember that the peacemakers be blessed.'' (unknown)

``I could wish a Government would give Christianity a chance,'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)
confessed Mr. Baskerville;
``but I suppose 'tis much the same thing as Free Trade--a fine thing if everybody played the game, but a poor thing for one nation if t`others are all for Protection.'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

``That's a lie,'' (Mr. Head)
answered Mr. Head.

``We've shown Free Trade is a fine thing--single-handed we've shown it, and why?

Because Free Trade's a strong sword; but Christianity's rusty and won't stand the strain no longer.

We've passed that stage; and if we was to start Christianity now and offer the cheek to the smiter--well, he (Head)'d damn soon smite, and then where are we?'' (unknown)

They chattered on and set the world right according to their outlook, instinct, and understanding.

Then the conversation turned into personal channels, and Mr. Baskerville, while admitting the justice of much that Jack asserted, yet blamed him (Jack) for a certain impatience and bitterness.

``If evolution is going to set all right and the unborn will come into a better world, why get so hot?'' (he)

he (Jack) asked.

``Because I'm a thinking, feeling man,'' (unknown)
answered the other.

``Because I hate to see wrong done in the name of right.

And you're the same--only you haven't got as much sense as me seemingly.

I'm useful--you only want to be useful and don't see how.'' (unknown)

``I want to do my part in the world; but just the right way is difficult to choose out among the many roads that offer, Jack.

You are positive, and that saves a deal of trouble, no doubt.

The positive people go the furthest--for good or evil.

But I'm not so certain.

I see deeper than you because I've been better educated, though I'm not so clever by nature.

Then there's another thing--sympathy.

People don't like me, and to be disliked limits a man's usefulness a lot.'' (unknown)

``That's stuff,'' (Jack/Jack Head)
answered Jack;
``no more than a maggot got in your head.

If they don't like you, there's a reason.

They'm feared of your sharp tongue, and think 'tis the key to a hard heart.

Then 'tis for you to show 'em what they can't see.

I'll tell you what you are: you'm a man sitting hungry in a wheat-field, because you don't know and won't larn how to turn corn into bread.

That's you in a word.'' (Jack/Jack Head)

Trowlesworthy was reached and Jack went his (Jack) way.

``You might come and drink a dish of tea some Sunday,'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)
said Mr. Baskerville, and the other promised to do so.

Then Humphrey proceeded beside the river, and presently ascended a rough slope to his (Humphrey) destination.

The ruin that alternately drew and repelled him (Humphrey) lay below; but for the moment he (Humphrey) did not seek it.

He (Humphrey) climbed to the high ground, dismounted, turned his (Humphrey) pony loose, and took his (Humphrey) pipe out of his (Humphrey) pocket.

The great cone of granite known as Hen Tor lies high upon the eastern bank of Plym, between that streamlet and the bog-foundered table-land of Shavercombe beyond.

From its crown the visitor marked Cornwall's coastline far-spreading into the west, and Whitsand Bay reflecting silver morning light along the darker boundaries of earth.

Spaces of grass and fern extended about the tor, and far below a midget that was a man moved along the edge of the ripe bracken and mowed it down with a scythe.

Half a dozen carrion crows took wing and flapped with loud croaking away as Humphrey ascended the tor and sat upon its summit.

Again he (Humphrey) traversed the familiar scene in his (Humphrey) mind, again perceived the difficulties of transit to this place.

Occasionally, before these problems, he (Humphrey) had set to work obstinately and sought solutions.

Once he (Humphrey) had determined to rebuild the ruin in the valley, so that he (Humphrey) might turn his (Humphrey) back on man and make trial of the anchorite's isolation and hermit's bastard peace; but to-day he (Humphrey) was in no mood for such experiments; his (Humphrey) misanthropic fit passed upon the west wind, and his (Humphrey) thoughts took to themselves a brighter colour.

Where he (Humphrey) sat two roof-trees were visible, separated by the distant height of Legis Tor.

Trowlesworthy and Ditsworthy alone appeared, and for the rest the river roamed between them, and flocks and herds wandered upon the hills around.

The man still moved below, and long ribbons of fallen fern spread regularly behind him (man).

A foul smell struck on Baskerville's nostrils, and he (Baskerville) saw death not far distant, where the crows had been frightened from their meal.

He (Baskerville) climbed away from the main pile of the tor and sat in a natural chair hollowed from the side of an immense block of granite that stands hard by.

He (Baskerville) smoked, and his (Baskerville) pony grazed.

A storm of rain fell and passed.

The sun succeeded upon it, and for a little while the moor glittered with moisture.

Then the wind dried all again.

The old man was now entirely out of tune with any thought of a dwelling here.

He (man) did not even descend the hill and inspect the ruin beneath.

But he (man) had come to spend the day alone, and was contented to do so.

His (man) mind busied itself with the last thing that a fellow-man had said to him (man).

He (man) repeated Jack Head's word over and over to himself.

Presently he (man) ate the food that he (man) had brought with him (man), drank at a spring, and walked about to warm his (man) body.

The carrion crows cried in air, soared hither and thither, settled again on the rocks at hand and waited, with the perfect patience of unconscious nature, for him (man) to depart.

But he (man) remained until the end of the day.

Then occurred a magnificent spectacle.

After gold of evening had scattered the Moor and made dark peat and grey rock burn, there rolled up from the south an immense fog, that spread its nacreous sea under the sunset.

Born of far-off fierce heat upon the ocean, it advanced and enveloped earth, valley by valley, and ridge by ridge.

Only the highest peaks evaded this flood of vapours, and upon them presently sank the sun.

His (Moor) light descending touched many points and uplifted sprays of mist; whereon, like magic, a thousand galleons rode over the pearl and advanced in a golden flotilla upon this fleeting sea.

The rare, brief wonder passed, and the sky above it faded; the sun sank; the fog rolled forward--heavy, cold, a burden for the wet wings of night.

Humphrey set off, and the carrion crows, full hungry, returned to sup.

In Baskerville's mind certain words reverberated still, as they had often done since they were spoken during the morning.

They chimed to the natural sounds that had fallen upon his (Humphrey) ear throughout the day; they were echoed in the wind and the distant water-murmur; in the cry of birds and call of beasts; in the steady rasping of his (Humphrey) pony's teeth through the herbage; and now, in its hoof-beat as it trotted by a sheep-track homeward.

And louder than all these repetitions of it, louder than the natural music that seemed to utter the words in many voices, there came the drumming of his (Humphrey) own pulse, laden with the same message, and the answering beat of his (Humphrey) heart that affirmed the truth of it.

``A man sitting hungry in a wheat-field, because you don't know and won't learn how to turn corn into bread.'' (Milly/Milly Luscombe/Luscombe)

CHAPTER V Milly and her (Milly) husband Rupert came on a Sunday to drink tea at Hawk House.

They found Humphrey from home, but he (Humphrey) had left a message with Susan Hacker to say that he (Humphrey) would return before five o'clock.

``He (Humphrey)'s got the rheumatics,'' (Mrs. Hacker)
said Mrs. Hacker.

``They have fastened cruel in his (Humphrey) shoulder-blades, and he (Humphrey)'ve started on his (Humphrey) pony and gone off to see the doctor.

Won't have none of my cautcheries, though I know what's good for rheumatics well enough, and I've cured three cases to common knowledge that neither doctor nor that Eliza Gollop could budge, do as they would.'' (Rupert/Rupert Baskerville)

Rupert expressed concern, and went out to meet his (Rupert) uncle, while Milly stopped and helped Susan Hacker to prepare tea.

``And how do 'e like being married?'' (unknown)

asked the elder.

``Very well; but not quite so well as I thought to,'' (Milly/Milly Luscombe/Luscombe)
answered Milly with her (Milly) usual frankness.

``Ah!

same with most, though few have the pluck to confess it.'' (unknown)

``Being married is a very fine thing if you've got such a husband as Rupert; but living along with your husband's people ain't so fine, if you understand me.

You see, he (Rupert)'s farmer now, and he (Rupert) will have his (Rupert) way--a terrible resolute chap where the land and the things be concerned.

But sometimes his (Rupert) mother gets a bit restive at Rupert's orders, and sometimes she (mother) says, in her (mother) quiet way, as her (mother) husband never would have held with this or that.

'Tis a thought awkward now and again, because, you see, Rupert ban't the favourite, and never was.'' (unknown)

``You side with him (Rupert), of course?'' (unknown)

``Always, and always shall do--right or wrong.'' (unknown)

``Maybe when Master Ned's married and away Mrs. Baskerville will go easier.'' (unknown)

``Don't think I'm grumbling.

She (Baskerville)'s a kind woman, but, like all old married folk, seem to think young married folk be only playing at it.

The truth is that I haven't got enough to do for the minute.'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

Mr. Baskerville returned in half an hour, and Rupert walked beside him (Rupert).

Then, with some silent suffering, the old man alighted, and a boy took the pony to its stable.

``Doctor was out,'' (he)
he (Doctor) said,
``so I'll have to trouble you to make up a bit of your ointment after all.'' (he)

``And so I will,'' (Susan/Susan Hacker/Hacker)
answered Susan.

``And if you'd gone to that Gollop woman for the beastliness she (Gollop) pretends will cure everything, I'd never have forgiven you.

She (Gollop) helped to kill off your brother, no doubt, but that's no reason why you should give her (Gollop) a chance to kill you.'' (unknown)

``You're all alike,'' (he)
he (brother) said;
``a jealous generation.

But if you can have your physic ready in an hour, so much the better; then Rupert shall give my back a good rub before he (Rupert) goes.'' (he)

Mrs. Hacker was doubtful.

``Better I do it,'' (she)
she (Hacker) said.

'''Tis the way it's rubbed in makes the cure.''

``He (Rupert)'s stronger and can rub harder,'' (the patient)
answered the patient.

``Uncle Nathan's none too grand, neither,'' (nephew)
declared his (Uncle) nephew.

``Won't say what's amiss, but I do think he (Uncle)'s not all he (Uncle) might be.

I asked Mrs. Lintern, who knows more about him (Uncle) than anybody, I reckon, and she (Lintern) told me 'twas nothing much in her (Lintern) opinion--only his (Uncle) throat a bit queer.'' (unknown)

``You and Uncle Nathan ought to have wives to look after you,'' (Milly/Milly Luscombe/Luscombe)
declared Milly as she (Milly) poured out tea.

``You men be unfinished, awkward things alone.

You'm always wanting us at every turn, for one reason or another, and after middle age a man looks a fool half his (man) time if he (man) haven't got a woman for his (man) own.

Men do the big things and alter the face of the earth and all that, but what becomes of their clever greatness without our clever littleness?'' (unknown)

``Cant!--cant!

You all talk that stuff and 'tisn't worth answering.

Ask the sailors if they can't sew better than their sweethearts.'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

Mr. Baskerville was in a hard mood and would allow no credit to the sex.

He (Baskerville) endured his (Baskerville) pain without comment, but it echoed itself in impatient and rather bitter speeches.

Rupert fell back on other members of the family, and spoke of his (Rupert) uncle, the master of `The White Thorn.'

``The good that man does isn't guessed,'' (he)
he (man) said.

``The little things--you'd be surprised--yet 'tisn't surprising neither, for every soul you meet speaks well of him (man); and a man can't win to that without being a wonder.

He (man)'s made of human kindness, and yet never remembers the kind things he (man) does--no memory for 'em at all.'' (Humphrey/Humphrey Baskerville/HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE)

Humphrey conceded the nobility of this trait, and Milly spoke.

``Not like some we could name, who'll give a gift to-day and fling it in your face to-morrow.'' (unknown)

``There are such.

My mother's father was such a one,'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

said Mr. Baskerville.

``He (Baskerville) never forgot a kindness--that he (Baskerville)'d done himself.

He (Baskerville) checked his (Baskerville) good angel's record terrible sharp, did that man.'' (visitors)

There came an interruption here, and unexpected visitors in the shape of Nicholas Bassett, the young man who had married Polly Baskerville, and Polly herself.

Nicholas was nervous and stood behind his (Nicholas) wife; Polly was also nervous, but the sight of her (Polly) brother Rupert gave her (Polly) courage.

Her (Polly) uncle welcomed her (Polly) with astonishment.

``Wonders never cease,'' (he)
he (uncle) said.

``I didn't count to get a visit from you, Polly, or your husband either.

You needn't stand there turning your Sunday hat round and round, Bassett.

I shan't eat you, though people here do seem to think I'm a man-eater.'' (unknown)

``We came for advice,'' (Polly/Polly Baskerville)
said Polly,
``and I made bold to bring Nicholas.

In fact, 'twas his (Nicholas) idea that I should speak to you.'' (Polly/Polly Baskerville)

Mr. Baskerville was gratified, but his (Baskerville) nature forbade him (Baskerville) to show it.

``A new thing to come to Uncle Humphrey when you might go to Uncle Nathan,'' (he)
he (Nathan) said.

'''Tis just about Uncle Nathan is the difficulty,'' declared his (Nathan) niece.

Then she (niece) turned to her (niece) husband.

``You speak, Nick.

You must know that Nick's rather slow of speech, and can't get his (Nick) words always, but he (Nick)'s improving.

Tell Uncle Humphrey how 'tis, Nick.'' (Mr. Bassett)

Mr. Bassett nodded, dried a damp brow with a red handkerchief, and spoke.

'''Tis like this here,'' he (Bassett) began.

``Under Mr. Vivian Baskerville's will--him (Baskerville) being my wife's father--she (wife) had five hundred pound.'' (unknown)

``We all know that,'' (Rupert/Rupert Baskerville)
said Rupert.

``And May, too.'' (unknown)

``Well, the law of the will was that the money should be handed over when the girls was wedded, or when they comed to the age of five-and-twenty.

Therefore, surely it's clear as my wife ought to have her (wife) five hundred--eh?'' (unknown)

``Perfectly clear--on the day she (wife) married you,'' (Rupert/Rupert Baskerville)
said Rupert.

``I thought you'd got it, Polly.'' (unknown)

``But I haven't.

There's legal difficulties--so Uncle Nathan says; and he (Nathan) told Nicholas that there was a doubt in his (Nathan) mind whether--what was it, Nick?'' (unknown)

``The man said that as trustee for everybody he (Nick) was very unwilling to disturb the money.

He (Nick) said 'twas out at interest and doing very well; and he (Nick) said he (Nick)'d pay us five per centum upon it, which comed to twenty-five pounds a year.'' (unknown)

``You're entitled to the capital if you want it,'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)
declared Mr. Baskerville.

``It can't be withheld.'' (unknown)

``I've been to the man twice since,'' (Polly/Polly Baskerville)
said Polly's husband,
``and he (husband)'s always terrible busy, or else just going into it in a few days, or something like that.

We've had six months' interest on it; but we want the money--at least, half of it--because we've got ideas about leasing a field where we live to Bickleigh, and buying a cow in calf and a lot of poultry.

With all Polly's farm cleverness we can do better with a bit of money than leave it in the bank.

At least, that's what we think.'' (Polly husband)

``Ask Rupert here to help,'' (uncle)
suggested her (Polly) uncle.

``He (uncle)'s on very good terms with Uncle Nat, and he (Nat)'s a man of business now, and Polly's elder brother, and a right to be heard.

No doubt, if he (Nat) says plain and clear that he (Nat) wants you to have your money without delay, you'll get it.'' (unknown)

``I'd leave it till autumn, after Ned's marriage,'' (Rupert/Rupert Baskerville)
said Rupert,
``then I'd press him (Rupert) to clear things up.

Ned will want tons of money then, and I believe Cora Lintern is to have a money present from Uncle Nathan.

She (Polly) got the secret out of her (Polly) mother, and, of course, told Ned; and now everybody knows.

But nobody knows the figure.

Therefore, I say Polly had better do nought till the wedding.'' (Rupert/Rupert Baskerville)

``Mr. Nathan's temper isn't what it was,'' (Rupert/Rupert Baskerville)
said Rupert's wife.

``His (Rupert) health be fretting him (Rupert) a lot, I believe.'' (unknown)

``I wish I had our money, anyhow,'' (Mr. Bassett)
declared Mr. Bassett;
``but if you say wait till autumn, of course we will do so.'' (Mr. Bassett)

Humphrey Baskerville spoke but little.

He (Baskerville) had fallen into deep private thought upon this news, and now was only aroused by his (Baskerville) niece getting up to depart.

``I hope you'll forgive us for troubling you,'' (Polly/Polly Baskerville)
said Polly;
``but we've talked it over a thousand times, and we felt we ought to take the opinion of some wiser person.

Still, if you say wait, we'll wait.'' (Polly/Polly Baskerville)

``I didn't say wait,'' (uncle)
answered her (Polly) uncle,
``and I don't take any responsibility for it.

Rupert advised you to wait, not me.

If a man owed me twopence under a will--let alone five hundred pound--I'd have it, and wouldn't wait a minute.'' (uncle)

The young couple departed in a good deal of agitation, and debated this advice very earnestly all the way home; but Rupert stuck to his (Rupert) own opinion, and, when they were gone, chode Humphrey for giving such counsel.

``I'm sure such a thing would hurt Uncle Nathan cruelly,'' (he)
he (Uncle) said.

'''Tis as much as to say that you don't trust him (Uncle)--don't trust a man who is trusted by the countryside as none ever was before.''

``Easy to be large-minded about other people's money,'' (uncle)
answered his (man) uncle.

``Only if 'twas yours, and not your sister's, I rather think you'd be a bit less patient with the man that held it from you.'' (another visitor)

Yet another visitor appeared and the family matter was dropped.

Mrs. Hacker brought in Mr. Head.

``Looks as if the whole countryside was coming here,'' (she)
she (Hacker) declared.

``Here's Jack for a cup of tea; and the ointment will be cool enough to use in half an hour.'' (unknown)

``Hullo, Bear!'' (Rupert/Rupert Baskerville)

said Rupert.

``Who'd have thought of seeing you?'' (unknown)

``I was axed to tea when I felt in a mind to come,'' (Mr. Head)
replied Mr. Head;
``and here I am, if not in the way.

And as to being a bear, I'm the sort that needs a lot of stirring up afore I roar--your wife will back me up in that.

How's Mr. Baskerville faring?'' (Mr. Head)

``Got the rheumatism,'' (Humphrey/Humphrey Baskerville/HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE)
answered Humphrey.

``Rupert here be going to rub in some ointment presently.'' (unknown)

``I hope `twill break the heart of it, I'm sure.

There's nothing worse.

It tells us the truth about our parts better than any sermon.

I'm not too gay to-day myself.

We was at it hammer and tongs in `The White Thorn' last night--me and your brother.

Such a Tory was never seen in the land afore.

I very soon settled Tom Gollop and a few others like him (Gollop), but Mr. Nathan's got more learning and more power of argument.

We drank, too--more than usual, owing to the thirstiness of the night and the flow of speech.

Quarts I must have took, and when Ben North looked in to say 'twas closing time, nothing would do but a few of us went in your brother's room, after house was shut, and went at it again.'' (unknown)

``Say you were drunk in a word, Jack,'' (Rupert/Rupert Baskerville)
suggested Rupert.

``Not drunk, Rupert--still, near it.

We all got in sight of it.

There's no prophet like the next morning after a wet night.

As a man fond of the flesh I say it.

And the older you grow, the sharper comes the day after a bust-up.

Then Nature gives you a proper talking to, and your heart swells with good resolutions against beer and other things.

And then, as soon as you are as right as ninepence--just by keeping those good resolves--blest if Nature don't tumble down what she (We)'s set up, and tempt you with all her (We) might to go on the loose again.

You can't steady her (We), though she (We) can mighty soon steady you.

Preaches to you one minute, and then starts off to get you into mischief the next.

That's her (We) way--no more sense than any other female.'' (unknown)

``Then so much the less reason to put your trust in her (We),'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)
answered Mr. Baskerville.

``She (We)'s a poor, untaught, savage thing at best.

'Tis madness to trust her (We), for nothing is weaker than she (We).'' (unknown)

``Nothing is stronger or so strong,'' (Jack/Jack Head)
declared Jack.

``Nature knows what she (We) wants, and she (We) gets what she (We) wants.

You can't deny that.

She (We)'s just, and never does nothing without a reason.

Very different to a woman there.

She (woman)'m digging her (woman) claws into your back because you've been doing some foolish thing, I'll warrant.'' (He)

He (Jack) drank his (Jack) tea and aired his (Jack) opinions.

But Mr. Baskerville was in no mood for Jack's philosophy.

He (Baskerville) retired presently with Rupert, stripped to the waist, and endured a great and forcible application of Mrs. Hacker's ointment.

The friction brought comfort with it, and he (Rupert) declared himself better as a result.

But he (Rupert) did not again descend from his (Rupert) chamber, and presently the three visitors departed together.

Mr. Head expressed great admiration for Susan Hacker.

``I should like to be better acquaint with that woman,'' (he)
he (Head) declared.

``For sense in few words there's not her (woman) equal about.'' (unknown)

``If you want to please her (woman), cuss Eliza Gollop,'' (Rupert/Rupert Baskerville)
explained Rupert.

CHAPTER VI The setting sun burnt upon Dewerstone's shoulder and beat in a sea of light against the western face of North Wood, until the wind-worn forest edge, taking colour on trunk and bough, glowed heartily.

Already the first summer splendour was dimmed, for these lofty domains suffered full fret of storm and asperity of season.

A proleptic instinct, stamped by the centuries, inspired this wood; it anticipated more sheltered neighbours in autumn, though it lagged behind them in spring.

Upon its boughs the last vernal splendour fluttered into being, and the first autumnal stain was always visible.

Now beech and larch revealed a shadow in their texture of leaf and needle though August had not passed, for their foliage was born into elemental strife.

Here homed the west wind, and the salt south storms emptied their vials; here the last snows lingered, and May frost pinched the young green things.

Now roseal and gracious light penetrated the heart of the wood, warmed its recesses, and dwelt upon a grass-grown track that wound through the midst.

Toward this path by convergent ways there came a man and woman.

As yet half a mile separated them, for they had entered the wood at opposite places; but one desire actuated both, and they moved slowly nearer until they met at a tryst in the deep heart of the trees.

Undergrowth rose about them, and their resort was carefully chosen and perfectly concealed.

Here oak closely clad the hill, and granite boulders offered an inner rampart against observation.

The man and woman were elderly, yet she (woman) was still personable, and he (man) retained a measure of unusual good looks.

They came to perform a little rite, sacred and secret, an event celebrated these many years, and unknown to any other human beings but themselves.

Nathan Baskerville put his (Baskerville) arms round Priscilla Lintern and drew her (Lintern) beside him (Baskerville) and kissed her (Lintern).

``We shall never find it this year, I'm much afraid,'' (he)
he (Baskerville) said.

``The time is past.

'Tis always later far than other lilies in the garden, but not so late as this.

However, I'll do my best.'' (unknown)

``No matter for the flower,'' (she)
she (Lintern) answered,
``so long as we keep up our custom.'' (she)

A slant flame from the sunset stole deliciously through the dusky hiding-places of the wood, and played on the deep mosses and fern-crowns and the tawny motley of the earth, spread like a coverlet beneath.

Here dead litter of leaf and twig made the covering of the ground, and through it sprang various seedling things, presently to bear their part in the commonwealth and succeed their forefathers.

The ground was amber-bright where the sunshine won to it, and everywhere stretched ivy and bramble, gleamed the lemon light of malempyre, sparkled green sorrel, and rose dim woodbine that wound its arms around the sapling oaks.

Wood-rush and wood-sage prospered together, and where water spouted out of the hill there spread green and ruddy mosses, embroidered with foliage of marsh violet and crowned by pallid umbels of angelica.

The silver of birches flashed hard by, and the rowan's berries already warmed to scarlet.

Hither after their meeting came the man and woman, and then Nathan, searching sharply, uttered a cry of triumph, and pointed where, at their feet, grew certain dark green twayblade leaves that sprouted from the grass.

Here dwelt lilies-of-the-valley--their only wild haunt in Devon--and the man now made haste to find a blossom and present it to his (man) mistress.

But he (man) failed to do so.

Only a dead spike or two appeared, and presently he (man) gave up the search with some disappointment.

``They must have bloomed just when I was ill and couldn't come,'' (he)
he (man) said.

'''Tis no matter at all,'' she (mistress) answered.

``The thought and the meeting here are the good thing.

We'll go back into the wood now, further from the path.

To me 'tis marvellous, Nat, to think the crafty world has never guessed.'' (unknown)

``It is,'' (he)
he (Nat) admitted.

``And sometimes in my dark moments--however, we can leave that to-day.

We're near at the end of our labours, so far as the children are concerned.

Cora was always the most difficult.

But the future's bright, save for the cash side.

I hope to God `twill come right afore the wedding; but--'' (she)

``Go on,'' (she)
she (me) said.

``We can't pretend to be so happy as usual this year.

Let's face it.

I know you're worried to death.

But money's nought alongside your health.

You're better again; you've shown me that clear enough.

And nothing else matters to us.'' (unknown)

``Yes, I'm all right, I hope.

But I'm a bit under the weather.

Things have gone curiously crooked ever since Vivian died.

I was a fool.

I won't disguise that; but somehow my luck seemed so good that a few little troubles never looked worth considering.

Then, just before he (Vivian) went, I got into a regular thunderstorm.

It blew up against the steady wind of my good fortune, as thunderstorms will.

Vivian did me a good turn by dying just when he (Vivian) did--I can't deny it; and everything is all right now--for all practical purposes.

The silver mine will be a wonder of the world by all accounts.

Still, I've had a good deal to trouble me, and things look worse when a man's sick.'' (unknown)

``Shall you be giving Polly Bassett her (Polly) money soon?

Heathman tells me her (Polly) husband's grumbling a bit.'' (unknown)

``All in good time.

When our Cora is married I shall try and fork out a good slice of Vivian's estate.

Ned must have the capital he (Ned) wants, and I've got to find a hundred for Cora's wedding gift.'' (unknown)

``Why do that yet?'' (unknown)

``I'll do it if I have to sell myself up,'' (he)
he (Cora) said fiercely.

``Isn't she (Polly) my first favourite of our three?

Don't I worship the ground she (Polly) goes on, and love her (Polly) better than anything in the world after you yourself?'' (She)

She (Polly) sighed.

``How it weighs heavier and heavier after all these years!

And I always thought `twould weigh lighter and lighter.

We were fools to have childer.

But for them we could have let the world know and been married, and gived back the five thousand to your wife's people.

But not now--never now, for the children's sake, I suppose.'' (unknown)

``They'll know in good time, and none else.

When I come to my end, I'm going to tell 'em I'm their father, according to your wish, and because I've promised you on my oath to do it; but none else must ever know it; and it would be a wiser thing, Priscilla, if you could only see it so, that they didn't either.'' (unknown)

``They must know, and they shall.'' (unknown)

``Well, it may be sooner than anybody thinks.

The position is clear enough: I might have married and still kept the five thousand, because the lawyers said that my dead wife's wish wouldn't hold water in law; but I didn't know that till 'twas too late, and your first child had come.

Then we talked it out, and you was content and so was I.

Now there are three of them, and though I'd face the music so brave as you and go to my grave spurned by all men, if necessary, what would better it for them?

Nothing short of an Act of Parliament would make 'em legitimate now.

I kept the condition of my dead wife, because you urged me to do it and weren't feared of the consequences; but now, though I can make you my lawful wife, I can't make them my lawful children, and therefore surely 'tis better they shall never know they are my children at all?'' (she)

'''Twas a promise,'' she (wife) said,

``and I hold you to it.

I'm fixed on it that they shall know.'' (she)

``Very well, so it shall be, then.

Only for God's sake look to it for everybody's sake that it don't get out after, and ruin you all.

I shouldn't sleep in my grave if I thought the life-long secret was common knowledge.'' (unknown)

``You can trust them to keep it, I should think.'' (unknown)

``The girls, yes; but Heathman's so easy and careless.'' (unknown)

``Suppose you was to marry me even now, Nat, would that help?'' (unknown)

``I'll do it, as I've always said I'll do it.

But that means I should be in honour bound to pay five thousand to my first wife's people.

Well, I can't--I can't at this moment--not a penny of it.

Just now I'm a good deal driven.

In a year or two I might, no doubt; but there's that tells me a year or two--'' (He)

He (Nat) put up his (Nat) hand to his (Nat) throat.

``You swore to me on your oath that you were better, last time you came down by night.'' (unknown)

``I was; but--it's here, Priscilla--deep down and-- Maybe `twill lift again, and maybe it won't.

But we must be ready.

I'd give my eternal soul if things were a little straighter; but time--plenty of time--is wanted for that, and 'tis just time I can't count upon.

I'm not so young as I was, and I've not the head for figures I used to have.'' (unknown)

``If you don't marry, you've got absolute power to dispose of that five thousand.

'Tis yours, in fact.

Yet at best that's a paltry quibble, as you've admitted sometimes.'' (unknown)

``Leave it,'' (he)
he (I) said.

``Don't let this day be nought but cloud.

We're married afore God, but not afore man, because to do that would have lost me five thousand pounds.

When I die, I've the right to make over that money to you--at least, what's left of it.'' (unknown)

``That's a certainty for me and Heathman and Phyllis?'' (unknown)

``Leave it--leave it,'' (he)
he (God) cried irritably.

``You know that what a man can do I shall do.

You're more to me than any living thing--much, much more.

You're my life, and you've been my life for thirty years--and you will be to the end of my life.

I know where I stand and how I stand.'' (unknown)

``Don't think I'd care to live a day longer than you do, Nat.

Don't think I'm careful for myself after you be gone.

'Tis only for your boy and girl as I care to know anything.'' (He)

He (boy) took her (girl) hand.

``I know you well enough--you priceless woman!'' (he)

he (boy) answered.

``Let's go a bit further through the forest.

Come what may, all's got to be bright and cheerful at Cora's wedding; and after, when they've got their money, I'll have a good go into things with Mr. Popham, my lawyer at Cornwood.

He (lawyer)'s heard nothing yet, but he (lawyer) shall hear everything.

Have no fear of the upshot.

I know where I've always trusted, and never in vain.'' (children)

Like two children they walked hand in hand together.

For a long time neither spoke, then she (they) addressed him (lawyer).

``You've taught me to be brave and put a bright face on life afore the world, and now I'll not be wanting.'' (unknown)

``Well I know that.

`Brave!'

'Tis too mild a a word for you.

You've come through your life in a way that would maze the people with wonder if they only knew it.

So secret, so patient, so clever.

Never was heard or known the like.

A wonderful wife--a wife in ten thousand.'' (unknown)

The sun began to sink where Cornwall, like a purple cloud, rose far off against the sky; yet still the undulations of the land, mingling with glory, melted into each other under the sunset, and still North Wood shone above the shadows.

But a deep darkness began to stretch upwards into it, where the Dewerstone's immense shade was projected across the valley.

At length only the corner of the forest flashed a final fire; then that, too, vanished, and the benighted trees sighed and shivered and massed themselves into amorphous dimness under the twilight.

The man and woman stopped together a while longer, and after that their converse ended.

They caressed and prepared to go back by different ways into the world.

``Come good or evil, fair weather or foul, may we have a few happy returns yet of this day; and may I live to find you the lily-of-the-valley again once or twice before the end,'' (he)
he (man) said.

For answer she (woman) kissed him (man) again, but could not trust herself to speak.

CHAPTER VII Life is a compromise and a concession.

According to the measure of our diplomacy, so much shall we win from our fellows; according to our physical endowment, so much will Nature grant.

All men are envoys to the court of the world, and it depends upon the power behind them whether they are heard and heeded, or slighted and ignored.

To change the figure, each among us sets up his (man) little shop in the social mart and tries to tempt the buyer; but few are they who expose even necessary wares, and fewer still the contemporary purchasers who know a treasure when they see it.

An accident now lifted the curtain from Humphrey Baskerville's nature, threw him (Baskerville) for a day into the companionship of his (Baskerville) kind, and revealed to passing eyes a gleam of the things hidden within him (Baskerville).

No conscious effort on his (Baskerville) part contributed to this illumination, for he (Baskerville) was incapable of making such.

His (Baskerville) curse lay in this: that he (Baskerville) desired to sell, yet lacked wit to win the ear of humanity, or waken interest in any buyer's bosom.

Yet now the goods he (Baskerville) offered with such ill grace challenged attention.

Accident focussed him (Baskerville) in a crowd; and first the people were constrained to admit his (Baskerville) presence of mind at a crisis, and then they could not choose but grant the man a heart.

It happened that on the day before Princetown pony fair Mr. Baskerville's groom fell ill and had to keep his (groom) bed; but twenty ponies were already at Princetown.

Only Humphrey and his (Humphrey) man knew their exact value, and the market promised to be unusually good.

His (Humphrey) stock represented several hundred pounds, for Mr. Baskerville bred a special strain possessing the Dartmoor stamina with added qualities of speed and style.

The irony of chance ordained that one who despised all sport should produce some of the best polo ponies in the West of England.

Mr. Baskerville saw nothing for it but to sell by deputy at loss, or withdraw his (Baskerville) stock from the fair.

He (Baskerville) debated the point with Mrs. Hacker, and her (Hacker) common-sense revealed an alternative.

``Lord, man alive, what are you frightened of?'' (she)

she (Hacker) asked.

``Can't you go up along, like any other chap with summat to sell, and get rid of your beasts yourself?

You did use to do it thirty year ago, and nobody was any the worse, I believe.'' (He)

He (chap) stared at her (Hacker).

``Go in a crowd like that and barter my things like a huckster?'' (unknown)

``Well, why not?

You'm only made of flesh and bone like t`others.

You won't melt away.

'Tis just because you always avoid 'em, that they think you give yourself airs, and reckon they ban't good enough company for you.'' (unknown)

``I don't avoid 'em.'' (unknown)

``Yes, you do.

But you'm not the only honest man in the world, though sometimes you think you are.

And if you'd ope your eyes wider, you'd find a plenty others.

For my part, if I was paid for it, I couldn't number more rogues in Shaugh than I can count upon the fingers of both hands.'' (unknown)

``To go up myself!

Who'd believe it was me if they saw me?'' (unknown)

``They want your ponies, not you; and when it came to paying the price of the ponies, they'd soon know 'twas you then.'' (unknown)

``I suppose you think I charge too much.

Like your impudence!

Are you going?'' (he)
