he (it) asked.

``Why, of course I'm going.

'Tis my only `out' for the year.'' (unknown)

``They'll fancy 'tis the end of the world up at `Duchy Inn' if I come along and take my place at the ordinary.'' (unknown)

``No, they won't: they'll be a deal too busy to trouble about you.

You go, master, and you'll stand a lot better in your own eyes for going.

`Twill be a great adventure in your life.

You'm a deal too much up on the hill there, along with the foxes and other wild things; and you know it.'' (unknown)

``I haven't the cut for a revel.

'Tis nonsense to think of my going up.'' (unknown)

``To think of it can't do no harm, anyway,'' (she)
she (you) said.

``You think and think, and you'll find 'tis your duty as a sensible creature to go.'' (unknown)

``Not my duty.

`Twill hurt none if I stay away.'' (unknown)

''`Twill hurt your pocket.

You know right well 'tis the proper thing that you go.

And if you do, I'll ax for a fairing.

And if you get me one, I'll get you one.''

``You can put off old age like a garment and be a girl again,'' (he)
he (You) said.

``So I can, then.

'Tis your brother sets that wise fashion, not you.

He (brother)'s as lively as a kitten when there's a frolic in the air.

And so be I--though all sixty-five.

You should have seen me at giglet market in my youth!'' (He)

He (brother) did not answer; but the next morning he (brother) appeared shamefaced and clad for the fair.

``Well done, you!'' (Mrs. Hacker)

cried Mrs. Hacker.

``Be you going to drive the black gig?

I was riding up in the pony-cart along with Mr. Waite's housekeeper from Coldstone, but--'' (unknown)

``You can come with me, if you please.

All foolery, and 'tis offering to rain--however, I'm going through with the job now.

And mind you don't take too much liquor up there.

I know your ways when you get with a lot of silly people.'' (Humphrey/Humphrey Baskerville/HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE)

They started presently, and Humphrey made sour remarks at the expense of Susan's bonnet.

Then by steep ascent and descent they went their way and fell in with other folk also bound for the festivity.

Some they passed and some passed them.

Cora Lintern and Ned Baskerville drove together in a flashy, high-wheeled dog-cart; and the sight of Cora brought a cloud upon Mr. Baskerville.

She (Susan) was soon gone, however.

The lofty vehicle slipped by with a glitter of wheels, a puff of dust, a shout from Ned as he (Ned) lifted his (Ned) whip hand, and a flutter of pale pink and blue where Cora sat in her (Susan) finery.

``Heartless minx!'' (the man)

growled the old man.

``A parrot and a popinjay.

No loss to the world if that pair was to break their necks together.'' (unknown)

``Don't you tell such speeches as that, there's a good man,'' (Mrs. Hacker)
answered Mrs. Hacker.

``The mischief with your sort is that you be always crying out nasty things you don't think; which is just the opposite of us sensible people, as only think the nasty things, but take very good care for our credit's sake not to say 'em.

None like you for barking; and them as hear you bark take it for granted you bite as well.

And when I tell 'em you don't bite, they won't believe it.'' (unknown)

``Take care I never bite you for so much plain speaking,'' (he)
he (you) said;
``and I'll thank you to lay hold on the reins while we walk up this hill; for I want to read a letter.

'Tis about the ponies from a would-be buyer.'' (he)

He (you) read and Mrs. Hacker drove.

They traversed the miles of moorland at a slow pace, and not a few who passed them displayed surprise at the spectacle of Mr. Baskerville on his (Baskerville) way to the fair.

At Devil's Bridge, beneath the last long hill into Princetown, a vehicle from Shaugh overtook them and the Linterns appeared.

Heathman was driving, and beside him (Baskerville) sat his (Baskerville) mother; while at the back of the cart were Nathan Baskerville and Phyllis Lintern.

``Hullo!

Wonders never cease!'' (the publican)

cried the publican.

``Good luck and long life to you, Humphrey!

Now I couldn't have seen a better sight than this.

Hold on!

I want to have a talk afore the fair.'' (unknown)

``If you want to talk, I'll onlight and you do the same,'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)
said Nathan's brother.

``The women can drive on, and we'll walk into Princetown.'' (Priscilla/Priscilla Lintern/Lintern)

Priscilla Lintern and Mrs. Hacker kept their places and drove slowly up the hill side by side; but not before Nat had chaffed Susan and applauded her (Susan) holiday bonnet.

Heathman and his (Nat) sister walked on together; the brothers remained behind.

The younger was in uproarious mood.

He (Nat) laughed and jested and congratulated Humphrey on his (Humphrey) courage in thus coming among the people.

None would have recognised in this jovial spirit that man who walked not long before with a woman in North Wood, and moved heavily under the burdens of sickness and of care.

But to Nathan belonged the art of dropping life's load occasionally and proceeding awhile in freedom.

He (Nathan) felt physically a little better, and intended to enjoy himself to-day to the best of his (Nathan) power.

Resolutely he (Nathan) banished the dark clouds from his (Nathan) horizon and let laughter and pleasure possess him (Nathan).

``How's your throat?'' (Humphrey/Humphrey Baskerville/HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE)

asked Humphrey.

``You don't look amiss, but they tell me you're not well.'' (unknown)

``I hope it may mend.

'Tis up and down with me.

I can't talk so loud as once I could, and I can't eat easy; but what's the odds as long as I can drink?

I'm all right, and shall be perfectly well again soon, no doubt.

And you--what in the name of wonder brings you to a revel?'' (unknown)

``My ponies.

There's twenty and all extra good.

Chapman goes and falls ill after the ponies was brought up here.

The fool would bring 'em though there's no need.

Buyers are very well content to come to my paddocks.

But custom is a tyrant to the old, and if I didn't send to the sales, Chapman would think something had gone wrong with the world.'' (unknown)

``I'm right glad you're here, and I hope 'tis the beginning of more gadding about for you.

'Tis men like you and me that lend weight to these meetings.

We ought to go.

'Tis our duty.'' (unknown)

``You're better pleased with yourself than I am, as usual.'' (unknown)

``We ought to be pleased,'' (unknown)
answered the other complacently.

``We are the salt of the earth--the rock that society is built on.'' (unknown)

``Glad you're so well satisfied.'' (unknown)

``Not with myself specially; but I'm very well pleased with my class, and the older I grow the better I think of it.'' (unknown)

``People be like yonder pool--scum at the top and dirt at the bottom,'' (Humphrey/Humphrey Baskerville/HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE)
declared Humphrey.

``The sweet water is in the middle; and the useful part of the people be the middle part.'' (unknown)

``In a way, yes.

We of the lower middle-class are the backbone: the nation has to depend on us; but I'm not for saying the swells haven't their uses.

Only they'd be nought without us.'' (unknown)

``It takes all sorts to make a world.

But leave that.

I ban't up here to talk politics.

What does doctor say about your throat?'' (unknown)

``Leave that too.

I'm not here to talk about my health.

I want to forget it for a few hours.

The wedding is on my mind just now.

Mrs. Lintern and her (Lintern) daughter intend it to be a bit out of the common; and so do I.

But the bride's mother's set on it taking place at our chapel, and Hester wants it to be at church.

Ned don't care a rush, of course.'' (unknown)

``It ought to be at church.'' (unknown)

``Don't see any pressing reason.

Toss up, I say.'' (unknown)

``You should know better than to talk like that.

You Dissenters--'' (unknown)

``No arguments, Humphrey.

But all the same they must be married in church or chapel, and since there's such a division of opinion--I'm anxious to see Ned married.

'Tis more than time and certainly no fault of his (Ned) that they didn't join sooner.

But Cora had her (Ned) own ideas and--'' (unknown)

``Oblige me by not naming either of them.

You can't expect me to be interested.

Even if they were different from what they are, I should remember the cruel past too keenly to feel anything good towards either of them.'' (unknown)

``Let the past go.

You're too wise a man to harbour unkind thoughts against headstrong youth.

Let 'em be happy while they can.

They'll have their troubles presently, like the rest of us.'' (unknown)

``They'll have what they're brewing, no doubt.

Empty, heartless wretches--I will say it, feel as you may for Cora.'' (unknown)

``I hope you'll live to see her (They) better part.

She (They)'s a sensible woman and a loving one, for all you think not.

At any rate, you'll come and see them married, Humphrey?'' (unknown)

``You can ask me such a thing?'' (unknown)

``Let bygones be bygones.'' (unknown)

``What was it you wanted to speak to me about?'' (unknown)

``Just that--the wedding.

I must make it a personal matter.

I attach a good deal of importance to it.

I'm very interested in the Linterns--wrapped up in them wouldn't be too strong a word for it.

I'll confess to you that the mother is a good deal to me--my best friend in this world.

I owe a lot of my happiness to her (mother).

She (mother)'s made my life less lonely and often said the word in season.

You know what a wise woman can be: you was married yourself.'' (Humphrey/Humphrey Baskerville/HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE)

Humphrey did not answer and his (Humphrey) brother spoke again.

``There's only us two left now--you and me.

You might pleasure me in this matter and come.

Somehow it's grown to be a feeling with me that your absence will mar all.'' (unknown)

``Stuff!

I've been the death's-head at too many feasts in our family.

In a word, I won't do it.

I won't be there.

I don't approve of either of 'em, and I've not interest enough in 'em now to take me across the road to see them.'' (unknown)

``If you'll come, the marriage shall be in church.

Priscilla will agree if I press it.

I can't offer more than that.'' (unknown)

``I won't come, so leave it.'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)

Nathan's high spirits sank for a little while; then Princetown was reached and he (Nathan) left his (Nathan) brother and strove to put this pain from him (Nathan) for the present, as he (Nathan) had banished all other sources of tribulation.

He (Nathan) was soon shaking hands with his (Nathan) acquaintance and making merry among many friends.

But Humphrey proceeded to the place where his (Humphrey) ponies were stalled, and immediately began to transact business with those who were waiting for him (Humphrey).

CHAPTER VIII Gipsy blood runs thin in England to-day, but a trickle shall be found to survive among the people of the booth and caravan; and glimpses of a veritable Romany spirit may yet be enjoyed at lesser fairs and revels throughout the country.

By their levity and insolence; by their quick heels and dark faces; by the artist in them; by their love of beauty and of music; by their skill to charm money from the pockets of the slow-thinking folk; and by their nimble wits you shall know them.

A few mongrels of the race annually find Princetown, and upon days of revel may there be seen at shooting-galleries, `high-fliers,' and `roundabouts.'

Here they are chaffing the spectators and cajoling pennies from young and old; here, astounding the people by their lack of self-consciousness; here, singing or dancing; here, chafering; here, driving hard bargains for the local ponies; here, changing their doubtful coins for good ones, or raising strife between market-merry folk and prospering from the quarrels of honest men, after the manner of their kind.

Two streams of holiday-makers drifted through each other and through the little fair.

They passed up and down the solitary street, loitered and chattered, greeted friends, listened to the din of the music, to the altercations of the customers and salesmen, to the ceaseless laughter of children and whinny of the ponies.

On either side of that open space spread in the village midst, an array of carts had been drawn up, and against these barricades were tethered various animals which the vehicles had brought.

They stood or reposed on litter of fern and straw cast down for them.

Here were pigs, flesh-coloured and black, and great raddled rams in a panting row.

Amid the brutes tramped farmers and their men.

The air was full of the smell of live mutton and swine; and among them--drifting, stopping in thoughtful knots, arguing, and laughing heavily, the slow-eyed yokels came and went.

The rams bleated and dribbled and showed in a dozen ways their hatred of this publicity; the pigs cared not, but exhibited a stoic patience.

Upon the greensward beside the road stood separate clusters of guarded ponies.

Old and young they were, gainly and ungainly, white, black, and brown, with their long manes and tails often bleached to a rusty pallor by the wind and sun.

In agitated groups the little creatures stood.

Company cried to company with equine language, and the air was full of their squealings, uttered in long-drawn protests or sudden angry explosions.

Occasionally a new drove from afar would arrive and trot to its place in double and treble ranks--a passing billow of black and bright russet or dull brown, with foam of tossing manes, flash of frightened eyes, and soft thud and thunder of many unshod hoofs.

The people now came close, now scattered before a pair of uplifted heels where a pony, out of fear, showed temper.

The exhibits were very unequal.

Here a prosperous man marshalled a dozen colts; here his (man) humbler neighbour could bring but three or four to market.

Sometimes the group consisted of no more than a mare and foal at foot.

Round about were children, who from far off had ridden some solitary pony to the fair, and hoped that they might get the appointed price and carry money home to their parents or kinsfolk.

Hanging close on every side to the main business and thrusting in where space offered for a stall, rows of small booths sprang up; while beyond them on waste land stood the merry-go-rounds, spinning to bray of steam-driven organs, the boxing-tent, the beast show and the arena, where cocoanuts were lifted on posts against a cloth.

Here worked the wanderers and played their parts with shout and song; but at the heart of the fair more serious merchants stood above their varied wares, and with unequal skill and subtlety won purchasers.

These men displayed divergent methods, all based on practical experience of human nature.

A self-assertive and defiant spirit sold braces and leather thongs and buckles.

His (merchants) art was to pretend the utmost indifference to his (merchants) audience; he (merchants) seemed not to care whether they purchased his (merchants) goods or no, yet let it be clearly understood that none but a fool would miss the opportunities he (fool) offered.

A cheap-jack over against the leather-seller relied upon humour and sleight of hand.

He (fool) sold watches that he (fool) asserted to be gold; but he (fool) was also prepared to furnish clocks of baser metal for more modest purses.

He (fool) dwelt upon the quality of the goods, and defied his (fool) audience to find within the width and breadth of the United Kingdom such machinery at such a price.

He (fool) explained also very fully that he (fool) proposed to return among them next year, with a special purpose to make good any defective timepieces that might by evil chance lurk unsuspected amid his (fool) stock.

He (fool) reminded them he (fool) had been among them during the previous year also, as a guarantee of his (fool) good faith.

Beyond him (fool) a big, brown half-caste sold herb pills and relied upon a pulpit manner for his (fool) success.

He (fool) came with a message of physical salvation from the God of the Christians.

He (God) mingled dietetics and dogma; he (God) prayed openly; he (God) showed emotion; he (God) spoke of Nature and the Power above Nature; he (God) called his (God) Maker to witness that nothing but the herbs of the field had gone to make his (God) medicine.

He (God) had good store of long words with which to comfort rustic ears.

He (God) spoke of 'a palliative,' 'a febrifuge,' and 'a panacea.'

He (God) wanted but three-pence for each box, and asserted that the blessing of the Lord accompanied his (Lord) physic.

``Why am I here?'' (he)

he (Lord) asked.

``Who sent me?

I tell you, men and women, that God sent me.

We must not carry our light under a bushel.

We must not hide a secret that will turn a million unhappy men and women into a million happy men and women.

God gave me this secret, and though I would much sooner be sitting at home in my luxurious surroundings, which have come to me as the result of selling this blessed corrective of all ills of the digestion and alimentary canals, yet--no--this world is no place for idleness and laziness.

So I am here with my pills, and I shall do my Master's work so long as I have hands to make the medicine and a voice to proclaim it.

And in Christ's own blessed words I can say that where two or three just persons are gathered together, there am I in the midst of them, my friends--there am I in the midst of them!'' (women)

Amid the welter of earth-colour, dun and grey there flashed yellow or scarlet, where certain Italian women moved in the crowd.

They sold trinkets, or offered to tell fortunes with the aid of little green parakeets in cages.

The blare and grunt of coarse melody persisted; and the people at the booths babbled ceaselessly where they sold their sweetmeats, cakes, and fruit.

Some were anchored under little awnings; some moved their goods about on wheels with flags fluttering to attract attention.

Old and young perambulated the maze.

Every manner of man was gathered here.

Aged and middle-aged, youthful and young, grey and white, black and brown, bearded and shorn, all came and went together.

Some passed suspicious and moody; some stood garrulous, genial, sanguine, according to their fortunes or fancied fortunes in the matter of sale and barter.

And later in the day, by the various roads that stretch north, south, and west from Princetown, droves of ponies began to wend, some with cheerful new masters; many with gloomy owners, who had nothing to show but their trouble for their pains.

This spacious scene was hemmed in by a rim of sad-coloured waste and ragged hills, while overhead the grey-ribbed sky hung low and shredded mist.

Humphrey Baskerville had sold his (Baskerville) ponies in an hour, and was preparing to make a swift departure when accident threw him (Baskerville) into the heart of a disturbance and opened the way to significant incidents.

The old man met Jack Head and was speaking with him (Head), but suddenly Jack caught the other by his (Jack) shoulders and pulled him (Jack) aside just in time to escape being knocked over.

A dozen over-driven bullocks hurtled past them with sweating flanks and dripping mouths.

Behind came two drovers, and a brace of barking dogs hung upon the flanks of the weary and frightened cattle.

Suddenly, as the people parted, a big brute, dazed and maddened by the yelping dogs now at his (Jack) throat, now at his (Jack) heels, turned and dashed into the open gate of a cottage by the way.

The door of the dwelling stood open and before man or sheepdog had time to turn him (man), the reeking bullock had rushed into the house.

There was a crash within, the agonised yell of a child and the scream of a woman.

Then rose terrified bellowings from the bullock, where it stood jammed in a passageway with two frantic dogs at its rear.

A crowd collected, and Mr. Baskerville amazed himself by rushing forward and shouting a direction.

``Get round, somebody, and ope the back door!'' (A woman)

A woman appeared at the cottage window with a screaming and bloody child in her (woman) arms.

``There's no way out; there's no way out,'' (she)
she (woman) cried.

``There's no door to the garden!'' (unknown)

``Get round; get round!

Climb over the back wall,'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

repeated Baskerville.

Then he (Baskerville) turned to the woman.

``Ope the window and come here, you silly fool!'' (he)

he (Baskerville) said.

She (woman) obeyed, and Humphrey found the injured child was not much hurt, save for a wound on its arm.

Men soon opened the rear door of the cottage and drove the bullock out of the house; then they turned him (Humphrey) round in the garden and drove him (Humphrey) back again through the house into the street.

The hysterical woman regarded Mr. Baskerville as her (woman) saviour and refused to leave his (Baskerville) side.

The first drover offered her (woman) a shilling for the damage and the second stopped to wrangle with Jack Head, who blamed him (Head) forcibly.

'''Twas the dogs' fault--anybody could see that,'' he (Head) declared.

``We're not to blame.'' (unknown)

``The dogs can't pay, you silly fool,'' (unknown)
answered Head.

``If you let loose a dog that don't know his (Head) business, you've got to look out for the trouble he (Head) makes.

'Tis the devil's own luck for you as that yowling child wasn't killed.

And now you want to get out of it for nought!

There's a pound's worth of cloam smashed in there.'' (The woman)

The woman, who was alone, sent messengers for her (woman) husband, but they failed to find him (husband); then she (woman) declared that Mr. Baskerville should assess the amount of her (woman) claim and the people upheld her (woman).

Thus most reluctantly he (Baskerville) was thrust into a sort of prominence.

``You was the only one with sense to tell 'em what to do; and so you'd better finish your good job and fix the price of the breakages,'' (Jack/Jack Head)
said Jack.

The man with the bullocks, when satisfied that Humphrey would be impartial and indifferent to either party, agreed to this proposal, and Mr. Baskerville, quite bewildered by such a sudden notoriety, entered the cottage, calculated the damage done, and soon returned.

``You've got to pay ten shillings,'' (he)
he (Baskerville) said.

``Your bullock upset a tray and smashed a terrible lot of glass and china.

He (Baskerville) also broke down four rails of the balusters and broke a lamp that hung over his (Baskerville) head.

The doctor will charge a shilling for seeing to the child's arm also.

So that's the lowest figure in fairness.

Less it can't be.'' (The drover)

The drover cursed and swore at this.

He (Baskerville) was a poor man and would be ruined.

His (Baskerville) master would not pay, and if the incident reached headquarters his (Baskerville) work must certainly be taken from him (Baskerville).

None offered to help and Humphrey was firm.

``Either pay and thank God you're out of it so easily,'' (he)
he (Humphrey) said,
``or tell us where you come from.'' (he)

The drovers talked together, and then they strove to bate the charges brought against them.

Their victim, now grown calmer, agreed to take seven shillings, but Mr. Baskerville would not hear of this.

He (Baskerville) insisted upon observance of his (Baskerville) ruling, and the man with the bullocks at length brought out a leather purse and counted from it seven shillings.

To these his (man) companion added three.

Then the leader flung the money on the ground, and to accompaniment of laughter and hisses hastened after his (man) stock.

The cattle were not for Princetown, and soon both men and their cavalcade plodded onward again into the peace and silence of a mist-clad moor.

They cursed themselves weary, kicked the offending dog and, with a brute instinct to revenge their mishap, smote and bruised the head of the bullock responsible for this misfortune when it stopped to drink at a pool beside the road.

Humphrey Baskerville won a full measure of applause on this occasion.

He (Baskerville) took himself off as swiftly as possible afterwards; but words were spoken of approval and appreciation, and he (Baskerville) could not help hearing them.

His (Baskerville) heart grew hot within him (Baskerville).

A man shouted after him (man),

``Good for the old Hawk!'' (him)

Before he (man) had driven off, Nathan Baskerville met him (Baskerville) at `The Duchy Hotel' and strove to make him (Baskerville) drink.

``A drop you must have along with me,'' (he)
he (Baskerville) said.

``Why, there's a dozen fellows in the street told me how you handled those drovers.

You ought to have the Commission of the Peace, that's what you ought to have.

You're cut out for it.'' (unknown)

``A lot of lunatics,'' (unknown)
answered the elder.

``No presence of mind in fifty of 'em.

Nought was done by me.

The job might have cost a life, but it didn't, so enough's said.

I won't drink.

I must get back home.'' (unknown)

``Did the ponies go off well?'' (unknown)

``Very.

If you see Susan Hacker, tell her (Hacker) I've gone.

The old fool's on one of they roundabouts, I expect.

And if she (Hacker) breaks it down, she (Hacker) needn't come back to me for the damages.'' (unknown)

``A joke!

A joke from you!

This is a day of wonders, to be sure!'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)

cried Nathan.

``Now crown all and come along o' me, and we'll find the rest of the family and the Linterns, and all have a merry-go-round together!'' (brother)

But his (Nathan) brother was gone, and Nathan turned and rejoined a party of ram-buyers in the street.

Elsewhere Mrs. Lintern and Mrs. Baskerville walked together.

Their hearts were not in the fair, but they spoke of the pending marriage and hoped that a happy union was in store for Ned and Cora.

The young couple themselves tasted such humble delights as the fair could offer, but Cora's pleasure was represented by the side glances of other girls, and she (Baskerville) regarded the gathering as a mere theatre for her (Baskerville) own display.

Ned left her (Baskerville) now and again and then returned.

Each time he (Ned) came back he (Ned) lifted his (Ned) hat to her (Baskerville) and exhibited some new sign of possession.

Cora affected great airs and a supercilious play of eyebrow that impressed the other young women.

She (Baskerville) condescended to walk round the fair and regarded this perambulation as a triumph, until the man who sold watches marked her (Baskerville) among his (man) listeners, observed her (Baskerville) vanity, and raised a laugh at her (Baskerville) expense.

Then she (Baskerville) lost her (Baskerville) temper and declared her (Baskerville) wish to depart.

She (Baskerville) was actually going when there came up Milly and her (Milly) husband, Rupert Baskerville.

Ned whispered to his (Ned) sister-in-law to save the situation if possible, and Milly with some tact and some good fortune managed to do so.

Cora smoothed her (Milly) ruffled feathers and joined the rest of the family at the inn.

There all partook of the special ordinary furnished on this great occasion to the countryside.

In another quarter Thomas Gollop, Joe Voysey and their friends took pleasure after their fashion.

Every man won some sort of satisfaction from the fair and held his (man) day as well spent.

Perhaps few could have explained what drew them thither or kept them for many hours wandering up and down, now drinking, now watching the events of the fair, now eating, now drinking again.

But so the day passed with most among them, and not until evening darkened did the mist thicken into rain and seriously damp the proceedings.

Humphrey Baskerville, well pleased with his (Baskerville) sales and even better pleased with the trivial incident of the bullock, went his (Baskerville) way homeward and was glad to be gone.

His (Baskerville) state of mind was such that he (Baskerville) gave alms to two mournful men limping slowly on crutches into Princetown.

Each of these wounded creatures had lost a leg, and one lacked an arm also.

They dragged along a little barrel-organ that played hymns, and their faces were thin, anxious, hunger-bitten.

These men stopped Mr. Baskerville, but not to beg.

They desired to know the distance yet left to traverse before they reached the fair.

``We set out afore light from Dousland, but we didn't know what a terrible road 'twas,'' (unknown)
said one.

``You see, with but a pair o' legs between us, we can't travel very fast.'' (Humphrey/Humphrey Baskerville/HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE)

Humphrey considered, and his (Humphrey) heart being uplifted above its customary level of caution, he (Humphrey) acted with most unusual impulse and served these maimed musicians in a manner that astounded them.

His (Humphrey) only terror was that somebody might mark the deed; but this did not happen, and he (Humphrey) accomplished his (Humphrey) charity unseen.

``It's up this hill,'' (he)
he (Humphrey) said;
``but the hill's a steep one, and the fair will be half over afore you get there at this gait.'' (he)

The men shrugged their shoulders and prepared to stump on.

``Get in,'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)
said Mr. Baskerville.

``Get in, the pair of you, and I'll run you to the top.'' (He)

He (Baskerville) alighted and helped them to lift their organ up behind, while they thanked him (Baskerville) to the best of their power.

They talked and he (Baskerville) listened as he (Baskerville) drove them; and outside the village, on level ground, he (Baskerville) dropped them again and gave them half-a-crown.

Much heartened and too astonished to display great gratitude, they crawled upon their way while Humphrey turned again.

The taste of the giving was good to the old man, and its flavour astonished him (man).

He (man) overtook the drovers and their cattle presently, and it struck him (man) that this company it was who had made the day so remarkable for him (man).

He (man) half determined with himself to stop and speak with them and even restore the money he (man) had exacted; for well he (man) knew the gravity of their loss.

But, unfortunately for themselves, the twain little guessed what was in his (man) mind; they still smarted from their disaster, and when they saw the cause of it they swore at him (man), shook their fists and threatened to do him (man) evil if opportunity offered.

Whereupon Mr. Baskerville hardened his (Baskerville) heart, kept his (Baskerville) money in his (Baskerville) pocket and drove forward.

CHAPTER IX The sensitive Cora could endure no shadow of ridicule.

To laugh at her (twain) was to anger her (twain), for she (twain) took herself too seriously, the common error of those who do not take their fellow-creatures seriously enough.

When, therefore, she (twain) committed a stupid error and Ned chaffed her (twain) about it, there sprang up a quarrel between them, and Cora, in her (twain) wounded dignity, even went so far as to talk of postponing marriage.

Nathan Baskerville explained the complication to a full bar; and when he (Baskerville) had done so the tide of opinion set somewhat against Ned's future bride.

``You must know that Phyllis Lintern has gone away from home, and last thing she (Lintern) did before she (Lintern) went was to ask Cora to look after a nice little lot of young ducks that belonged to her (Lintern) and were coming forward very hopeful.

Of course, Cora said she (Lintern) would, and one day, mentioning it to my nephew Rupert's wife, Milly told her (Milly) that the heads of nettles, well chopped up, were splendid food for young ducks.

Wishful to please Phyllis and bring on the birds, what does Cora do but busy herself for 'em?

She (Phyllis) gets the nettle-tops and chops 'em up and gives 'em to the ducklings; and of course the poor wretches all sting their throats and suffocate themselves.

For why?

Because she (Phyllis) let 'em have the food raw!

We all know she (Phyllis) ought to have boiled the nettles.

And a good few have laughed at her (Phyllis) about it and made her (Phyllis) a bit savage.'' (unknown)

``That's no reason, surely, why she (Phyllis) should quarrel with her (Phyllis) sweetheart.

'Twasn't his (Cora) fault,'' (Jack/Jack Head)

declared Jack Head, who was in the bar.

``None in the world; but Ned joked her (Phyllis) and made her (Phyllis) rather snappy.

In fact, he (Ned) went on a bit too long.

You can easily overdo a thing like that.

And none of us like a joke at our expense to be pushed too far.'' (unknown)

``It shows what a clever woman she (woman) is, all the same,'' (Mr. Voysey)
declared Mr. Voysey;
``for when Ned poked fun at her (woman) first, which he (Ned) did coming out of church on Sunday, I was by and heard her (woman).

What d'you think she (woman) said?

`You don't boil thistles for a donkey,' says she (woman), `so how was anybody to know you boil nettles for a duck?'

Pretty peart that--eh?'' (Mr. Voysey)

``So it was,'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)
declared Nathan.

``Very sharp, and a good argument for that matter.

I've bought Phyllis a dozen new birds and nothing more need come of it; but Ned's a bit of a fool here and there, and he (Ned) hadn't the sense to let well alone; and now she (Phyllis)'s turned on him (Ned).'' (unknown)

``He (Ned)'ll fetch her (Phyllis) round, a chap so clever with the girls as him (chap),'' (Joe Voysey/Joe/Voysey)
said Voysey; whereupon Timothy Waite, who was of the company, laughed scornfully.

``How can that man be clever at anything?'' (he)

he (man) asked.

``Here's his (man) own uncle.

Be Ned clever at anything on God's earth but spending money, Mr. Baskerville?

Come now!

An honest answer.'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)
replied Nathan promptly.

``He (Nathan) was never known to fall off a horse.'' (Timothy/Waite/Mr. Waite)

The laugh rose against Timothy, for the farmer's various abilities did not extend to horsemanship.

He (Timothy) had been thrown a week before and still went a little lame.

``Ned's all right,'' (Jack/Jack Head)
added Jack Head.

``Lazy, no doubt--like everybody else who can be.

But he (Head)'s generous and good-hearted, and no man's enemy.

The girl's a fool to keep him (fool) dangling.

A little more of it and he (fool)'ll--however, I'll not meddle in other people's business.'' (Mr. Gollop/Gollop)

Mr. Gollop entered at this moment and saw his (Gollop) foe.

``Do I hear John Head saying that he (Head) don't meddle with other people's business?'' (the sexton)

asked the sexton.

``Gin cold, please.

Well, well; since when have Head made that fine rule?'' (unknown)

``Drink your gin,'' (Jack/Jack Head)
said Jack,
``and then have another.

You ban't worth talking to till you've got a drop of liquor in you.

When you're tuned up I'll answer you.

How's Masterman getting on?

He (Masterman) must be a patient man, or else a terrible weak one, to have you still messing about the church.'' (Jack/Jack Head)

``Better you leave the church alone,'' (Thomas/Thomas Gollop)
retorted Thomas.

``You'd pull down every church in the land if you could; and if it wasn't for men like me, as withstand your sort and defy you, there'd very soon be no law and order in the State.'' (Jack/Jack Head)

'''Tis your blessed church where there's no law and order,'' answered Jack.

``The State's all right so long as the Liberals be in; but a house divided against itself falleth.

You won't deny that.

And that's the hobble you Christians have come to.

And so much the easier work for my side--to sweep the whole quarrelsome, narrow-minded boiling of you to the devil.'' (unknown)

``Stop there, Jack!'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

cried Mr. Baskerville.

``No religion in this bar and no politics.

You know the rules.'' (unknown)

``Let him (Baskerville) go on,'' (Gollop/Eliza/Eliza Gollop)
said Gollop gloomily.

``There's a bitter truth in what he (Baskerville) says.

We're not shoulder to shoulder and none can pretend we are.

Take Masterman--that man!

What did he (man) say only this morning in vestry?

`Gollop,' he (man) said, `the roots are being starved.

If we don't get rain pretty quick there'll be no turnips--no, nor mangolds neither.''' (a dozen)

Half a dozen raised their voices in support of this assertion.

``That's truth anyway,'' (Timothy/Waite/Mr. Waite)
declared Timothy.

``Never knew such a beastly drought at this season.

Even rain will not bring the crop up to average weight now.

It's beyond nature to do it.'' (unknown)

``Well, he (Timothy)'s going to pray for rain,'' (Gollop/Eliza/Eliza Gollop)
said Gollop.

``Next Sunday we shall ax for `moderate rain and showers.''' (unknown)

``Well, why not?'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)

asked Nathan.

``That's what the man's there for surely.'' (unknown)

``Why not?

Because the glass is up `pon top of everything, and the wind's in the east steady as a rock.

That's why not.

You don't want prayer to be turned into a laughing-stock.

We don't want our ministers to fly in the face of Providence, do we?

To pray for rain at present be equally mad as to pray for snow.

'Tis just courting failure.

Then this here man, Jack Head, and other poisonous members, will laugh, like Elijah when he (Elijah) drawed on them false prophets, and say our Jehovah be asleep.'' (unknown)

``Not me,'' (unknown)
answered Head.

'''Tis your faith be asleep.

You've given your side away properly now, my bold hero!

So you've got such a poor opinion of your Jehovah that you reckon to ax Him (hero) to take the wind out of the east be going too far?

But you're right.

Your God can't do it.

All the same, Masterman's a better Christian than you.''

``You speak as a rank atheist, Jack,'' (Timothy/Waite/Mr. Waite)
said Timothy Waite.

``And what sense there is in you is all spoiled because you're so fierce and sour.'' (unknown)

``Not me--far from it.

We was talking of Jehovah, I believe, and there's no law against free speech now, so I've a right to say my say without being called to order by you or any man.

Tom here don't trust his (Tom) God to bring rain when the glass is set fair; and I say that he (Tom) be perfectly right--that's all.

Gollop ought to have the faith that moves mountains, no doubt; but he (Tom) hasn't.

He (Tom) can't help feeling terrible shaky when it comes to a challenge.

That's the good my side's doing, though he (Tom) do swear at us.

We're making the people common-sensible.

Faith have had a long run for its money.

Now we're going to give Works a bit of a show.

Masterman fawns on Jehovah like a spaniel bitch, and thinks that all this shoe-licking be going to soften the God of the stars.

But if there was a God, He (God)'d be made of sterner stuff than man makes Him (God).

We shouldn't get round Him (man), like a naughty boy round a weak father.

In fact, you might so well try to stop a runaway steam-roller by offering it a cabbage-leaf, as to come round a working God by offering Him (God) prayers.'' (unknown)

``How you can stand this under your roof, Nathan, I'm blessed if I know,'' (Mr. Gollop/Gollop)
grumbled Mr. Gollop.

'''Tis very evil speaking, and no good will come to you by it.''

``Light will shine even on this man afore the end,'' (the innkeeper)
declared the innkeeper.

``God will explain as much as is good for Jack to know.

He (God) shows each of us as much as we can bear to see--like He (God) did Moses.

If Jehovah was to shine too bright on the likes of Head here, He (God)'d dazzle the man and blind him (God).'' (unknown)

``God will explain--eh?

That's what you said, Nat.

Then why don't He (God) explain?

I'm a reasonable man.

I'm quite ready and willing to hear.

But `twill take God all His (God) time to explain some of His (God) hookem-snivey tricks played on honest, harmless humans.

Let's hear first why He (God) let the snake into the garden at all, to fool those two poor grown-up children.

You talk about original sin!

'Tis a dirty lie against human nature.

If you're in the right, 'twas your God sent it--stuck the tree under Eve's nose--just as if I put a bunch of poison berries in a baby's hand and said, `You mustn't eat 'em,' and then left the rest to chance and an enemy.

Who'd be blamed if the child ate and died?

Why, I should.

And jury would bring it in murder--quite right too.

Look at your God's blackguard doings against all they peaceful people He (God) set His (God) precious Jews against!

Shameful, I call it.

Driving 'em out of their countries, harrying 'em, killing 'em by miracles, because He (God) knowed the Jews wasn't good men enough to do it.

Chosen people!

A pretty choice!

He (God)'s been judging us ever since He (God) made us; now let's judge Him (God) a bit, and see what His (God) games look like to the eyes of a decently taught Board School boy.'' (unknown)

``You'll roast for this, John Head, and well you'll deserve it,'' (Mr. Gollop/Gollop)
said Mr. Gollop.

``Not I, Thomas.

I've just as much right to crack a joke against your ugly, short-tempered Jehovah as you would have to laugh at the tuft of feathers on the end of a pole that foreign savages might call God.

There's not a pin to choose betwixt them and you.'' (unknown)

``We can only hope you'll have the light afore you've gone too far, Jack,'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)
said Nathan.

``You're getting up home to sixty, and I'm sure I hope God's signal-post will rise up on your path afore you go much further.'' (unknown)

'''Tis certainly time,'' answered Head.

``And if your God's in earnest and wants to put me right, the sooner He (God) begins the better for us both--for my salvation and His (God) credit.'' (unknown)

``He (God)'s got His (God) holy self-respect, however,'' (Gollop/Eliza/Eliza Gollop)
argued Gollop.

``If I was Him (God), I'd not give myself a thought over the likes of you.

`Good riddance'--that's what I should say.'' (unknown)

``If you was God for five minutes I wonder what you'd do, Tom,'' (Joe Voysey/Joe/Voysey)
speculated Joe Voysey.

``Give me a new back, I hope.

That's the first favour I should ax.'' (unknown)

``I'd catch you up into heaven, Joe.

That's the kindest thing the Almighty could do for you.'' (Joe Voysey/Joe/Voysey)

But Voysey looked doubtful.

``If you was to wait till I gived the word, `twould be better,'' (he)
he (Voysey) said.

``Nobody wants to leave his (Voysey) job unfinished.'' (unknown)

``A good brain gone to rot--that's what's happened to you, Jack,'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)
said Nathan sadly.

``Lord, He (Lord) only knows why you are allowed to think such thoughts.

No doubt there's a reason for it, since nought can happen without a reason; but the why and wherefore are hid from us common men, like much else that's puzzling.

Anyway, we can stick to this--we Christians: though you've got no use for God, Jack, 'tis certain that God's got a use for you; and there may be those among us who will live to see what that use is.'' (unknown)

``Well, I'm ready for a whisper,'' (the free-thinker)
declared the free-thinker.

``He (God) won't have to tell me twice--if He (God) only makes His (God) meaning clear the first time.'' (Heathman/Heathman Lintern)

They talked a little longer, and then Heathman Lintern came among them.

``Be Jack Head here?'' (he)

he (Jack) asked.

``The chimney to his (Jack) house have took fire seemingly, and policeman's made a note of it.

But 'twas pretty near out when I come by.'' (unknown)

``Hell!'' (Jack/Jack Head)

cried Jack.

``That's another five shilling gone!'' (He)

He (Jack) left hurriedly to the tune of laughter, and failed to hear Gollop's triumphant final argument.

``There!

There!'' (the sexton)

shouted the sexton.

``There 'tis--`hell' in his (sexton) everyday speech!

He (sexton) can't get away from it: 'tis part of nature and a common item--just as natural as heaven.

And argue as he (sexton) pleases, the moment he (sexton)'s took out of himself, the truth slips.

Well may he (sexton) say `hell'!

There's nobody living round here will ever have more cause to say it.

And that he (sexton)'ll find long afore I, or another, drop the clod on his (sexton) bones.'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)

CHAPTER X Thanks more to the diplomacy of Nathan Baskerville than Ned's own skill in reconciliation, Cora forgave her (sexton) lover and their marriage day was fixed.

Not a few noticed that the master of `The White Thorn' held this union much to heart, and indeed appeared more interested in its achievement than any other save Ned himself.

A change had come over Nathan and his (Nathan) strength failed him (Nathan).

The affection of his (Nathan) throat gained upon him (Nathan) and his (Nathan) voice grew weaker.

He (Nathan) resented allusions to the fact and declared that he (Nathan) was well.

Only his (Nathan) doctor and Priscilla Lintern knew the truth; and only she (Lintern) understood that much more than physical tribulation was responsible for the innkeeper's feverish activity of mind and unsleeping energy poured forth in secret upon affairs.

The extent of this immense diligence and devotion was hidden even from her (Lintern).

She (Lintern) supposed that a temporary cloud had passed away; and she (Lintern) ceased not, therefore, from begging him (innkeeper) to save his (innkeeper) powers and so afford himself an opportunity to recover.

But the man believed that he (innkeeper) was doomed, and suspected that his (innkeeper) life could only be held upon uncertain tenure of months.

The doctor would not go so far as this gloomy opinion; yet he (doctor) did not deny that it might be justified.

Nathan felt no doubt in his (Nathan) own mind, and he (Nathan) believed that Cora's wedding was the last considerable event of a personal and precious nature that he (Nathan) could hope to see accomplished.

Afterwards, but not until he (Nathan) found himself upon his (Nathan) deathbed, the innkeeper designed a confession.

Circumstances and justice, as he (Nathan) conceived it, must make this avowal private; but those most interested were destined to know the hidden truth concerning themselves.

He (Nathan) had debated the matter with Priscilla, since decision rested with her (Priscilla); but she (Priscilla) was of his (Nathan) mind and, indeed, had been the first to suggest this course.

Cora's shopping roused all the household of Undershaugh to a high pitch of exasperation.

Much to the girl's surprise her (girl) mother produced fifty pounds for a wedding outfit, and the bride employed agreeable days in Plymouth while she (girl) expended this handsome gift.

A house had been taken at Plympton.

The face of it was `genteel' in Cora's estimation; but the back was not.

However, the rear premises satisfied Ned, and its position with respect to town and country suited them both.

There remained contracts and settlements, in which Nathan Baskerville represented both parties.

Ned was generous and indifferent; Cora exhibited interest and a faculty for grasping details.

She (girl) told herself that it was only reasonable and wise to do so.

At any time the reckless Ned might break his (Ned) neck; at any time the amorous Ned might find her (girl) not all-sufficing.

No sentiment obscured Cora's outlook.

She (girl) astounded Nathan Baskerville by the shrewdness of her (girl) stipulations.

Few prophesied much joy of this marriage, and even Priscilla, albeit Nathan was impatient at her (Priscilla) doubts, none the less entertained misgivings.

She (Priscilla) knew the truth of her (Priscilla) daughter, and had long since learned the truth concerning young Baskerville.

Those who desired to comfort her (Priscilla) foretold that man and wife would go each their own way and mind each their own business and pleasure.

Not the most sanguine pretended to suppose that Ned and Cora would unite in any bonds of close and durable affection.

The man's mother trusted that Cora's common-sense and practical spirit might serve as a steady strain to curb his (Cora) slothful nature; but May Baskerville was the only living soul who, out of her (mother) warm heart and trusting disposition, put faith in his (Cora) marriage to lift her (mother) brother toward a seemly and steadfast position in the ranks of men.

At Hawk House the subject of the wedding might not be mentioned.

In consequence renewed coolness had arisen between the brothers.

Then came a rumour to Humphrey's ear that Nathan was ill, and he (Nathan) felt concern.

The old man had no eye to mark physical changes.

He (man) was slow to discern moods or read the differences of facial expression, begot by mental trouble on the one hand and bodily suffering on the other.

Now, greatly to his (man) surprise, he (man) heard that Nathan began to be very seriously indisposed.

The news came to him (Nathan) one morning a month before Cora's wedding.

Heathman Lintern called upon the subject of a stallion, and mentioned casually that Humphrey's brother had lost his (brother) voice and might never regain it.

'''Tis terrible queer in the bar at `The White Thorn' not to hear him (Thorn) and to know we never may no more,'' he (Thorn) said.

``He (Thorn)'s gone down and down very gradual; but now he (Thorn) can only whisper.

'Tis a wisht thing to lose the power of speech--like a living death, you might say.'' (unknown)

``When did this happen?

I've marked no change, though 'tis a good few weeks now since I spoke with him (Thorn).'' (unknown)

``It comed gradual, poor chap.'' (Humphrey/Humphrey Baskerville/HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE)

Humphrey rose and prepared on the instant to start for Shaugh.

``I must see the man,'' (he)
he (man) said.

``We're out for the minute owing to this wedding.

But, since he (man)'s fallen ill, I must go to him (man).

We'll hope 'tis of no account.'' (Heathman/Heathman Lintern)

They set out together and Heathman was mildly surprised to learn the other's ignorance.

``He (man) keeps it so close; but you can't hide your face.

We've all marked it.

The beard of the man's grown so white as if the snow had settled on it, and his (man) cheeks be drawed too.

For my part I never felt nothing in life to make me go down-daunted afore, except when your son Mark died; but, somehow, Nat Baskerville be a part of the place and the best part.

I've got a great feeling towards him (Mark).

'Tis making us all very uncomfortable.

Especially my mother.

He (Mark) talks to her (mother) a lot, feeling how more than common wise she (mother) be; and she (mother) knows a lot about him (Mark).

She (mother)'s terrible down over it and, in fact, 'tis a bad job all round, I'm afraid.'' (Humphrey/Humphrey Baskerville/HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE)

Humphrey's answer was to quicken his (Humphrey) pace.

``He (Humphrey) kept it from me,'' (he)
he (Humphrey) replied.

``I suppose he (Humphrey) thought I ought to have seen it for myself.

Or he (Humphrey) might have wrongly fancied I didn't care.'' (unknown)

``Everybody cares--such a wonderful good sort as him (Humphrey).

`Twill cast a gloom over this blessed wedding.

I wish to God 'twas over and done with--the wedding, I mean--since it's got to be.'' (unknown)

``Why do you wish that?'' (unknown)

``Because I'm sick of the thing and that awnself-LSB-1-RSB- baggage, my sister.

God's truth!

To watch her (sister) getting ready.

Everything's got to go down afore her (sister), like the grass afore the scythe.

You may work your fingers to the bone and never get a thank you.

I had a row with her (sister) last night, and she (sister) got lashing me with her (sister) tongue till I rose up and fetched her (sister) a damned hard box on the ear, grown woman though she (sister) is.

My word, it tamed her (sister) too!

`There!'

I said.

`That's better than all the words in the dictionary.

You keep your snake's tongue between your teeth,' I said.

There's no answering her (sister) with words, but if her (sister) husband has got a pinch of sense, which he (husband) hasn't, he (husband)'ll do well to give her (sister) a hiding at the start.

It acted like a charm.'' (unknown)

-LSB-1-RSB- Awnself --selfish.

``Don't want to hear nothing about that.

They're making their own bed, and `twill be uneasy lying,'' (Humphrey/Humphrey Baskerville/HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE)

said Humphrey.

``Leave them, and talk of other things.'' (unknown)

``Very pleased,'' (Cora/Cora Lintern/Lintern)
answered Lintern.

``Ban't a subject I'm fond of.

Undershaugh without Cora would be a better place to live in--I know that and I say it.

And my mother knows it too; though say it she (mother) won't.'' (subjects)

They talked on various subjects, and Heathman informed Mr. Baskerville that he (Baskerville) would soon be a great-uncle.

``Rupert's wife be going to have a babby--that's the last news.

I heard it yester-eve at `The White Thorn.''' (unknown)

``Is that so?

They might have told me, you'd think.

Yet none has.

They kept it from me.'' (unknown)

``Holding it for a surprise; or maybe they didn't think `twould interest you.'' (unknown)

``No doubt that was the reason,'' (Humphrey/Humphrey Baskerville/HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE)
answered Humphrey.

And then he (Humphrey) spoke no more, but worked his (Humphrey) own thoughts into a ferment of jealous bitterness until the village was reached.

Arrived, he (Humphrey) took no leave of Heathman, but forgot his (Humphrey) presence and hastened to the inn.

Nathan was standing at the door in his (Nathan) apron, and the brothers entered together.

``What's this I hear?'' (Humphrey/Humphrey Baskerville/HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE)

said Humphrey as they entered the other's private chamber.

``Well, I'm ill, to be frank.

In fact, very ill.

I'd hoped to hide it up till after the wedding; but my voice has pretty well gone, you see.

Gone for good.

You'll never hear it again.

But that won't trouble you much--eh?'' (unknown)

``I should have marked something wrong when last we met, no doubt.

But you angered me a bit, and angry men are like drunken ones; their senses fail them.

I didn't see or hear what had happed to you.

Now I look and listen, I mark you're bad.

What does the doctor say?'' (he)

'''Tis what he (doctor) don't say.

But I've got it out of him (doctor).

He (doctor) took me to Plymouth a month ago--to some very clever man there.

I've talked such a lot in my life that I deserve to be struck dumb--such a chatterbox as I have been.''

``Is that all?'' (unknown)

``For the present.

We needn't go beyond that.

I shall soon get used to listening instead of talking.

Maybe I'll grow wiser for it.'' (unknown)

``That wasn't all they told you?'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)

Nathan looked round and shut the door which stood ajar behind them.

``There's no hiding anything from you that you want to find out.

As a matter of fact, I'm booked.

I know it.

'Tis only a question of--of months--few or many.

They give me time to put things as straight--as straight as I can.'' (unknown)

``So like as not they lie.

You'll do better to go off to London while you may, and get the best opinion up there.'' (unknown)

``I would, if 'twas only to pleasure you.

But that's no use now.'' (unknown)

``Can you let down your food easy?'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)

Nathan shook his (Nathan) head.

``I dare not eat in company no more,'' (he)
he (Nathan) said;
``it's here.'' (he)

He (Nathan) put his (Nathan) hand to his (Nathan) throat and then drew it down.

``You don't suffer, I hope?'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)

Nathan nodded.

``I can tell you, but I trust you not to let it out to any soul.

We must have the wedding off cheerful and bright.

I shall keep going till then, if I'm careful.

Only a month now.'' (unknown)

``You ought to be lying up close, and never put your nose out this coarse weather.'' (unknown)

``Time enough.

Leave it now.

I'm all right.

I've had a good life--better than you might think for.

I wish for my sake, and knowing that I've got my end in sight, you'd do the last thing you can for me and countenance this wedding.

Perhaps I've no right to ask; but if you knew--if you knew how hard life can be when the flesh gives way and there's such a lot left to do and think about.

If you only knew--'' (unknown)

``You say `the last thing I can do for you.'

Are you sure of that?'' (the man)

A strange and yearning expression crossed the face of the younger man.

He (man) stroked his (man) beard nervously and Humphrey, now awake to physical accidents, marked that his (man) hands were grown very thin and his (man) skin had taken on it a yellowish tinge of colour.

There was silence between them for some moments.

Then Nathan shook his (Nathan) head and forced a smile upon his (Nathan) face.

``Nothing else--nothing at all.

But it's no small thing that I ask.

I know that.

You've a right to feel little affection for either of them--Ned or Cora.

But my case is different.

Cora's mother--'' (he)

Again he (Cora) stopped, but Humphrey did not speak.

``Cora's mother has been a good friend to me in many ways.

She (mother) is a clever woman and can keep her (mother) own counsel.

There's more of Priscilla Lintern in Cora than you might think.

You'll never know how terribly Cora felt Mark's death; but she (Lintern) did.

Only she (Lintern) hid it close.

As to Ned--'' (He)

He (Ned) began to cough and suffered evident pain in the process.

When the cough ceased it was some time before he (Ned) could speak.

Then, to Humphrey's discomfort, his (Humphrey) brother began to weep.

``There--there,'' (he)
he (Humphrey) said, as one talks to a child.

``What I can do, I'll do.

God knows this is a harsh shock to me.

I didn't dream of such a thing overtaking you.

How old are you?'' (unknown)

``In my sixty-third year.'' (unknown)

``Hope despite 'em.

They don't know everything.

Pray to the Almighty about it.

You're weak.

You ought to drink, if you can't eat.

I'll come to the wedding and I'll give the woman a gift--for your sake and her (woman) mother's--not for her (woman) own.'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)

Nathan, now unnerved, could not reply.

But he (Nathan) took his (Nathan) brother's hand and held it.

``God bless you for this,'' (he)
he (God) whispered.

``If you could but understand me better and believe that with all my black faults I've meant well, I should die easier, Humphrey.'' (unknown)

``Don't talk about dying.

You're a bit low.

I haven't forgotten when Mark went.

Now 'tis my turn.

Why don't you trust me?'' (unknown)

``You never trusted me, Humphrey.'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)

The other darted a glance and Nathan's eyes fell.

``Never--and you were right not to,'' (he)
he (Humphrey) added.

Humphrey rose.

``I'm your brother and your friend.

I can't be different to what I am.

I don't respect you--never did.

But--well--a silly word most times, but I'll use it--I love you well enough.

Why shouldn't I?

You're my brother--all I've got left.

I'm cut up about this.

I wish I could lighten your load, and I'm willing to do it if 'tis in my power.'' (unknown)

``You have.

If you come to that wedding I shall die a happy man.'' (unknown)

``That's nought.

Ban't there anything deeper I can do--for you yourself and your peace of mind?'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)

Again Nathan struggled with his (Nathan) desires.

But pride kept him (Nathan) silent.

He (Nathan) could not tell the truth.

``No,'' (he)
he (Nathan) answered at last.

``Nothing for me myself.'' (unknown)

``Or for any other?'' (The innkeeper)

The innkeeper became agitated.

``No, no.

You've done a good day's work.

No more for the present.

I've not thrown up the sponge yet.

Will you take a glass of the old sloe gin before you go?'' (Humphrey/Humphrey Baskerville/HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE)

Humphrey shook his (Humphrey) head.

``Not for me.

When's the wedding?'' (unknown)

``Third of November.'' (unknown)

``I shall be there, and your--Cora Lintern will have a letter from me next week.'' (unknown)

``You make me a happier man than you know, Humphrey.'' (unknown)

``Let it rest then.

I'll see you again o' Sunday.'' (companies)

They parted, and while one put on his (Humphrey) hat and hastened with tremulous excitement to Undershaugh, the other breasted the hill homewards, and buttoned his (Humphrey) coat to the wind which sent leaves flying in wild companies at the spinney edge by Beatland Corner.

The sick man rejoiced upon his (man) way; the hale man went moodily.

``I can do no more,'' (Humphrey/Humphrey Baskerville/HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE)
said Humphrey to himself.

``He (Humphrey)'s a Baskerville, despite the grip of death on him (Humphrey).

Perhaps I was a fool to tell him (fool) I didn't respect him (fool).

He (fool)'ll think of it again when he (fool)'s got time for thought by night, and `twill rasp home.'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)

Following upon this incident it seemed for a season that Nathan's health mended.

His (Nathan) disease delayed a little upon its progress, and he (Nathan) even hoped in secret that his (Nathan) brother might be right and the physicians wrong.

He (Nathan) flashed with a spark of his (Nathan) old fire.

He (Nathan) whispered jokes that woke noisy laughter.

In secret he (Nathan) ticked off the days that remained before Ned and Cora should be married.

It wanted less than a fortnight to the event, and all was in readiness for it.

Humphrey Baskerville had sent Cora twenty pounds, and she (Nathan) had visited him (Baskerville) and thanked him (Baskerville) personally for his (Baskerville) goodness.

The old man had also seen Ned, and although his (man) nephew heard few compliments and came from the interview in a very indignant frame of mind, yet it was felt to be well that Humphrey had thus openly suffered the past to be obliterated.

Then came a midnight when Priscilla Lintern, lying awake and full of anxious thoughts, heard upon the silence a sound.

At first she (Lintern) believed it to be the four feet of some wandering horse as he (Humphrey) struck the ground with his (Humphrey) hoofs in leisurely fashion, and slowly passed along the deserted road; then she (Lintern) perceived that it was the two feet of a man moving briskly and carrying him (man) swiftly forward.

The feet stopped, the outer wicket gate was opened, and some one came to the door.

Priscilla's window looked forth from a thatched dormer above, and now she (Priscilla) threw it up and leant out.

She (Priscilla) knew by intuition the name of the man below.

``Is that you, Jim?'' (she)

she (Priscilla) asked.

``Yes'm.

Master's took cruel bad and can't fetch his (Master) breath.

He (Master) knocked me up, and I went first for Miss Gollop, who was to home luckily.

Then I comed for you.'' (Mrs. Lintern)

Mrs. Lintern was already putting on her (Lintern) clothes.

``You'd best to go back,'' (she)
she (Lintern) said.

``I'll be up over at once, after I've waked up my son and sent him (son) riding for doctor.'' (Heathman/Heathman Lintern)

Fifteen minutes later Heathman, still half asleep, cantered on a pony through a rainy night for medical help, and his (son) mother hastened up to `The White Thorn,' and steeled her (mother) heart for what she (mother) might find there.

She (mother) had long learned to conceal all emotion of spirit, and she (mother) knew that under no possible stress of grief or terror would truth have power to escape the prison of her (mother) heart.

CHAPTER XI The accident of a heavy cold had suddenly aggravated the morbid condition of Nathan Baskerville's throat, and set all doubt of the truth at rest.

Often on previous occasions he (Baskerville) had anticipated death at short notice, and prepared to face it; but now he (Baskerville) trusted fate not to deal the final blow before his (Baskerville) daughter's marriage.

His (Baskerville) only concern was to be on his (Baskerville) feet again swiftly, that none of the plans for the wedding should be changed.

The doctor warned him (doctor) that he (doctor) was very ill, and took the gravest view of his (doctor) condition; but Nathan, out of a sanguine heart, declared that he (Nathan) would make at least a transient recovery.

He (Nathan) obeyed the medical man's directions very carefully, however; he (Nathan) kept his (Nathan) bed and put himself into the hands of the parish nurse.

In sombre triumph she (nurse) came to this important case, and brought with her (nurse) certain errors of judgment and idiosyncrasies of character that went far to counter-balance real ability begot of experience.

She (nurse) was a good nurse, but an obstinate and foolish woman.

No more conscientious creature ruled a sick room or obeyed a doctor's mandate; but she (nurse) added to her (nurse) prescribed duties certain gratuitous moral ministrations which were not required by science or demanded by reason.

Mrs. Lintern saw Mr. Baskerville often, and sometimes shared the night watches with Eliza Gollop.

The latter viewed her (Gollop) attentions to Nathan and her (Gollop) emotion before his (Nathan) suffering with a suspicious eye.

But she (Gollop) reserved comment until after the end.

The case was not likely to be a long one in her (Gollop) opinion.

For one week little happened of a definite character, and during that time Nathan Baskerville saw his (Baskerville) relations and several of his (Baskerville) more intimate friends.

Then ensued a malignant change, and at the dawn of this deterioration, after the doctor had left him (doctor), Miss Gollop sat alone with her (Gollop) patient and endeavoured to elevate his (patient) emotions.

``I've flashed a bit of light on a wandering soul at many a deathbed,'' (she)
she (Gollop) declared;
``and I hope I shall be spared to do so at many more.

There's not a few men and women that wouldn't hear me in health, but they listened, meek as worms, when the end was in sight, and they hadn't strength left to move an eye-lash.

That's the time to drive truth home, Mr. Baskerville, and I've done it.

But always cheerful, mind.

I'm not the sort to give up hoping.'' (she)

``I'm sure not,'' (he)
he (Baskerville) whispered.

``Wasn't Christ's first and last message hope?'' (unknown)

``Don't you talk.

Let me do the talking.

Yes, 'twas hope He (Baskerville) brought into this hopeless world.

But even hope can be trusted too much.

You must put your hope in the next world now, not in this one, I'm afraid.'' (unknown)

``Did he (Baskerville) say so?'' (unknown)

``Yes--I knew he (Baskerville) would.

Death was in his (Baskerville) eyes when he (Baskerville) went out of your chamber.

Still, there's plenty of time.

Things may mend.

He (Baskerville)'s going to send a new physic.'' (unknown)

``What's the good of that if I've got to go?'' (unknown)

``You'll know presently, my poor man.

'Tis to ease what be bound to creep over you later on.'' (unknown)

``Bodily pain's nought.

Haven't I suffered all that man can suffer?'' (unknown)

``No, you haven't--not yet.

Don't talk about that part.

You shan't suffer while I'm here--not if I can help it in reason, and under doctor's orders.

But I won't stray beyond them; I was never known to take anything upon myself, like some of they hospital chits, that call themselves nurses, do.'' (unknown)

``When is Mrs. Lintern coming?'' (Gollop/Eliza/Eliza Gollop)

Eliza's lips tightened.

``Very soon, without a doubt; though why, I can't ezacally say.

Listen to me a little afore she (Lintern)'s here.

'Tis my duty to say these things to you, and you're not one that ever stood between man or woman and their duty.'' (unknown)

``I'll not see them married now.

That's cruel hard after--'' (unknown)

``How can you say that?

You may be there in the spirit, if not in the flesh.

I suppose you ban't one of they godless ones that say ghosts don't walk?

Haven't I beheld 'em with these eyes?

Didn't I go down to Mrs. Wonnacott at Shaugh Bridge in the dimpsy of the evening two year ago; and didn't I see a wishtness coming along out of they claypits there?

'Tis well known I seed it; and if it weren't the spirit of Abraham Vosper, as worked there for fifty year and then was run over by his (Abraham) own team of hosses and fractured to death in five places, whose spirit was it?

So you may be at your nephew's wedding with the best; and, for my part, I shall know you be there, and feel none the less cheerful for it.'' (unknown)

``So much to do--so many to save--and no strength and no time--no time,'' (he)
he (nephew) said.

The air was dark and hurtling with awful wings for Nathan Baskerville.

He (Baskerville) heard and saw the storm coming.

But others would feel it.

He (Baskerville) was safe from the actual hurricane, but, by anticipation, dreadfully he (Baskerville) endured it now.

Death would be no release save from physical disaster.

His (Baskerville) place was with the living, not with the dead.

Cruelly the living must need him (Baskerville) presently; the dead had no need of him (Baskerville).

Miss Gollop supposed that she (Gollop) read her (Gollop) patient's heart.

'''Tis your own soul you must seek to save, Mr. Baskerville.

None can save our souls but ourselves.

And as for time, thanks to the rivers of blood Christ shed, there's always time for a dip in 'em.

You're well thought on.

But that's nought.

'Tis the bird's-eye view the Almighty takes that will decide.

And our conscience tells us what that view's like to be.

'Tis a good sign you be shaken about it.

The best sort generally are.

I've seen an evil liver go to his (Almighty) doom like a babby dropping asleep off its mother's nipple; and I've seen a pious saint, such as my own father was, get into a terrible tear at the finish, as if he (father) seed all the devils in hell hotting up against his (father) coming.''

She (mother) ministered to the sick man, then sat down and droned on again.

But he (father) was not listening; his (father) strength had nearly gone, his (father) gaiety had vanished for ever.

Not a smile was left.

The next world at this juncture looked inexpressibly vain and futile.

He (father) cared not a straw about it.

He (father) was only concerned with his (father) present environment and the significance of passing from it at this juncture.

``Run out--all run out!'' (he)

he (father) whispered to himself.

Would there be no final parenthesis of strength to deal with the manifold matters now tumbling to chaos?

Was the end so near?

He (father) brushed aside lesser things and began to think of the one paramount obligation.

``Why don't she (father) come?

Why don't she (father) come?'' (he)

he (father) whispered; but Miss Gollop did not hear him (father).

This was a sort of moment when she (Gollop) felt the call of her (Gollop) faith mighty upon her (Gollop).

She (Gollop) had often inopportunely striven to drag a dying's man's mind away from earth to the spectacle of heaven and the immense difficulty of winning it.

``How many houses have you got, Mr.

Baskerville?'' (she)

she (Gollop) asked abruptly; and in a mechanical fashion he (Baskerville) heard and answered her (Gollop).

``Six--two here and four at Bickleigh; at least, they can't be called mine, I'm afraid, they're all--'' (unknown)
``And you'd give the lot for one little corner in a heavenly mansion--wouldn't you, Mr.

Baskerville?'' (unknown)

``No doubt--no doubt,'' (he)
he (Baskerville) said.

``Don't talk for a bit.

I'm broken; I'm terrible anxious; I must see-- Give me something to drink, please.'' (she)

While she (Gollop) obeyed him (Baskerville) Mrs. Lintern came in.

The doctor, who had perceived her (Lintern) tragic interest in the patient, kept her (Lintern) closely informed of his (patient) condition, and Priscilla had learned within the hour that Nathan was growing worse.

Now she (Priscilla) came, and Mr. Baskerville asked Miss Gollop to leave them.

``I can't think why,'' (Gollop/Eliza/Eliza Gollop)
murmured Eliza.

``I'm not generally told to go out except afore relations.

Still, I can take my walk now instead of this afternoon.

And if the new physic comes, don't you give him (Baskerville) none, Mrs. Lintern, please.

'Tis very powerful and dangerous, and only for skilled hands to handle.'' (the nurse)

Neither spoke until the nurse had departed.

``And I shall be gone exactly twenty minutes and no more,'' (she)
she (nurse) said.

``I've got my reputation, I believe, if some of us haven't; but with chapel people--'' (people)
The exact problem respecting chapel people she (nurse) left unstated, and in closing the door behind her (nurse) made some unnecessary noise.

Then Priscilla folded Nathan in her (Priscilla) arms and kissed him (Nathan).

He (Nathan) held her (Priscilla) hand and shut his (Nathan) eyes while she (Priscilla) talked; but presently he (Nathan) roused himself and indicated that the confession to his (Nathan) children must not in safety be longer delayed.

``I don't feel particular worse, though I had a bit of a fight for wind last night; but I am worse, and I may soon be a lot worse.

They'd better all come to-day--this afternoon.'' (unknown)

``They shall,'' (she)
she (Priscilla) promised.

``If that was all--my God, if that was all, Priscilla!'' (unknown)

``It is all that matters.'' (unknown)

'''Tis the least--the very least of it.

Dark--dark wherever I turn.

Plots miscarried, plans failed, good intentions all gone astray.''

She (Priscilla) thought that he (God) wandered.

``Don't talk, 'tis bad for you.

If you've got to go, go you must--God pity me without you!

But you are all right, such a steadfast man as you.

The poor will call you blessed, and your full tale of well-doing will never be told.'' (unknown)

``Well-meaning, that's all--not well-doing.

A dead man's motives don't count, 'tis his (man) deeds we rate him (man) by.

He (man)'s gone.

He (man) can't explain what he (man) meant.

Pray for me to live a bit longer, Priscilla.

Beg 'em for their prayers at the chapel; beg 'em for their prayers at church.

I'm terrible, terrible frighted to go just now, and that's truth.

Frighted for those I leave--for those I leave.'' (She)

She (Priscilla) calmed him (man) and sought to banish his (man) fears.

But he (man) entered upon a phase of mental excitement, deepening to frenzy.

He (man) was bathed in sweat and staring fixedly before him (man) when the nurse returned.

After noon the man had regained his (man) nerve and found himself ready for the ordeal.

A dose of the new drug brought ease and peace.

He (man) was astonished and sanguine to feel such comfort.

But his (man) voice from the strain of the morning had almost become extinguished.

When Priscilla and his (man) children came round him (man) and the family were alone, he (man) bade the woman speak.

``Tell them,'' (he)
he (man) said.

``I'm not feared to do it, since you wish them to know, but my throat is dumb.'' (Heathman/Heathman Lintern)

Heathman stood at the bottom of the bed and his (man) mother sat beside it.

Cora and Phyllis were in chairs by the fire.

They looked and saw Mrs. Lintern clasp her (Lintern) hands over Nathan Baskerville's.

The act inspired her (Lintern), and she (Lintern) met the astonished glances of her (Lintern) children.

``For all these years,'' (she)
she (Lintern) said,
``you've been kept without hearing the truth, you three.

You only knew I was a widow, and that Mr. Baskerville was a widower, and that we were friends always, and that he (Baskerville) never married again because his (Baskerville) dead wife didn't want him (Baskerville) to.

But there's more to know.

After Mrs. Baskerville died, Nathan here found me an orphan girl, working for my living in a china and glass shop at Bath.

I hadn't a relation or friend in the world, and he (friend) got to love me, and he (friend) wanted to marry me.

But I wouldn't have it, because, in honour to his (friend) wife's relations, if he (friend)'d married me he (friend)'d have had to give up five thousand pound.

And they would have taken very good care he (friend) did so.

The law was his (friend) side, but truth was against it, since his (friend) wife gave him (friend) the money only if he (friend) didn't wed.. She (wife) couldn't enforce such a thing, but he (friend) acted as if she (wife) could.

I went to live with him (friend), and you three children were born.

Then, a bit after, he (friend) came back here, and of course I came with him (friend).

He (friend)'s your father, but there's no call for any else to know it but us.

I don't care, and never shall care if everybody knows it.

A better man won't breathe God's air in this world than your father, and no woman have been blessed with a kinder husband in the eye of the Almighty.

But there's you three to think of, and `twould be against you if this was known now.

He (Almighty) didn't even want to tell you; but I was determined that you should know it afore either of us died.

And now it's pleased God to shorten your dear father's days; and you've got to hear that he (God) is your father.'' (she)

There was a silence.

``I ask them to forgive me,'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)
whispered Nathan Baskerville.

``I ask my son and my daughters to forgive me for what I've done.'' (unknown)

``No need for that,'' (Priscilla/Priscilla Lintern/Lintern)
answered Priscilla.

``Lie down and be easy, and don't get excited.'' (He)

He (Baskerville) had sat up and was holding his (Baskerville) beard, and stroking it nervously.

Mrs. Lintern shook his (Baskerville) pillow and took his (Baskerville) hand again.

Then she (Lintern) looked at her (Lintern) son, who stood with his (Baskerville) mouth open, staring at the sick man.

His (Baskerville) expression indicated no dismay, but immense astonishment.

``Well, I'm damned!'' (he)

he (Baskerville) said.

``This beats cock-fighting!

You my father!

And now you'm going to drop out--just when I might have been some use to you.

There!

what a `mazing thing, to be sure.'' (unknown)

``Call him (father) by his (father) right name then--for my sake, Heathman,'' (mother)
urged his (father) mother.

``Why--good God!--I will for his (God) own,'' (the man)
answered the man.

``I don't care a curse about such things as laws and all the rest of it.

He (God)'s been a rare good sort all his (God) life; and no man could have a better father, whichever side the blanket he (father) was got.

I'll call him (father) father, and welcome, and I wish to Christ he (Christ) wasn't going to die.'' (Heathman/Heathman Lintern)

Heathman came and took Nathan's hand, and his (Nathan) mother broke down at his (Nathan) words, buried her (mother) face in the counterpane and wept.

``Tell them to come over,'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)
whispered Mr. Baskerville to his (Baskerville) son.

``And thank you, and God bless you, son.

You've done more than you know to lighten a cruel load.'' (unknown)

``Come here, you two, and kiss your father,'' (Heathman/Heathman Lintern)
said Heathman.

The girls came, and first Phyllis kissed Nathan nervously, and then the touch that he (Nathan) hungered for rested a moment on his (Nathan) cheek.

With Cora's kiss the tension subsided; he (Nathan) sank back, and Priscilla drew the sheet up to his (Nathan) beard, and again lifted the pillow.

``Now I shall go in some sort of peace, though an erring and a sinful man,'' (he)
he (man) murmured.

``If you can forgive me, so will my Saviour.

And let this secret be a secret for ever.

Remember that, all of you.

'Tis beyond human power to make you legitimate Baskervilles; but Baskervilles you are, and, please God, will lead a better and wiser life than I have led.

No need to tell anybody the truth.
