Forgive your father, and forget him (father) so soon as ever you can; but worship your mother always--to your dying day worship her (mother); protect her (mother) and shield her (mother), and stand between her (mother) and the rough wind, and be proud of having such a blessed brave woman for a mother.'' (unknown)

``You needn't tell me that,'' (Heathman/Heathman Lintern)
said Heathman.

The other stopped, but held up his (father) hand for silence.

After a little rest he (father) proceeded.

``The time's coming when she (mother) will need all the love and wit you've got among you.

'Tis no good talking much about that, and I haven't the human courage left to meet your hard faces, or tears, or frowns.

All I say is, forgive me, and love your mother through thick and thin.

All the blame is mine--none of it belongs to her (mother).'' (He)

He (father) held his (father) hand out to Cora.

She (mother) was sitting on the edge of the bed looking out of the window.

``You'll remember, my Cora,'' (he)
he (Cora) said.

``And--and let me hear you call me `father' just once--if you can bring yourself to do it.'' (unknown)

``The money, dear father?'' (she)

she (mother) asked.

He (father) smiled, and it was the last time that he (father) ever did so.

``Like my sensible Cora,'' (he)
he (Cora) answered.

But he (Cora) did not continue the subject.

``You'd best all to go now,'' (Priscilla/Priscilla Lintern/Lintern)
declared Priscilla.

She (Priscilla) rose and looked straight into the eyes of her (Priscilla) children each in turn.

The girls flinched; the son went to her (Priscilla) and kissed her (Priscilla).

``Don't you think this will make any difference to me,'' (Heathman/Heathman Lintern)
said Heathman.

``You're a damned sight too good a mother for me, whether or no--or for them women either; and this man here--our father, I should say--needn't worrit about you, for I'll always put you afore anything else in the world.'' (unknown)

``And so will I, mother,'' (Phyllis/Phyllis Lintern)
said Phyllis.

``Of course, we all will,'' (Cora/Cora Lintern/Lintern)
added Cora;
``and the great thing must be for us all to keep as dumb as newts about it.

`Twould never do for it to come out--for mother's sake more than ours, even.

I don't say it for our sakes, but for mother's sake, and for father's good name, too.'' (Cora/Cora Lintern/Lintern)

``Such wisdom--such wisdom!'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)

said Nathan.

``You've all treated me better than I deserved--far better.

And God will reward you for such high forgiveness to a wicked wretch.

I'll see you all again once before I die.

Promise that.

Promise you'll come again, Cora.'' (unknown)

``I will come again,'' (she)
she (mother) said;
``and please, father, make mother promise on her (mother) oath to be quiet and sensible and not run no risks.

If it got out now--you never know.

We're above such small things, but many people would cold shoulder us if they heard of it.

You know what people are.'' (she)

Her (mother) mother looked at her (mother) without love.

The girl was excited; she (mother) began to appreciate the significance of what she (mother) had heard; her (mother) eyes were wet and her (mother) voice shook.

``I'll be `quiet and sensible,' Cora Lintern,'' (the mother)
said the mother.

``I've been `quiet and sensible' for a good many years, I believe, and I shan't begin to be noisy and foolish now.

You're quite safe.

Better you all go away now and leave us for the present.'' (the girls)

They departed silently, and, once below, the girls crept off together, like guilty things, to their home, while Lintern dallied in the bar below and drank.

He (Lintern) was perfectly indifferent to the serious side of his (Lintern) discovery, and, save for his (Lintern) mother's sake, would have liked to tell the men in the bar all about it.

He (Lintern) regarded it rather as a matter of congratulation than not.

No spark of mercenary feeling touched his (Lintern) emotion.

That he (Lintern) was a rich man's son had not yet occurred to him (son); but that he (son) was a good man's son and a popular man's son pleased him (son).

Mrs. Lintern suffered no detraction in his (son) eyes.

He (son) felt wonder when he (son) considered her (Lintern) power of hiding this secret for so many years, and he (son) experienced honest sorrow for her (Lintern) that the long clandestine union was now to end.

The day's event, indeed, merely added fuel to the flame of his (son) affection for her (Lintern).

But it was otherwise with the sisters.

Phyllis usually took on the colour of Cora's thought, and now the elder, with no little perspicacity, examined the situation from every point of view.

``The only really bright side it's got is that there'll be plenty of money, I suppose.

I'd give a sovereign, Phyllis, to see the will.

Father--how funny it sounds to say it--poor father was always terrible fond of me, and I've often wondered why for.

Now, of course, 'tis easy to explain.'' (unknown)

``What about the wedding?'' (Phyllis/Phyllis Lintern)

asked Phyllis.

''`Twill have to be cruel quiet now, I suppose.''

``Certainly not,'' (sister)
answered her (Phyllis) sister.

''`Twill have to be put off, that's all.

I won't have a scrubbly little wedding smothered up in half mourning, or some such thing; but, come to think of it, we shan't figure among the mourners in any case--though we shall be among them really.

`Twill be terrible difficult to help giving ourselves away over this.

I think the best thing would be for mother to take the money and clear out, and go and live somewhere else--the further off the better.

For that matter, when the will's read, everybody will guess how it is.''

``Heathman might go on with the public-house.'' (unknown)

``Yes, he (it) might.

But I hope he (it)'ll do no such thing,'' (sister)

answered her (mother) sister.

``He (it)'s always the thorn in my side, and always will be.

Don't know the meaning of the word `decency.'

However, he (it)'s not like to trouble us much when we're married.

I shan't be sorry to change my name now, Phyllis.

And the sooner you cease to be called Lintern, too, the better.'' (unknown)

``About mother?'' (unknown)

``I shouldn't presume to say a word about mother, one way or the other,'' (Cora/Cora Lintern/Lintern)
answered Cora.

``I'm not a fool, and I'm not going to trouble myself about the things that other people do; but all the same, I shall be glad to get out of it and start with a clean slate among a different class of people.'' (unknown)

``What amazing cleverness to hide it all their lives like that,'' (Phyllis/Phyllis Lintern)
speculated Phyllis.

``I'm sure us never would have been so clever as to do it.'' (unknown)

``It became a habit, no doubt.

'Twas salt to their lives, I reckon, and made 'em all the fonder of each other,'' (Cora/Cora Lintern/Lintern)

declared Cora.

``Everyday married life must have looked terrible tame to them--doing what they did.

Their time was one long love-making in secret.'' (unknown)

``I'm awful sorry for mother now, though,'' (Phyllis/Phyllis Lintern)
continued Phyllis;
``because when he (Cora) dies she (Phyllis) can't put on weeds and go and hear the funeral sermon, and do all the things a proper widow does do.'' (Phyllis/Phyllis Lintern)

``No,'' (sister)
admitted her (widow) sister;
``that she (widow) certainly can't.

She (widow)'ll have to hide the truth pretty close from this day forward, that's very clear.

She (widow) owes that to me--and to you; and I shall see she (widow) pays her (widow) debt.'' (sister)

``She (widow) will, of course,'' (unknown)
replied the other.

``She (widow)'s a terrible brave woman, and always has been.

She (widow)'ll hide it up close enough--so close as we shall, for that matter.

Heathman's the only one who's like to let it out.

You know what a careless creature he (widow) is.'' (Cora/Cora Lintern/Lintern)

Cora frowned.

``I do,'' (she)
she (widow) said.

``And I know there's no love lost between him (Cora) and me.

A coarse man, he (man) is, and don't care what gutter he (man) chooses his (man) friends out of.

Take one thing with another, it might be so well to marry Ned at the appointed time, and get it hard and fast.'' (unknown)

So they talked, and misprized Heathman from the frosty standpoint of their own hearts.

Rather than bring one shadow on his (Ned) mother's fame, the brother of these girls would have bitten out his (Ned) tongue and swallowed it.

CHAPTER XII Nathan Baskerville's bedroom faced the south.

A text was nailed upon the wall over his (Baskerville) head, and an old photograph of his (Baskerville) father stood upon the mantelpiece.

To right and left of this memorial appeared trinkets made of shells.

A pair of old carriage lamps, precious from association, decorated either end of the mantelshelf.

An old print of Niagara Falls, that his (Baskerville) mother had valued, was nailed above it.

A white curtain covered the window, but there was no blind, for this man always welcomed daylight.

On the window-ledge there languished a cactus in a pot.

It was a gift under the will of an old dead woman who had tended it and cherished it for twenty years.

One easy chair stood beside the bed, and on a table at hand were food and medicine.

Many came to see the dying man, and Humphrey Baskerville visited him (Baskerville) twice or thrice in every week.

More than once Nathan had desired to speak of private matters to his (Nathan) brother, but now he (Nathan) lacked the courage, and soon all inclination to discuss mundane affairs departed from him (Nathan).

There followed a feverish week, in which Nathan only desired to listen to religious conversation.

Recorded promises of hope for the sinner were his (Nathan) penultimate interest on earth.

He (Nathan) made use of a strange expression very often, and desired again and again to hear the Bible narrative that embraced it.

''`This day shalt thou be with me in Paradise,''' he (Nathan) said to Humphrey and to many others.

``I cling to that.

It was spoken to a thief and a failure.'' (him)

All strove to comfort him (thief), but a great mental incubus haunted his (thief) declining hours.

His (thief) old sanguine character seemed entirely to have perished; and its place was taken by spirits of darkness and of terror.

''`The fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom,''' he (Lord) said to Eliza Gollop, when she (Gollop) was alone with him (Lord).

``If I'd marked that better, I might now have got beyond that stage and learned to love Him (Lord).

But I'm in fear--my life hasn't took me further than that--all's fearful still.'' (unknown)

``No need in your case, I hope, so far as mortal man can say,'' (she)
she (Gollop) answered.

'''Tis natural to be uneasy when the journey's end falls in sight; and we all ought to be.

But then comes Christ and casts out fear.

You've a right, so far as man can say, to trust Him (man) and fear nought.''

``But man doesn't know.

Yet He (man) forgave the dying thief.'' (unknown)

``He (man) did so, though us have no right to say whether 'twas a bit of rare kindness in Him (man), or whether he (man) made a practice of it.

But for my part I steadfastly believe that He (man) do forgive everything but the sin against the Holy Ghost.

Of course, that's beyond His (man) power, and would never do.'' (Mrs. Lintern)

Mrs. Lintern spent much time at `The White Thorn,' and since her (Lintern) visits relieved Eliza of work, she (Lintern) acquiesced in them, while reserving the right of private judgment.

Priscilla and her (Priscilla) children all saw the sufferer together more than once; and then came a day when Heathman, Cora, and Phyllis took their leave of him (Cora).

The young man then secreted his (man) emotion and roamed for an hour alone upon the Moor; the girls felt it but little.

Cora declared afterwards to Phyllis that since this great confession had been made, her (Phyllis) mind dimly remembered her (Phyllis) tender youth and a man in it.

This man she (Phyllis) had regarded as her (Phyllis) father.

All the children were deceived at an early age.

They had, indeed, been led implicitly to suppose that their father died soon after the birth of Phyllis.

One last conversation with his (father) brother, Humphrey long remembered.

It was the final occasion on which Nathan seemed acutely conscious, and his (Nathan) uneasiness of mind clearly appeared.

They were alone, and the elder perceived that Nathan desired and yet feared to make some statement of a personal character.

That he (character) might ease the other's mind and open the way to any special conversation he (character) desired, Mr. Baskerville uttered certain general speeches concerning their past, their parents, and the different characteristics of temperament that had belonged to Vivian and themselves.

``We were all as opposite as men can be, and looked at life opposite, and set ourselves to win opposite good from it.

Who shall say which comes out best?

On the whole, perhaps Vivian did.

He (Vivian) died without a doubt.

There are some men bound to be pretty happy through native stupidity and the lack of power to feel; and there are some men--mighty few--rise as high as happiness, and glimpse content by the riches of their native wisdom.

I've found the real fools and the real wise men both seem to be happy.

A small brain keeps a man cheerful as a bird, and a big one leads to what's higher than cheerfulness; but 'tis the middle bulk of us be so often miserable.

We'm too witty to feed on the fool's pap of ignorance; and not witty enough to know the top of wisdom.

I speak for myself in that; but you've been a happy, hopeful man all your days; so belike, after all, you're wiser than I granted you to be.'' (unknown)

``Me wise!

My God!

Don't you say that.

My happiness was a fool's happiness; my laughter a fool's laughter all the time.

At least--not all the time; but at first.

We do the mad things at the mad age, and after, when the bill comes in--to find us grown up and in our right minds--we curse Nature for not giving us the brains first and the powers afterwards.

Man's days be a cruel knife in the hand of a child.

Too often the heedless wretch cuts hisself afore he (Man)'s learned how to handle it, and carries the scar for ever.'' (unknown)

``True for you.

Nature's a terrible poor master, as I've always said, and always shall.

We know it; but who stands up between a young man and his (man) youth to protect him (man) therefrom?

We old blids see 'em thinking the same vain things, and doing the same vain things, and burning their fingers and scorching their hearts at the same vain fires; and we look on and grin, like the idiots we are, and make no effort to help 'em.

Not you, though--not you.

You was always the young man's friend.

You never was a young man yourself exactly.

An old head on young shoulders you always carried; and so did I.'' (unknown)

``Don't think it--not of me.

'Tisn't so.

No man was madder than me; none was crueller; none committed worse sins for others' backs to bear.

The best that any man will be able to say of me a month after I'm in my grave is that I meant well.

And maybe not many will even say that.

Death's no evil to me, Humphrey, but dying now is a very cruel evil, I assure you.

The cloud lies behind, not in front.'' (unknown)

``So it does with every man struck down in the midst of his (man) work.

Shall you write your own verse according to our old custom?'' (unknown)

The other shook his (man) head.

``No.

I'll stick up no pious thought for men to spit upon when they pass my grave.

I'd rather that no stone marked it.

`Twill be remembered--in one heart--and that's more than ever I'll deserve.'' (unknown)

``Don't be downcast.

Leave afterwards to me.

I think better of you for hearing you talk like this.

You tried to brace me against the death of my son; now I'll brace you against your own death.

You don't fear the thing, and that's to the good.

But, like all busy men, it finds you with a lot of threads tangled, I suppose.

That's the fate of every one who tries to do other people's work besides his (son) own, and takes off the shoulders of others what properly belongs there.

They'll have to look to their own affairs all round when you go.'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)

Nathan's answer was a groan, and with the return of the nurse, Humphrey went away.

From that hour the final phases of the illness began; suffering dimmed the patient's mind, and turned his (patient) thoughts away from everything but his (patient) own physical struggle between the intervals of sleep.

His (patient) torments increased; his (patient) consciousness, flinging over all else, was reduced to its last earthly interest.

He (patient) kept his (patient) eyes and his (patient) attention ceaselessly fixed upon one thing so long as his (patient) mind continued under his (patient) control.

Not grief at the past; not concern at the future; not the face of Priscilla, and not the touch of her (Priscilla) hand absorbed his (patient) intelligence now; but the sight of a small bottle that held the anodyne to his (patient) misery.

That he (patient) steadfastly regarded, and pointed impatiently to the clock upon the mantelpiece when the blessed hour of administration struck.

The medicine was guarded jealously by Eliza Gollop, and once, when frenzied at the man's sufferings, Priscilla had sought to administer a dose, the other woman came between and sharply rebuked her (Priscilla).

``It's death!'' (she)

she (Priscilla) whispered under her (Priscilla) voice.

``D'you want to murder him (man)?

He (man)'s taking just what the doctor allows--the utmost limit.'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)

After three days of unutterable grief, Nathan's brother became aware of the situation, and perceived that the end tarried.

He (brother) debated on this long-drawn horror for a night, and next day spoke to the doctor.

He (doctor) put the case without evasion or obscurity, and the professional man heard him (man) in patience and explained at once his (man) deep sympathy and his (man) utter powerlessness to do more.

``He (man)'s dying--you grant that?'' (unknown)

``Certainly, he (man)'s dying--the quicker the better now, poor fellow.

The glands are involved, and the end must come tolerably soon.'' (unknown)

``How long?'' (unknown)

``Impossible to say.

A few days probably.

He (man) keeps his (man) strength wonderfully well.'' (unknown)

``But it would be better if he (man) didn't?

Wouldn't it be better if he (man) died to-night?'' (unknown)

``Much--for all our sakes,'' (the physician)
admitted the physician.

``Can't you help him (physician) out of it, then?'' (unknown)

``Impossible.'' (unknown)

``Why?

You'd do as much for a horse or dog.'' (unknown)

``My business is to prolong life, not hasten death.

The profession recognises no interference of that sort.'' (unknown)

``Who knows anything about it?

A dying man dies, and there's an end.'' (unknown)

``I cannot listen to you, Mr. Baskerville.

We must think of the greatest good and the greatest safety to the greatest number.

The law is very definite in this matter, and I have my profession to consider.

You look at an individual case; the law looks at the larger question of what is convenient for a State.

Your brother is having medicinal doses of morphia as often as it is possible to give them to him (brother) without danger to life.'' (unknown)

``In fact, Nature must kill him (brother) her (brother) own hard way.'' (unknown)

``Much is being done to lessen his (brother) pain.'' (unknown)

``But a double dose of your physic would--'' (unknown)
``End his (brother) life.'' (unknown)

``How?'' (unknown)

``He (brother) would become unconscious and in three, or possibly four, hours he (brother) would die.'' (unknown)

``You'd call that murder?'' (unknown)

``That is the only name for it as the law stands.'' (unknown)

``You won't do that?'' (unknown)

``No, Mr. Baskerville.

I wish I could help him (Baskerville).

But, in a word, I have no power to do so.'' (unknown)

``Is it because you think `twould be a wrong thing, or because you know 'tis unlawful?'' (unknown)

asked the elder.

``You might say 'twas impertinent to ask it, as it touches religion; but I'm ignorant and old, and want to know how it looks to the conscience of a learned man like you--you, that have been educated in all manner of deep subjects and the secrets of life.'' (The doctor)

The doctor reflected.

He (doctor) was experienced and efficient; but like many other professional men, he (doctor) had refused his (doctor) reason any entrance into the arcanum of his (doctor) religious opinions.

These were of the customary nebulous character, based on tradition, on convention, on the necessity for pleasing all in a general practice, on the murmur of a mother's voice in his (doctor) childhood.

``I am a Christian,'' (he)
he (Christian) said.

``And I think it wrong to lessen by one moment the appointed life of any man.'' (unknown)

``But not wrong to lengthen it?'' (unknown)

``That we cannot do.'' (unknown)

``Then surely you cannot shorten it, either?

Tell me this, sir: why would you poison a dog that's dying, so that its misery may be ended?'' (unknown)

``I will not argue about it.

The cases are not parallel.

Common humanity would, of course, put a period to the agony of any unconscious beast.'' (unknown)

``But wouldn't free an immortal soul from its perishing dirt?'' (unknown)

``No.

I am diminishing his (we) pain enormously.

I can do no more.

Remember, Mr. Baskerville, that our Lord and Master healed the sick and restored the dead to life.

He (Baskerville) never shortened any man's days; He (Baskerville) prolonged them.'' (unknown)

``I'm answered,'' (unknown)
replied the elder.

``Your conscience is--where it should be: on the side of the law.

I'm answered; but I'm not convinced.'' (Humphrey/Humphrey Baskerville/HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE)

They parted, and Humphrey found the other's argument not strong enough to satisfy him (Humphrey).

He (Humphrey) wrestled with the problem for some time and ere long his (Humphrey) impression grew into a conviction, his (Humphrey) conviction ripened to a resolve.

In the afternoon of that day he (Humphrey) returned to `The White Thorn' and found Mrs. Lintern with his (Thorn) brother.

Eliza had gone out for a while.

Nathan appeared to be half unconscious, but his (Nathan) mind clearly pursued some private train of thought.

Priscilla rose from her (Priscilla) chair beside the bed and shook hands with Humphrey.

Nathan spoke, but not to them.

``A mighty man of valour.

His (man) burning words melted the wax in a man's ears, I warn you.... Melted the wax in a man's ears.... Melted the wax.... Oh, Christ, help me!

Isn't it time for the medicine yet?'' (He)

He (Christ) stared at the bottle.

It was placed on a bracket in his (Christ) sight.

``What did the doctor say to-day?'' (Humphrey/Humphrey Baskerville/HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE)

asked Humphrey.

``Said it was wonderful--the strength.

There's nothing to stop him (Humphrey) living three or four days yet.'' (unknown)

``D'you want him (Humphrey) to?'' (unknown)

``My God, no!

I'd--I'd do all a woman could do to end it.'' (Humphrey/Humphrey Baskerville/HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE)

Humphrey regarded her (woman) searchingly.

``Will he (Humphrey) come to his (Humphrey) consciousness again?'' (unknown)

``I asked the doctor the same question.

He (doctor) said he (doctor) might, but it was doubtful.'' (The man)

The sick man groaned.

Agony had long stamped its impress on his (man) face.

``When is he (man) to have the medicine?'' (unknown)

``When Miss Gollop comes back,'' (she)
she (Gollop) said.

``There's an hour yet.

The Lord knows what an hour is to me, watching.

What must it be to him (Lord)?'' (unknown)

``Why, it may be a lifetime to him (Lord)--a whole lifetime of torment yet before he (Lord)'s gone,'' (Humphrey/Humphrey Baskerville/HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE)
admitted Humphrey.

``I pray to God day and night to take him (God).

If I could only bear it for him (God)!'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

Mr. Baskerville knelt beside his (Baskerville) brother, spoke loudly, squeezed the sufferer's hand and tried to rouse him (Baskerville).

``My physic, Eliza, for your humanity, Eliza--the clock's struck--I heard it--I swear--oh, my merciful Maker, why can't I have it?'' (He)

He (Baskerville) writhed in slow suffocation.

``I'll give him (Baskerville) his (Baskerville) medicine,'' (Humphrey/Humphrey Baskerville/HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE)
said Humphrey.

``This shan't go on.'' (unknown)

``She (Eliza)'ll make trouble if you do.'' (unknown)

``I hope not, and it's no great matter if she (Eliza) does.'' (He)

He (Humphrey) crossed the room, examined the bottle, took it to the light and poured out rather more than a double dose.

He (Humphrey) crossed the room with it, heaved a long breath, steadied himself and then put his (Humphrey) arm round his (Humphrey) brother and lifted him (Humphrey).

``Here you are, Nat.

You'll sleep awhile after this.

`Twill soon ease you.'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)

Nathan Baskerville seized the glass like one perishing of thirst, and drank eagerly.

He (Baskerville) continued to talk a little afterwards, but was swiftly easier.

Presently the drug silenced him (Baskerville) and he (Baskerville) lay still.

Humphrey looked at his (Humphrey) watch.

``I can tell you,'' (he)
he (Humphrey) said.

``Because you'll understand.

His (Humphrey) troubles are ended for ever now.

He (Humphrey) won't have another pang.

I've taken it upon myself.

You're a wise and patient woman.

You've got other secrets.

Better keep this with the rest.'' (He)

He (Humphrey) was excited.

His (Humphrey) forehead grew wet and he (Humphrey) mopped it with the sheet of the bed.

Priscilla did not reply; but she (Priscilla) went on her (Priscilla) knees beside Nathan and listened.

``At six o'clock, or maybe a bit earlier, he (Nathan)'ll stop.

Till then he (Nathan)'ll sleep in peace.

When does Eliza Gollop come back?'' (unknown)

``After four.'' (unknown)

``I'll wait then.'' (unknown)

``You're a brave man.

'Tisn't many would do so much as that, even for a brother.'' (unknown)

``Do as you would be done by covers it.

'Tis a disgrace to the living that dying men should suffer worse terror and pain than dying beasts.

Terror they must, perhaps, since they can think; but pain--no need for that.'' (unknown)

``I'll bless you for this to my own last day,'' (she)
she (I) said.

She (I) rose then and fetched a chair.

She (I) held Nathan's hand.

He (Nathan) was insensible and breathing faintly but easily.

Suddenly Mrs. Lintern got up and hastened across the room to the medicine bottle.

``We must think of that,'' (she)
she (Lintern) said.

``Leave it.

He (Nathan)'s had enough.'' (unknown)

``He (Nathan)'s had too much,'' (she)
she (Lintern) answered.

``There's the danger.

When that woman comes back she (woman)'ll know to half a drop what's gone.

She (woman) guessed the wish in me to do this very thing two days ago.

She (woman) read it in my eyes, I believe.

And God knows the will was in my heart; but I hadn't the courage.'' (unknown)

``Let her (woman) find out.'' (unknown)

``No--not her (woman).

Some--perhaps many--wouldn't matter; but not her (woman).'' (Priscilla/Priscilla Lintern/Lintern)

Priscilla took the bottle, lifted it and let it fall upon the floor.

It broke, and the medicine was spilled.

``There,'' (she)
she (Priscilla) said.

``That will answer the purpose.

You had given him (God) his (God) dose and, putting the bottle back, it broke.

I'll send Heathman off quick to Yelverton for another bottle, so it shall be here before the next dose is due.

Then you won't be suspected.'' (He)

He (God) listened, and perceived how easily came the devious thought to her (Priscilla) swift mind.

It did not astonish him (God) that she (Priscilla) was skilled in the art to deceive.

``I've taken the chances--all of them,'' (he)
he (God) said.

``I've thought long about this.

I needn't have told you to keep the secret, for it can't be kept.

And I don't want it to be kept really.

You can't hide it from the nurse.

She (nurse)'ll know by the peace of poor Nat here how it is.'' (Priscilla/Priscilla Lintern/Lintern)

Priscilla looked again.

Profound calm brooded over the busy man of Shaugh Prior.

He (man) was sinking out of life without one tremor.

``There's an awful side to it,'' (the woman)
the woman murmured.

``There was,'' (he)
he (man) said.

``The awfulness was to see Nature strangling him (man) by inches.

There's nought awful now, but the awfulness of all death.

'Tis meant to be an awful thing to the living--not to the dying.'' (unknown)

For half an hour they sat silent.

Then Priscilla lifted the clothes and put her (Priscilla) hand to Nathan's feet.

``He (Nathan)'s cold,'' (she)
she (Priscilla) said.

``Cold or heat are all one to him (Nathan) now.'' (Gollop/Eliza/Eliza Gollop)

A little later Eliza Gollop returned.

She (Gollop) came at the exact hour for administration of the medicine, and she (Gollop) sought the bottle before she (Gollop) took off her (Gollop) bonnet and cloak.

``Where--why--?'' (she)

she (Gollop) cried out.

``I gave him (Nathan) his (Nathan) physic a bit ago,'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)
said Mr. Baskerville.

``The bottle is broke.'' (The nurse)

The nurse hurried to her (nurse) patient and examined him (patient) closely.

She (nurse) perceived the change.

``He (patient)'s dying!'' (she)

she (nurse) said.

``So he (patient) was when you went away.'' (She)

She (nurse) broke off and panted into anger.

``You've--you've--this is murder--I won't stop in the house.

I--oh, you wicked woman!'' (She)

She (woman) turned upon Mrs. Lintern and poured out a torrent of invective.

Then Humphrey took her (woman) by the shoulders and put her (woman) out of the room.

``You can go,'' (he)
he (Humphrey) said.

``You'll not be wanted any more.'' (She)

She (woman) hastened from the inn and then went off to the vicarage as fast as her (woman) legs would carry her (woman).

Another half-hour passed and none came to them.

From time to time Priscilla put her (Priscilla) ear to Nathan's face.

``I don't think he (Nathan)'s breathing any more,'' (she)
she (Priscilla) said.

Then came a noise and a grumbling of men's voices below.

A violent strife of words clashed in the bar.

The day had waned and it was growing dark.

``They'll be against you, I'm fearing,'' (Priscilla/Priscilla Lintern/Lintern)
said Priscilla.

'''Tis of no account.

They always are.''

Presently Dennis Masterman entered the room.

``I hear poor Baskerville is going and they can't find his (Baskerville) minister.

Can I be of any comfort to him (Baskerville)?'' (He)

He (Baskerville) made no allusion to the things that he (Baskerville) had heard, and Humphrey did not immediately answer him (Humphrey).

He (Humphrey) was leaning over his (Humphrey) brother.

Then he (Humphrey) took out his (Humphrey) watch, opened it, and put the polished inner case to Nathan's lips.

``Light a candle and bring it here,'' (he)
he (Nathan) said to Priscilla.

She (Priscilla) obeyed, and he (Nathan) examined the polished metal.

``No stain--he (Nathan)'s dead, I suppose.'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

Then Mr. Baskerville turned to the clergyman.

``If you can pray, I'll be glad for you to do it.'' (Dennis/Masterman/Dennis Masterman)

Dennis immediately knelt down; the old man also went slowly on his (Dennis) knees and the weeping woman did the same.

``O Almighty God, Who has been pleased to take our brother from his (God) sufferings and liberate an immortal soul from mortal clay, be Thou beside him (God) now, that he (God) may pass over the dark river with his (God) hand in his (God) Saviour's, and enter as a good and faithful servant into the joy of his (God) Lord.

And support the sorrows of those who--who cared for him (God) on earth, and help them and all men to profit by the lesson of his (God) charity and lovingkindness and ready ear for the trouble of his (God) fellow-creatures.

Let us walk in the way that he (God) walked, and pass in peace at the end as he (God) has passed.

And this we beg for the sake of our Mediator and Comforter, our Blessed Lord and Redeemer, Thy Son, Jesus Christ.'' (unknown)

``Amen,'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)
said Mr. Baskerville,
``and thank you.'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

He (Baskerville) rose, cast one glance at the grief-stricken woman by the bed, then looked upon his (Baskerville) brother and then prepared to depart.

But he (Baskerville) returned for a moment.

``Will you do the rest?'' (he)

he (Baskerville) asked of Mrs. Lintern.

``Or shall I tell 'em to send?'' (unknown)

``No, I daren't.

Tell him (Baskerville) to send.

I must go home,'' (she)

she (Lintern) answered.

A loud noise persisted in the bar, but he (Baskerville) did not enter it.

He (Baskerville) took his (Baskerville) hat and an old umbrella from the corner of the sick-room, then descended and went out into the night.

CHAPTER XIII The doctor who attended Nathan Baskerville in his (Baskerville) last illness heard from Eliza Gollop what had been done, and he (Baskerville) took a serious view of it.

From the standpoint of his (Baskerville) opinions Humphrey Baskerville had struck a blow at society and the established order.

The physician was sober-minded and earnest.

He (physician) communicated with the coroner of the district, stated the case impartially and left the official to act as seemed proper to him (official).

But the coroner was also a medical man, and he (coroner) reduced the problem to its simplest possible dimensions.

Death had been hastened by an uncertain measure of time for one who was enduring extreme agony.

He (coroner) judged the case on its own merits, after a rare judicial faculty peculiar to himself.

He (coroner) made no effort to consider its general bearing and tendency; he (coroner) did not enlarge his (coroner) survey to the principles involved.

His (coroner) sympathy was entirely on the side of Humphrey Baskerville; he (Baskerville) applauded the old man in his (Baskerville) heart and declared no inquest necessary.

None was therefore held.

Those interested in Nathan's end took opposite views, and as for Humphrey himself, he (Humphrey) was hidden for a time from the people and did not appear again in public until his (Humphrey) brother's funeral.

He (Humphrey) failed, therefore, to learn the public opinion.

Jack Head and those who thought as he (Head) did, upheld the action; but not a few shared the faith of Thomas Gollop, openly expressed at the bar of `The White Thorn' while still the dead master lay above.

For two days Nathan kept a sort of humble state, and the folk from far and near enjoyed the spectacle of his (Nathan) corpse.

Many tramped ten miles to see him (Nathan).

The humblest people appeared; the most unexpected persons acknowledged debts of unrecorded kindness.

He (Nathan) lay in his (Nathan) coffin with a face placid and small behind the bush of his (Nathan) silver beard.

Women wept at the sight and took a morbid joy in touching his (Nathan) folded hands.

Then he (Nathan) was hidden for ever and carried with difficulty down the narrow and winding stair of the inn.

Thomas Gollop dug the grave and Joe Voysey helped him (Voysey).

No younger men assisted them.

They felt a sort of sentiment in the matter.

'''Tis the last pit I shall open, Joe,'' said Mr. Gollop;

``and for my part, if I had my way, I shouldn't make it very deep.

In these cases the law, though slow, is sure, and it may come about that he (Gollop)'ll have to be digged up again inside a month to prove murder against that dark, awful man to Hawk House.'' (Mr. Gollop/Gollop)

'''Tis the point of view.

I don't look at it quite the same.

For my part, in my business, I see a lot of death--not men but plants.

And when a bush or what not be going home, I don't stand in the way.

`No good tinkering,' I often says to Miss Masterman, for the silly woman seems to think a gardener can stand between a plant and death.

`The herb be going home,' I says, `and us can't stay the appointed time.'

`But I don't want it to go home--it mustn't go home,' she (Masterman)'ll answer me--like a silly child talking.

However, when her (Masterman) back be turned, I do my duty.

The bonfire's the place.

Jack Head looked over the kitchen-garden wall a bit agone and seed me firing up; and he (Head) said, `Ah, Joe, your bonfire's like charity: it covers a multitude of sins!'

A biting tongue that man hath!''

Joe chuckled at the recollection, but Gollop was not amused.

``A plant and a man are very different,'' (he)
he (man) answered.

``Scripture tells us that the fire is the place for the withered branch, but where there's a soul working out its salvation in fear and trembling, who be we worms to stand up and say `go'?'' (unknown)

``It might be the Lord put it in Mr. Baskerville's heart,'' (Joe Voysey/Joe/Voysey)
argued Voysey.

``The Lord ban't in the habit of putting murder in people's hearts, I believe.'' (unknown)

``You didn't ought to use the word.

He (Voysey) might have you up if he (Voysey) come to hear it.'' (unknown)

``I wish he (Voysey) would; I only wish he (Voysey) would,'' (Thomas/Thomas Gollop)
declared Thomas.

``Fearless you'd find me, with Eliza's evidence behind me, I can promise you.

But not him (Thomas): he (Thomas) knows too well for that.'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)

They stood and rested where Nathan's grave began to yawn beside that of his (Nathan) brother.

White marble shone out above Vivian, and not only his (Vivian) farewell verse, but also a palestric trophy representing the old wrestler's championship belt, was carved there.

''`Twill make history in more ways than one--this death will,'' foretold Thomas.

``What do you think?

Parson's going to help with the funeral!'' (unknown)

``Why not?'' (unknown)

''`Why not?'

You ask that!

Nat was a Dissenter and his (Dissenter) dissenting minister be going to bury him (Dissenter); but Masterman says, seeing how highly thought upon he (Masterman) was by all parties, that it becomes all parties to be at his (Masterman) grave.

And he (Masterman)'s going to be there; and if the bishop comed to learn of it, there'd be a flare-up that might shake England in my opinion.''

``If his (bishop) reverence says he (bishop)'ll be there, there he (bishop)'ll be.'' (unknown)

``I don't doubt that.

My belief is that all's well knowed at headquarters, and they're giving the man rope enough to hang hisself with.

This may be the last straw.'' (Thomas/Thomas Gollop)

Comforted by the reflection, Thomas resumed his (Thomas) labours.

``He (Thomas)'ll lie cheek by jowl with his (Thomas) brother,'' (he)
he (Thomas) said.

``Go easy in that corner, Joe; us'll be getting to the shoulder of Vivian's bricks afore long.'' (Nathan/Nathan Baskerville/Mr. Nathan)

The circumstance of Nathan's passing had been received with very real grief by most of his (Nathan) relations.

Even distant kindred mourned and not a few of the race, who were strangers to the Baskervilles of Shaugh Prior, appeared at the funeral.

Mrs. Baskerville of Cadworthy felt helpless and faced almost with a second widowhood, for all her (Baskerville) financial affairs had rested in Nathan's willing hand since her (Baskerville) husband died.

Her (Baskerville) daughters also mourned in very genuine fashion.

Their uncle had been kind, helpful, and generous to them.

Only Mr. Bassett did not greatly suffer, for now he (Bassett) knew that his (Bassett) wife must inherit her (wife) own and hoped, indeed, for some addition under the will of the departed innkeeper.

As for Rupert Baskerville, he (Baskerville) endured very real grief; but Ned was too concerned with the bearing of this event on his (Ned) own affairs to feel it deeply.

He (Ned) would now be free to administer his (Ned) capital as he (Ned) pleased.

Only his (Ned) mother stood between.

One black cloud, however, thrust itself upon his (Ned) immediate future.

His (Ned) wedding was postponed.

Cora insisted upon it, and her (mother) mother supported her (mother).

Their motives were widely different, but they arrived at the same conclusion.

Priscilla hid her (Priscilla) grief from all eyes but her (Priscilla) son's; while he (son), less skilled, surprised the folk by his (son) evident sorrow.

They failed to understand it, and acute people laughed, judged it to be simulation, and despised the man for his (man) display.

Cora and Phyllis neither pretended nor felt grief.

The elder had talked her (Phyllis) sister round, and they arrived at a perfectly rational conclusion.

It was averse from their father.

It led them to regard him (father) as a selfish and a cruel man.

They considered also that he (man) had deceived himself, and wickedly wronged the unborn that he (man) might perform a far-fetched obligation to the dead.

Cora put the case very clearly.

``Mother won't see it, and 'tis vain to try to make her (Mother); and Heathman won't see it, because he (Cora)'s a fool, and only just misses being weak in his (Cora) head.

But I see it clear enough, and the ugly truth of the man is that for five thousand pounds he (man) was content to let his (man) children come into the world bastards.

That's what he (man) did, and I'm not going to pretend I care for him (man) or shall ever respect his (man) memory.'' (unknown)

``It'll never come out, however,'' (Phyllis/Phyllis Lintern)
said Phyllis.

``I'm sure I hope it won't--not out of my mouth, anyway.

But still it is so, and all the money he (man) may have left behind him (man) won't make me feel different.'' (unknown)

``We shall be rich, I hope, anyway,'' (Phyllis/Phyllis Lintern)
speculated Phyllis.

``I suppose we shall; and that's the only bright thing about it.'' (the mourners)

''`Twill be funny not walking first behind the coffin, and not sitting in the mourners' pew after for the Sunday sermon; and we knowing all the time that's where we ought to be,'' said the younger; but Cora exploded the theory.

``Not at all.

We've no right there--not the right of the most distant cousin twenty times removed.

Mother was his (cousin) mistress, and she (Mother) daren't use the word `husband' even to us, though I've seen her (Mother) mouth itching to do it.

'Tis always `your dear father.'

She (Mother) can't put on a widow's streamers, though it's in her (Mother) heart to.

She (Mother)'ll have to balance her (Mother) black pretty cautious, I can tell you, if she (Mother) don't want the people to be staring.'' (unknown)

``Surely it must all come out if he (father) leaves his (father) money to us.'' (unknown)

``He (father)'ll do it clever,'' (Cora/Cora Lintern/Lintern)
said Cora bitterly.

``With all his (Cora) faults he (Cora) was clever enough.

He (Cora) didn't hide this--so clever as a lapwing hides her (Mother) nest--for near thirty years, to let it come out the minute he (Cora) was dead.'' (unknown)

``If I was engaged to be married, like what you are, I shouldn't be so nervous,'' (Phyllis/Phyllis Lintern)
said Phyllis.

``As to that, 'twas as well for me that it fell out now and not later.

It may mean a bigger establishment after all; and even a bigger wedding, if I put it off till spring.'' (unknown)

``My word, what'll Ned say?'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

But Ned's view did not enter as a serious factor into Cora's.

``He (Cora)'s all right,'' (she)
she (Phyllis) answered.

``If I'm content, so's he (Cora).'' (unknown)

Storm heralded the funeral day, and dawn blinked red-eyed from much weeping.

It was hoped that further torrents might hold off until after the ceremony, and happily they did so, though intermittent rain fell and the wind stormed roughly out of a sad-coloured south.

''`Blessed be the carpse that the rain rains on,''' said Joe Voysey in muffled accents to Jack Head.

They were walking under the coffin, and bore it, with the assistance of six other men, to the grave.

``Ban't so blessed for them that's alive, however,'' (Jack/Jack Head)
answered Jack.

``The mourners will be lashed out of their skins by the look of it.

Death's never so busy as at a funeral.'' (men)

A purple pall spread over the coffin, and while humble men carried the weight of Nathan Baskerville's dust, others of greater repute stood at the corners of the coverlet.

They included Mr. Luscombe of Trowlesworthy, Timothy Waite of Coldstone Farm, Heathman Lintern as representing Undershaugh, one Mr. Popham from Cornwood, Nathan's lawyer, and others.

Humphrey Baskerville walked beside the coffin as chief mourner, and Hester Baskerville, on her (others) son Ned's arm, followed him (Baskerville) with the rest of the family, save Nathan's namesake, who was at sea.

Other relations came after them, with Nicholas Bassett, Polly's husband, and Milly, the wife of Rupert.

Cora and her (Milly) mother and her (Milly) sister were next in the long procession, and half a dozen private carriages stood together beneath the churchyard wall to support a convention and indicate the respect that their owners entertained towards the dead.

Flowers covered the pall and stood piled beside the grave.

Crosses, wreaths, and various trophies were here, together with many little humble bunches from cottage gardens, and not a few mere gleanings from the hedgerow of scarlet and crimson berries, or the last autumnal splendour of beech and briar.

The air was heavy with emotion, and many wept.

A congregational minister conducted the service, and the vicar helped him (vicar).

After the body had sunk to earth and the rite was nearly accomplished, the chief mourners took their last look upon the lid, according to custom.

Leaves whirled in the air, and the branches overhead made a mighty sigh and swough in the brief silence.

Underfoot was trampled mire and reeking grass.

A pushing child slipped in the clay at the grave-mouth, and nearly fell in.

She (vicar) was dragged back by Thomas Gollop and despatched weeping to the rear.

Humphrey Baskerville came almost the last to look into the grave, and as others had fallen away from it when he (Baskerville) did so, he (Baskerville) assumed a momentary prominence.

His (Baskerville) small, bent, and sombre shape appeared alone at the edge of the cleft-in earth, with flowers piled about his (Baskerville) knees.

Then suddenly, ominously, cutting its way through the full diapason of the storm-sounds on trees and tower, there crept a different utterance.

The wind shouted deep and loud; but this noise was thin and harsh--a hissing, a sharp, shrill sibilation that gained volume presently and spread epidemic into the crowded ranks of the collected men.

They were mostly the young who permitted themselves this attack, but not a few of their elders joined with them.

The sounds deepened; a groan or two threaded the hisses.

Then Baskerville, from his (Baskerville) abstraction, awakened to the terrific fact that here, beside his (Baskerville) brother's grave, in the eyes of all men, a demonstration had broken out against him (Baskerville).

Hands were pointed, even fists were shaken.

He (Baskerville) could not immediately understand; he (Baskerville) looked helplessly into certain angry faces, and then shrank back from the grave to where his (Baskerville) relations stood.

``What's the meaning of this?'' (he)

he (Baskerville) asked Ned; but the young man turned and pretended not to hear him (man).

Then the truth came hurtling like a missile.

Voices shouted at him (man) the words `murderer' and `brother-killer.'

The fire that lights a mob into one blaze was afoot, and leaping from heart to head.

Many for a jest bellowed these insults at him (man), and thought it good for once to bate so unpopular a creature.

A few in honest and righteous rage cried out their wrath.

Of such were those who stoned the martyrs to serve their jealous gods.

More stones than one now actually did fly, and Humphrey was struck upon the arm.

A counter display of feeling ran like a wave against the enemies of the man, and induced a shock in the crowd.

Masterman and others laboured to still the gathering storm; women's voices clacked against the gruffer noise of the men.

Voysey, with admirable presence of mind, drew some boards over the dead in his (Voysey) grave, that no quick spirit might suddenly fall upon him (Voysey).

The disturbance ended as swiftly as it had begun, for Humphrey Baskerville made a bolt, dashed through the crowd, descended the churchyard steps, and reached the street.

A dozen hastened to follow, but Jack Head, Lintern, Waite, Mr. Masterman, and Ben North, the policeman, resisted the rioters, and kept them within the churchyard walls as far as possible.

Jack hit so hard that soon he (Jack) was involved in a battle against odds on his (Jack) own account.

Meantime, with a clod or two whizzing past his (Jack) head, Humphrey reached the street corner and hastened round it.

Here was silence and peace.

He (Humphrey) stopped, and his (Humphrey) brain grew dizzy.

Such exertion he (Humphrey) had not made for many years.

He (Humphrey) heard the noise of men and hastened on.

A chaos of ideas choked his (Humphrey) mind and dammed all play of coherent thought.

He (Humphrey) had heard a rumour that the thing he (Humphrey) had done for his (Humphrey) brother was regarded differently by different men, but he (Humphrey) knew not that so many were incensed and enraged.

The shock of the discovery disarmed him (Humphrey) now and left him (Humphrey) frantic.

He (Humphrey) looked forward, and believed that his (Humphrey) last hope of reconciliation with humanity was dead.

He (Humphrey) envied the eternal peace of his (Humphrey) brother as he (Humphrey) struggled on against the hill homeward.

Into the black and water-logged heart of Shaugh Moor he (Moor) climbed presently, and from exhaustion and faintness fell there.

He (Moor) stopped upon the ground for a few moments; then lifted himself to his (Moor) hands and knees; then sat down upon a stone and stared down into the theatre of this tragedy.

Overhead a sky as wild as his (Moor) soul made huge and threatening preparations for the delayed tempest.

Through the tangled skirts of the darkness westerly there strove and spread great passages of dazzling silver all tattered and torn and shredded out of the black and weltering clouds.

For a moment in the midst of this radiance there opened a farewell weather-gleam, where the azure firmament was seen only to vanish instantly.

Then the gloom gathered, and huddled up in ridges of purple and of lead.

Aloft, from the skirt of the main cumulus, where it swept under the zenith, there hung, light as a veil, yet darker than the sky behind them, long, writhing tentacles, that twisted down and curled in sinister suspension, that waved and twined, and felt hither and thither horribly, like some aerial hydra seeking prey.

For a time these curtains of the rain swayed clear of earth; but their progress swept them against it, and they burst their vials upon the bosom of the Moor.

The storm shrieked, exploded, emptied itself with howling rage out of the sudden darkness.

Then the fury of these tenebrous moments passed; the hurricane sped onward, and the dim wet ray that followed struck down upon a heath whitened with ice for miles.

A bitterness of cold and an ice-blink of unfamiliar radiance were thrown upwards from the crust of the hail; but soon it melted, and the waste, now running with a million rivulets, grew dark again.

The spectacle must have been impressive to any peaceful mind, but Baskerville saw nothing hyperbolic in the rage of wind and water.

The storm cited by Nature was not more tremendous than that tornado now sweeping through his (Baskerville) own soul.

END OF SECOND BOOK BOOK III CHAPTER I Humphrey Baskerville continued to stalk the stage of life like a lonely ghost, and still obscured from all men and women the secrets of his (Baskerville) nature, and the fierce interest of his (Baskerville) heart in matters human.

The things that he (Baskerville) most wished to display he (Baskerville) deliberately concealed, as a shy child who makes a toy, and longs to show it, but dares not, yet grows warm to the roots of his (Baskerville) being if the treasure is found and applauded.

Behind doubts, suspicions and jealousies he (Baskerville) hid himself; his (Baskerville) tongue was rough; his (Baskerville) utterances at the outrage put upon him (Baskerville) before the people by his (Baskerville) brother's grave were bitter and even coarse.

Nor did it abate his (Baskerville) concern to know that the hostile explosion was as much simulated as genuine, as much mischievous as meant.

It drove him (Baskerville) in upon himself; it poisoned his (Baskerville) opinion of human wisdom; and for a time he (Baskerville) moved through darkest night.

Yet this transcendent gloom preceded a dawn; the crisis of his (Baskerville) unquiet days approached; and, from the death of Nathan onward, life changed gradually for the man, and opened into a way that until now had been concealed from his (man) scrutiny.

There chanced an hour when Humphrey Baskerville rode upon his (Baskerville) pony under the high ground above Cornwood.

He (Baskerville) came by appointment to meet his (Baskerville) dead brother's lawyer, and accident had postponed the interview for some weeks.

The solicitor desired to see him (solicitor).

There were strange rumours in the air, and it was declared that a very surprising and unexpected condition of things had appeared upon the publican's passing.

Humphrey refused to hear even his (Humphrey) own relations upon the matter, for he (Humphrey) held Nathan's estate no concern of his (Humphrey); but at the urgent entreaties of Mr. Popham, the master of Hawk House now rode to see him (House).

He (House) had, however, already made it clear that he (House) was to be considered in no way responsible for his (House) brother's obligations, and felt unprepared to offer advice or engage himself in any particular.

He (House) passed across the shoulder of Pen Beacon, through a wild world of dun-coloured hills, streaked with flitting radiance, and clouded in billowy moisture driven before a great wind.

The sky was lowering, and a gale from the Atlantic swept with tremendous power along; but the nature of the scene it struck was such that little evidence of the force displayed could appear to the beholder.

Stone and steep and sodden waste stared blindly at the pressure and flinched not.

It remained for wandering beast or man to bend before it and reveal its might.

On the pelt of the sheep and cattle, or against the figure of a wanderer, its buffet was manifest; and, in the sky, the fierce breath of it herded the clouds into flocks, that sped and spread and gathered again too swiftly for the telling.

They broke in billows of sudden light; they massed into darkness and hid the earth beneath them; then again they parted, and, like a ragged flag above a broken army, the clean blue unfurled.

Over this majestic desolation suddenly there shot forth a great company of rooks, and the wind drove them before it--whirling and wheeling and tumbling in giddy dives, only to mount again.

A joyous spirit clearly dominated the feathered people.

They circled and cried aloud in merry exultation of the air.

They swooped and soared, rushed this way and that on slanting pinions, played together and revelled in the immense force that drove them like projectiles in a wild throng before it.

Even to these aerial things such speed was strange.

They seemed to comment in their language upon this new experience.

Then the instinct unfathomed that makes vast companies of living creatures wheel and warp together in mysterious and perfect unison, inspired them.

They turned simultaneously, ascended and set their course against the wind.

But they could make no headway now, and, in a cloud, they were blown together, discomforted, beaten to leeward.

Whereupon they descended swiftly to the level of the ground, and, flying low, plodded together back whence they had come.

At a yard or two above earth's surface they steadily flapped along, cheated the wind, and for a few moments flashed a reflected light over the Moor with their innumerable shining black bodies and pinions outspread.

At a hedge they rose only to dip again, and here Humphrey, who drew up to watch them, marked how they worked in the teeth of the gale, and was near enough to see their great grey bills, their anxious, glittering eyes, and their hurtling feathers blown awry as they breasted the hedge, fought over, and dipped again.

'''Tis the same as life,'' he (Humphrey) reflected.

``Go aloft and strive for high opinions, and the wind of doubt blows you before it like a leaf.

Up there you can travel with the storm, not against it.

If you want to go t`other way, you've got to feel along close to earth seemingly--to earth and the manners of earth and the folk of the earth.

And hard work at that; but better than driving along all alone.'' (He)

He (Humphrey) derived some consolation from this inchoate thought, and suspected a moral; but the simile broke down.

His (Humphrey) mind returned to Mr. Popham presently, and, taking leave of the Moor, he (Moor) descended and arrived at the lawyer's house upon the appointed hour.

The things that he (Moor) heard, though he (Moor) was prepared for some such recital, astounded him (Moor) by their far-reaching gravity.

The fact was of a familiar character; but it came with the acidulated sting of novelty to those involved.

An uproar, of which Humphrey in his (Humphrey) isolation had heard but the dim echo, already rioted through Shaugh Prior, and far beyond it.

``I'll give you a sketch of the situation,'' (the man)
said the man of business.

``And I will then submit my own theory of it--not that any theory can alter the exceedingly unpleasant facts.

It belongs merely to the moral side of the situation, and may help a little to condone our poor friend's conduct.

In a word, I do not believe he (friend) was responsible.'' (unknown)

``Begin at the other end,'' (Humphrey/Humphrey Baskerville/HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE)
answered Humphrey.

``Whether he (Humphrey) was responsible or not won't help us now.

And it won't prevent honest men spurning his (Humphrey) grave, I fancy.'' (Mr. Popham/Popham)

Mr. Popham collected his (Popham) papers and read a long and dismal statement.

His (Popham) client had always kept his (Popham) affairs closely to himself, and such was the universal trust and confidence that none ever pressed him (Popham) to do otherwise.

He (Popham) had been given a free hand in the administration of considerable sums; he (Popham) had invested where he (Popham) pleased, and for many years had enjoyed the best of good fortune, despite the hazardous character of the securities he (character) affected.

``No man was ever cursed with such an incurable gift of hope,'' (the lawyer)
explained the lawyer.

``All along the line you'll find the same sanguine and unjustifiable methods exhibited.

The rate per cent was all he (lawyer) cared about.

His (lawyer) custom was to pay everybody four and a half, and keep the balance.

But when companies came to grief nobody heard anything about it; he (lawyer) went on paying the interest, and, no doubt, went on hoping to make good the capital.

This, however, he (lawyer) seldom appears to have done.

There are about forty small people who deposited their savings with him (lawyer), and there is nothing for any of them but valueless paper.

He (lawyer) was bankrupt a dozen times over, and the thing he (lawyer)'d evidently pinned his (lawyer) last hope to--a big South American silver mine--is going the way of the others.

Had it come off, the position might have been retrieved; but it is not coming off.

He (lawyer) put five thousand pounds into it--not his (lawyer) own money--and hoped, I suppose, to make thirty thousand.

It was his (lawyer) last flutter.'' (unknown)

``Where did he (lawyer) get the money?'' (unknown)

``By mortgaging Cadworthy and by using a good deal of his (lawyer) late brother's capital.

I mean the estate of Mr. Vivian Baskerville.'' (unknown)

``He (Baskerville)'s a fraudulent trustee, then?'' (unknown)

``He (Baskerville) is.

He (Baskerville) had already mortgaged all his (Baskerville) own property.

He (Baskerville) was in a very tight place about the time of Mr. Vivian's death, and the money he (Vivian) had to handle then carried him (Vivian) on.'' (unknown)

``What did he (Vivian) do with his (Vivian) own money?

How did he (Vivian) spend that?'' (unknown)

``We shall never know, unless somebody comes forward and tells us.

I trace the usual expenditures of a publican and other expenses.

He (publican) always kept a good horse or two, and he (publican) rode to hounds until latterly, and subscribed to several hunts.

He (publican) was foolishly generous at all times.

I see that he (publican) gave away large sums anonymously--but unfortunately they were not his (publican) own.

There is no doubt that his (publican) judgment failed completely of late years.

He (publican) was so accustomed to success that he (publican) had no experience of failure, and when inevitable failures came, they found him (publican) quite unprepared with any reserves against them.

To stem the tide he (publican) gambled, and when his (publican) speculations miscarried, he (publican) waded still more deeply.

He (publican) was engaged in borrowing a large sum of money just before his (publican) final illness.

Indeed, he (publican) came to me for it, for he (publican) kept me quite in the dark concerning existing mortgages on his (publican) property.

But he (publican) forgot I should want the title-deeds.

He (publican) was a devious man, but I shall always believe that he (publican) lacked moral understanding to know the terrible gravity of the things he (publican) did.'' (unknown)

``How do we stand now?'' (unknown)

``The estate is from six thousand to seven thousand pounds to the bad.'' (unknown)

``What is there against that?'' (unknown)

``The assets are practically nil.

About forty pounds at the bank, and the furniture at `The White Thorn' Inn.

Of course, his (Thorn) largest creditor will be Mr. Ned Baskerville, of Cadworthy Farm.

I want to say, by the way, that this state of things is quite as much of a surprise to me as to anybody.

It is true that I have been his (Baskerville) solicitor for twenty years, but my work was nominal.

I had no knowledge whatever of his (Baskerville) affairs.

He (Baskerville) never consulted me when in difficulties, or invited my opinion on any subject.'' (unknown)

``What about the Linterns?'' (unknown)

``They have asked to stop at Undershaugh for the present.

I fancy Mrs. Lintern was a close friend of your brother's.

However, she (Lintern) is not communicative.

The mortgagee in that case, of course, forecloses, and will, I think, be contented to let Mrs. Lintern stop where she (Lintern) is.'' (unknown)

``There was no will?'' (unknown)

``I can find none.'' (unknown)

``Yet I know very well he (brother) made one ten years ago.

At least, he (brother) came to me once rather full of it.'' (unknown)

``It is very likely that he (brother) destroyed it.'' (unknown)

There was a silence; then Humphrey Baskerville asked a question.

``Well, what d'you want of me?'' (unknown)

The other shrugged his (Baskerville) shoulders.

``I leave that to you.

You know how much or how little you regard this disaster as a personal one.'' (unknown)

``It has nothing whatever to do with me.

I never lent him (Baskerville) a penny.

He (Baskerville) never asked me to do so.'' (unknown)

``You don't recognise any obligation?'' (unknown)

``Absolutely not a shadow of any such thing.'' (unknown)

``The family of which you are now head--?'' (unknown)

``A sentimental lawyer!'' (unknown)

The other laughed.

``Not much room for sentimentality--at least, plenty of room, no doubt.

Of course, if you don't consider--'' (He)

He (lawyer) broke off, but his (lawyer) listener did not speak.

``It is to be understood I must not ask you to help me?'' (unknown)

``Not in any practical way--not with money--certainly not.

For the rest, if as a man of business I can be of any service--'' (unknown)

``For the sake of the family.'' (unknown)

``The family is nothing to me--at least, the one hit hardest is nothing to me.

He (man)'ll have to work for his (man) living now.

That's no hardship.

It may be the best thing that's befallen him (man) yet.'' (unknown)

``Very true, indeed.

Well, let us leave the main question open.

The case has no very unusual features.

Occasionally the world trusts a man to his (man) grave, and then finds out, too late, that it was mistaken.

It is extraordinary what a lot of people will trust a good heart, Mr. Baskerville.

Trust, like hope, springs eternal in the human breast.'' (unknown)

``Does it?

I've never found much come my way.

And I'm not strong in trust myself.

I felt friendly to Nathan, because he (Nathan) was my own flesh and blood; but trust him (Nathan)--no.'' (unknown)

``He (Nathan) didn't confide in you?'' (unknown)

``Never.'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

Mr. Baskerville rose.

``I shall see my relations no doubt pretty soon.

I fancy they'll pay me some visits.

Well, why not?

I'm lonely, and rolling in money--so they think.

And--there's a woman that I rather expect to call upon me.

In fact, I've bidden her (woman) to do so.

Perhaps, if she (woman) don't, I'll call on her (woman).

For the present we can leave it.

If there's no money, nobody can hope to be paid.

We'll talk more on that later.

Who's got Cadworthy?'' (unknown)

``Westcott of Cann Quarries.

He (Westcott) lent the money on it.'' (unknown)

``What the devil does he (devil) want with it?'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

asked Mr. Baskerville.

``That I can't tell you.

Probably he (Baskerville) doesn't want it.

He (Baskerville)'s foreclosed, of course.

It was only out of friendship and regard for Mr. Nathan that he (Nathan) lent so much money on the place.

He (Nathan) tells me that your brother explained to him (Nathan) that it was for a year or so to help Ned; and out of respect for the family he (Ned) gladly obliged.'' (unknown)

``Didn't know Westcott was so rich.'' (unknown)

``You never know who's got the money in these parts.

But 'tis safe to bet that it isn't the man who spends most.

There's Mr. Timothy Waite, too, he (Waite) lent Nathan a thousand, six months ago.

Some cock-and-bull story your poor brother told him (brother), and of course, for such a man, he (man) gladly obliged.

Each that he (man) raised money from thought he (man) was the only one asked, of course.'' (unknown)

``He (man) was a rogue, and the worst sort of rogue--a chapel-going, preaching, generous-handed, warm-hearted rogue.

Such men are the thieves of virtue.

'Tis an infamous story.'' (The lawyer)

The lawyer stared, and Humphrey continued.

``Such men are robbers, I tell you--robbers of more than money and widows' houses.

They are always seeming honest, and never being so.

They run with the hare and hunt with the hounds.

They get the benefit of being rogues, and the credit of honest men.

They are imitation good men, and at heart know not the meaning of real goodness.

They have the name of being generous and kind--they are neither.

Look what this man has left behind him (man)--blessings turned to curses.

All a sham, and a lifelong theft of men's admiration and esteem--a theft; for he (man) won it by false pretences and lived a lie.'' (unknown)

``He (man) is dead, however.'' (unknown)

``Yes, he (man) is dead; and I suppose you are the sort who like to palter with facts and never speak ill of the dead.

Why should we not tell the truth about those who are gone?

Does it hurt them to say it?

No; but it may do the living some good to say it.

If living knaves see us condoning and forgiving dead ones, will they turn from their knavery any the quicker?

We're a slack-twisted, sentimental generation.

Justice is the last thing thought of.

It's so easy to be merciful to people who have sinned against somebody else.

But mercy's slow poison, if you ask me.

It rots the very roots of justice.'' (unknown)

The other shrugged his (it) shoulders.

``The first of Christian virtues, Mr. Baskerville, we must remember that.

But argument won't alter facts.

You don't see your way to do anything definite, so there's an end of it.

Of course, there is no shadow of obligation.'' (unknown)

``You're right.

I'll visit you again presently.

Meantime you might let me have a copy of the claims.

I'm interested in knowing how many fools trusted my dead brother with their money.

I should like to know what manner of man and woman put their savings into another man's pocket without security.

It seems contrary to human nature.'' (unknown)

``There's no objection at all.

They are all clamouring for their money.

And if the South American silver mine had done all that was hoped, not only would they have had their cash, but your brother must have saved his (brother) own situation, cleared his (brother) responsibilities, and died solvent.'' (unknown)

''`If.'

There's generally a rather big `if' with a South American anything, I believe.''

They parted, and Humphrey Baskerville rode home again.

Upon the way he (Baskerville) deeply pondered all the things that he (Baskerville) had heard, and not until he (Baskerville) was back at Hawk House did distraction from these thoughts come.

Then he (Baskerville) found that a woman waited to see him (Baskerville).

It was Priscilla Lintern, who had called at his (Baskerville) invitation; and now he (Baskerville) remembered that he (Baskerville) had asked her (Lintern), and half regretted the act.

CHAPTER II Mrs. Lintern arrived by appointment, for while one instinct of his (Baskerville) nature pressed Humphrey to evade this problem and take no hand in the solution, another and more instant impulse acted in opposition.

He (Baskerville) surveyed the sweep of events as they struck at those involved in Nathan's ruin and death; and acting upon reasons now to be divulged, he (Nathan) sent first for the mistress of Undershaugh; because in his (Nathan) judgment her (mistress) right to consideration was paramount.

Even in the act of summoning her (mistress), he (Nathan) told himself that these claims were no business of his (Nathan) to investigate; and that he (Nathan) was a fool to meddle.

He (Nathan) repudiated responsibility at one breath, and deliberately assumed it with the next.

His (Nathan) own motives he (Nathan) did not pause to examine.

Introspection irritated him (Nathan) and he (Nathan) turned from his (Nathan) conflicting ideas with impatience.

In himself he (Nathan) only saw a very ill-balanced, imprudent, and impertinent person; yet he (Nathan) proceeded.

Now came Mrs. Lintern to know what he (Nathan) would have, and he (Nathan) saw her (Lintern) with an emotion of hearty regret that he (Nathan) had invited her (Lintern).

In answer to his (Nathan) first question she (Lintern) assured him (Nathan) that she (Lintern) and her (Lintern) children were well.

``I'm afraid putting off the wedding has annoyed your nephew a good bit,'' (she)
she (Lintern) said;
``but Cora felt that it was better; and so did I.'' (she)

``Why did you think so?'' (she)

``Well, your brother held it so much to heart; and he (brother) was Ned's uncle.

We could only have made a very quiet business of it in decency; and Cora felt `twould be sad to marry under the cloud of death.'' (unknown)

``Half the sorrow in the world is wasted on what can't be helped.

It's folly to mourn what's beyond altering--just as great folly as to mourn the past.

Surely you know that?'' (unknown)

``No doubt; but who can help it that's made on a human pattern?'' (unknown)

``The world would be a cheerful place if none wept for what can't be altered.

There was nothing in reason to stand between us and the wedding.

'Twas my brother's last wish, for that matter.'' (She)

She (you) did not answer and a silence fell between them.

He (brother) was determined that she (you) should break it, and at length she (you) did so.

``Your brother was very fond of Cora.

Of course, we at Undershaugh miss him (Cora) a very great deal.'' (unknown)

``You would--naturally.'' (unknown)

``At present the idea is that they get married in spring; and that won't be none too soon, for everything's altered now.

They'll have to sell half they bought, and get rid of their fine house and their horses, and much else.

This business has entirely altered the future for them, poor things.'' (unknown)

``Utterly, of course.

`Twill have to be real love to stand this pinch.

Better they wait a bit and see how they feel about it.

They may change their minds.

Both are pretty good at that.'' (She)

She (they) sighed.

``They understand each other, I believe.

But Ned won't change, whatever Cora does.

He (Cora)'s wrapped up heart and soul in her (they).'' (unknown)

``He (Cora)'ll have to seek work now.'' (unknown)

``Yes; he (Cora) is doing so.'' (unknown)

``The one thing he (Cora)'s never looked for.

Harder to find work than foxes.'' (unknown)

``He (Cora)'s not good for much.'' (unknown)

``You say that of your future son-in-law?'' (unknown)

``Truth's truth.

A harmless and useless man.

I can't for the life of me think what he (man)'ll find to do.'' (unknown)

``Nathan would have given him (Nathan) a job--eh?

How wonderful he (Nathan) was at finding work for people.

And what does Cora think of it all?

'' (unknown)

:
``She (man)'s a very secret girl.'' (unknown)

``And Heathman?'' (unknown)

``Heathman be going to make my home for me--somewhere.

'Tisn't decided where we go.'' (unknown)

``You leave Undershaugh, then?'' (unknown)

``Yes.'' (unknown)

``Nathan wouldn't have wished that, I'm sure.'' (unknown)

``We were to have stopped, but the new owner wants to raise the rent to nearly as much again.'' (unknown)

``What used you to pay?'' (She)

She (man) hesitated.

Like many people whose position has forced them into the telling of countless lies, she (man) was still tender of truth in trifles.

``No matter,'' (he)
he (owner) said.

``I can guess the figure very easily, and nought's the shape of it.'' (unknown)

A sinister foreboding flashed through her (man) mind.

It seemed impossible to suppose such an innuendo innocent.

Miss Gollop had said many offensive things concerning her (Gollop) after Nathan's death; but few had believed them, and still fewer shown the least interest in the subject.

It was absurd to suppose that Humphrey Baskerville would trouble his (Baskerville) head with such a rumour.

``Your brother was generous to all,'' (she)
she (Gollop) answered.

``Why, he (brother) was.

And if charity shouldn't begin at home, where should it?'' (unknown)

``He (brother) was very generous to all,'' (she)
she (Gollop) repeated.

``I've been seeing Mr. Popham to-day.'' (unknown)

``He (Popham)'s a true kind man, and wishful to do what he (Popham) can.

The rent asked now for Undershaugh is too high, even in the good state we've made it.

So I've got to leave.'' (unknown)

''`Twill be a wrench.''

``Yes, indeed.'' (unknown)

``But not such a bad one as his (Popham) death?'' (unknown)

``That's true.'' (He)

He (Popham) probed her (Gollop).

``Never to see him (Popham) come down your path with his (Popham) bustling gait; never to hear the laughter of the man.

You held his (Popham) hand when he (Popham) went out of life.

He (Popham) loved you--'twas the master passion of him (Popham).'' (unknown)

A flush of colour leapt and spread over her (Gollop) face.

She (Gollop) gasped but said nothing.

``A cruel thing that he (Popham) left you as he (Popham) did.'' (unknown)

``What was I?'' (she)

she (Gollop) began, alert and ready to fight at once and crush this suspicion.

``What are you saying?

We were nothing--'' (He)

He (Popham) held up his (Popham) hand.

``A fool's trick--a lifelong fool's trick to hide it--a cruel, witless thing--a wrong against generations unborn--scandalous--infamous--beyond belief in a sane man.'' (unknown)

``I don't understand you.

God's my--'' (unknown)

``Hush--hush!

I'm not an enemy.

You needn't put out your claws; you needn't lie to me.

You needn't break oaths to me.

It's a secret still; but I know it--only me.

You were his (God) mistress, Priscilla Lintern--his (God) mistress and the mother of his (God) children.'' (unknown)

``He (God) never told you that.'' (unknown)

``Not he (God).'' (unknown)

``Who did tell you?'' (unknown)

``Cora told me.'' (unknown)

``She (Lintern)'d rather have--'' (unknown)
``She (Lintern) told me--not in words; but every other way.

I knew it the hour she (Lintern) came to see me, after she (Lintern) was engaged to marry my son.

She (Lintern) strokes her (Lintern) chin like Nat stroked his (Nat) beard.

Have you marked that?

She (Lintern) thinks just like Nat thought in a lot of ways, though she (Lintern)'s not got his (Nat) heart.

She (Lintern)'s not near so silly as he (Nat) was.

Her (Lintern) voice was the echo to his (Nat) as soon as I got the clue.

Her (Lintern) eyes were his (Nat) again.

She (Lintern) handles her (Lintern) knife and fork just like he (Nat) was wont to do it; she (Lintern) sets her (Lintern) head o' one side to listen to anybody in the way he (Nat) did.

There's birds do it too--when they gather worms out of the grass.

And from that I took to marking t`others.

Your second girl be more like you; but Heathman will be nearer his (Nat) father every day as he (Nat) gets older.

If he (Nat) growed a beard, he (Nat)'d be nearer him (Nat) now.

Wait and watch.

And he (Nat)'s got his (Nat) heart.

Don't speak till you hear more.

From finding out that much, I sounded Nathan himself.

Little he (Nathan) guessed it, but what I didn't know, I soon learned from him (Nathan).

Cora was the apple of his (Cora) eye.

She (girl) could do no wrong.

'Twas Vivian and Ned over again.

He (Ned) spoke of you very guarded, but I knew what was behind.

It came out when he (Ned) was dying, and he (Ned) was too far gone to hide it.

And let me say this: I'll never forgive him (Ned) for doing such a wicked thing--never.

God may; but I won't.

I wouldn't forgive myself if I forgave him (God).

But you--you--dull man as I am, I can see a bit of what your life was.'' (unknown)

``A better life--a more precious life than mine no woman ever lived.'' (He)

He (man) took a deep breath.

Here she (woman) tacitly confessed to all that he (man) had declared.

She (woman) did not even confirm it in words, but granted it and proceeded with the argument.

And yet his (man) whole theory had been built upon presumption.

If she (woman) had denied the truth, he (man) possessed no shadow of power to prove it.

``If ever I pitied anybody, I pity you; and I admire you in a sort of left-handed way.

You're a very uncommon creature to have hid it in the face of such a village as Shaugh Prior.'' (unknown)

``What I am he (man) made me.

He (man) was a man in ten thousand.'' (unknown)

``I hope he (man) was.

Leave him (man).

Let me say this afore we get on.

I don't judge you and, God knows it, I'm alive to this thing from your point of view.

You loved him (God) well enough even for that.

But there's no will.
