He (God) had nothing to leave; therefore--unless you've saved money during his (God) lifetime--?'' (unknown)

``I don't want you to have anything to do with my affairs, Mr.

Baskerville.'' (unknown)

``As you please.

But there are your children to be considered.

Now it may very much surprise you to know that I have thought a lot about them.

Should you say, speaking as an outsider, that I'm under any obligation to serve them?'' (Mrs. Lintern)

The sudden and most unexpected question again startled the blood from Mrs. Lintern's heart.

``What a terrible curious man you are!

What a question to ask me!'' (she)

she (Lintern) said.

``Answer it, however--as if you wasn't interested in it.'' (unknown)

``No,'' (she)
she (Lintern) declared presently.

``None can say that they are anything to do with you.

You wasn't your brother's keeper.

They be no kin of yours in law or justice.'' (unknown)

``In law--no.

In justice they are of my blood.

Not that that's anything.

You're right.

They are nought to me.

And you are less than nought.

But--'' (He)

He (kin) stopped.

``Why have you told me that you have found this out?'' (she)

she (Lintern) asked.

``What good can come of it?

You'll admit at least 'tis a sacred secret, and you've no right whatever to breathe it to a living soul?

You won't deny that?'' (unknown)

``There again--there's such a lot of sides to it.

You might argue for and against.

Justice is terrible difficult.

Suppose, for instance, that I held, like Jack Head holds and many such, that 'tis a very improper thing and a treachery to the unborn to let first cousins mate--suppose I held to that?

Ought I to sit by and let Cora marry Ned?

Now there's a nice question for an honest man.

``You were going to let Cora marry your own son.'' (unknown)

``I don't know so much about that.

They were engaged to each other before I found it out, and then, as she (Head) soon flung him (Cora) over, there was no need for me to speak.

Now, the question is, shall I let these two of the same blood breed and maybe bring feebler things than themselves into the world?'' (unknown)

``This is all too deep for me.

One thing I know, and that is you can say nought.

You've come to the truth, by the terrible, wonderful brains in your head; but you've no right to make it known.'' (unknown)

``You're ashamed of it?'' (She)

She (Head) looked at him (Cora) almost with contempt.

``You can ask that and know me, even so little as you do?

God's my judge that I'd shout it out from the top of the church tower to-morrow; I'd be proud for the world to know; and so much the louder I'd sing it because he (God)'s gone down to his (God) grave unloved and in darkness.

It would make life worth living to me, even now, if I could open my mouth and fight for him (God) against the world.

Not a good word do I hear now--all curse him (God)--all forget the other side of him (God)--all forget how his (God) heart went out to the sorrowful and sad....

But there--what's the use of talking?

He (God) don't want me to fight for him (God).'' (unknown)

``If you feel that, why don't you stand up before the people and tell 'em?'' (unknown)

``There's my children.'' (unknown)

``Be they more to you than he (God) was?'' (unknown)

``No; but they are next.'' (unknown)

``I hate deceit.

Who'll think the worse of them?'' (unknown)

``Who won't?'' (unknown)

``None that are worth considering.'' (unknown)

``You know very little about the world, for all that you are deep as the dark and can find out things hidden.

What about my darters?

No, it wouldn't be a fair thing to let it out.'' (unknown)

``I hold it very important.'' (unknown)

``It shan't be, I tell you.

You can't do it; you never would.'' (unknown)

``You're right.

I never would.

But that's not to say I don't wish it to come out.

For them, mind you, I speak.

I leave you out now.

I put you first and you say you'd like it known.

So I go on to them, and I tell you that for their peace of mind and well-being in the future, 'tis better a thousand times they should start open and fair, without the need of this lie between them and the world.'' (unknown)

``I don't agree with that.

When the truth was told them on his (you) deathbed, 'twas settled it should never go no further.'' (unknown)

``Wait and think a moment before you decide.

What has it been to you to hide the truth all your life?'' (unknown)

``A necessity.

I soon grew used to it.

Nobody was hurt by it.

And Nathan kept his (Nathan) money.'' (unknown)

``Don't fool yourself to think that none was hurt by it.

Everybody was hurt by it.

A prosperous lie be like a prosperous thistle: it never yet flourished without ripening seed and increasing its own poisonous stock a thousandfold.

The world's full of that thistledown.

Your children know the truth themselves; therefore I say it should come out.

They've no right to stand between you and the thing you want to do.

I'll wager Heathman don't care--it's only your daughters.'' (unknown)

``More than that.

Nathan would never have wished it known.'' (unknown)

``No argument at all.

He (Nathan) was soaked in crookedness and couldn't see straight for years afore he (Nathan) died.'' (unknown)

``I won't have it and I won't argue about it.'' (unknown)

``Well, your word's law.

But you're wrong; and you'll live to know you're wrong.

Now what are you going to do?

We'll start as though I knew nought of this for the moment.'' (unknown)

``I stop at Undershaugh till spring.

I've got no money to name.

We shall settle between ourselves--me and Heathman.'' (unknown)

``I'll--'' (He)
He (Nathan) stopped.

``No,'' (he)
he (Nathan) said;
``I can't promise anything, come to think of it; and I can't commit myself.

'Tis folly to say, `let the position be as though I didn't know the truth.'

It can't be.

I do know it, and I'm influenced by it.

I'll do nothing at all for any of you unless this comes out.

I say that, not because I don't care for my brother's children, but because I do care for them.'' (he)

``I don't want you to do anything.

I've got my son.

I refuse absolutely to speak.

Until my children are all of one mind about it, the thing must be hidden up--yes, hidden up for evermore.

I won't argue the right or the wrong.

'Tis out of my hands, and so long as one of them says `no,' I hold it my duty to keep silent.

And, of course, 'tis yours also.'' (unknown)

``Who knows what my duty would be if Ned was going to marry Cora?

I'd sacrifice the unborn to you; but not to your daughter and my nephew.

There have been enough tongues to curse that worthless pair already.

You don't want their own children to do the same in the time to come?

But perhaps I know as much about Cora as you do about Ned.

Wait and see if she (daughter) changes her (daughter) mind, since he (Ned) has lost his (Ned) fortune.'' (Priscilla/Priscilla Lintern/Lintern)

Priscilla rose.

``I will go now,'' (she)
she (Priscilla) said.

``Of course, you can't guess how this looks to a woman--especially to me of all women.

To find that you knew--and no doubt you thought I'd come here and drop dead afore you of shame.'' (unknown)

``No, I didn't.

If you'd been that sort, I shouldn't have plumped it out so straight.

You are a brave creature, and must always have been so.

Well, I won't deny you the name of wife in secret--if you like to claim it.'' (She)

She (wife) was moved and thanked him (I).

Satisfaction rather than concern dominated her (wife) mind as she (wife) returned homeward.

She (wife) felt glad that Nathan's brother knew, and no shadow of fear dimmed her (wife) satisfaction; for she (wife) was positive that, despite any declared doubts, he (brother) would never make the truth public.

Her (wife) own attitude was even as she (wife) had described it.

She (wife) would have joyed to declare her (wife) close companionship, if only to stop the tongues of those who hesitated not to vilify the dead before her (wife).

Eliza Gollop had told many stories concerning Mrs. Lintern's attendance in the sick room; but few were interested in them or smelt a scandal.

They never identified Priscilla with the vanished innkeeper; they did not scruple to censure Nathan before her (Priscilla) and heap obloquy on his (Nathan) fallen head.

Often with heart and soul she (Priscilla) longed to fight for him (Nathan); often she (Priscilla) had some ado to hide her (Priscilla) impotent anger; but a lifetime of dissimulation had skilled her (Priscilla) in the art of self-control.

She (Priscilla) listened and looked upon the angry man or woman; she (Priscilla) even acquiesced in the abuse by silence.

Seldom did she (Priscilla) defend the dead man, excepting in secret against her (Priscilla) daughters.

CHAPTER III When Cora Lintern returned home she (Priscilla) brought with her (Priscilla) a resolution.

Her (Priscilla) intentions were calculated to cause pain, and she (Priscilla) carried them so much the quicker to execution, that the thing might be done and the blow struck as swiftly as possible.

She (Priscilla) revealed her (Priscilla) plan to none, and only made it public when he (Lintern) who was chiefly involved had learned it.

Ned Baskerville called to see Cora, who had been stopping with friends; and when she (Priscilla) had spoken upon general subjects, she (Priscilla) made him (Cora) come out with her (Priscilla) to the wintry side of West Down, and there imparted her (Priscilla) wintry news.

``Have you found anything to do?'' (Cora/Cora Lintern/Lintern)

was Cora's first question, and he (Cora) answered that he (Cora) had not.

``People don't understand me,'' (he)
he (Cora) said.

``Here is Rupert talking about labourer's work, as if it was a perfectly decent suggestion to make.

My farm's gone, and he (Rupert) seems to think I might offer to stop there under somebody, like he (Rupert) has himself.'' (unknown)

``You want something better.'' (unknown)

``Why, of course.

I might get a clerkship or some such thing, I should think.

A man who has lived my life can't go and dig potatoes.

But the difficulty is to get work like that away from towns.

I can't be expected to live in a town, and I won't.'' (unknown)

``Mr. Tim Waite is a friend of the people I've been stopping with,'' (she)
she (You) said.

``He (Waite)'s rich and all that.

I believe he (Waite) might find--'' (unknown)

``Thank you for nothing, Cora.

I'm hardly likely to trouble him (Cora), am I?'' (unknown)

``Not much use talking like that.'' (unknown)

``I'll take patronage, if I must, because beggars can't be choosers; but I'll not take it from my inferiors.'' (unknown)

''`Inferiors'!

That's a funny word for you to use.

How is Timothy Waite your inferior?

I don't see it.''

``Don't you?'' (he)

he (Waite) answered, getting red.

``Then you ought to see it.

Damn it all, Cora, you're so cold-blooded where I'm concerned.

And yet you're supposed to love me and want to marry me.'' (unknown)

``I'm not a fool, and if 'tis cold-blooded to have a bit of common-sense, then I'm cold-blooded.

Though I'm a bit tired of hearing you fling the word in my face.

Timothy Waite always was as good a man as you; and why not?'' (unknown)

``I should call him (man) a mean, money-grubbing sort of chap myself--close-fisted too.

He (man)'s not a sportsman, anyway.

You can't deny that.'' (unknown)

``Not much good being generous, if you've got nought to be generous with.

And mean he (man) is not.

He (man) lent money to your uncle, and never pushed the claim half as hard as many smaller men.

I know him (man) a long sight better than you do.

And, if you've got any sense left, you'll go to him (man) and ask him (man) if he (man) can help you to find a job.

I'm only thinking of you--not myself.

I can go into a hat shop any day; but you--you can't do anything.

What are you good for?

For that matter you don't seem to be able to get a chance to show what you are good for.

All your swell hunting friends are worth just what I said they were worth.

Now you're down on your luck, they look t`other way.'' (He)

He (man) began to grow angry.

``You're the fair-weather sort too, then?

One here and there has hinted to me that you were--your brother always said it.

But never, never would I stand it from any of them.

And now I see that it is so.'' (unknown)

``No need to call names.

The case is altered since Nathan Baskerville ruined you, and I'm not the sentimental kind to pretend different.

As we're on this now, we'd better go through with it.

You want to marry me and I wanted to marry you; but we can't live on air, I believe.

I can't, anyway.

It's a very simple question.

You wish to marry me so soon as I please; but what do you mean to keep me on?

I've got nothing--you know that; and you've got less than nothing, for there's the rent of the house we were to have lived in.'' (unknown)

``I've let the house and I am looking round.

I'm open to any reasonable offer.'' (unknown)

``What nonsense you talk!

Who are you that people should make you offers?

What can you do?

I ask you that again.'' (unknown)

``By God!

And you're supposed to love me!'' (unknown)

``When poverty comes in at the door--you know the rest.

I'm not a heroine of a story-book.

All very well for you; but what about me?

You can't afford to marry, and I can't afford not to; so there it stands.

There's only one thing in the world--only one thing--that you can be trusted to earn money at, and that's teaching people to ride horses.

And that you won't do.

I've thought it out, and you needn't swear and curse; because it's the truth.'' (unknown)

``Damn it all--'' (unknown)
``No good raging.

You're selfish, and you never think of me working my fingers to the bone and, very likely, not knowing where to look for a meal.

You only want me--not my happiness and prosperity.

That's not love.

If you loved me, you would have come long since and released me from this engagement, and saved me the pain of all this talk.

Nobody ever thinks of me and my future and my anxieties.

I've only got my face and--and--you say `damn' and I'll say it too.

Damn--damn--damn--that's thrice for your once; and I hate you thrice as much as you hate me, and I've thrice the reason to.

I hate you for being so selfish; and 'tis no good ever you saying you care about me again, because you never did--not really.

You couldn't--else you wouldn't have put yourself first always.'' (He)

He (I) started, quite reduced to silence by this assault.

She (it) struck him (I) dumb, but his (I) look infuriated her (it).

``You won't make me draw back, so you needn't think it,'' (she)
she (it) cried.

``I'm not ashamed of a word I've said.

'Tis you ought to be ashamed.

And I'm not sorry for you neither, for you've never once been sorry for me.

After the crash, not one word of trouble for my loss and my disappointment did you utter--'twas only whining about your horses, and the house at Plympton, and all the rest of it.

Vain cursing of the man in his (man) grave; when you ought to have cursed yourself for letting him (man) have the power to do what he (man) did.

I'd have stuck to you, money or no money, if you'd been a different man--I swear that.

I'd have taken you and set to work--as I shall now, single-handed--but how can any decent girl with a proper conceit of herself sink herself to your level and become your drudge?

Am I to work for us both?

Are you going to live on the money I make out of women's bonnets?'' (unknown)

``No!'' (he)

he (drudge) answered.

``Don't think that.

I'm dull, I know, and slow-witted.

Such a fool was I that I never believed anything bad of a woman, or ever thought an unkind thought of anything in petticoats.

But you use very straight English always, and you make your meaning perfectly clear.

I know it won't be easy for me to get the work I want.

I may be poor for a long time--perhaps always.

I'll release you, Cora, if that's what you wish.

No doubt I ought to have thought of it; but I'll swear I never did.

I thought you loved me, and everything else was small by comparison.

If anybody had said `release her (me),' I'd have told him (Cora) that he (Cora) didn't know what love of woman meant--or a woman's love of man.

But you can be free and welcome, and put the fault on my shoulders.

They can bear it.

Go to Timothy.

He (Timothy)'s always wanted you.'' (unknown)

``You needn't be coarse.

I'm sick and tired of all you men.

You don't know what love means--none of you.

And since you say I'm to go, I'll go.

And I'll find peace somewhere, somehow; but not with none of you.'' (He)

He (Timothy) laughed savagely.

``You've ruined me--that's what you've done.

Meat and drink to you, I'll wager!

Ruined me worse than ever my uncle did.

I could have stood up against that.

I did.

I'd pretty well got over the pinch of it.

Though 'twas far more to me than anybody, I took it better than anybody, and my own mother will tell you so.

But why?

Because I thought I'd got you safe enough and nothing else mattered.

I never thought this misfortune meant that you'd give me the slip.

If any man had hinted such a thing, I'd have knocked his (man) teeth down his (man) throat.

But I was wrong as usual.'' (unknown)

``You gave me credit for being a fool as usual.'' (unknown)

``Never that, Cora.

I always knew very well you were clever, but I thought you were something more.

You crafty things--all of you!

And now--what?

`Twill be said I've jilted another girl--not that the only woman I ever honestly worshipped with all my heart have jilted me.'' (unknown)

``No need to use ugly, silly words about it.

All that will be said by sensible people is that we've both seen reason and cut our coats according to our cloth.

The people will only say you've got more wits than they thought.

Let it be understood we were of the same mind, and so we both get a bit of credit for sense.'' (unknown)

``Never!'' (he)

he (they) burst out passionately.

``You're a hard-hearted, cruel devil.

You know where the fault is and who's to blame.

You think of nought but your own blasted comfort and pleasure, and you never cared no more for me than you cared for my cousin before me.

But I'll not hang myself--be sure of that!'' (She)

She (me) shrugged her (me) shoulders.

``You might do worse, all the same,'' (she)
she (me) said.

``For you're only cumbering the earth that I can see.'' (he)

Thereupon he (cousin) swore wild oaths and rushed off and left her (me) on the hillside alone.

When he (cousin) was gone she (me) went her (me) own way, but not to Undershaugh.

By deep lanes and field-paths familiar to her (me) she (me) took a long walk, and at the end of it found herself at Coldstone Farm, the abode of Mr. Timothy Waite.

He (Waite) was from home, and she (me) asked for pen and paper that she (me) might leave a note for him (Waite).

Her (me) communication was short, and when she (me) had written it and sealed it with exceeding care, she (me) set off again for home.

Anon Mr. Waite opened it and was much disappointed at the length.

But Cora's matter atoned for this shortcoming.

``Have settled with N.B.

Yours, C.'' (she)

And elsewhere, while she (me) retraced her (me) way from Coldstone, the discarded lover came to a wild conclusion with himself.

He (lover) steadied his (lover) steps, stood at the Moor edge in two minds, then turned and set off for Hawk House.

This blow had staggered him (House), had even awakened him (House) from the fatuous dream in which he (House) passed his (House) days.

He (House) had a vague idea that Humphrey might be glad to know of this broken engagement; that it might even put his (Humphrey) uncle into a more amiable temper.

Ned had been advised by Rupert to see Mr. Baskerville; but had declined to do so until the present time.

At Hawk House Mrs. Hacker met him (Hawk) and made no effort to hide astonishment.

``Wonders never cease, I'm sure!

You, of all men!

Master be on the Moor, riding somewheres, but if you want him (Moor), you can wait for him (Moor).

He (Moor) always comes in at dusk.

How's your young woman?'' (The man)

The man was in no mood for talk with Susan and cut her (Susan) short.

``I'll wait, then,'' (he)
he (man) said.

``I'll wait in the garden.'' (He)

He (man) walked up and down amid the nut trees for an hour.

Then Humphrey returned.

Tea was served for them in the kitchen; Susan went out and the way opened for Ned.

``You might be surprised to see me,'' (he)
he (Ned) began;
``but though I know you don't like me--natural enough too--still, I'm your eldest nephew, and I felt at a time like this you'd not refuse to let me speak to you.'' (he)

``Speak, and welcome.'' (unknown)

``Of course, all our lives are turned upside down by this terrible business.'' (unknown)

``Not all.

In these cases 'tis the drones, not the workers, that are hit hardest.

If you've got wit enough to understand what you see under your eyes, you'll find that your brother Rupert, for instance, can go on with his (Rupert) life much as before; and scores of others--they've lost a bit of money--cheated out of it by my brother, the late Nathan Baskerville--but it don't wreck them.

'Tis only such as you--accustomed all your life to idle and grow fat on other men's earnings--'tis only such as you that are stranded by a thing like this.

I suppose you want to get back into the hive--like t`other drones when the pinch of winter comes--and the world won't let you in?'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

This uncompromising speech shook Ned and, under the circumstances, he (Ned) felt that it was more than he (Ned) could bear.

``If you knew what had happened to me to-day, you'd not speak so harsh, Uncle Humphrey,'' (he)
he (Humphrey) answered.

``I may tell you that I've been struck a very cruel blow in the quarter I least expected it.

Cora Lintern's thrown me over.'' (unknown)

``Cat-hearted little bitch,'' (he)
he (Lintern) said.

``And you bleat about a `cruel blow'!

Why, you young fool, escape from her (bitch) is the best piece of fortune that ever fell to your lot--or is ever likely to.

And you ask me to be sorry for you!

Fool's luck is always the best luck.

You've had better fortune far than ever you deserved if she (bitch)'s quitted you.'' (unknown)

``You can't look at it as I do; you can't see what my life must be without her (bitch).'' (unknown)

``Eat your meat and don't babble that stuff.'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

Ned shook his (Ned) head.

``Don't want nothing, thank you.'' (unknown)

``Well, hear me,'' (Humphrey/Humphrey Baskerville/HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE)
said Humphrey.

``You sought me of your own free will, and so you may as well listen.

You've come, because you think I can do you a turn--eh?'' (unknown)

``I'm down on my luck, and I thought perhaps that you--anyway, if you can help, or if you can't, you might advise me.

I've looked very hard and very far for a bit of work such as I could do; and I've not found it.'' (unknown)

``The work you can do won't be easily found.

Begin at the beginning.

You're Godless--always have been.'' (unknown)

``Let God alone and He (God)'ll let you alone--that's my experience,'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)
said Ned.

``Is it?

Well, your experience don't reach far.

You've come to the place where God's waiting for you now--waiting, and none too pleased at what you bring afore Him (God).

You're a fool, and though we mourn for a wise man after he (man)'s dead, we mourn for a fool all the days of his (fool) life.

D'you know where that comes from?

Of course you don't.'' (unknown)

``I can mend, I suppose?

Anyway, I've got to be myself.

Nobody can be different to their own character.'' (unknown)

``Granted--you can't rise above your own character; but you can easily sink below it.

That's what you have done, and your father helped you from the first.'' (unknown)

``I won't hear you say nothing against him (father), Uncle Humphrey.

Good or bad, he (Humphrey) was all goodness to me.'' (unknown)

``You think so, but you're wrong.

Well, I'll leave him (Humphrey).

But 'tis vain to judge you too hard when I remember your up-bringing.'' (unknown)

``All the same, I will say this for myself: when you pull me to pieces, you'll find no wickedness in me worth mentioning.

Whatever I may be, I've always behaved like a gentleman and a sportsman, and none will deny it,'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

declared Ned.

``The biggest fool can be witty when it comes to excusing his (Ned) own vices to his (Ned) conscience,'' (the man)
replied the old man.

``Fox yourself with that rubbish, if you can, not me.

To behave like a gentleman is to be a gentleman, I should think, and I understand the word very different from you.

You're a selfish, worthless thing--a man that's reached near to thirty without putting away his (man) childish toys--a man that's grown to man's estate and stature without doing so much good in the world as my blind pony--nay, nor so much good as the worm that pulls the autumn leaves into the wet ground.

And you pride yourself on being a gentleman!

Better larn to be a man first and a gentleman afterwards.'' (unknown)

``I've never had no occasion to work till now.

Nobody ever asked me to; nobody ever wanted me to.

It was natural that I shouldn't.

A man can't help his (man) character, and I can't help mine.

I hate work and always shall.'' (unknown)

``That's clear, then.

And I can't help my character either.

I hate idleness and always shall.

Never have I given a loafer a helping hand, and never will I.

A man ought to be like Providence and only help those who help themselves.'' (unknown)

``But I mean to work; I need to work; I must work.'' (unknown)

``Laziness is a cancer,'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)
said Mr. Baskerville.

'''Tis just as much a cancer as the human ill we call by that name.

And 'tis a modern thing.

There's something rotten with the world where any man can live without earning the right to.

When next you find yourself caddling about on the Moor wasting your time, take a look at the roundy-poundies--they circles of stones cast about on the hillsides and by the streams.

My son Mark knew all about them.

They were set up by men like ourselves who lived on the Moor very long ago.

Life was real then.

Nought but their own sweat stood between the old men and destruction.

The first business of life was to keep life in them days.

They hunted to live, not for pleasure.

They hunted and were hunted.

No time to be lazy then.

Did they help beggars?

Did they keep paupers?

No; all had to toil for the common good; and if a man didn't labour, he (man) didn't eat.

They had their work cut out for 'em to wring a bare living out of the earth and the creatures on it.

No softness of mind or body then.

No holidays and pleasurings and revels then.

And I'd have it so again to-morrow, if I could.

Work and eat; idle and starve--that's what I'd say to my fellow-creatures.''

``I mean to work; I'm ready for work.'' (unknown)

``All very well to say that now.

You may be ready for work; but what sort of work is ready for you?

What can you do?

Can you break stones?

There's a Cornish proverb hits you this minute: `Them as can't scheme must lowster.'

Your father was very fond of using it--to every lazy body but you.

It means that if you haven't the wits to make a living with your brains, you must do it with your hands.

It all comes back to work.'' (unknown)

``I know it does.

I keep on telling you I'm ready for it--any amount of it.

But not breaking stones.

I've got brains in my head, though I know you don't think so.

I came to-day to know if you would give those brains a trial.

I'm a free man now.

Cora has flung me over, so there's no obligation anywhere.

I'm free to stand up and show what I'm good for.

I've sold my horses and given up hunting already.

That's something.'' (unknown)

``Something you couldn't help.

How much did you get for that big bright bay?'' (unknown)

``Forty-five guineas.'' (unknown)

``And gave?'' (unknown)

``Seventy.

But, of course, I've not got enough capital all told to be much practical use in buying into anything.

What I really want is five hundred pounds.'' (unknown)

``A common want.'' (unknown)

``And I thought perhaps that you--I thought of it as I came here to see you.'' (unknown)

``And still you try to make out you're not a fool?'' (unknown)

``I can give interest and security.'' (unknown)

``Yes--like your Uncle Nathan, perhaps.

In a word, I'll not do anything.

Not a farthing of money and not a hand of help.

But--'' (He)

He (Nathan) stopped as the younger man rose.

``I didn't ask for money; I only suggested a loan.'' (unknown)

``I'll loan no loans to you or any man.

But this I will do, because you are the head of our family now, and I don't want anybody to say I helped to cast you lower when you were down.

This I will do: I'll double the money you earn.'' (unknown)

``Double it!'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

exclaimed Ned.

``That's my word; and now the boot's on the other leg, and I'm the fool for my pains, no doubt.

But understand me.

'Tis what you earn , not what you get.

When you come to me and say, `I've found a job, and I'm paid so much a week for doing it by an independent man,' then I'll double what he (man) gives you.

But let there be no hookemsnivey dealings, for I'll very soon find them out if you try it.

Let it be figures, let it be horses, let it be clay, let it be stones by the road--I'll double what you earn for five years.

By that time, maybe, you'll know what work means, and thank Heaven, that's taught you what it means.

Go and find work--that's what you've got to do; go and find what you're worth in the open market of men.

And you needn't thank me for what I offer.

`Twill be little enough, I promise you--as you'll find when you come to hear the money value of your earning powers.'' (unknown)

``All the same I do thank you, and I thank you with all my heart,'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)
said Ned:
``and perhaps you'll be a bit more astonished than you think for, Uncle Humphrey, when you find what I can do.'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

Then his (Humphrey) nephew went away in doubt whether to be elated or cast down.

CHAPTER IV An elderly man called Abraham Elford became tenant of `The White Thorn' after Baskerville's death.

He (Baskerville) lacked the charm of Nathan, and it was rumoured that the quality of his (Nathan) liquor by no means equalled that provided by the vanished master of the inn; but no choice offered of other drinking houses, and the new publican retained all former patronage.

One subject at this season proved rich enough to shut out all lesser matters from conversation, for the wide waves of concern set rolling when Nathan died had as yet by no means subsided.

Each day for many days brought news of some fresh disaster to humble folk; and then came another sort of intelligence that gratified the few and angered the many.

Mr. Elford and certain of his (Elford) customers, not directly interested, found the subject of Nathan's affairs exceedingly wearisome and often sought to turn talk into other channels; but not for long could they be said to succeed.

Local politics and weather soon lost their power to hold the people; and those disasters spread by the late publican swiftly cropped up again to the exclusion of less pungent concerns.

A party of men was assembled at `The White Thorn' near Christmas time, and they wrangled on over this well-trodden ground until Joe Voysey, who had not suffered, turned to the grey-headed host behind the bar and asked a question.

``Did this here fire fail afore you comed, Abraham?'' (he)

he (Abraham) asked.

'''Tis a well-known fact that `The White Thorn' hearth haven't been cold for a hundred year--peat always smouldering, or else blazing, upon it.''

``Yes, and a thousand pities,'' (unknown)
answered the other.

``At the time of Mr. Baskerville's death, of course, there was a terrible deal of running about and confusion.

And the fire was forgot.

I knowed the old saying and was very sorry to see it black out.'' (unknown)

``What do it matter?'' (Jack/Jack Head)

asked Jack Head.

He (Head) was in a quarrelsome mood and bad company on the occasion.

``These silly sayings and fancies are better forgot.

Who's the wiser for a thing like that?

Probably, when all's said, 'tis a lie.

I dare say the fire went out scores of times when Nathan was here, and somebody just lit it again and said nought about it.'' (unknown)

``That's wrong, Jack,'' (Heathman/Heathman Lintern)
declared Heathman Lintern, who was present.

``Mr. Baskerville took a lot of care of the fire and felt very proud of it.

A score of times I've heard him (Baskerville) tell people about it, and that the fire had never been douted for more than a hundred years.'' (unknown)

``One thing I know, that if there was such a place as hell, he (Baskerville)'d soon meet with a fire as would last longer still,'' (unknown)
answered Head.

``A fire that never will be douted.

And right well he (Baskerville)'d deserve it.'' (Thomas/Thomas Gollop)

Thomas Gollop found himself in agreement with this ferocity.

``You're right there, and there is such a place--have no fear of that, though 'tis your way to scorn it.

For my part I say that there couldn't be no justice without it.

He (Gollop) devoured widows' houses and stole the bread of the poor--what worse can any man do?'' (unknown)

``A man can backbite the dead, and spit out his (man) poison against them as never hurt him (man) in word or deed,'' (Heathman/Heathman Lintern)
answered Heathman Lintern.

'''Tis always your way to blackguard them that be out of earshot and the power to answer; and the further a man be away, the louder you yelp.

Faults or no faults, the likes of you wasn't worthy to wipe his (man) shoes.''

``You Linterns--well, I'll say nought,'' (Jack/Jack Head)
began Jack Head; but the subject was too attractive for him (Head) and he (Head) proceeded.

``If he (Head) left your mother any money, it's against the law, and you can tell her (mother) so.

It wasn't his (Head) to leave, and if she (mother) got money from him (Head) in secret, it's my money--not hers--mine, and many other people's before it's hers.

And if she (mother) was honest she (mother)'d give it back.'' (unknown)

``You've lost your wits over this,'' (Cora/Cora Lintern/Lintern)
answered Lintern,
``and if you wasn't an old man, Jack, I'd hammer your face for mentioning my mother's name in such a way.

She (mother) never had a penny by him (Jack), and the next man that says she (mother) did shall get a flea in his (man) ear--old or young.'' (Cora/Cora Lintern/Lintern)

``Let it be a lesson to all sorts and conditions not to trust a Dissenter,'' (Gollop/Eliza/Eliza Gollop)
said Gollop.

``I've known pretty well what they're good for from the first moment they began to lift their heads in the land.

They never were to be trusted, and never will be.

And as for Nathan Baskerville, he (Baskerville) was a double serpent, and I shall tell the truth out against him (Baskerville) when and where I please; and why for not?'' (unknown)

``You don't know the meaning of truth,'' (Heathman/Heathman Lintern)
began Heathman;
``no more don't that old cat, your sister.'' (Heathman/Heathman Lintern)

``Better leave my sister alone, or `twill be the worse for you,'' (the parish clerk)
answered the parish clerk.

``I'll leave her (clerk) alone when she (clerk) leaves my mother alone, and not sooner.

She (clerk) a lying, foul-minded old baggage--not to be trusted in a respectable house--and if I was better to do, I'd have the law of her (clerk) for the things she (clerk)'s said.'' (unknown)

``You talk of the law,'' (Jack/Jack Head)
answered Jack.

``You might just so well talk of the prophets.

One's as rotten as t`other nowadays.

The law's gone that weak that a man's savings can be taken out of his (man) pocket by the first thief that comes along with an honest face; and him (man) powerless.

Five-and-thirty pound--that's what he (man) had of mine, and the law looks on and does nought.'' (unknown)

``Because there's nought for it to do,'' (Mr. Elford/Elford)
suggested Mr. Elford.

``The law can't make bricks without straw--'' (Jack/Jack Head)
``Just what it can do--when it's writing its own bills o' costs,'' (Jack/Jack Head)
answered Jack.

``They'm damn clever at that; but let a rogue rob me of my savings and the law don't care a brass farthing.

Why?

Because I'm poor.'' (unknown)

``Is there to be nought declared in the pound?'' (an man)

inquired an old man beside the fire.

``He (man) had eight, ten of mine, and I was hopeful us might get back a little, if 'twas only shillings.'' (unknown)

``You'll see nothing of it, gaffer,'' (unknown)
declared Head.

``There wasn't much more than enough to pay for the man's coffin.

And the tears shed at his (man) grave!

I laugh when I think of all them gulls, and the parsons, with their long faces, thinking they was burying a good man and a burning light.'' (unknown)

``A burning light now, if he (man) wasn't afore,'' (Gollop/Eliza/Eliza Gollop)
said Gollop, returning to his (man) favourite theme.

``You're a mean cur at heart, Jack,'' (the man)
burst out the dead man's son to Mr. Head.

``With all your noise about justice and liberty and right and wrong, none on God's earth can show his (God) teeth quicker and snarl worse if his (God) own bone be took away.

You knowed Nathan Baskerville--no one knowed him (Baskerville) better than you.

And well you know that with all his (Baskerville) faults and foolish, generous way of playing with his (Baskerville) money and other people's--well, you know there was a big spirit in the man.

He (man) meant terrible kindly always.

He (man) didn't feather his (man) own nest.

For a hundred that curse him (man) now, there's thousands that have blessed him (man) in past years.

But 'tis the curses come home to roost and foul a man's grave; the blessings be forgot.'' (The man)

The young man's eyes shone and his (man) eloquence silenced the bar for a moment.

Jack Head stared.

'''Tis Mark Baskerville speaking,'' he (Head) said.

``Even so he (Head) was used to talk!

But I didn't know you was the soft sort too, Heathman.

What was Nat to you, or you to Nat, that you can stand up for him (Nat) and talk this nonsense in the face of facts?

Where's my money?

When you tell me that, I'll tell you--'' (Joe Voysey/Joe/Voysey)

``Who knows whether you'm forgot after all, Jack?'' (Joe Voysey/Joe/Voysey)

interrupted Joe Voysey.

``Everybody ban't ruined.

There's a few here and there--especially the awful poor people--as have had their money made good.'' (unknown)

``I know all about that,'' (fool parson)
answered Head; '''tis that fool, the parson.

Masterman have no more idea of justice than any other church minister, and he (Masterman)'s just picked and chosen according to his (Masterman) own fancy, and made it up to this man and that man out of his (man) own riches.''

``To no man has he (man) made it up,'' (Gollop/Eliza/Eliza Gollop)
corrected Gollop.

'''Tis only in the case of certain needy females that he (man)'ve come forward.

A widow here and there have been paid back in full.

I made so bold as to ask Lawyer Popham about it; but he (Lawyer)'s not a very civil man, and he (man) fobbed me off with a lawyer's answer that meant nought.''

'''Tis well knowed to be Masterman, however,'' said Voysey.

``Yes; well knowed to us; but not to the general public.

Some think it's the lawyer himself; but that's a wild saying.

Last thing he (lawyer)'d do.

He (lawyer)'ll be out of pocket as it is.'' (a woman)

At this juncture was presented the unusual spectacle of a woman in the bar of `The White Thorn,' and Susan Hacker entered.

She (Hacker) was known to several present and men liked her (Hacker).

She (Hacker) understood the sex, and could give as good as she (Hacker) got.

She (Hacker) expected little in the way of civility or sense from them, and she (Hacker) was seldom disappointed.

``Hullo!'' (unknown)

cried Head.

``Be you on the downward path then, Susan?

'Tis your old man driving you to drink without a doubt!'' (The woman)

The abundant woman pushed Jack out of her (woman) way and came to the counter.

``Don't you pay no heed to that there sauce-box,'' (she)
she (woman) said.

``And him (Jack) old enough and ugly enough to know better, you'd think.

A drop of gin hot, please.

I be finger-cold and I've got to speed home yet.'' (unknown)

``How's `the Hawk'?'' (Mr. Voysey)

asked Mr. Voysey.

``We all thought when poor old Nathan was took off that he (Nathan)'d come forward with his (Nathan) money bags--knowing the man, didn't we, souls?'' (Susan/Susan Hacker/Hacker)

This excellent jest awakened laughter till Susan stopped it.

She (Susan) took her (Susan) drink to the fire, loosed a mangy little fur tippet from her (Susan) great shoulders and warmed her (Susan) feet alternately.

``A funny old fool you are, Joe--just funny enough to make other fools laugh.

And why should Humphrey Baskerville waste his (Baskerville) money on a lot of silly people?

Which of you would come forward and help him (Baskerville) if he (Baskerville) was hard up?'' (unknown)

``I would,'' (Jack/Jack Head)
said Jack Head.

``With my opinions I'd help any thrifty person let in by this dead man--if I could.

But I was let in myself.

And you're in the truth to call us fools, for so we were.'' (unknown)

``It's reason, every way, that your master might think of his (master) brother's good name and right the wrong done by the man who was here afore me,'' (Mr. Elford/Elford)
declared Mr. Elford impartially.

``Why?'' (Mrs. Hacker)

asked Mrs. Hacker.

``Why do you say 'tis reason?

If 'tis reason for him (Elford), 'tis just as much reason for every other man who can afford to mend it.'' (unknown)

``That's what I say,'' (Jack/Jack Head)
argued Jack Head, but none agreed with him (Head).

``Ban't our business, but 'tis Humphrey Baskerville's,'' (the publican)
declared the publican.

``The dead man was his (man) own brother and his (man) only one.

For the credit of the family he (man) ought to come forward, and not leave the parson and other outsiders to do it.'' (unknown)

``Because your brother does wrong, 'tis no business of yours to right the wrong,'' (Mrs. Hacker)
answered Mrs. Hacker.

``Besides, 'tis well known that charity begins at home.'' (unknown)

``And stops there,'' (Gollop/Eliza/Eliza Gollop)
suggested Gollop.

``No doubt at Hawk House, you and him (House) be as snug as beetles in the tree bark, while other people don't know where to turn for a roof to cover 'em.'' (unknown)

``They'd have poor speed if they was to turn to you, anyway,'' (she)
she (Gollop) said.

'''Tis like your round-eyed, silly impudence to speak like that of a better man than ever you was or will be, or know how to be.

He (man) ban't bound to tell you where he (man) spends his (man) money, I believe; and if you was half as good a man--but there, what can you expect from a Gollop but a grunt?

You'm a poor generation, you and your sister--God knows which is the worse.''

``Bravo, Susan!

Have another drop along o' me,'' (Heathman/Heathman Lintern)

cried Heathman Lintern, and she (Susan) agreed to do so.

``What do you know and what don't you know?'' (unknown)

asked Head presently.

``Be your old party going to do anything or nothing?'' (unknown)

``I don't know.

But this I do know, that all your wild tales down here about his (Bravo) money be silly lies.

We live hard enough, I can promise that, whatever you may think.

If every man here spent his (man) money so wise as Humphrey Baskerville, you wouldn't all be boozing in this bar now, but along with your lawful wives and families, helping the poor women to find a bit of pleasure in life.

But I know you; you get a shipload of brats and leave their mothers to do all the horrid work of 'em, while you come in here every night like lords, and soak and twaddle and waste your money and put the world right, then go home not fit company for a dog--'' (Mr. Voysey)

``Steady on--no preaching here--rule of the bar,'' (Mr. Voysey)
said Mr. Voysey.

``You think we're all blanks because you drew a blank, Susan.

Yes, a blank you drew, though you might have had me in the early forties.'' (unknown)

``You!

I'd make a better man than you with a dozen pea-sticks,'' (Susan/Susan Hacker/Hacker)

retorted Susan.

``And I didn't draw a blank, I drawed Hacker, who'd be here now teaching you chaps to drink, if the Lord had spared him (Lord).

You can't even drink now--so feeble have you growed.

Hacker, with all his (Lord) faults, was a fine man; and so's Humphrey Baskerville in his (Baskerville) way.'' (unknown)

``Talk on; but talk to the purpose, Susan.

What have he (Baskerville) done?

That's the question.

You ain't going to tell me he (Baskerville)'s done nought,'' (Mr. Head)

suggested Mr. Head.

``I ain't going to tell you nothing at all, because I don't know nothing at all.

He (Head) wouldn't ax me how to spend his (Head) money--nor you neither.'' (unknown)

``Tell us who he (Head)'s helping--if anybody,'' (the man)
persisted the man.

``How is it none haven't handed me back my money?

You can mention--if you've got the pluck to do it--that I want my bit back so well as t`others; and mine be quite as much to me as Ned Baskerville's thousands was to him (Baskerville).'' (unknown)

``Charity begins at home,'' (Susan/Susan Hacker/Hacker)
repeated Susan,
``and I'll lay you my hat, though the fog's took the feather out of curl, that if he (Baskerville) does anything, `twill be for his (Baskerville) own first.

He (Baskerville)'s that sort, I believe.'' (Susan/Susan Hacker/Hacker)

``They people at Cadworthy?'' (unknown)

``Yes.

Not that I think he (Baskerville)'ll do aught; but if he (Baskerville) does, `twill be there.

Mrs. Baskerville be taking very unkindly to the thought of leaving.

She (Baskerville)'ve lived here all her (Baskerville) married life and brought all her (Baskerville) childer there.

But she (Baskerville)'ve got to go.

They're all off after Lady Day.

Too much rent wanted by the new owner.'' (unknown)

``Same with us,'' (Heathman/Heathman Lintern)
said Heathman.

``These here men, who have got the places on their hands now, `pear to think a Dartmoor farm's a gold mine.

Me and my mother clear out too.'' (Mrs. Hacker)

Mrs. Hacker drank again.

``And after this glass, one of you chaps will have to see me up over,'' (she)
she (Hacker) said.

``We'll all come, if you'll promise another drink at t`other end,'' (Heathman/Heathman Lintern)
declared Heathman; but Susan turned to Jack Head.

``You'd best to come, Jack,'' (she)
she (Susan) declared.

He (Jack) exhibited indifference, but she (Susan) pressed him (Jack) and he (Jack) agreed.

``If I've got a man to look after me, there's no hurry,'' (she)
she (Susan) concluded.

``I'm in for a wigging as 'tis.'' (Mr. Head)

The easy soul stopped on until closing time, and then Mr. Head fulfilled his (Head) promise and walked homeward beside her (Susan) through a foggy night.

She (Susan) rested repeatedly while climbing the hill to the Moor, and she (Susan) talked without ceasing.

Susan was exhilarated and loquacious as the result of too much to drink.

Head, however, bore with her (Susan) and acquired a most startling and unexpected piece of information.

He (Moor) mentioned the attitude of Heathman Lintern and his (Moor) fiery championship of the dead.

``I thought he (Moor)'d have come across and hit me down, because I told the naked truth about the man.

And he (man) denied that his (man) mother was the better by a penny when Nathan died.

But how about it when he (Nathan) was alive?'' (unknown)

``Truth's truth,'' (Susan/Susan Hacker/Hacker)
answered Susan.

``You might have knocked me down with a feather when--but there, what am I saying?'' (He)

He (Nathan) smelt a secret and angled for it.

``Of course, you're like one of the Baskerville family yourself, and I've no right to ask you things; only such a man as me with a credit for sense be different to the talking sort.

Truth's truth, as you say, and the truth will out.

But Eliza Gollop--of course she (Gollop) knows nothing.

She (Gollop) couldn't keep a secret like you or me.'' (Mrs. Hacker)

Mrs. Hacker stood still again and breathed hard in the darkness.

Her (Hacker) tongue itched to tell a tremendous thing known to her (Hacker); but her (Hacker) muddled senses fought against this impropriety.

``Two can often keep a secret that pretty well busts one,'' (Mr. Head)
said Mr. Head with craft.

He (Head) believed that Humphrey Baskerville was paying some of his (Baskerville) brother's debts; and since this procedure might reach to him (Baskerville), he (Baskerville) felt the keenest interest in it.

Mrs. Lintern did not concern him (Baskerville).

He (Baskerville) had merely mentioned her (Lintern).

But Priscilla was the subject which filled Susan's mind to the exclusion of all lesser things, and she (Susan) throbbed to impart her (Susan) knowledge.

No temptation to confide in another had forced itself upon her (Susan) until the present; yet with wits loosened and honour fogged by drink, she (Susan) now yearned to speak.

At any other moment such a desire must have been silenced, by reason of the confession of personal wrongdoing that it entailed.

Now, however, she (Susan) did not remember that.

She (Susan) was only lusting to tell, and quite forgot how she (Susan) had learned.

Thus, while Head, to gain private ends, endeavoured to find whether Mr. Baskerville was paying his (Baskerville) brother's debts, Susan supposed that his (Baskerville) mind ran upon quite another matter: the relations between Priscilla Lintern and Humphrey's dead brother.

Mrs. Hacker knew the truth.

She (Hacker) had acquired it in the crudest manner, by listening at the door during an interview between Nathan's mistress and her (mistress) master.

This tremendous information had burnt her (mistress) soul to misery ever since; but a thousand reasons for keeping the secret existed.

Her (mistress) own good name was involved as much as another's.

She (mistress) could not whisper a word for her (mistress) credit's sake; and a cause that weighed far heavier with her (mistress) was the credit of Eliza Gollop.

Eliza had guessed darkly at what Susan now knew; but as a result of her (Susan) subterranean hints, Eliza had suffered in the public esteem, for few believed her (Eliza).

To confirm Eliza and ratify her (Eliza) implications was quite the last thing that Mrs. Hacker would have desired to do; and yet such was the magic sleight of alcohol to masquerade in the shape of reason, justice, and right--such also its potency to conceal danger--that now this muddled woman fell.

She (woman) was intelligent enough to make Jack promise on Bible oaths that he (Jack) would keep her (woman) secret; and then she (woman) told him (Jack) the last thing that he (Jack) expected to hear.

With acute interest he (Jack) waited to know Humphrey's future intentions respecting his (Jack) brother's creditors; instead he (Jack) listened to widely different facts.

``I'll tell you if you'll swear by the Book to keep it to yourself.

I'll be the better for telling it.

'Tis too large a thing for one woman--there--all that gin--I know 'tis that have loosed my tongue even while I'm speaking.

And yet, why not?

You're honest.

I'm sure I can't tell what I ought to do.

You might say 'twas no business of mine, and I don't wish one of 'em any harm--not for the wide world do I.'' (unknown)

``I'll swear to keep quiet enough, my dear woman.

And 'tis your sense, not your thimble of liquor, makes you want to talk to me.

If not me, who?

I'm the sort that knows how to keep a secret, like the grave knows how to keep its dead.

I'm a friend to you and Mr. Baskerville both--his (Baskerville) greatest friend, you might say.'' (unknown)

``In a word, 'tis natural that young Lintern--you swear, Jack--on your Bible you swear that you won't squeak?

'' (unknown)

-LSB-1-RSB- -LSB-1-RSB- Squeak --break silence.

``I ain't got one; but I'll swear on yours.

You can trust me.'' (Cora/Cora Lintern/Lintern)

'''Twas natural as Lintern got vexed down there then, and you was lucky not to feel the weight of his (Lintern) fist.

For why--for why?

He (Lintern)'s Nathan's son!

Gospel truth.

They'm all his (Lintern): Cora, t`other girl, and Heathman.

The mother of 'em told my master in so many words; and I heard her (mother) tell him (master).

I was just going into the room, but stopped at the door for some reason, and, before I could get out of earshot, I'd catched it.

There!''

``Say you was eavesdropping and have done with it,'' (Mr. Head)
said Mr. Head.

He (Head) took this startling news very quietly, and advised Susan to do the like.

``The less you think about it, the better.

What's done be done.

We don't know none of the rights of it, and I'm not the sort to blame anybody--woman or man--for their private actions.

'Tis only Nathan's public actions I jumped on him (Nathan) for, and if Heathman was twice his (Nathan) son, I'd not fear to speak if 'twas a matter of justice.'' (unknown)

``I didn't ought to have told you, but my mind's a sieve if there's a drop of gin in my stomach.

I had to let it go to-night.

If I hadn't told you what I knowed, so like as not I'd have told Mr. Baskerville hisself when I got back; and then `twould have comed out that I'd listened at the door--for I did, God forgive me.'' (Susan/Susan Hacker/Hacker)

Susan became lachrymose, but Jack renewed his (Jack) promises and left her (Susan) tolerably collected.

The confession had eased her (Susan) mind, calmed its excitement, and silenced her (Susan) tongue also.

Jack tried to learn more of the thing that interested him (Jack) personally, but upon that subject she (Susan) knew nothing.

She (Susan) believed the general report: that Mr. Masterman, by secret understanding with the lawyer, was relieving the poorest of Nathan's creditors; and she (Susan) inclined to the opinion that her (Susan) master had no hand in this philanthropy.

They parted at the garden wicket of Susan's home, and Mr. Head left her (Susan) there; but not before she (Susan) had made him (Head) swear again with all solemnity to keep the secret.

CHAPTER V As Humphrey Baskerville had pointed out to his (Baskerville) nephew Ned, disaster usually hits the weak harder than the strong, and the lazy man suffers more at sudden reverses than his (man) neighbour, who can earn a living, come what trouble may.

Rupert and his (Rupert) wife were prepared to seek a new home, and Milly, at the bottom of her (Milly) heart, suffered less from these tribulations than any of her (Milly) husband's relations.

The blow had robbed him (husband) of nothing, since he (husband) possessed nothing.

To work to win Cadworthy was no longer possible, but he (husband) might do as well and save money as steadily elsewhere; and the change in their lives for Milly meant something worth having.

In her (Milly) heart was a secret wish that her (Milly) coming child might be born in her (Milly) own home.

As for her (Milly) husband he (husband) now waited his (husband) time, and did not immediately seek work, because Humphrey Baskerville directed delay.

His (Baskerville) reason was not given, nor would he (Baskerville) commit himself to any promise; but he (Baskerville) offered the advice, and Rupert took it.

Mrs. Baskerville's grief at leaving her (Baskerville) home proved excessive.

She (Baskerville) belonged to the easy sort of people who are glad to trust their affairs in any capable control, and she (Baskerville) suffered now at this sudden catastrophe, even as Ned suffered.

She (Baskerville) had very little money, and was constrained to look to her (Baskerville) sons for sustenance.

It was proposed that she (Baskerville) and May should find a cottage at Shaugh; but to display her (Baskerville) poverty daily before eyes that had seen her (Baskerville) prosperity was not good to her (Baskerville).

She (Baskerville) found it hard to decide, and finally hoped to continue life in a more distant hamlet.

All was still in abeyance, and the spring had come.

Until Ned's future theatre of toil was certain, his (Ned) mother would not settle anything.

She (mother) trusted that he (Ned) might win a respectable post, but employment did not offer.

Hester's youngest son Humphrey had been provided for by a friend, and he (Humphrey) was now working with Saul Luscombe at Trowlesworthy.

Then came a date within six weeks of the family's departure.

The packing was advanced, and still nothing had been quite determined.

Ned was anxious and troubled; Rupert waited for his (Rupert) uncle to speak.

He (Rupert) knew of good work at Cornwood, and it was decided that his (Rupert) mother and May should also move to a cottage in that churchtown, unless Ned achieved any sort of work within the next few weeks.

Then his (Ned) plans might help to determine their own.

At this juncture, unexpectedly on a March evening, came their kinsman from Hawk House, and Rupert met him (Rupert) at the outer gate.

``Is your mother here?'' (the rider)

asked the rider, and when he (Rupert) heard that the family was within--save Ned, who stayed at Tavistock on his (Ned) quest--he (Ned) dismounted and came among them.

A litter and disorder marked the house.

There were packing-cases in every room; but less than a moiety of Hester's goods would leave her (mother) home.

She (mother) must dwell in a small cottage henceforth, and her (mother) furniture, with much of her (mother) china and other precious things, was presently destined to be sold.

The period of her (mother) greatest grief had long passed; she (mother) had faced the future with resignation for many months, and returned to her (mother) usual placidity.

She (mother) and her (mother) daughter could even plan their little possessions in a new cottage, and smile together again.

They had fitted their minds to the changed condition; they had calculated the probable result of the sale, and Mrs. Baskerville, thrown by these large reverses from her (Baskerville) former easy and tranquil optimism, had fallen upon the opposite extreme.

She (Baskerville) now looked for no amelioration of the future, foresaw no possibility of adequate work for Ned, and was as dumb as a wounded horse or cow, even at the tragical suggestion of her (Baskerville) son's enlistment.

This he (son) had openly discussed, but finding that none exhibited any horror before the possibility, soon dropped it again.

To these people came Mr. Baskerville--small, grey, saturnine.

His (Baskerville) eyes were causing him (Baskerville) some trouble, and their rims were grown red.

They thought in secret that he (Baskerville) had never looked uglier, and he (Baskerville) declared openly that he (Baskerville) had seldom felt worse.

'''Tis the season of the year that always troubles me,'' he (Baskerville) said.

``Gout, gravel, rheumatism, lumbagy--all at me together.

Nature is a usurer, Hester, as you may live to find out yet, for all you keep so healthy.

She ('T) bankrupts three parts of the men you meet, long afore they pay back the pinch of dust they have borrowed from her ('T).

The rate of interest on life runs too high, and that's a fact, even though you be as thrifty of your powers as you please, and a miser of your vital parts, as I have always been.'' (unknown)

``Your eyes are inflamed seemingly,'' (sister-in-law)
said his (miser) sister-in-law.

``Vivian's went the same once, but doctor soon cured 'em.'' (he)

They sat in the kitchen and he (doctor) spoke to May.

``If you'll hurry tea and brew me a strong cup, I'll thank you.

I feel just as if `twould do me a deal of good.'' (She)

She (sister-in-law) obeyed at once, and Humphrey, exhibiting a most unusual garrulity and egotism, continued to discuss himself.

``For all my carcase be under the weather, my mind is pretty clear for me.

Things be going well, I'm glad to say, and you might almost think I-- However, no matter for that.

Perhaps it ban't the minute to expect you to take pleasure at any other's prosperity.

There's nothing like health, after all.

You'll find yourself more peaceful now, Hester, now you know the worst of it?'' (unknown)

``Peaceful enough,'' (she)
she (you) said.

``I don't blame myself, and 'tis vain to blame the dead.

Master trusted his (Master) brother Nathan, like you trust spring to bring the leaves.

Therefore it was right and proper that I should do the same.

'Twas all put in his (Nathan) hands when Vivian died.

Even if I would have, I wasn't allowed to do anything.

But, of course, I trusted Nathan too.

Who didn't?'' (unknown)

``I didn't, never--Rupert will bear me out in that.

I never trusted him (Rupert), though I envied the whole-hearted respect and regard the world paid him (Rupert).

We envy in another what's denied to ourselves--even faults sometimes.

Yet I'm pretty cheerful here and there--for me.

Have you heard any more said about his (Rupert) death and my hand in it?'' (unknown)

``A lot,'' (Mrs. Baskerville)
answered Mrs. Baskerville.

``And most understanding creatures have quite come round to seeing your side.

Only a man here and there holds out that you were wrong.'' (unknown)

``I may tell you that the reverend Masterman couldn't find no argument against it.

He (Masterman) came to see me not long since.

He (Masterman) wouldn't be kept to the case in point, but argued against the principle at large.

When I pinned him (Masterman) to Nathan at last, he (Nathan) said, though reluctantly, that he (Nathan) believed he (Nathan) would have done no less for his (Nathan) own brother.

That's a pretty good one to me--eh?'' (unknown)

``My Uncle Luscombe thinks you did the proper thing,'' (Milly/Milly Luscombe/Luscombe)
declared Milly.

Presently May called them to the table and handed Humphrey his (Humphrey) tea.

He (Humphrey) thanked her (Milly).

``No sugar,'' (he)
he (Humphrey) said,
``and you ought not to take none neither, May.

Trouble haven't made you grow no narrower at the waist seemingly.'' (he)

The girl tried to smile, and her (girl) family stared.

Jocosity in this man was an exhibition almost unparalleled.

If he (man) ever laughed it was bitterly against the order of things; yet now he (man) jested genially.

The result was somewhat painful, and none concealed an emotion of discomfort and restraint.

The old man perceived their surprise and returned into himself a little.

``You'll wonder how I come to talk so much about my own affairs, perhaps?

'Tisn't often that I do, I believe.

Well, let's drop 'em and come to yours.

Have you found work, Rupert?'' (unknown)

``I can, when you give the word.

There's Martin at Cornwood wants me, and mother can come there.

We've seen two houses, either of which would suit her (mother) and May very well.

One, near the church, she (mother) likes best.

There's a cottage that will fit me and Milly not far off.'' (unknown)

``Why go and have an expensive move when you can live at Shaugh Prior?'' (unknown)

``I've got my feelings,'' (the widow)
answered the widow rather warmly.

``You can't expect me to go there.'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

Mr. Baskerville asked another question.

``So much for you all, then.

And what of Ned?'' (unknown)

``At Tavistock, wearing out his (Ned) shoe-leather trying to find work.'' (unknown)

``If he (Ned)'s only wearing out shoe-leather, no harm's done.'' (unknown)

``He (Ned) told us what you offered last year, and I'm sure 'twas over and above what many men would have done,'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)
declared Ned's mother.

``I was safe to offer it,'' (he)
he (Ned) answered.

'''Tis only to say I'll double nought.

He (Ned)'s not worth a box of matches a week to any man.''

``They very near took him (man) on at the riding-school when he (man) offered to go there.'' (unknown)

``But not quite.'' (unknown)

``And that gave him (man) the idea to `list in the horse soldiers.

He (man) knows all about it, along of being in the yeomanry.'' (unknown)

``To enlist?

Well, soldiering's man's work by all accounts, though I hold 'tis devil's work myself--just the last mischief Satan finds for idle hands to do.'' (unknown)

``It would knock sense into Ned, all the same,'' (Rupert/Rupert Baskerville)
argued Rupert.

``The discipline of it would be good for him (Rupert), and he (Rupert) might rise.'' (unknown)

``But he (Rupert)'s not done it, you say?'' (unknown)

``No,'' (Mrs. Baskerville)
answered Mrs. Baskerville.

``He (Rupert)'s not done it.

I've suffered so much, for my part, that when he (Rupert) broke the dreadful thing upon me, I hadn't a tear left to shed.

And the calm way I took it rather disappointed him (Rupert), poor fellow.

He (Rupert) had a right to expect to see me and May, if not Rupert, terrible stricken at such a thought; but we've been through such a lot a`ready that we couldn't for the life of us take on about it.

I'm sure we both cried rivers--cried ourselves dry, you might say--when Cora Lintern threw him (Lintern) over; but that was the last straw.

Anything more happening leaves us dazed and stupid, like a sheep as watches another sheep being killed.

We can't suffer no more.'' (unknown)

``Even when Ned went out rather vexed because we took it so calm, and said he (Ned)'d end his (Ned) life, we didn't do anything--did we, mother?'' (unknown)

asked May.

``No,'' (Hester/Hester Baskerville)
answered Hester.

``We was past doing or caring then--even for Ned.

Besides, he (Ned)'s offered to make a hole in the water so terrible often, poor dear fellow.

'Twas a case where I felt the Lord would look after His (Lord) own.

Ned may do some useful thing in the world yet.

He (Ned)'s been very brave over this business--brave as a lion.

'Tis nought to me.

I'm old, and shan't be here much longer.

But for him (Ned) and May 'twas a terrible come-along-of-it.'' (unknown)

``Ned's a zany, and ever will be,'' (Humphrey/Humphrey Baskerville/HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE)
declared Humphrey.

``Rupert, here, is different, and never was afraid of work.

Fortune didn't fall to him (Rupert), and yet 'twas his (Rupert) good fortune to have to face bad fortune, if you understand that.

Money, till you have learned the use of it, be a gun in a fool's hand; and success in any shape's the same.

If it comes afore you know the value and power of it, 'tis a curse and a danger.

It makes you look awry at life, and carry yourself too proud, and cometh to harm and bitterness.

I know, none so well.'' (unknown)

They did not answer.

Then May rose and began to collect the tea things.

Humphrey looked round the dismantled room, and his (Humphrey) eyes rested on the naked mantelshelf.

``Where are all the joanies?

'' (he)

-LSB-1-RSB- he (Humphrey) asked.

``You used to have two big china figures up there.'' (unknown)

-LSB-1-RSB- Joanies --ornaments of glass or china.

``Some are packed, and some will go into the sale.

They two you mean are worth money, I'm told,'' (Mrs. Baskerville)

explained Mrs. Baskerville.

Then the visitor said a thing that much astonished her (Baskerville).

''`Twill give you trouble now,'' he (visitor) remarked,

``but `twill save trouble in the end.

Let me see them put back again.'' (he)

Milly looked at May in wonder.

To argue the matter was her (Milly) first thought; but May acted.

``They be only in the next room, with other things to be sold,'' (she)
she (Milly) said.

``You can see them again, uncle, if you mind to.'' (Rupert/Rupert Baskerville)

Rupert spoke while she (Milly) was from the room.

``Why don't you buy 'em, uncle?

They'd look fine at your place.'' (unknown)

``Put 'em back on the shelf,'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)
answered Mr. Baskerville.

``And, what's more, you may, or may not, be glad to know they can stop there.

'Tis a matter of no account at all, and I won't have no talk about it, but you can feel yourself free to stay, Hester, if you'd rather not make a change at your time of life.

You must settle it with Rupert and your darter.

In a word, I've had a tell with the owner of the farm and he (owner)'s agreeable.'' (unknown)

``I know he (owner)'s agreeable,'' (Humphrey/Humphrey Baskerville/HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE)
answered Humphrey's nephew,
``but I'm not agreeable to his (Humphrey) rent.'' (Humphrey nephew)

``If you'd keep your mouth shut till you'd heard me, `twould be better.

I was going to say that Mr. Westcott of Cann Quarries, who foreclosed on the mortgage of this place when your uncle died--Mr. Westcott is agreeable to let me have Cadworthy; and, in a word, Cadworthy's mine.'' (unknown)

May came in at this moment with the old china figures.

She (Cann) entered a profound silence, and returned the puppets to their old places on the mantelpiece.

It seemed that this act carried with it support and confirmation of the startling thing that Hester Baskerville had just heard.

Humphrey spoke again.

``Past candle-teening, and snow offering from the north.

I must be gone.

Fetch up my pony, Rupert, and then you can travel a bit of the way back along with me.'' (nephew)

His (Rupert) nephew was glad to be gone.

A highly emotional spirit began to charge the air.

Hester had spoken to May, and her (their) daughter, grown white and round-eyed, was trying to speak.

``You mean--you mean we can all stop, and Rupert can go on here?'' (she)

she (their) said at last.

``If he (Rupert) thinks it good enough.

He (Rupert)'d bought back a bit of the place a`ready, as he (Rupert) thought, from Ned.

I can go into all that with him (Rupert).

And for you women--well, you're used to the rounds of Cadworthy, and I'm used to your being here.

You've done nought but trust a weak man.

I don't want all the blue-LSB-2-RSB- to be off the plum for you yet.

But I waited till now, because you'll see, looking back, that you'll be none the worse for smarting a few months.

I've smarted all my life, and I'm not very much the worse, I suppose.

So now I'll be gone, and you can unpack when you please.'' (unknown)

-LSB-2-RSB- Blue --bloom.

They could not instantly grasp this great reversal of fortune.

``Be you sure?'' (niece)

asked his (you) niece.

``Oh, uncle, be you sure?'' (unknown)

``Sure and sure, and double sure.

A very good investment, with a man like your brother Rupert to work it for me.

But let him (Rupert) see the rent's paid on the nail.'' (He)

He (Rupert) rose, and Mrs. Baskerville tried to rise also, but her (Baskerville) legs refused to carry her (Baskerville).

``Get my salts,'' (she)
she (Baskerville) said to Milly; then she (Baskerville) spoke to her (Baskerville) brother-in-law.

``I'm a bit dashed at such news,'' (she)
she (Baskerville) began.

``It have made my bones go to a jelly.

'Tis almost too much at my age.

The old can't stand joy like the young; they'm better tuned to face trouble.

But to stop here--to stop here--'tis like coming back after I'd thought I was gone.

I can't believe 'tis true.

My God, I'd said `good-bye' to it all.

The worst was over.'' (unknown)

``No, it wasn't,'' (Humphrey/Humphrey Baskerville/HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE)
answered Humphrey.

``You think 'twas; but I know better.

The worst would have come the day the cart waited, and you got up and drove off.

Now cheer yourself and drink a drop of spirits.

And don't expect Rupert home till late.

I'll take him (Rupert) back with me to supper.'' (He)

He (Rupert) offered his (Rupert) hand, and the woman kissed it.

Whereupon he (Rupert) uttered a sound of irritation, looked wildly at her (woman), and glared at his (Rupert) fingers as though there had been blood upon them instead of tears.

Milly stopped with Mrs. Baskerville; May went to the door with her (Milly) uncle and helped him (uncle) into his (uncle) coat.

``I can't say nothing,'' (she)
she (Milly) whispered.

``It won't bear talking about--only--only-- If you knew how I loved mother--'' (he)
``Be quiet,'' (he)
he (uncle) answered.

``Don't you play the fool too.

I let you fret to get your fat down a bit--that was the main reason, I do believe; and now you'll only get stouter than ever, of course.

Go back to her (mother), and let's have no nonsense; and, mind, when I come over again, that my house is tidy.

I never see such a jakes of a mess as you've got it in.'' (He)

He (uncle) went out and met Rupert at the gate.

``You'd best to come back with me,'' (he)
he (Rupert) said.

``I've told them you'll sup at Hawk House.

`Twill give 'em time to calm down.

It takes nought to fluster a woman.'' (unknown)

''`Nought'!

You call this `nought'!''

Rupert helped Mr. Baskerville on to his (Rupert) pony and walked beside him (Rupert).

It was now nearly dark, and a few flakes of snow already fell.

``Winter have waited for March,'' (Humphrey/Humphrey Baskerville/HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE)
said Humphrey;
``and I waited for March.

You might ask why for I let 'em have all this trouble.

'Twas done for their good.

They'll rate what they've got all the higher now that it had slipped from them; and so will you.'' (Humphrey/Humphrey Baskerville/HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE)

Rupert said nothing.

``Yes,'' (uncle)
repeated his (Rupert) uncle;
``winter waited for the new year, and so did I.

And now 'tis for you to say whether you'll stop at my farm or no.'' (uncle)

``Of course, I'll stop.'' (unknown)

``No silly promises, mind.

This is business.

You needn't be thanking me; and in justice we've got to think of that fool, your elder brother.

But be it as it will, 'tis Hester's home for her (Rupert) time.'' (unknown)

``I'll stop so long as my mother lives.'' (unknown)

``And a bit after, I hope, if you don't want to quarrel with me.

But I shall be dead myself, come to think of it.

What shall I forget next?

So much for that.

We'll go into figures after supper.'' (unknown)

``I know you don't want no thanks nor nothing of that sort,'' (Rupert/Rupert Baskerville)
said Rupert;
``but you know me pretty well, and you know what I feel upon it.

'Tis a masterpiece of goodness in you to do such a thing.'' (Rupert/Rupert Baskerville)

``Say no more.

I've killed two birds with one stone, as my crafty manner is.

That's all.

'Tis a very good farm, and I've got it cheap; and I've got you cheap--thanks to your mother.

I benefit most--my usual way in business.'' (the footfall)

They passed along, and the snow silenced the footfall of horse and man.

Near Hawk House came the sudden elfin cry of a screech-owl from the darkness of the woods.

``Hush!'' (Humphrey/Humphrey Baskerville/HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE)

said Humphrey, drawing up.

``List to that.

I'm glad we heard it.

A keeper down along boasted to me a week ago that he (keeper)'d shot every owl for a mile round; but there's a brave bird there yet, looking round for his (keeper) supper.'' (unknown)

The owl cried again.

'''Tis a sound I'm very much addicted to,'' explained Mr. Baskerville.

``And likewise I'm glad to hear the noise of they kris-hawks sporting, and the bark of a fox.

They be brave things that know no fear, and go cheerful through a world of enemies.

I respect 'em.'' (unknown)

``You never kill a snake, 'tis said.'' (unknown)

``Not I--I never kill nought.

A snake's to be pitied, not killed.

He (fox)'ll meddle with none as don't meddle with him (fox).

I've watched 'em scores an' scores o' times.

They be only humble worms that go upon their bellies dirt low, but they gaze upward for ever with their wonnerful eyes.

Belike Satan looked thus when they flinged him (Satan) out of heaven.'' (unknown)

``You beat me,'' (Rupert/Rupert Baskerville)
said Rupert.

``You can always find excuses for varmints, never for men.'' (uncle)

His (Rupert) uncle grunted.

``Most men are varmints,'' (he)
he (Rupert) answered.

CHAPTER VI The effect of his (Rupert) financial tribulation on Jack Head was not good.

Whatever might have been of Humphrey Baskerville's theories as to the value worldly misfortune and the tonic property of bad luck upon character, in this man's case the disappearance of his (man) savings deranged his (man) usual common-sense, and indicated that his (man) rational outlook was not based upon sure foundations.

From the trumpery standpoint of his (man) personal welfare, it seemed, after all, that he (man) appraised life; and upon his (man) loss a native acerbity and intolerance increased.

He (man) grew morose, his (man) quality of humour failed him (man), and his (man) mind, deprived of this cathartic and salutary sense, grew stagnant.

At his (man) best Jack was never famed for a delicate choice of time or place when pushing his (man) opinions.

Propriety in this connection he (man) took pleasure in disregarding.

He (man) flouted convention, and loved best to burst his (man) bombshells where they were most certain to horrify and anger.

Following the manner of foolish propagandists, he (man) seldom selected the psychological moment for his (man) onslaughts; nor did he (man) perceive that half the battle in these cases may depend upon nice choice of opportunity.

There came an evening, some time after he (man) had learnt the secret of the Lintern family, when Head, returning to Shaugh Prior, fell in with Cora, who walked upon the same road.

He (Cora) had never liked her (man), and now remembered certain aggressive remarks recently cast at him (Cora) by her (man) brother.

The man was going slower than the woman, and had not meant to take any notice of her (man), but the somewhat supercilious nod she (man) gave him (man) touched his (man) spleen, and he (man) quickened his (man) pace and went along beside her (man).

``Hold on,'' (he)
he (man) said,
``I'll have a tell with you.

'Tisn't often you hear sense, I believe.'' (he)

Cora, for once in a mood wholly seraphic over private affairs, showed patience.

``I'm in a bit of a hurry, but I've always got time to hear sense,'' (she)
she (man) said.

Thus unexpectedly met, Mr. Head found himself with nothing to say.

One familiar complaint at that time running against Cora for the moment he (Cora) forgot.

Therefore he (Cora) fell back upon her (man) brother.

``You might tell Heathman I was a good bit crossed at the way he (Cora) spoke to me two nights agone.

I've as much right to my opinion as him (Cora), and if I say that the late Nathan Baskerville was no better than he (Baskerville) should be, and not the straight, God-fearing man he (man) made us think--well, I'm only saying what everybody knows.'' (unknown)

``That's true,'' (she)
she (man) said.

``Certainly a good many people know that.'' (unknown)

``Exactly so.

Then why for does he (man) jump down my throat as if I was backbiting the dead?

Truth's truth, and it ban't a crime to tell the truth about a man after he (man)'s dead, any more than it be while he (man)'s alive.'' (unknown)

``More it is.

Very often you don't know the truth till a man's dead.

My brother's a bit soft.

All the same, you must speak of people as you find them.

And Heathman had no quarrel with Mr. Baskerville, though most sensible people had seemingly.

He (Baskerville) was a tricky man, and nobody can pretend he (Baskerville) was honest or straight.

He (Baskerville)'s left a deal of misery behind him (Baskerville).'' (Cora/Cora Lintern/Lintern)

The relationship between Cora and Nathan Baskerville suddenly flashed into Jack's memory.

Her (it) remark told him (Cora) another fact: he (Cora) judged from it that she (it) could not be aware of the truth.

It seemed improbable that Cora could utter such a sentiment if she (it) knew that she (it) spoke of her (it) father.
