Then he (Cora) remembered how Heathman certainly knew the truth, and he (Cora) assumed that Cora must also know it.

She (it) was, therefore, revealing her (it) true thoughts, secure in the belief that, since her (it) companion would be ignorant of the relationship between her (it) and the dead, she (it) need pretend to no conventional regard before him (companion).

At another time Jack Head might have approved her (it) frankness, but to-day he (Head) designed to quarrel, and chose to be angered at this unfilial spirit.

Upon that subject his (Head) mouth was sealed, but there returned to him (Head) the recollection of her (it) last achievement.

He (Head) reminded her (it) of it and rated her (it) bitterly.

``Very well for you to talk of dishonest men and crooked dealings,'' (he)
he (Head) retorted.

``You, that don't know the meaning of a straight deed--you that flung over one chap and made him (chap) hang himself, and now have flung over another.

You may flounce and flirt and walk quick, but I'll walk quick too, and I tell you you're no better than a giglet wench--heartless, greedy, good for nought.

You chuck Ned Baskerville after keeping him (Baskerville) on the hooks for years.

And why?

Because he (Baskerville) came down in the world with a run, and you knew that you'd have to work if you took him (Baskerville), and couldn't wear fine feathers and ape the beastly people who drive about in carriages.'' (she)

Her (You) lips tightened and she (You) flashed at him (Baskerville).

``You stupid fool!'' (she)

she (You) said.

``You, of all others, to blame me--you, who were never tired of bawling out what a worthless thing the man was.

You ought to be the first to say he (man)'s properly punished, and the first to say I'm doing the right thing; and so you would, but just because you've lost a few dirty pounds, you go yelping and snarling at everybody.

You're so mighty clever that perhaps you'll tell me why I should marry a pauper, who can't find work far or near, because he (man)'s never learnt how to work.

Why must I keep in with a man like that, and get children for him (man), and kill myself for him (man), and go on the parish at the end?

You're so fond of putting everybody right, perhaps you'll put me right.'' (unknown)

The other was not prepared for this vigorous counter-attack.

``Very well for you to storm,'' (he)
he (man) said;
``but you only do it to hide your own cowardly nature.

You pretended you was in love with him (man), and took his (man) gifts, and made him (man) think you meant to marry him (man), and stick up for him (man) for better, for worse; but far from it.

You was only in love with his (man) cash, and hadn't got no use for the man.

I'm not saying you would do well to marry him (man) for the minute; but to chuck him (man) when he (man)'s down--'' (he)

``You're a one-sided idiot--like most other men,'' (she)
she (You) answered.

'''Tis so easy for you frosty creatures, with no more feeling than a frog, to talk about `love' and `waiting.'

There, you make a sane woman wild!

Waiting, waiting--and what becomes of me while I'm waiting?

I'm a lovely woman, you old fool, don't you understand what that means?

Waiting--waiting--and will time wait?

Look at the crows'-feet coming.

Look at the line betwixt my eyebrows and the lines from my nose, each side, to the corners of my mouth.

Will they wait?

No, curse 'em, they get deeper and deeper, and no rubbing will rub 'em out, and no waiting will make them lighter.

So easy to bleat about `faithfulness' and `patience' if you're ugly as a gorilla and flat as a pancake.

I'm lovely, and I'm a pauper, and I've got nought but loveliness to stand between me and a rotten life and a rotten death in the workhouse.

So there it is.

Don't preach no more of your cant to me, for I won't have it.''

She (I) was furious; the good things in her (I) mind had slipped for the moment away.

While uttering this tirade she (I) stood still, and Mr. Head did the like.

He (Head) saw her (I) argument perfectly well.

He (Head) perceived that she (I) had reason on her (I) side, but her (I) impatience and scorn angered him (Head).

Her (I) main position he (Head) could not shake, but he (Head) turned upon a minor issue and made feeble retort.

His (Head) answer failed dismally in every way.

Of its smallness and weakness she (I) took instant advantage; and, further, it reminded her (I) of the satisfactory event that Mr. Head had for the moment banished from her (I) mind.

``Hard words won't make the case better for you,'' (he)
he (Head) began.

``And to be well-looking outside is nought if you're damned ugly inside; and that's what you be; and that's what everybody very well knows by now.'' (She)

She (I) sneered at him (Head).

``Parson's talk--and poor at that.

If you want to snuffle that sort of trash you'd better ask Mr. Masterman to teach you how.

You, of all folk--so wise and such a book-reader!

What's the good of telling that to me?

'Tis the outside we see, and the outside we judge by; and, for the rest, you'll do well to mind your own business, and not presume to lecture your betters.'' (unknown)

``Very grand!

Very high and mighty, to be sure.

That's how you talked to Humphrey Baskerville, I suppose, and got a flea in your ear for your pains.

And I'll give you another.

'Tis the inside that matters, and not the out, though your empty mind thinks different.

And mark this: you'll go begging now till you're an old woman; and `twon't be long before you'll have your age dashed in your face by every female you anger.

Yes, you'll go begging now--none will have you--none will take you with your record behind you.

An old maid you'll be, and an old maid you'll deserve to be.

You just chew the end of that.'' (unknown)

``What a beast you are!'' (she)

she (maid) retorted.

``What a low-minded, cowardly creature to strike a woman so.

But you spoke too soon as usual.

The likes of you to dare to say that!

You, that don't know so much about women as you do about rabbits!'' (unknown)

``I know enough about men, anyhow, and I know no man will ever look at you again.'' (unknown)

``Liar!

A man asked me to marry him (man) months ago!

But little did I think you'd be the first to know it when we decided that it should be known.

He (man) asked, and he (man) was a man worth calling one, and I took him (man), so you may just swallow your own lies again and choke yourself with 'em.

You're terrible fond of saying everybody's a fool--well, `twill take you all your time to find a bigger one than yourself after to-day.

And don't you never speak to me again, because I won't have it.

Like your cheek--a common labouring man!--ever to have spoke to me at all.

And if you do again, I'll tell Mr. Timothy Waite to put his (Waite) whip round your shoulders, so now then!'' (unknown)

``Him (Waite)!'' (unknown)

``Yes, `him (Waite)'; and now you can go further off, and keep further off in future.'' (She)

She (me) hastened forward to carry her (me) news to other ears, and Jack Head stood still until she (me) was out of sight.

He (Head) felt exceedingly angry, but his (Head) anger swiftly diminished, and he (Head) even found it possible to laugh at himself before he (Head) reached Shaugh Prior.

He (Head) knew right well that he (Head) must look a fool, but the knowledge did not increase his (Head) liking for Cora Lintern.

He (Head) reflected on what he (Head) had heard, and saw her (me) making fun of him (Head) in many quarters.

He (Head) even debated a revenge, but no way offered.

Once he (Head) speculated as to what her (me) betrothed would say if he (Head) knew the truth of Cora's paternity; but, to do him (Head) justice, not the faintest thought of revealing the secret tempted Jack.

``Leave it, and she (me)'ll most likely wreck herself with him (Jack),'' (he)
he (Jack) thought.

``Waite's a sharp chap, and not easily hoodwinked.

So like as not, when he (Jack)'s seen a bit of her (me) mean soul he (Jack)'ll think twice while there's time.'' (Mr. Head)

Mr. Head began to reflect again upon his (Head) own affairs, and, finding himself at the vicarage gate, went in and asked for Dennis Masterman.

The rumour persisted, and even grew, that Dennis was paying back certain losses incurred at Nathan Baskerville's death among the poorest of the community.

The fact had wounded Mr. Head's sense of justice, and he (Head) was determined to throw some light on Masterman's foggy philanthropy.

The vicar happened to be in, and soon Mr. Head appeared before him (Head).

Their interview lasted exactly five minutes, and Jack was in the street again.

He (Jack) explained his (Jack) theory at some length, and gave it as his (Jack) opinion that to pick and choose the cases was not defensible.

He (Jack) then explained his (Jack) own loss, and invited Mr. Masterman to say whether a more deserving and unfortunate man might be found within the quarters of the parish.

The clergyman listened patiently and answered with brevity.

``I hear some of the people are being helped, but personally the donor is not known to me.

I have nothing to do with it.

He (donor), or she (Jack)--probably a lady, for they do that sort of thing oftenest--is not responsible to anybody; but, as far as I have heard, a very good choice has been made among the worst sufferers.

As to your case, Jack, it isn't such a very hard one.

You are strong and hale still, and you've got nobody to think of but yourself.

We know, at any rate, that Mr. Nathan Baskerville did a lot of good with other people's money.

Isn't that what you Socialists are all wanting to do?

But I dare say this misfortune has modified your views a little here and there.

I've never yet met a man with fifty pounds in the bank who was what I call a Socialist.

Good-evening to you, Jack.'' (Alice/Alice Masterman)

CHAPTER VII Alice Masterman, the vicar's sister, came in to speak with Dennis after Jack Head had gone.

He (Head) was composing a sermon, but set it aside at once, for the tone of her (Masterman) voice declared that she (Masterman) could brook no denial.

``It's Voysey,'' (she)
she (Masterman) said.

``I'm sorry to trouble you about him (Voysey) again, but he (Voysey)'s got bronchitis.'' (unknown)

``Well, send him (Voysey) some soup or something.

Has that last dozen of parish port all gone yet?'' (unknown)

``I was thinking of another side to it,'' (she)
she (Masterman) confessed.

``Don't you think this might be an excellent opportunity to get rid of him (Voysey)?'' (unknown)

``Isn't that rather hitting a man when he (man)'s down?'' (unknown)

``Well, it's perfectly certain you'll never hit him (man) when he (man)'s up again.

If you only realised how the man robs us--indirectly, I mean.

He (man) doesn't actually steal, I suppose, but look at the seed and the thousand and one things he (man)'s always wanting in the garden, and nothing to show but weeds.'' (unknown)

``You must be fair, Alice.

There are miles of large, fat cabbages out there.'' (unknown)

``Cabbages, yes; and when I almost go down on my knees for one, he (man) says they're not ready and mustn't be touched.

He (man) caught the cook getting a sprig of parsley yesterday, and was most insolent.

She (Alice) says that if he (man) opens his (man) mouth to her (Alice) again she (Alice)'ll give warning; and she (Alice) means it.

And even you know that cooks are a thousand times harder to get than gardeners.'' (Dennis/Masterman/Dennis Masterman)

Dennis sighed and looked at his (Dennis) manuscript.

``Funny you should say these things--I'm preaching about the fruits of the earth next Sunday.'' (unknown)

``The man's maddening--always ready with an excuse.

The garden must be swarming with every blight and horror that was ever known, according to him (man).

And somehow I always feel he (man)'s being impertinent all the time he (man)'s speaking to me, though there's nothing you can catch hold of.

Now it's mice, and now it's birds, and now it's canker in the air, or some nonsense; and now it's the east wind, and now it's the west wind--I'm sick of it; and if you ask for an onion he (man) reminds you, with quite an injured air, that he (man) took three into the house last week.

There's a wretched cauliflower we had ages ago, and he (man)'s always talking about it still, as if it had been a pineapple at least.'' (unknown)

``I know he (man)'s tiresome.

I tell you what--wait till he (man)'s back, and then I'll give him (man) a serious talking to.'' (unknown)

``Only two days ago I met him (man) lumbering up with that ridiculous basket he (man) always will carry--a huge thing, large enough to hold a sack of potatoes.

And in the bottom were three ridiculous little lettuces from the frame, about as long as your thumb.

I remonstrated, and, of course, he (man) was ready.

'I know to a leaf what his (man) reverence eats,' he (man) said; `and if that woman in the kitchen, miscalled a cook, don't serve 'em up proper, that's not my fault.'

He (cook) didn't seem to think I ever ate anything out of the garden.'' (unknown)

``Old scoundrel!

I'll talk to him (scoundrel) severely.

I've had a rod in pickle ever since last year.'' (Dennis/Masterman/Dennis Masterman)

Dennis laughed suddenly, but his (Dennis) sister was in no laughing mood.

``I really can't see the funny side,'' (she)
she (sister) declared.

``Of course not.

There is none.

He (Dennis)'s a fraud; but I remembered what Travers said last year--you recollect?

The thrips and bug and all sorts of things got into the vines, and we asked Travers what was the matter, and he (Travers) explained what a shameful muddle Voysey had made.

Then, when Joe had gone chattering off, saying the grapes were worth five shillings a pound in open market, and that they'd only lost their bloom because we kept fingering them, Travers said he (Travers) looked as if he (Travers) was infested with thrips and mealy bug himself.

I shall always laugh when I think of that--it was so jolly true.'' (unknown)

``I hate a man who never owns that he (man) is wrong; and I do wish you'd get rid of him (man).

It's only fair to me.

I have but few pleasures, and the garden is one of them.

He (man) tramples and tears, and if you venture to ask him (man) to tidy--well, you know what happens.

The next morning the garden looks as though there had been a plague of locusts in it--everything has gone.'' (unknown)

``He (man) ought to retire; but he (man)'s saved nothing worth mentioning, poor old fool!'' (unknown)

``That's his (man) affair.'' (unknown)

``It ought to be; but you know well enough that improvidence all round is my affair.

We are faced with it everywhere.

Head has just been in here.

There's a rumour about the poor people that the innkeeper swindled.

He (innkeeper) took their savings, and there's nobody to pay them back now he (innkeeper)'s gone.

But it seems that here and there those hit hardest--mostly women--have had their money again.

Not your work, I hope, Alice?

But I know what you do with your cash.

Voysey was talking about it a little time ago, and I blamed him (Voysey) for not having saved some money himself by this time.

He (Voysey) said, `Better spend what you earn on yourself than give it to somebody else to save for you.'

The misfortunes of the people seemed to have pleased him (Voysey) a good deal.

`We'm mostly in the same box now,' he (Voysey) said; `but I had the rare sense to spend my brass myself.

I've had the value of it in beer and tobacco, if no other way.''' (unknown)

``Detestable old man!

And Gollop's no better.

Anybody but you would have got rid of them both years and years ago.'' (unknown)

``They must retire soon--they simply must.

They're the two eldest men in the parish.'' (unknown)

``And, of course, you'll pension them, or some such nonsense.'' (unknown)

``Indeed, I shall do no such thing.

Perhaps this is the end of Voysey.

He (man) may see the sense of retiring now.'' (unknown)

``Not he (man).

He (man)'ll be ill for six weeks, and lie very snug and comfortable drawing his (man) money at home; then, when the weather gets to suit him (man), he (man)'ll crawl out again.

And everything that goes wrong all through next year will be owing to his (man) having been laid by.'' (unknown)

``I'll talk to him (man),'' (brother)
repeated her (man) brother.

``I'll talk to him (man) and Gollop together.

Gollop has pretty well exhausted my patience, I assure you.'' (Miss Masterman/Masterman)

Miss Masterman left him (man) with little hope, and he (man) resumed his (man) sermon on the fruits of the earth.

But next Sunday the unexpected happened, and Thomas Gollop, even in the clergyman's opinion, exceeded the bounds of decency by a scandalous omission.

It happened thus.

The sexton, going his (sexton) rounds before morning service, was confronted with an unfamiliar object in the churchyard.

A tombstone had sprung up above the dust of Nathan Baskerville.

He (Baskerville) rubbed his (Baskerville) eyes with astonishment, because the time for a memorial was not yet, and Thomas must first have heard of it and made ready before its erection.

Here, however, stood what appeared to be a square slate, similar in design to those about it; but investigation proved that an imitation stone had been set up, and upon the boards, painted to resemble slate, was inscribed a ribald obituary notice of the dead.

It scoffed at his (Thomas) pretensions, stated the worst that could be said against him (Thomas), and concluded with a scurrility in verse that consigned him (Thomas) to the devil.

Now, by virtue of his (devil) office, apart from the fact of being a responsible man enlisted on the side of all that was seemly and decorous, Mr. Gollop should have removed this offence as quickly as possible before any eye could mark it.

Thus he (Gollop) would have disappointed those of the baser sort who had placed it there by night, and arrested an outrage before any harm was done by it.

But, instead, he (Gollop) studied the inscription with the liveliest interest, and found himself much in sympathy therewith.

Here was the world's frank opinion on Nathan Baskerville.

The innkeeper deserved such a censure, and Thomas saw no particular reason why he (Thomas) should interfere.

He (Thomas) was alone, and none had observed him (Thomas).

Therefore he (Thomas) shuffled off and, rather than fetch his (Thomas) spade and barrow to dig up this calumny and remove it, left the board for others to discover.

This they did before the bells began to ring, and when Dennis Masterman entered the churchyard, on his (Masterman) way to the vestry, he (Masterman) was arrested by the sight of a considerable crowd collected about the Baskerville graves.

The people were trampling over the mounds, and standing up on the monuments to get a better view.

On the outskirt of the gathering was Ben North in a state of great excitement; but single-handed the policeman found himself unable to cope with the crowd.

A violent quarrel was proceeding at the centre of this human ring, and Masterman heard Gollop's voice and that of Heathman Lintern.

Dennis ordered some yelling choir-boys down off a flat tomb, then pushed his (Dennis) way through his (Dennis) congregation.

Parties had been divided as to the propriety of the new monument, and the scene rather resembled that in the past, when Nathan Baskerville was buried.

As the vicar arrived, Heathman Lintern, who had lost his (Baskerville) self-control, was just knocking Mr. Gollop backwards into the arms of his (Gollop) sister.

The man and woman fell together, and, with cries and hisses, others turned on Heathman.

Then a force rallied to the rescue.

Sunday hats were hurled off and trampled into the grass; Sunday coats were torn; Sunday collars were fouled.

Not until half a dozen men, still fighting, had been thrust out of the churchyard, was Dennis able to learn the truth.

Then he (Dennis) examined the cause of the riot and listened to Lintern.

The young man was bloody and breathless, but he (man) gasped out his (man) tale.

A dozen people were already inspecting the new gravestone when Heathman passed the church on his (man) way to chapel with his (man) mother and sisters.

He (man) left them to see the cause of interest, and, discovering it, ordered Gollop instantly to remove it.

This the sexton declined to do on the ground that it was Sunday.

Thereupon, fetching tools, Heathman himself prepared to dig up the monument.

But he (sexton) was prevented.

Many of the people approved of the joke and decreed that the board must stand.

They arrested Heathman in his (sexton) efforts to remove it.

Then others took his (sexton) side and endeavoured to drag down the monument.

Having heard both Lintern and Gollop, the clergyman read the mock inscription.

``D'you mean to say that you refuse to remove this outrageous thing?'' (he)

he (clergyman) asked the sexton; but Thomas was in no mood for further reprimand.

He (Thomas) had suffered a good deal in credit and temper.

Now he (Thomas) mopped a bleeding nose and was insolent.

``Yes, I do; and I won't break the Fourth Commandment for you or fifty parsons.

Who the mischief be you to tell me to labour on the Lord's Day, I should like to know?

You'll bid me covet my neighbour's ass and take my neighbour's wife next, perhaps?

And, when all's said, this writing be true and a lesson to the parish.

Let 'em have the truth for once, though it do turn their tender stomachs.'' (unknown)

``Get out of the churchyard, you old blackguard!'' (Heathman/Heathman Lintern)

cried Heathman.

``You're a disgrace to any persuasion, and you did ought to be hounded out of a decent village.'' (unknown)

``Leave Gollop to me, Lintern.

Now lend a hand here, a few of you; get this infamous thing away and destroyed before anybody else sees it.

And the rest go into church at once.

Put on your surplices quick, you boys; and you, Jenkins, tell Miss Masterman to play another voluntary.'' (Dennis/Masterman/Dennis Masterman)

Dennis issued his (Dennis) orders and then helped to dig up this outrage among the tombs.

Thomas Gollop and his (Gollop) sister departed together.

Ben North, Lintern, and another assisted Mr. Masterman.

Then came Humphrey Baskerville upon his (Baskerville) way to church, and, despite the entreaty of the young clergyman that he (clergyman) would not read the thing set up over Nathan's grave, insisted on doing so.

``I hear in the street there's been a row about a tombstone to my brother.

Who put it there?

'Tis too soon by half.

I shall lift a stone to the man when the proper time comes,'' (he)

he (man) said.

``It isn't a stone, it's an unseemly insult--an outrage.

Not the work of Shaugh men, I hope.

I shall investigate the thing to the bottom,'' (Dennis/Masterman/Dennis Masterman)

answered Dennis.

``Let me see.

Stay your hand, Lintern.'' (The man)

The old man put on his (Lintern) glasses deliberately, and read the evil words.

``Tear it down,'' (he)
he (Lintern) said.

``That ban't all the truth about the man, and half the truth is none.

Quick, away with it!

There's my sister-in-law from Cadworthy coming into the gate.'' (Dennis/Masterman/Dennis Masterman)

The burlesque tombstone was hurried away, and Masterman went into the vestry.

Others entered church, and Heathman at last found himself alone.

The bells stopped, the organ ceased to grunt, and the service proceeded; but young Lintern was only concerned with his (Lintern) own labours.

He (Lintern) ransacked Mr. Gollop's tool-shed adjoining the vestry.

It was locked, but he (Lintern) broke it open, and, finding a hatchet there, proceeded to make splinters of the offending inscription.

He (Lintern) chopped and chopped until his (Lintern) usual equitable humour returned to him (Lintern).

Then, the work completed, he (Lintern) returned to his (Lintern) father's grave and repaired the broken mound.

He (Lintern) was engaged upon this task to the murmur of the psalms, when Jack Head approached and bade him (Head) `good-morning.'

``A pretty up-store, I hear.

And you in the midst of it--eh?'' (unknown)

``I was, and I'd do the same for any chap that did such a beastly thing.

If I thought you had any hand in it, Jack--'' (the son)

The other remembered that the son of the dead was speaking to him (Jack).

``Not me,'' (he)
he (Jack) answered.

``I have a pretty big grudge against Nathan Baskerville that was, and I won't deny it; but this here--insults on his (Baskerville) tomb--'tis no better than to kick the dead.

Besides, what's the use?

It won't right the wrong, or put my money back in my pocket.

How did it go--the words, I mean?'' (unknown)

``I've forgot 'em,'' (Heathman/Heathman Lintern)
answered Heathman.

``Least said, soonest mended, and if it don't do one thing, and that is get Gollop the sack, I shall be a bit astonished.'' (He)

He (Baskerville) laughed.

``You should `a' seen the old monkey just now!

He (monkey) was the first to mark this job, and he (monkey) let it stand for all to see, and was glad they should see it--shame to him (monkey).'' (unknown)

``Wrote it himself so like as not.'' (unknown)

``Hadn't the wit to.

But he (monkey) left it, and he (monkey) was well pleased at it.

And then, when I ordered him (monkey) as sexton to take it down, he (monkey) wouldn't, and so I lost my head and gave him (monkey) a tap on the ribs, and over he (monkey) went into his (monkey) sister's arms, as was standing screeching like a poll-parrot just behind him (monkey).

Both dropped; then Tom Sparkes hit me in the mouth; and so we went on very lively till Mr. Masterman came.'' (unknown)

``Wouldn't have missed it for money,'' (Jack/Jack Head)
said Jack.

``But just my luck to be t`other side the village at such a moment.'' (He)

He (Jack) sat down on a sepulchre and filled his (Jack) pipe.

He (Jack) knew well why Heathman had thrown himself so fiercely into this quarrel, and he (Jack) admired him (Jack) for it.

The sight of the young man reminded him (Jack) of his (Jack) sister.

``So your Cora is trying a third, she (sister) tells me?'' (unknown)

``Yes; 'tis Tim Waite this time,'' (Cora/Cora Lintern/Lintern)
answered Cora's brother.

``I shouldn't envy him (Cora) much--or any man who had to live his (man) life along with her (sister).'' (unknown)

``You're right there: no heart--that's what was left out when she (sister) was a-making.

She (sister) told me the news a bit ago, just when I was giving her (sister) a rap over the knuckles on account of that other fool, Ned Baskerville.

And she (sister) got the best of the argument--I'll allow that.

In fact, you might say she (sister) scored off me proper, for I told her (sister) that no decent chap would ever look at her (sister) again, and what does she (sister) answer?

Why, that Tim Waite's took her (sister).'' (unknown)

``Yes, 'tis so.

He (Waite) and me was talking a bit ago.

He (Waite)'ll rule her (sister).'' (unknown)

``But I got it back on Cora,'' (Mr. Head)
continued Mr. Head.

``I'm not the sort to be beat in argument and forget it.

Not I!

I'll wait, if need be, for a month of Sundays afore I make my answer; but I always laugh last, and none don't ever get the whip-hand of me for long.

And last week I caught up with her (sister) again, as we was travelling by the same road, and I gave her (sister) hell's delights, and told her (sister) the ugly truth about herself till she (sister) could have strangled me if she (sister)'d been strong enough.'' (unknown)

``I know you did.

She (sister) came home in a pretty tantara--blue with temper; and she (sister)'s going to tell Waite about it.

But don't you sing small, Jack; don't you let Timothy bully you.'' (unknown)

``No man bullies me,'' (unknown)
said Head;
``least and last of all a young man.

Waite have too much sense, I should hope, to fall foul of me.

But if it comes to that, I can give him (Waite) better than he (Waite)'ll give me--a long sight better, too.'' (unknown)

``The Cadworthy people have been a bit off us since Cora dropped Ned,'' (Heathman/Heathman Lintern)
declared Heathman.

``No wonder, neither, but my mother's cruel galled about it.

'Twasn't her (mother) fault, however.

Still, that's how it lies.'' (Mr. Head)

Mr. Head was examining this situation when the people began to come out of church.

He (Head) rose, therefore, and went his (Head) way, while Heathman also departed.

Many returned to the outraged grave, but all was restored to order, and nothing remained to see.

CHAPTER VIII Jack Head presently carried his (Jack) notorious grievances to Humphrey Baskerville, and waited upon him (Jack) one evening in summer time.

They had not met for many weeks, and Jack, though he (Jack) found little leisure to mark the ways of other people at this season, could not fail to note a certain unwonted cheerfulness in the master of Hawk House.

Humphrey's saturnine spirit was at rest for the moment.

To-night he (Humphrey) talked upon a personal topic, and found evident pleasure in a circumstance which, from the standpoint of his (Humphrey) visitor, appeared exceedingly trivial.

The usual relations of these men seemed changed, and Mr. Baskerville showed the more reasonable and contented mind, while Jack displayed an active distrust of everything and everybody.

``I wanted a bit of a tell with you,'' (he)
he (Jack) began,
``and thought I might come over.'' (he)

``Come in and welcome,'' (Humphrey/Humphrey Baskerville/HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE)
answered Humphrey.

``I hope I see you pretty middling?'' (unknown)

``Yes, well enough for that matter.

And you?'' (unknown)

``Never better.

'Tis wonnerful how the rheumatics be holding off--along of lemons.

You might stare, but 'tis a flame-new remedy of doctor's.

Lemon juice--pints of it.'' (unknown)

``Should have reckoned there was enough lemon in your nature without adding to it.'' (unknown)

``Enough and to spare.

Yet you needn't rub that home to-day.

I've heard a thing that's very much pleased me, I may tell you.

Last news such a cranky and uncomfortable man as me might have expected.'' (unknown)

``Wish I could hear summat that would please me, I'm sure,'' (Jack/Jack Head)
said Jack.

``But all that ever I hear of nowadays is other people's good luck.

And there's nothing more damned uninteresting after a bit.

Not that I grudge t`others--'' (unknown)

``Of course you don't--not with your high opinions.

You've said to me a score of times that there's no justice in the world, therefore 'tis no use your fretting about not getting any.

We must take things as we find them.'' (unknown)

``And what's your luck, then?

More money rolling in, I suppose?'' (unknown)

``My luck--so to call it--mightn't look over large to another.

'Tis that my nephew Rupert and his (Rupert) wife want for me to be godfather to their babe.

The child will be called after me, and I'm to stand godfather; and I'll confess to you, in secret, that I'm a good deal pleased about it.'' (Jack/Jack Head)

Jack sniffed and spat into the fire.

He (Jack) took a pipe out of his (Jack) pocket, stuffed it, and lighted it before he (Jack) answered.

``I was going to say that little things please little minds, but I won't,'' (he)
he (Jack) began.

``If you can find pleasure in such a trifle--well, you'm fortunate.

I should have reckoned with all the misery there is in the world around you, that there'd be more pain than pleasure in--'' (He)

He (Jack) broke off.

'''Tis the thought,'' explained Mr. Baskerville.

``It shows that they young people feel towards me a proper and respectful feeling.

It shows that they'd trust me to be a godparent to this newborn child.

I know very well that folk are often asked just for the sake of a silver spoon, or a christening mug; but my nephew Rupert and his (Rupert) wife Milly be very different to that.

There's no truckling in them.

They've thought this out, and reckoned I'm the right man--old as I am.

And naturally I feel well satisfied about it.'' (unknown)

``Let that be, then.

If you're pleased, their object be gained, for naturally they want to please you.

Why not?

You must die sooner or later, though nobody's better content than me to hear you'm doing so clever just at present.

But go you must, and then there's your mighty fortune got to be left to something or somebody.'' (unknown)

``Mighty's not the word, Jack.'' (unknown)

``Ban't it?

Then a little bird tells the people a lot of lies.

And, talking of cash, I'm here over that matter myself.'' (Humphrey/Humphrey Baskerville/HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE)

But Humphrey was not interested in cash for the moment.

``They sent me a very well-written letter on the subject,'' (he)
he (Humphrey) continued.

``On the subject of the child.

'Twas more respectful to me and less familiar to put it in writing--so they thought.

And I've written back a long letter, and you shall hear just how I wrote, if you please.

There's things in my letter I'd rather like you to hear.'' (Mr. Head)

Mr. Head showed impatience, and the other was swift to mark it.

``Another time, if 'tis all the same to you,'' (Jack/Jack Head)
Jack replied.

``Let me get off what's on my chest first.

Then I'll be a better listener.

I ha'n't got much use for second-hand wisdom for the moment.'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

Mr. Baskerville had already picked up his (Baskerville) letter; but now he (Baskerville) flung the pages back upon his (Baskerville) desk and his (Baskerville) manner changed.

``Speak,'' (he)
he (Baskerville) said.

``You learn me a lesson.

Ban't often I'm wrapped up in my own affairs, I believe.

I beg your pardon, Head.'' (unknown)

``No need to do that.

Only, seen from my point, with all my misfortunes and troubles on my mind, this here twopenny-halfpenny business of naming a newborn babby looks very small.

You can't picture it, no doubt--you with your riches and your money breeding like rabbits.

But for a man such as me, to see the sweat of his (man) brow swept away all at a stroke--nought else looks of much account.'' (unknown)

``Haven't you got over that yet?'' (unknown)

``No, I haven't; and more wouldn't you, if somebody had hit you so hard.'' (unknown)

``Say your say then, if `twill do you any sort of good.'' (unknown)

``What I want to know is this.

Why for do Lawyer Popham help one man and not help t`other?

Why do this person--I dare say you know who 'tis--do what he (Popham)'s doing and pick and choose according to his (Popham) fancy?

It isn't Masterman or I'd have gived him (Masterman) a bit of my mind about it.

And if I could find out who it was, I would do so.'' (unknown)

``The grievance is that you don't get your bit back?

Are you the only one?'' (unknown)

``No, I'm not.

There's a lot more going begging the same way.

And if you know the man, you can tell him (man) from me that he (man) may think he (man)'m doing a very fine thing, but in my opinion he (man) isn't.'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

Mr. Baskerville had relapsed into his (Baskerville) old mood.

``So much for your sense, then--you that pride yourself such a lot on being the only sane man among us.

Have you ever looked into the figures?'' (unknown)

``I've looked into my own figures, and they be all I care about.'' (unknown)

``Exactly so!

But them that want to right this wrong have looked into all the figures; and so they know a great deal more about 'em than you do.

You're not everybody.

You're a hale, hearty creature getting good wages.

More than one man that put away money with my brother is dead long ago, and there are women and children to be thought upon; and a bedridden widow, and two twin boys, both weak in the head; and a few other such items.

Why for shouldn't there be picking and choosing?

If you'd been going to lend a hand yourself and do a bit for charity, wouldn't you pick and choose?

Ban't all life picking and choosing?

Women and childer first is the rule in any shipwreck, I believe--afloat or ashore.

And if you was such a born fool as to trust, because others trusted, and follow the rest, like a sheep follows his (fool) neighbour sheep, then I should reckon you deserve to whistle for your money.

If this chap, who was fond of my brother and be set on clearing his (brother) name, will listen to me, you and the likes of you will have to wait a good few years yet for your bit--if you ever get it at all.

You ought to know better--you as would shoulder in afore the weak!

And now you can go.

I don't want to see you no more, till you've got into a larger frame of mind.'' (unknown)

``What a cur-dog you be!'' (unknown)

said Head, rising and scowling fiercely.

``So much for Christian charity and doing to your neighbour as you would have him (I) do to you--so much for all your cant about righteousness.

You wait--that's all!

Your turn will come to smart some day.

And if I find out this precious fool, who's got money to squander, I'll talk a bit of sense to him (fool) too.

He (fool)'s no right to do things by halves, and one man's claim on that scamp, your brother, is just as lawful and proper as another man's; and because a person be poor or not poor don't make any difference in the matter of right and wrong.'' (unknown)

``That's where you're so blind as any other thick-headed beetle,'' (Humphrey/Humphrey Baskerville/HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE)
snarled back Humphrey.

``For my part I've looked into the figures myself, and I quite agree with Nathan's friend.

None has a shadow of reason to question him (Nathan) or to ask for a penny from him (Nathan).

'Tis his (Nathan) bounty, not your right.'' (unknown)

``Very easy to talk like that.

Why don't you put your fingers in your own pocket and lend a hand yourself?

Not you--a sneaking old curmudgeon!

And then want people to think well of you.

Why the devil should they?

Close-fisted mully-grubs that you are!

And hark to this, Miser Baskerville, don't you pretend your nephew wants you to stand gossip for his (nephew) bleating baby to pleasure you.

'Tis because he (nephew)'s got his (nephew) weather-eye lifting on your dross.

Who's like to care for you for yourself?

Not a dog.

Your face be enough to turn milk sour and give the childer fits.'' (unknown)

``Get along with you,'' (Humphrey/Humphrey Baskerville/HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE)
answered Humphrey.

``You--of all men!

I could never have believed this--never.

And all for thirty-five pounds, fifteen and sevenpence!

So much for your wisdom and reason.

Be off and get down on your knees, if they'll bend, and ask God to forgive you.'' (unknown)

Head snorted and swore.

Then he (God) picked up his (God) hat and departed in a towering rage.

Mr. Baskerville's anger lasted a shorter time.

He (Baskerville) walked to the window, threw it open, listened to Head's explosive departure and then, when silence was restored, Humphrey himself went to his (Humphrey) doorstep and looked out upon the fair June night.

Mars and a moon nearly full sailed south together through unclouded skies, and beneath them lay, first, a low horizon, whose contour, smoothed by night's hand into dim darkness, showed neither point nor peak under the stars.

Beneath all, valley-born, there shone silver radiance of mist--dense and luminous in the moonlight.

Apparently quiescent, this vapour in truth drifted with ghostly proper motion before the night wind, and stole from the water-meadows upward toward the high places of the Moor.

Against these shifting passages of fog, laid along the skirts of forest and above the murmuring ways of a hidden river, ascended silhouettes of trees, all black and still against the pearly light behind them.

The vapour spread in wreaths and filaments of moisture intermingled.

Seen afar it was still as standing water; but to one moving beside it, the mist appeared as on a trembling loom where moonlight wove in ebony and silver.

The fabric broke, ravelled, fell asunder, and then built itself up once more.

Again it dislimned and shivered into separate shades that seemed to live.

From staple of streams, from the cold heart of a nightly river were the shadows born; and they writhed and worshipped--poor, heart-stricken spirits of the dew--love-mad for Selene on high.

Only when red Mars descended and the moon went down, did these forlorn phantoms of vapour shrink and shudder and lie closer, for comfort, to the water mother that bore them.

Hither, nigh midnight, in a frame of mind much out of tune with the nocturnal peace, passed Jack Head upon his (Head) homeward way.

His (Head) loss had now become a sort of mental obsession, and he (Head) found it daily wax into a mightier outrage on humanity.

He (Head) would have suffered in silence, but for the aggravation of these events whereby, from time to time, one or another of the wounded found his (Head) ill fortune healed.

Examination might have showed an impartial mind that much method distinguished the process of this alleviation.

Those responsible for it clearly possessed close knowledge of the circumstances; and they used it to minister in turn to the chief sufferers.

The widows and fatherless were first indemnified; then others who least could sustain their losses.

A sane system marked the procedure; but not in the eyes of Mr. Head.

First, he (Head) disputed the right of any philanthropist to select and single out in such a matter, and next, when defeated in argument on that contention, he (Head) fell back upon his (Head) own disaster and endeavoured to show how his (Head) misfortune was among the hardest and most ill-deserved.

That man after man should be compensated and himself ignored, roused Jack to a pitch of the liveliest indignation.

He (Jack) became a nuisance, and people fled from him (Jack) and his (Jack) inevitable topic of speech.

And now he (Jack) had heard Humphrey Baskerville upon the subject, and found him (Jack) as indifferent as the rest of the world.

The old man's argument still revolved in Jack's head and, too late, came answers to it.

He (Jack) moved along in the very extremity of rage, and Humphrey might have smarted to hear the things that his (Humphrey) former friend thought against him (Humphrey).

Then, as ill chance willed, another came through the night and spoke to Head.

Timothy Waite went happily upon his (Waite) homeward way and found himself in a mood as sweet as Jack's was the reverse.

For Timothy was love-making, and his (Jack) lady's ripe experience enabled her (lady) to give him (Jack) many pleasant hours of this amusement.

Neither was sentimental, but Cora, accustomed to the ways and fancies of the courting male, affected a certain amount of femininity, and Timothy appreciated this, and told himself that his (Timothy) future wife possessed a woman's charms combined with a man's practical sense.

He (Timothy) was immensely elated at the thing he (Timothy) had done, and he (Timothy) felt gratified to find that Miss Lintern made a most favourable impression amid his (Timothy) friends and relations.

Now, moved thereto by his (Timothy) own cheerful heart, he (Timothy) gave Jack Head `good night' in a friendly tone of voice and added,

``A beautiful evening, sure enough.'' (Jack/Jack Head)

The way was overshadowed by trees and neither man recognised the other until Waite spoke.

Then Mr. Head, feeling himself within the atmosphere of a happy being, grunted a churlish answer and made himself known.

Thereon Timothy's manner changed and he (Timothy) regretted his (Timothy) amenity.

``Is that Head?'' (he)

he (Timothy) asked in an altered tone.

``You know my voice, I suppose.'' (unknown)

``Yes, I do.

I want to speak to you.

And I have meant to for some time past.

But the chance didn't offer, as you don't go to church, or any respectable place; and I don't frequent publics.'' (unknown)

The other bristled instantly.

``What the hell's the matter with you?'' (he)

he (Timothy) shouted.

``Nothing's the matter with me.

But there's a lot the matter with you by all accounts, and since you can't keep a civil tongue in your head, it's time your betters took you in hand a bit.'' (Jack/Jack Head)

Jack stared speechless at this blunt attack.

The moon whitened his (Jack) face, his (Jack) lean jaw dropped and his (Jack) teeth glimmered.

``Well, I'm damned!

`My betters'--eh?'' (unknown)

``Yes; no need for any silly pretence with me.

You know what I think of your blackguard opinions and all that rot about equality and the rest.

I'm not here to preach to you; but I am here to tell you to behave yourself where ladies are concerned.

Miss Lintern has told me what you said to her (Lintern), and she (Lintern) complained sharply about it.

You may think it was very clever; but I'd have you to know it was very impertinent, coming from you to her (Lintern).

Why, if I'd been by, I'd have horsewhipped you.

And if it happens again, I will.

You're a lot too familiar with people, and seem to think you've a right to talk to everybody and anybody in a free and easy way--from parson downwards.

But let me tell you, you forget yourself.

I'd not have said these things if you'd been rude to any less person than the young lady I'm going to marry.

But that I won't stand, and I order you not to speak to Miss Lintern again.

Learn manners--that's what you've got to do.'' (Timothy/Waite/Mr. Waite)

Having uttered this admonition, Mr. Waite was proceeding but Jack stopped him (Jack).

``I listened to you very patient,'' (he)
he (Jack) said.

``Now you've got to listen to me, and listen you shall.

Why, God stiffen it, you bumbling fool!

who d'you think you are, and who d'you think any man is?

You be china to my cloam, I suppose?

And who was your grandfather?

Come now, speak up; who was he (grandfather)?'' (unknown)

``I'm not going to argue--I've told you what I wish you to do.

It doesn't matter who my grandfather was.

You know who I am, and that's enough.'' (unknown)

``It is enough,'' (Jack/Jack Head)
said Jack;
``it's enough to make a toad laugh; but I don't laugh--no laughing matter to me to be told by a vain, puffed-up booby, like you, that I'm not good enough to have speech with people.

And that tousled bitch--there--and coming on what I've just heard!

If it don't make me sick with human nature and all the breed!'' (Jack/Jack Head)

``Be sick with yourself,'' (Timothy/Waite/Mr. Waite)
answered Timothy.

``I don't want to be too hard on an uneducated and self-sufficient man; but when it comes to insulting women, somebody must intervene.'' (the man)

By way of answer the older man turned, walked swiftly to Waite and struck him (Waite) on the breast.

The blow was a hard one and served its purpose.

Timothy hit back and Head closed.

``You blackguard anarchist,'' (the farmer)
shouted the farmer.

``You will have it, will you?

Then take it!'' (Jack/Jack Head)

Jack found himself no match for a strong and angry man full twenty-five years his (Jack) junior, and he (Jack) reaped a very unpleasant harvest of blows, for the master of Coldstone carried an ash sapling and when he (Jack) had thrown Mr. Head to the ground he (Jack) put his (Jack) foot on him (Jack) and flogged him (Jack) heartily without heeding where his (Jack) strokes might fall.

Head yelled and cursed and tried to reach the other's legs and bring him (Jack) down.

A column of dust rose into the moonlight and Timothy's breath panted steaming upon the air.

Then, with a last cruel cut across the defeated labourer's shoulders, he (labourer) released him (labourer) and went his (labourer) way.

But Head was soon up again and, with a bleeding face, a torn hand and a dusty jacket, he (labourer) followed his (labourer) enemy.

Rage is shrewd of inspiration.

He (labourer) remembered the one blow that he (labourer) could deal this man; and he (labourer) struck it, hoping that it might sink far deeper than the smarting surface-wounds that now made his (labourer) own body ache.

``Devil--coward--garotter!'' (he)

he (Devil) screamed out.

``You that hit old men in the dark--listen to me!'' (Timothy/Waite/Mr. Waite)

Waite stopped.

``If you want any more, you can have it,'' (he)
he (Waite) answered.

``But don't go telling lies around the country and saying I did anything you didn't well deserve.

You struck me first, and if you are mad enough to strike your betters, then you'll find they will strike back.'' (unknown)

``I'll strike--yes, I'll strike--don't fear that.

I'll strike--a harder blow than your evil hand knows how.

I'll strike with truth--and that's a weapon goes deeper than your bully's stick.

Hear me, and hear a bit about your young lady--`young lady'!

A woman without a father--a child got--ax her (woman) mother where and how--and then go to blazing hell--you and your nameless female both.

I know--I know--and I'll tell you if you want to know.

She (female)'s Nathan Baskerville's bastard--that's what your `young lady' is!

There's gall for yours.

There's stroke for stroke!

And see which of us smarts longest now!'' (Jack/Jack Head)

Jack took his (Jack) bruises homeward and the other, dazed at such a storm, also went his (Jack) way.

He (Jack) scoffed at such malice and put this evil thing behind him (Jack).

He (Jack) hastened forward, as one hastens from sudden incidence of a foul smell.

But the wounded man had sped a poison more pestilential far than any born of physical cause.

The germ thus despatched grew while Waite slept; and with morning light its dimensions were increased.

Under the moon, he (Waite) had laughed at this furious assault, and scorned it as the vile imagining of a beaten creature; but with daylight he (Waite) laughed no longer.

The barb was fast; other rumours set floating after the innkeeper's death now hurtled like lesser arrows into his (innkeeper) bosom; and Mr. Waite felt that until a drastic operation was performed and these wounds cleansed, his (Waite) peace of mind would not return.

He (Waite) debated between the propriety of speaking to Cora about her (Waite) father, or to Mrs. Lintern on the subject of her (Waite) husband; and he (husband) decided that the latter course would be more proper.

CHAPTER IX Susan Hacker and her (Hacker) master sat together in the kitchen.

He (master) had lighted his (master) pipe; she (Hacker) was clearing away the remains of a somewhat scanty meal, and she (Hacker) was grumbling loudly as she (Hacker) did so.

``Leave it,'' (he)
he (master) cried at length,
``or I won't show you the christening mug for Milly's baby.

It have come from Plymouth, and a rare, fine, glittering thing it is.'' (he)

``I won't leave it,'' (she)
she (Milly) answered.

``You can't see the end of this, but I can.

People know you've got plenty of money, but they don't know the way you're fooling it about, and presently, when you go and get ill, and your bones begin to stick through your skin, 'tis I shall be blamed.'' (unknown)

``Not a bit of it.

They all think I'm a miser, don't they?

Let 'em go on thinking it.

'Tis the way of a miser's bones to stick out through his (miser) skin.

Everybody knows that I live cheap from choice and always have.

I hate the time given to eating and drinking.'' (unknown)

``You've always lived like a labouring man,'' (she)
she (you) admitted.

``But of late, here and there, people be more friendly towards you, because you let your folk bide at Cadworthy; and I'm sick and tired of hearing Hester Baskerville tell me you don't eat enough, and Rupert and Milly too.

Then there's that Gollop woman and a few other females have said things against me about the way I run this house.

And 'tis bad to suffer it, for the Lord knows I've got enough on my mind without their lies.'' (unknown)

``Get 'em off your mind, then,'' (he)
he (Lord) answered.

``You're a changed woman of late, and I'll tell you what's done it.

I only found out myself a bit ago and said nought; but now I will speak.

I've wondered these many weeks what had come over you, and three days since I discovered.

And who was it, d'you think, told me?'' (Susan/Susan Hacker/Hacker)

Her (woman) guilty heart thumped at Susan's ribs.

``Not Jack Head?'' (she)

she (woman) asked.

``Jack?

No.

What does he (Jack) know about you?

Jack's another changed creature.

He (Jack) was pretty good company once, but his (Jack) losses have soured him (Jack).

'Twasn't Jack.

'Twas the reverend Masterman.

You've signed the pledge, I hear.'' (unknown)

``He (Masterman)'d no business to tell,'' (Susan/Susan Hacker/Hacker)
declared Susan.

``Yes, I have signed it.

I'm a wicked woman, and never another drop shall pass my lips.'' (he)

'''Tis that that's made you cranky, all the same,'' he (Masterman) declared.

``You was accustomed to your tipple and you miss it.

However, I'm the last to say you did wrong in signing.

When your organs get used to going without, you'll find yourself better company again.

And don't worry about the table I keep.

I live low from choice, not need.

It suits me to starve a bit.

I'm the better and cheerfuller for it.'' (she)

But then she (I) took up the analysis and explained to him (Masterman) whence his (Masterman) good health and spirits had sprung.

``Ban't that at all.

'Tis what you be doing have got into your blood.

I know--I know.

You've hid it from all of 'em, but you haven't hid it from me.

I don't clean up all the rubbish you make and sift your waste-paper basket for nought.

I itch to let it out!

But God forgive me, I've let out enough in my time.'' (He)

He (God) turned on her (you) angrily; then fearlessly she (you) met his (God) frown and he (God) subsided.

``You're a dangerous, prying woman,'' (he)
he (God) said,
``and you ought to be ashamed of yourself.'' (he)

``I'm all that,'' (she)
she (woman) admitted;
``and shame isn't the word.

I'm ashamed enough, and more than ashamed.'' (she)

``If you let out a breath of my little games, I'll pack you off into the street that very day, Susan.'' (She)

She (Susan) sat down by the fire and took her (Susan) knitting off the peat box where it was usually to be found.

``You needn't fear me,'' (she)
she (Susan) answered.

``I've had my lesson.

If ever I tell again what I should not, you may kick me into the gutter.'' (He)

He (I) mused over the thoughts that she (Susan) had awakened.

``I know a mazing deal more about the weaknesses of my brother Nathan now than ever I did while the man was in life,'' (he)
he (man) began.

``He (man) was always giving--always giving, whether he (man) had it to give or whether he (man) hadn't.

I'm not defending him (man), but I know what it felt like a bit now.

Giving be like drink: it grows on a man the same as liquor does.

Nathan ought to have taken the pledge against giving.

And yet 'tis just another example of how the Bible word never errs.

On the face of it you'd think 'twas better fun to receive than to give.

But that isn't so.

Once break down the natural inclination, shared by the dog with his (Nathan) bone, to stick to what you've got--once make yourself hand over a bit to somebody else--and you'll find a wonderful interest arise out of it.'' (unknown)

``Some might.

Some would break their hearts if they had to fork out like you've been doing of late.'' (unknown)

``They be the real misers.

To them their stuff is more than food and life and the welfare of the nation.

And even them, if we could tear their gold away from them, might thank us after they'd got over the operation, and found themselves better instead of worse without it.'' (unknown)

``All that's too deep for me,'' (she)
she (They) answered.

``The thing that's most difficult to me be this: How do you get any good out of helping these poor folk all underhand and unknown?

Surely if a man or woman does good to others, he (man)'s a right to the only payment the poor can make him (man).

And that's gratitude.

Why won't you out with it and let them thank you?'' (unknown)

``You're wrong,'' (he)
he (man) said.

``I've lived too many years in the world to want that.

I'm a fool here and there, Susan; but I'm not the sort of fool that asks from men and women what's harder to give than any other thing.

To put a fellow-creature under an obligation is to have a faith in human nature that I never have had, and never shall have.

No, I don't want that payment; I'm getting better value for my money than that.'' (unknown)

``So long as you're satisfied--'' (Humphrey/Humphrey Baskerville/HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE)
Silence followed and each pursued a private line of thought.

Humphrey puffed his (Humphrey) pipe; Susan knitted, and her (Susan) wooden needles tapped and rattled a regular tune.

She (Susan) was wondering whether the confession that she (Susan) desired to make might be uttered at this auspicious moment.

Her (Susan) conscience tortured her (Susan); and it was the weight of a great misery on her (Susan) mind, not the fact of giving up liquor, that had of late soured her (Susan) temper.

She (Susan) had nearly strung herself to tell him (Humphrey) of her (Susan) sins when he (Humphrey), from the depths of his (Humphrey) being, spoke again.

But he (Humphrey) was scarcely conscious of a listener.

``To think that a man like me--so dark and distrustful--to think that even such a man--I, that thought my heart was cracked for ever when my son died--I, that said to myself `no more, no more can any earthly thing fret you now.'

And yet all the time, like a withered pippin--brown, dry as dust--there was that within that only wanted something--some heat to the pulp of me--to plump me out again.

To think that the like of me must have some other thing to--to cherish and foster!

To think my shrivelled heart-strings could ever stretch and seek for aught to twine around again!

Who'd believe it of such a man as me?

God A'mighty!

I didn't believe it of myself!'' (unknown)

``But I knowed it,'' (Susan/Susan Hacker/Hacker)
said Susan.

``You always went hunger-starved for people to think a bit kindly of you; you always fretted when decent folk didn't like you.'' (unknown)

``Not that--not that now.

I wanted their good-will; but I've found something a lot higher than that.

To see a poor soul happy is better far than to see 'em grateful.

What does that matter?

To mark their downward eye uplifted again; to note their fear for the future gone; to see hope creep back to 'em; to watch 'em walk cheerful and work cheerful; to know they laugh in their going once more; that they lie themselves down with a sigh of happiness and not of grief--ban't all that grander than their gratitude?

Gratitude must fade sooner or late, for the largest-hearted can't feel it for ever, try as he (creep) may.

Benefits forgot are dust and ashes to the giver--if he (creep) remembers.

But none can take from me the good I've won from others' good; and none can make that memory dim.'' (fairy)

'''Tis a fairy story,'' murmured Mrs. Hacker.

``No,'' (he)
he (creep) said, '''tis a little child's story--the thing they learn at a mother's knees; and because I was a growed-up man, I missed it.

'Tis a riddle a generous child could have guessed in a minute; but it took one stiff-necked fool from his (fool) adult days into old age afore he (fool) did.''

Susan's mind moved to her (Susan) purpose, and she (Susan) knew that never again might fall so timely a moment.

She (Susan) put down her (Susan) knitting, flung a peat on the fire, and spoke.

``You be full of wonderful tales to-night, but now I'll please ask you to listen to me,'' (she)
she (Susan) began.

``And mark this: you can't well be too hard upon me.

I've got a pack of sins to confess, and if, when you've heard 'em, you won't do with me no more, then do without me, and send me through that door.

I deserve it.

There's nought that's bad I don't deserve.'' (He)

He (I) started up.

``What's this?'' (he)

he (I) said.

``You haven't told anybody?'' (unknown)

``No, no, no.

Ban't nothing about your affairs.

In a word, I overheard a secret.

I listened.

I did it out of woman's cursed curiosity.

And, as if that weren't enough, I got drunk as a fly down to `The White Thorn' a while back and let out the truth.

And nought's too bad for me--nought in nature, I'm sure.'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

Mr. Baskerville put down his (Baskerville) pipe and turned to her (woman).

``Don't get excited.

Begin at the beginning.

What did you hear?'' (unknown)

``I heard Mrs. Lintern tell you she (Lintern) was your brother's mistress.

I heard her (Lintern) tell you her (Lintern) children was also his (brother).'' (unknown)

``And you're scourged for knowing it.

Let that be a lesson to you, woman.'' (unknown)

``That's only the beginning.

I ban't scourged for that.

I'm scourged because I've let it out again.'' (unknown)

``I'm shocked at you,'' (he)
he (brother) answered.

``Yes, I'm very much shocked at you; but I'm not at all surprised.

I knew as sure as I knew anything that `twould out.

The Lord chooses His (Lord) own time and His (Lord) own tool.

But that don't make your sin smaller.

You're a wicked woman.'' (unknown)

``I've signed the pledge, however, and not another drop--'' (unknown)
``How many of 'em did you tell?'' (unknown)

``But one.

Of course, I chose the man with the longest tongue.

Jack Head saw me up the hill after closing time and--there 'twas--I had to squeak.

But I made him (Head) swear as solemn as he (Head) knowed how that he (Head) wouldn't.'' (unknown)

``He (Head)'s not what he (Head) was.

We had a proper row a month ago.

I doubt if he (Head)'ll ever speak to me again.

And until he (Head) makes a humble apology for what he (Head) spoke, I won't hear him (Head).'' (unknown)

``He (Head) swore he (Head) wouldn't tell.'' (unknown)

``Be that as it may, it will be known.

It's started and it won't stop.'' (unknown)

They talked for two hours upon the problems involved in these facts.

Then there came a knock at the door and Susan went to answer it.

Mr. Baskerville heard a protracted mumble and finally, after some argument, Mrs. Hacker shut the door and returned into the kitchen with a man.

It was Jack himself.

He (Jack) explained the reason for his (Jack) unduly late visit.

He (Jack) was anxious and troubled.

He (Jack) spoke without his (Jack) usual fluency.

``I didn't come to see you,'' (he)
he (Jack) said.

``I waited till 'twas past your hour for going to bed.

But knowing that Mrs. Hacker was always later, I thought to speak to her (Hacker).

However, nothing would do but I came in, and here I be.'' (unknown)

``I'll have nought to say to you, Head--not a single word--until you make a solemn apology for your infernal impudence last time you stood here afore me,'' (the master)
said the master of Hawk House, surveying his (House) visitor.

``So Susan tells me, and so I will then,'' (Jack/Jack Head)
replied Jack.

``So solemn as ever you like.

You was right and I was wrong, and I did ought to have been kicked from here to Cosdon Beacon and back for what I said to you.

We'm always punished for losing of our tempers.

And I was damn soon punished for losing mine, as you shall hear.

But first I confess that I was wrong and ax you, man to man, to forgive me.'' (unknown)

``Which I will do, and here's my hand on it,'' (unknown)
said the other.

The old men shook hands and Susan wept.

Her (Susan) emotion was audible and Humphrey told her (Susan) to go to bed.

She (Susan) refused.

``I'm in this,'' (she)
she (Susan) said.

'''Tis all my wicked fault from beginning to end, and I'm going to hear it out.

I shall weep my eyes blistered afore morning.''

``Don't begin now, then.

If you're going to stop here, be silent,'' (Humphrey/Humphrey Baskerville/HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE)

said Humphrey.

She (Susan) sniffed, wiped her (Susan) face, and then fetched a black bottle, some drinking water, and two glasses.

``Light your pipe and say what you feel called upon to say,'' (Humphrey/Humphrey Baskerville/HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE)
concluded Humphrey to Mr. Head.

'''Tis like this,'' answered the other.

``Every man wants to boss somebody in this world.

That's a failing of human nature, and if we ain't strong enough to lord it over a fellow-creature, we try to reign over a hoss or even a dog.

Something we have to be master of.

Well, long since I marked that, and then, thanks to my understanding and sense, I comed to see--or I may have read it--that 'twas greater far to lord it over yourself than any other created thing.'' (unknown)

``And harder far,'' (Humphrey/Humphrey Baskerville/HUMPHREY BASKERVILLE)
said Humphrey.

``Without doubt you'm right.

And I set about it, and I had myself in hand something wonderful; and very proud I felt of it, as I had the right to feel.'' (unknown)

``Then the Lord, seeing you puffed up, sent a hard stroke to try whether you was as clever as you thought you was--and He (Lord) found you were not,'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)
suggested Mr. Baskerville.

``I don't care nothing about that nonsense,'' (Jack/Jack Head)
answered Jack;
``and, knowing my opinions, there ain't no call to drag the Lord in.

All I do know is that my hard-earned savings went, and--and--well, I got my monkey up about it, and I got out of hand.

Yes, I got out of hand.

The awful shock of losing my thirty-five pounds odd took me off my balance.

For a bit I couldn't stand square against it, and I did some vain things, and just sank to be a common, everyday fool, like most other people.'' (Jack/Jack Head)

'''Tis a good thing you can see it, for `twill end by righting your opinion of yourself.''

``My opinion of myself was a thought too high.

I admit it,'' (Jack/Jack Head)

answered Jack.

``For the moment I was adrift--but only for the moment.

Now I've come back to my common-sense and my high ideas, I can assure you.

But the mischief is that just while I was dancing with rage and out of hand altogether, I did some mistaken things.

Enough I had on my mind to make me do 'em, too.

But I won't excuse 'em.

I'll say, out and out, that they were very wrong.

You've agreed to overlook one of those things, and you say you'll forgive me for talking a lot of rubbish against you, for which I'm terrible sorry.

So that's all right, and no lasting harm there.

But t`other job's worse.'' (Jack/Jack Head)

Jack stopped for breath, and Susan sighed from the bottom of her (Susan) immense bosom.

Humphrey poured out some gin and water for his (Humphrey) guest.

Then he (Humphrey) helped himself more sparingly.

``Here's to you,'' (Jack/Jack Head)
said Jack.

``To drink under this roof is to be forgiven.

Now I'll go on with my tale, and tell you about the second piece of work.'' (He)

He (Jack) related how he (Jack) had left Hawk House in wrath, how he (Jack) had met with Timothy Waite; how he (Jack) had been reproved and how he (Jack) had hit back both with his (Jack) fists and his (Jack) tongue.

``He (Jack) knocked me down and gave me the truth of music with his (Jack) heavy stick.

I hit him (Jack) first, and I'm not saying anything about what he (Jack) did, though there may be thirty years between us; but anyway he (Jack) roused Cain in me and I told him (Jack), in a word, that the woman he (Jack) was going to marry was the natural child of Nathan Baskerville.

'Twas a double offence against right-doing, because I'd promised Susan here not to let it out, and because to tell Waite, of all men, was a cowardly deed against the girl, seeing he (Waite) meant to marry her (girl).

But I'd quarrelled with her (girl) already, and tell him (Waite) I did; and now I tell you.'' (He)

He (Waite) drank and stared into the fire.

For some time Humphrey did not reply; but at last he (Humphrey) expressed his (Humphrey) opinion.

``It all depends on the sort of chap that Waite may prove to be.

He (Waite)'ll either believe you, or he (Waite) won't.

If he (Waite) don't, no harm's done.

If he (Waite) do, then 'tis his (Waite) character and opinions will decide him (Waite).

For his (Waite) own sake we'll trust he (Waite)'ll throw her (girl) off, for woe betide the man that marries her (girl); but if he (Waite) loves her (girl) better than her (girl) havage, he (Waite)'ll go his (Waite) way and care nothing.

If he (Waite) looks at it different, and thinks the matter can't rest there, he (Waite)'ll go further.

For my part I can't say I care much about it.

All I know is that Priscilla Lintern has rare virtues, though she (Lintern) weren't virtuous, and she (Lintern)'ve lived on no bed of roses, for all the brave way in which she (Lintern) stands up for my late brother.

She (Lintern) won't be sorry the murder's out.

When she (Lintern) told me--or when I told her (Lintern)--I made it plain that in my opinion this ought to be known.

She (Lintern) stood for the children, not herself, and said it never must be known for their sakes.

Well, now we shall see who hears it next.

As for you two, you've got your consciences, and it ban't for me to come between you and them.'' (unknown)

``Well, I've told my story, and admitted my failings like a man,'' (Jack/Jack Head)
said Jack,
``and, having done so, I can do no more.

My conscience is cleared, and I defy it to trouble me again; and I may add that I'll take mighty good care not to give it the chance.

So there you are.

And come what may, I can stand to that.'' (Jack/Jack Head)

``How if they deny it and have you up for libel?'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

asked Mr. Baskerville; but Jack flouted the idea.

``Not them,'' (he)
he (Jack) said.

``Have no fear on that score.

I've got this woman for witness, and I've got you.

For that matter, even if 'twas known, nobody wouldn't die of astonishment.

Since the things Eliza Gollop said after Nathan died, `twould come as a very gentle surprise, I believe.

And, when all's said, who's the worse, except what be called public morals?'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

Mr. Baskerville nodded.

``There's some sense in what you say, Jack.

And I'm glad we're friends again.

And now I'm going to bed, so I'll ax you to be gone.'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)

Head rose, finished his (Jack) refreshment, and shook Mr. Baskerville's hand.

``And I'm the better for knowing as you've been large-minded enough to forgive me,'' (he)
he (Jack) said.

``And as you can, I suppose Susan here can.

I know I'm very much in her (Susan) black books, and I deserve that too, and I'd make it up to her (Susan) in any way I can--except to marry her (Susan).

That I never will do for any woman as long as I live.'' (unknown)

``No, and never will get the chance to,'' (Susan/Susan Hacker/Hacker)
replied Susan;
``and I only trust to God `twill all die out, and we hear no more of it.'' (Susan/Susan Hacker/Hacker)

Head turned at the door and spoke a final word.

``It may interest you to know that everybody have had their money now--everybody but me and Thomas Coode, the drunken farmer at Meavy.

'Tis strange I should be put in the same class with Coode; but so it is.

However, I've larned my lesson.

I shall say no more about that.

Think of it I must, being but mortal, but speak I won't.'' (unknown)

``You'll do well to forget it,'' (Ned/Mr. Baskerville/Ned Baskerville)
answered Mr. Baskerville.

``The man, or woman if 'twas one, be probably settled in their mind not to pay you or Coode back--since you're so little deserving.'' (Jack/Jack Head)

Jack shrugged his (Jack) shoulders, but kept his (Jack) recent promise and went out silently.

CHAPTER X A jay, with flash of azure and rose, fluttered screaming along from point to point of a coppice hard by Hawk House, and Cora Lintern saw it.

She (woman) frowned, for this bird was associated in her (woman) mind with a recent and an unpleasant incident.

Her (woman) brother Heathman, whose disparate nature striking against her (woman) own produced many explosions, had recently told her (woman) that the jay was her (woman) bird--showy, tuneless, hard-hearted.

She (woman) remembered the occasion of this attack, but for the moment had no energy at leisure with which to hate him (brother); for difficulties were rampant in her (woman) own path, and chance began to treat her (woman) much as she (woman) had treated other people in the past.

In a word, her (woman) lover grew colder.

As yet she (woman) had no knowledge of the reason, but the fact could not be denied, and her (woman) uneasiness increased.

He (lover) saw somewhat less of her (woman), and he (lover) made no effort to determine the time of the wedding.

Neither did he (lover) invite her (woman) to do so.

He (lover) had come twice to see Mrs. Lintern when Cora was not by, and an account of these visits was reported by her (Lintern) mother.

``I don't exactly know why he (Cora) dropped in either time,'' (Mrs. Lintern)
said Mrs. Lintern.

``He (Cora) kept talking on everyday matters, and never named your name.

'Twas curious, in fact, the way he (Cora) kept it out.

All business, but nothing about the business of marrying you.

Yet there was plenty on his (Cora) mind, I do believe.

I should reckon as he (Cora)'d come for a special purpose, but finding himself here, it stuck in his (Cora) throat.

He (Cora)'s strong with men, but weak with women.

Have he (Cora) told you of aught that's fretting him (Cora)?'' (daughter)

Her (Lintern) daughter could remember nothing of the sort.

Neither did she (Lintern) confess what she (Lintern) did know--that Waite was unquestionably cooler than of old.

'''Tis time the day was named,'' declared Priscilla.

``And you'd better suggest it when next you meet with him (Waite).'' (Cora/Cora Lintern/Lintern)

But Cora did not do so, because there was much in Timothy's manner that told her (Priscilla) he (Timothy) desired no expedition.

Some time had now elapsed since last she (Priscilla) saw him (Timothy), and to-day she (Priscilla) was going, in obedience to a note brought by a labourer, to meet him (labourer) at the Rut, half a mile from Coldstone Farm.

That he (labourer) should have thus invited her (Priscilla) to come to him (labourer) was typical of the change in his (labourer) sentiments.

Formerly he (labourer) would have walked or ridden to her (Priscilla).

The tone of his (labourer) brief note chilled her (Priscilla), but she (Priscilla) obeyed it, and was now approaching their tryst at evening time in early September.

In a little field nigh Hawk House she (Priscilla) heard the purr of a corn-cutting machine.

It was clinking round and round, shearing at each revolution a slice from the island of oats that still stood in the midst of a sea of fallen grain.

A boy drove the machine, and behind it followed Humphrey Baskerville and Rupert.

The younger man had come over to help garner the crop.

Together they worked, gathered up the oats, and set them in little sheaves.

The waning sunlight gilded the standing oats.

Now and then a dog barked and darted round the vanishing island in the midst, for there--separated from safety by half an acre of stubble--certain rabbits squatted together, and waited for the moment when they must bolt and make their final run to death.

Cora, unseen, watched this spectacle; then Mrs. Hacker appeared with a tray, on which were three mugs and a jug of cider.

The girl was early for her (girl) appointment, but she (girl) sauntered forward presently and marked Timothy Waite in the lower part of the valley.

It was the Rut's tamest hour of late summer, for the brightness of the flowers had ceased to shine; the scanty heath made little display, and autumn had as yet lighted no beacon fire.

Stunted thorn trees ripened their harvest, but the round masses of the greater furze were dim; a prevalent and heavy green spread over the Rut, and the only colour contrast was that presented by long stretches of dead brake fern.

The litter had been cut several weeks before and allowed to dry and ripen.

It had now taken upon itself a dark colour, widely different from the richer, more lustrous, and gold-sprinkled splendour of auburn that follows natural death.

The dull brown stuff was being raked together ready for the cart; and Cora, from behind a furze clump, watched her (masses) sweetheart carry immense trusses of the bracken and heave them up to the growing pile upon a wain that waited for the load.

All she (masses) could see was a pair of straight legs in black gaiters moving under a little stack of the fern; then the litter was lifted, to reveal Timothy Waite.

Presently he (Waite) looked at his (Waite) watch and marked that the time of meeting was nearly come.

Whereupon he (Waite) donned his (Waite) coat, made tidy his (Waite) neckcloth, handed his (Waite) fork to a labourer, and left the working party.

He (Waite) strolled slowly up the coomb along the way that she (masses) must approach, while she (masses) left her (masses) hiding-place and set out to meet him (Waite).

He (Waite) shook hands, but he (Waite) did not kiss her (masses), and he (Waite) did not look into her (masses) eyes.

Instead, he (Waite) evaded her (masses) own glance, spoke quickly, and walked quickly in unconscious obedience to his (Waite) own mental turmoil.

``I can't run,'' (she)
she (masses) said.

``If you want me to hear what you're saying, Timothy, you must go slower, or else sit down in the hedge.'' (unknown)

``It's terrible,'' (he)
he (Timothy) answered.

``It's terrible, and it's made an old man of me.

But some things you seem to know from the first are true, and some you seem to know are not.

And when first I heard it I said to myself, t 'Tis a damned lie of a wicked and venomous man'; but then, with time and thought, and God knows how many sleepless nights, I got to see 'twas true enough.

And why wasn't I told?

I ask you that.

Why wasn't I told?'' (unknown)

Her (man) heart sank and her (man) head grew giddy.

She (man) translated this speech with lightning intuition, and knew too well all that it must mean.

It explained his (God) increasing coolness, his (God) absences and evasions.

It signified that he (God) had changed his (God) mind upon learning the secret of the Linterns.

A natural feminine, histrionic instinct made her (man) pretend utmost astonishment, though she (man) doubted whether it would deceive him (God).

``What you're talking about I haven't the slightest idea,'' (she)
she (man) said.

``But if you have a grievance, so have I--and more than one.

You wasn't used to order me here and there six weeks ago.

'Twas you that would come and see me then; now I've got to weary my legs to tramp to do your bidding.'' (He)

He (tramp) paid no heed to her (man) protest.

``If you don't understand, then you must, and before we part, too.

I can't go on like this.

No living man could do it.

I called twice to see your mother about it, for it seemed to me that 'twas more seemly I should speak to her (mother) than to you; but when I faced her (mother) I couldn't open my mouth, much as I wanted to do so.

She (mother) shook me almost, and I'd have been thankful to be shook; but 'tis the craft and cunning of the thing that's too much for me.

I've been hoodwinked in this, and no doubt laughed at behind my back.

That's what's made me feel as I do now.

I waited and hoped on, and loved you for years, and saw you chuck two other men, and found I'd got you at last, and reckoned I was well rewarded for all my patience; and--then--then--this--'' (unknown)

``What?

This what?

Are you mad?

What didn't you dare to speak to my mother, and yet you can speak to me?

What have I done that's set you against me?

What sin have I committed?

Don't think I'm blind.

I've seen you cooling off clear enough, and for the life of me I couldn't guess the reason, try as I would and sorrow about it as I would.

But since you've ordered me here for this, perhaps you'll go straight on and tell me what's all the matter.'' (unknown)

``I want you to answer me one question.
